description: College and School Results

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: After a fourweek run at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the show On than From Russia41 French Masterpieces will open Thursday at 10 A.M. at the Knoedler Gallery, 21 East 70th Street, and continue through May 26.

title: Stock Split Is Approved By Marinduque Mining Corp.
description: Shareholders of the Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation, meeting yesterday in Manila, the Philippines, approved a sixforone split of the capital stock and a classification of this stock into Class A and. Class B shares.

title: LTV, Union Oil and Boeing Lift Profits
description: Earnings for the first quarter of this year continued to make pleasant reading, with most companies posting large gains over last year's period and records in a number of cases.

title: OFFICIALDOM TIED TO HOUSING BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that widespread segregated neighborhoods resulted from official action of Federal, state and local governments in conjunction with the private housing industry.

title: VIETCONG RELEASE 322 ON SCHEDULE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 1 (Reuters)The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government released 322 South Vietnamese civilians yesterday, Saigon high command sources reported today.

title: G.O.P. in Assembly Delays Drug Bill; Prospects for Passage Now Uncertain
description: ALBANY, April 30Governor Rockefeller's drugpenalty bill appeared faltering in the Assembly today as the Republicans put off action after an inconclusive conference and the Conservative party announced its opposition.

title: Puerto Rican Art Is Shown Uptown
description: El Museo del Barrio, the Puerto Rican community museum founded in 1969, opened yesterday the city's first largescale exhibition of Puerto Rican Art. It is the museum's first show in its new location, 1945 Third Avenue between 107th and 108th Streets.

title: CHARGES ENLIVEN EVE OF ELECTION
description: Charges and countercharges marked the last day of campaigning yesterday as voters prepared to go to the polls to elect members of their community school boards.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent, to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent, to New York

title: People in Sports: Jim Brewer Signs Rich Cavalier Contract
description: Jim Brewer of the University of Minnesota, the second player selected in the recent National Basketball Association college draft, signed yesterday with the Cleveland Cavaliers. The terms were not announced, but it was believed he received $1million on a contract that will run at least three years. The 6foot9inch center had also been drafted by the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association.

title: Reform Jews Here Reject Nixon Policy On. Soviet Exit Tax
description: The New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, an influential Jewish congregational group, has rejected President, Nixon's appeal to use quiet diplomacy concerning the applications of Jews in the Soviet Union for exit visas.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Phil, harmonic Hall, 7:30.

title: Official Denies Report on Bar to Bugging on TeamsterMafia Tie
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen labeled as spurious today an article in The New York Times yesterday that quoted Government sources as saying that he and Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst had refused to continue electronic surveillance of West Coast Mafia figures involved with the teamsters union.

title: KODAK'S BREAKUP ASKED IN GAF SUIT
description: The GAF Corporation filed an antitrust suit against the Eastman Kodak Company yesterday, asking that the photographic and chemical concern be divided into 10 separate businesses.

title: Assembly, 620, Approves Bonds to Aid Handicapped
description: TRENTON, April 30  The State Assembly, by a vote of 62 to 0, approved and sent to Governor Cahill today a measure authorizing a $25million bond issue to finance the expansion and construction of dayschool educational centers for thousands of New Jersey's severely handicapped children.

title: Government by Example
description: WASHINGTONAlmost fifty years ago, Mr. Justice Brandeis, dissenting in the famous wiretapping case, Olmstead v. United States, said: Our Government is the potent, the omnipresent teacher: For good or evil, it teaches the whole people by its example.

title: Music: New and Newer
description: If new music is not as new as newer music, then there was better new music than newer music at the New and Newer Music concert Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall.

title: Richardson Draft Surprises Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, April 30President Nixon's draft of Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson to be Attorney General, while sending a shock wave of surprise through the top ranks of the Pentagon, was not expected to disrupt the management of a defense program that has a momentum of its own.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Early James Joyce, discussing James Joyce and His Fingernails. Yes, that's it, his fingernails.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: April 15Bost. 134, Knicks 108. April 18Knicks 129, Boston 96. April 20Knicks 98, Boston 91. April 22Knicks 117, Bost. 110

title: Firestone Workers Return
description: AKRON, Ohio, April 30The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that 1,000 workers who walked off their jobs last Thursday had returned to work at plants at Decatur and Bloomington, Ill. A company spokesman said that nego tiations on a new conttact were continuing with the United Rubber Workers, which urged the workers to end the walkout.

title: NO HARM ABROAD SEEN BY ROGERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today he did not believe that the Watergate scandal would damage American foreign relations so long as there was full and complete disclosure of the facts, prosecution of all those guilty and remedial action to prevent such affairs in the future..

title: Renovating With No Man Around the House
description: For a woman alone to take on brownstone and renovate it or to buy a house in the suburbs just for herself sounds like a pretty formidable undertaking.

title: HYPERTENSION RATE IN MASS TEST IS HIGH
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 30 (AP)  The nation's first program of mass medical tests for high blood pressure  often called the nation's No. 1 killer  has found more than onethird of those tested suffering from the disease.

title: Egyptian Air Bases Reported Equipped For Libyan Planes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30Diplomatic sources report that ground equipment has been installed at some Egyptian air bases for Frenchbuilt fighterbombers from Libya and Britishbuilt planes from other Arab countries, and that it has been tested by the aircraft during brief visits.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The bond market, virtually unaffected by the resignation of some top Administration aides, traded in a narrow range yesterday in uneventful dealings. Corporate and taxexempt bonds were generally described as firm while Treasury coupon issues retreated a bit in advance of the auction of up to $2.5billion of n e w Government securities today and tomorrow. Some shortterm interest rates, meanwhile, pressed higher in the money market. Threemonth certifipates of deposit were widely written at a rate of 7.40 per cent, up about five basis points from the levels of late last week, and Federal fundsovernight interbank loanstraded in a high range of 78 per cent despite two injections of oneday credit by the Reserve.

title: ROGERS DEPENDS CAMBODIA RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the continued American bombing in Cambodia was legally justified by the Constitution and was a meaningful interim action to force the Communistbacked insurgents there to agree to ceasefire.

title: METS PUT MILNER ON DISABLED LIST
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 30 While enjoying a full day in first place in the National League's East Division, the New York Mets played an exhibition game here and made some medical decisions. John Milner, the Mets, first baseman, who suffered a pulled hamstring in Houston last week, saw Dr. Peter LaMotte and the team physician recommended Milner not play for two weeks. So the Mets leading slugger was placed on the 15day disabled list.

title: METS PUT MILNER ON DISABLED LIST
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 30 While enjoying a full day in first place in the National League's East Division, the New York Mets played an exhibition game here and made some medical decisions. John Milner, the Mets first baseman, who suffered a pulled hamstring in Houston last week, saw Dr. Peter LaMotte and the team physician recommended Milner not play for two weeks. So the Mets leading slugger was placed on the 15day disabled list.

title: Stadium: Club Says Deal Is Not Affected
description: The renovation of Yankee Stadium and the Yankees continued presence there won't be affected by the change in the club's high command, city and team officials said yesterday.

title: Text of Rogers Note on Authority for Bombing in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Following is the text of a State Department memorandum presented to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today by Secretary of State William P. Rogers, setting forth the basis of Presidential authority to continue bombing in Cambodia:

title: Equity Scandal Cited
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission called on state regulatory and enforcement authorities today to plug any holes in their supervision of the insurance infi dustry so that swindles like the Equity Funding matter cannot recur.

title: RIGHTS TRIAL, BASED ON A MURDER, OPENS
description: The trial of Vincent Pace who is accused of murdering a 28yearold Manhattan model to prevent her from testifying against him in a narcotics trial, opened yesterday in Federal court here.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Election Board Official Quits
description: Amid today's school board elections and preparations for the June 4 primaries, the Board of Elections is losing its administratormanager. Alexander Bassett, 58 years old, is resigning today after 34 years with the board. David Dinkins, the board president, said he knew of no replacement at this time and that the $19,500ayear position would probably remain vacant through the June polling.

title: PARKWAY IS SEEKING TO END BOTTLENECK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 30 (AP)The New Jersey Turnpike and New Jersey Highway Authorities announced today that they would undertake extensive construction costing $18.5million to eliminate a bottleneck in the Toms River section of the Garden State Parkway.

title: UEHARA, COMPOSER, GIVES NONCONCERT
description: Kazuo Uehara, a 23yearold Japanese composer working at the Manhattan School of Music's Electronic Laboratory, offered a sensitive nonconcert Sunday night at the Kitchen, 240 Mercer Street. Mr. Uehara's minimal program was rather feisty about his aims, peppered as it was with such notions as this EVENT will refuse to exist as a CONCERT, diffusion, condensation, chaos, revolution and this is a condition of life in NATUREREVERSION TO NATURE.

title: NEW DATA CITED
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 President Nixon told the nation tonight that he accepted the responsibility for what happened in the Watergate case even though he had had no knowledge of political espionage or attempts to cover it up.

title: Nixon Asks Tax Law Shift To Ease Filing on Income
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Nixon Administration propoeed today changes in The tax laws and tax forms that would make it easier for millions, of individuals to figure out their Federal income taxes. The Administration's proposals contained little, however, that appeared likely, ta satisfy the demands of those who have been calling for reform of the tax laws.

title: Big A Has a Trainer With Style
description: At the age of 22, Alan Marcus had struck it rich as owner and president of a Texas dress company dedicated to putting Marcus Originals on the backs of ypung women.

title: Bill on Accident Insurance Approved in Trenton Vote
description: TRENTON, April 30  The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that eliminates the allornothing concept in New Jersey laws covering accident insurance and enables accident victims to collect damages even if they contribute to an accident.

title: POLAND, CIIILE, QUIT IN FEDERATION CUP
description: BAD HOMBURG, West Ger many, April 30 (UPI)Poland has withdrawn from the annual women's Federation Cup tennis competition in protest over the participation of South Africa, the defending champion, organizers of the event said today. South Africa's apartheid policy is the reason for the protest.

title: Slain Indian's Body escorted for Burial On Sioux Territory
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D. May 1The body of Frank Clearwater, one of the two Indlans killed by gunfire during the siege of Wounded Knee, was taken through a police blockade this afternoon to a burial place on the neighboring Rosebud Sioux Reservation.

title: Electdral Revision Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Senator Henry Belimn, Republican of Oklahoma, said today that the Watergate disclosures showed the necessity for replacing the Electoral College system of electing Presidents with a national primary and their direct election. President Nbron said in his speech last night that the nation's election system needed drastic revision.

title: $100,000 IS OFFERED FOR CONTROL OF M.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Establishment of a $100,000 scientific research prize, one of the largest medical awards ever offered in American, history, was announced today by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Golden Age for U.S.?
description: Cultural historians use the concept of a golden agea time when a society achieves and sustains a very high level of art and civilization, as did ancient Greece, a world of light and confidence in the words of the British aft critic, Sir Kenneth Clark.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The twopart devaluation of the dollar, combined with other factors, has produced a dramatic improvement in United States unitlabor costs in manufacturing relative to the other industrial countries, Congress was told today.

title: Cahill Tells Student Rally in Trenton He Will Fight for ChurchSchool Aid,
description: TRENTON, May 1 (UPI) Thousands of Catholic parochial school students jammed into Trenton today to protest a Federal court decision declaring the state's program of aid to private schools unconstitutional.

title: Biaggi Now Asks Release Of Jury Record, but in Full
description: In a sudden legal maneuver reversing his past positions, Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday Asked a Federal Court judge to allow full disclosure of his 1971 grandjury testimony, including the names of all other persons. The judge quickly rejected the bid.

title: N. Baxter Jackson Dies at 82; ExChairman of Chemical Bank
description: N. Baxter Jackson, who retired in 1956 as chairman of the board of Chemical Bank but continued as a director until 1968, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 82, and he lived at 19 East 72d Street.

title: M'GOVERN LAUDS NIXON ADMISSION
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (Reuters)Senator George McGovern, the defeated 1972 Democratic Presidential nominee, praised President Nixon today for admitting a mistake on the Watergate affair but criticized him for suggesting that espionage was typical of American politics.

title: Auto Safety Winner Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) A 12yearold Davenport, Iowa, girl is top winner among 39,838 entries in the American Automobile Association's 29th annual school traffic safety poster contest. Julie Rastner, a sixth grader, will receive $650 in United States savings bonds.

title: Former Queens D.A. Aide Asks to Testify Privately
description: Joseph Monty, the former chief rackets investigator in the Queens District Attorney's office, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to quash a subpoena requiring him to testify in public before the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: Nixon Is Expected To Move on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 President Nixon intends to issue an economic policy statement tomorrow that is expected to include selective tightening of his wageprice stabilization program.

title: TEXTILE WORKERS STRIKE 400 SHOPS
description: Workers in wholesale fabric establishments struck 400 shops in New York and New Jersey yesterday after rejecting contract proposals made by two textile employer associations.

title: Boyd M. Smith, Former Dean Of Yale Architecture School
description: NEW HAVEN, May 1Prof. Boyd M. Smith, former dean of the Yale School of Architecture and Design and chairman of the university's drama department, died last Thursday in Greenville, Tenn. He was 85 years old.

title: Connecticut, Citing Loan, Curbs Sales by gchenley
description: HARTFORD, May 1 (AP) The Connecticut Liquor Control Commission suspended today for 90 days the state liquor shipping permit of the Schenley Affiliated Brands Corporation of New York, a major liquor distiller.

title: Charlotte Ford Is Wed to J. A. Forstmann
description: Charlotte Ford, who has spent most of her adult life as one of the world's most eligible women, took herself out of the ranking last night. The 32yearold elder daughter of Henry Ford 2d, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company, was married in a 6 P.M. civil ceremony to J. Anthony Forstmann, an investment banker.

title: CONNALLY. TO SHIFT TO THE G.O.P. TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally will announce at a news conference in Houston tomorrow his longexpected switch from the Democratic to the Republican party.

title: Goodrich Strike Throat
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 1 (AP)The United Rubber Workers announced today that it would call a strike at the B. F. Goodrich Company unless a contract was reached. The union said a strike deadline had not yet been set.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Frederick Beebe Dies at 59; Chairman of Washington Post
description: Frederick Sessions Beebe, chairman of the board of the Washington Post Company and overseer of a communications concern that includes. The Washington Post, Newsweek magazine, a chain of radio and television stations and a partial interest in The International Herald Tribune, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He, was 59 years old and lived at 210 East 62d Street and in Montauk, L. I.

title: Nater to Replace Brewer
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (AP) Swen Nater will replace Jim Brewer in the United States) lineup for Saturday's game here.

title: Redman Victory Signals Hall's Return to Racing
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 1 Hi, Jim Hall, it's so nice to have you back where you belong.

title: Dr. T. Campbell Goodwin Dead; Specialist in Learning Problems
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., May 1  Dr. T. Campbell Goodwin, a pioneer in the use of a computerized talking typewriter to teach children who were considered hopelessly autistic, died yesterday in Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, of which he was emeritus chief of pediatrics. He was 71 years old, and was also emeritus professor of pediatrics at Columbia University.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: SOYBEAN FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT

title: KENNECOTT GLUM ON CHILEAN PACT
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation sees no hope of any amicable settlement with the Chilean Government over expropriation of its copper mining properties in that country.

title: College Baseball
description: College Baseball

title: Four Charged. Upstate in Plot To Cheat Aliens Seeking Jobs
description: BUFFALO, May 1Last September, William Truesdale, an investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization Service here, received a phone call from a Buffalo businessman. The merchant said he had received a letter from a Korean, thanking him in advance for a job that was supposedly waiting for him in the United States.

title: COMMODITY ACTIVITY ADDED BY DREXEL
description: The securities brokerage house of Drexel Burnham & Co., Inc., has formally entered the domestic and foreign commodities business, Robert E. Linton, executive vice president, announced yesterday.

title: Watchman Swings a Clock But Robber Still Gets $19
description: HERKIMER, N. Y, May 1 (AP)A 65yearold night watchman struck a pistolWielding robber on the head with his heavy watchman's clock early today, but still lost $19.

title: Clouds Over Argentina
description: Six weeks after the first round of elections designed to return the country peacefully to democratic rule, Argentina continues to be wracked by explosive divisions and urban terrorism that will make effective civilian government extremely difficult. The murder of the former chief of the armed forces by the Trotskyist People's Revolutionary Army, which has provoked the imposition of a state of emergency in Buenos Aires and five provinces, is merely the latest in a long series of incidents certain to cause trouble for Dr. Hctor J. Cmpora, the Peronist who will become President May 25.

title: An Agent Dissents on Need ForF.B.I. Man as Director
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) While most of the F.B.I.'s top officials are reported in agreement that the agency's permanent director should be an F.B.I. career man, at least one disagrees.

title: Collection of Networks
description: WASHINGTONThe stunning succession with which Watergate events bombarded this city heightened some of its characteristic reactions to upheaval.

title: OPINION IS DIVIDED ON BASERENT Bit
description: Landlord leaders denounced and tenant spokesmen supported yesterday a bill approved by the City Council's Housing Committee that would repeat the controversial maximum baserentformula of the local rentcontrol law.

title: People in Sports: It's Time For Handing Out Rewards
description: Basketball, hockey and baseball players were rewarded with new contracts and a bonus yesterday. Bob Lantier of the Detroit Pistons and John Bucyk, the elder statesman of the Boston Bruins, received new contracts and Steve Busby, the Kansas City Royals rookie pitcher, was promised a bonus for his nohitter last Friday against the Detroit Tigers.

title: 5 Elderly Guests Killed in Hotel Fire at Lakewood
description: LAKEWOOD, May 1  A fire killed five elderly persons and destroyed the 74yearold Manhattan Hotel in this resort town early this morning.

title: MARTY BRILL DIES; ALLAMERICA BACK
description: LOS ANGELES May 1 (AP)  Marty, Brill, an allAmerica halfback under Knute Rockne at the University of Notre Dame in 1930 and later head football coach at La Salle College and Loyola University here died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: Except for All the Others
description: PARISAn aspect of the Watergate mess more considered abroad than in the United States was summarized in The London Observer, which editorialized: The way this scandal is now being relentlessly exposed should  strengthen America's claim to be the most open society: political skulduggery has happened in many countries but in few could it have been exposed as publicly as now in the U.S.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House said that Robert F. Froehlke has resigned as Secretary of the Army. President Nixon, according to his press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, accepted the resignation with regret. Mr. Froehlke joined the Defense Department in 1969 and was in charge of intelligence there until two years ago when he became Secretary of the Army. Mr. Ziegler said that a successor to Mr. Froehlke would be named in the near future. Mr. Froehlke was said to be returning to private life. There have been reports that Howard Calloway of Georgia, a Republican is being consmerect for ???

title: Tuesday Night Box Scores
description: Tuesday Night Box Scores

title: 2 in Train Caboose Killed
description: THISTLE, Utah, May 1 (AP) Two trainmen eating lunch in a caboose were killed yesterday when another train crashed into their car. The victims were identified as Douglas Callor, 20 years old, of Carbcmville, and Joe Garcia, 26, of Sunnyside.

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: SaintGobain Sets A Tender Offer for CertainTeed Stock
description: Compagnie de SaintGobainPontttMousson announced yesterday that it planned to make a cash tender offer for common stock and Series A convertible preferred stock of the CertainTeed Corporation. The French concern is a diversified company engaged principally in the production and sale of glass, pipe and paper products. Certain  Teed is an American diversified company making building products and mechanical products for transportation and industry. SaintGobain intends to purchase all shares offered up to 1.75 million in any, combination of common and Series A preferred shares, counting each common share as one and each preferred share as two. The offer would provide that the French concern might at its option purchase more shares.

title: Luce Hall of Reporting Opens With Nostalgia at Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Henry R. Luce Hall of New Reporting opened today at the Smithsonian Institution, but to most of the visitors the lure appeared to be nostalgic rather than journalistic.

title: Ziegler Apologizes to Washington Post on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secreary, apologized to The Washington Post today for his earlier criticisms of the newspaper's coverage of the Watergate case.

title: Body Found in Upper Bay
description: The body of a man was taken yesterday from the Upper Bay near Pier 39, at Coffey and Ferris Streets, Brooklyn, by members of Launch No. 5 of the harbor squad. The police of the Union Street precinct station said the body was of a man in his late fifties.

title: Trucker and Police in Parking Accord
description: A garmentcenter trucking concern that has been accused by the police of being dominated by the Mafia dropped $1million damage suit against the Police Department yesterday in return for a promised reduction in parking tickets issued to its trucks.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Strike at St. Lawrence
description: CANTON, N. Y., May 1 (AP) About 175 service employes at St. Lawrence University went on strike today in the first such walkout in the institution's 116year history. The Building Service Union strikes forced the closing of two of the university's three dining halls.

title: New Suffolk Community Will Discourage Autos
description: EATONS NECK, L. I., May 1 Details of a planned community of $100,000 homes that would provide residents with inducepents not to own an automobile were announced today.

title: $2.9BILLION ASKED IN FOREIGN AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Nixon today asked Congress to authorize $2.9billion in foreign economic and military aid in the fiscal year beginning July 1, including $632million for rebuilding all countries of Indochina except North Vietnam.

title: WALLACE STANDS IN GIVING SPEECH
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 1 Gov. George C. Wallace made a public speech tonight from a standing position for the first time since he was paralyzed from the waist down in an attempt on his life one year ago.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Scattered violence broke out hi the South Jamaica area of Queens last night as bands of youths demonstrated in protest against the fatal shooting of a 10yearold black boy by a police officer last Saturday morning.

title: Women's Interclub Golf
description: Women's Interclub Golf

title: U.S. WARNS HANOI MILITARY ACTION COULD BE RESUMED
description: PARIS, May 1North Vietnamese and United States negotiators returned home today with the American threatening resumption of United States military action in Vietnam if violations of the ceasefire continued and Hanoi's representative ruling out a meeting soon between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho.

title: Interior Secretary Urges All Drivers To Conserve Gas
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Warning that the nation faces potentially severe gasoline shortages this summer, Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton urged all Americans today to restrict, their driving voluntarily.

title: AGING OF STAFF A C.I.A. PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 James R. Schlesinger, the Director of Central Intelligence, has told Congress that a major problem confronting the Central Intelligence Agency is that its spies are becoming too old and too numerous.

title: Lakers Check Knicks, 115 to 112
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 1The Los Angeles Lakers clearly outplayed the New York Knicks for three quarters, then just did hold off a fourthperiod rally for a 115112 victory tonight, and took a 10 lead in the fourofsevengame series for the championship of the National Basketball Association.

title: Public TV Board Says F.C.C. Cannot Rule Over It
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has told the Federal Communications Commission that the F.C.C. lacks legal jurisdiction over the operations and activities of the independent corporation.

title: U.S. Aid Rejected By Missouri Town
description: STOUTSVILLE, Mo.  If anyone went out hunting for towns that looked as if they could use a little help, Stoutsville would surely have to wind up pretty high on the list. This hamlet tucked among the hardwood ridges and scrubby bottomland along Buck Creek is about as down as a town can get. Situated in Mark Twain country, just off Highway 24 some 35 miles southwest of Hannibal and the Mississippi, it has watched more in resignation than in anger over most of the last 50 or so years as its population dwindled from over 600 to about 30.

title: Black Caucus Drops Role as Minority Spokesman and Emphasizes Legislative Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, May 1After setting itself up as national spokesman for blacks, an investigative body and a clearinghouse for black concerns, the Congressional Black Caucus has decided to do that which its members were elected to dolegislate.

title: N.H.L. Playoff
description: Chicago vs. Montreal

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Having just returnee from conferences with United Nations and national European leaders in Geneva, Vienna and London, I've seen Watergate dominate the front pages of the European press as well as all discussions, official and unofficial.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Declines outnmbered advancet again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market. It was the seventh consecutive session that prices ended lower in both markets.

title: SCHAEFER IN RED, UNION SKIPS RAISE
description: In a highly unusual labormanagement move, two teamster locals and the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company announced yesterday they had signed a new threeyear contract that provides for no increase in the wage rate.

title: Contract Given on Antenna Fot Earth Station in China
description: DALLAS, May 1 (AP)E Systems, Inc., said yesterday that it had a contract from GTE International Systems Corporation of Waltham, Mass., to provide a satellite communications antenna to be built in China near Peking.

title: 6 MAY BE INDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Government investigators say they now have evidence that highranking officials of the White House and the Committee for the Reelection of the President conspired after the June, 1972, Watergate breakin to arrange a careful cover story designed to obstruct the Federal investigation.

title: Records: By McCartney
description: Paul McCartney has not fared well critically with his albums since his breakup with John Lennon, George Harrison and Ringo Starr and the formation of his current group, Wings. Possibly this is because McCartney was the romantic, the seeker after melody, or at least appeared to be, whereas Lennon went introspective and Harrison impressed with talent that was always there but never allowed to surface. Both these approaches were more fashionable to trendy critical earsand possibly (with Bangladesh and immigration scenes) more newsworthy. (Ringo? He appears more interested in films these days.)

title: Welfare Work Program Upheld By State Court as Constitutional
description: Putting thousands or welfare recipients to work at tasks ordinarily done by Civil Service, employes is not unconstitutional and cannot be called peonage, Justice Samuel J. Silverman ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Indians in Tribal Elections May Now Vote at Age 18
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The Interior Department announced today a change in regulations to lower the voting age of Indians in tribal elections to 18.

title: Sofres Have Signed Swen Nater, They Say
description: RICHMOND, May 1 (AP) the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association signed Swen Nater of the University of California, Los Angeles, to a multiyear contract today, a spokesman for the Squires said. Nater, currently playing for the United States against the Soviet Union, was the top draft pick of the Milwaukee Bucks in the rival National Basketball Association.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Psychiatrist Wins Award
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Robert Coles, a 43yearold Harvard psychiatrist, was awarded a $10,000 prize today for his research into the effects of poverty and racism on the mental health of children. He received the McAlpin research achievement award of the National Association of Mental Health, a voluntary organization.

title: The Next 75 Years
description: In launching the celebration of New York City's first 75 years as a consolidated unit formed through fusing its five boroughs, Mayor Lindsay has helped point the way for the 75 to come. On the eve of the official festivities, Mr. Lindsay unveiled a plan for the integration and regionalization of mass transit facilities serving the central city and its suburbs.

title: 2 Escape Apartment Blast
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 1 (UPI)An explosion reduced a sixunit brick apartment complex to rubble today but the two persons in the building were unhurt. The cause of the blast was not determined.

title: New Suffolk Community Will Discourage Autos
description: EATONS NECK, L. I., May 1 Details of a planned community of $100,000 homes that would provide residents with inducements not to own an automobile were announced today.

title: A Listing of New Books

description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Nixon today asked Congress to authorize $2.9billion in foreign economic and military aid in the fiscal year beginning July 1, including $632million for rebuilding all countries of Indochina except North Vietnam.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (AP)Robert H. Finch, a former Presidential counselor, has offered to help President Nixon reorganize the White House staff, a spokesman for Mr. Finch said today.

description: Two years ago the Blassport collection by Bill Blass was a neat assemblage of classic jackets, sweaters, pants  and all that. Now it's furbearing sweaters, strapless evening dresses, fox boasjust about everything.

description: MEMPHIS, May 1 (AP) The swollen waters of the Mississippi continued their relentless journey to the Gulf of Mexico today, and authorities warned people in the flood's wake of more rain.

title: GEN. MINH PROPOSES POLITICAL PROGRAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1 (UPI)  Duong Van Minh, the retired general who overthrew Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963, made an apparent bid for leadership of a third force political movement today by offering his own program for South Vietnam's political future.

title: Bridge:
description: Although mathematics and bridge have some features in common, notably the need for their practitioners to have analytical shitity, few academic mathematicians reach the highest ranks as cardplayers. The ability to calculate percentages is of much less significance in practical play than the art of making human judgments about one's partners and opponents, so mathematical bridge experts are greaty outnumbered by members of the legal profession.

description: Joseph Weissglass, president of the Weissglass Gold Seal Dairy Corporation on Staten Island, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 8 Buttonwood Road, in the Dongan Hills area of Staten Island.

The bill, which originated in the state Senate, would have ptotected reporters from  revealing sources of information during inquiries by prosecuting attorneys, grand juries and legislative committees.

But, according to more than one source, that is how the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company consolidated its three agencies and in the process dumped Gardner Advertising, which had served it for more than 30 years.

description: MOSCOW, May 1Leonid Ibrezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today reaffirmed the Kremlin's desire for further improvement in SovietAmerican relations.

description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 1 (AP)  Circuses are becoming a determining factor in where and when World Hockey Association championship playoff games will be played.

description: Offers of money, adoption, mothering and clothes have poured into St. Vincent's Hospital for Kim Cruz, the 3monthold baby who was admitted there on Saturday in critical condition after being beaten.

title: U.S. Briefs Brandt Aides on Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The United States has told the Soviet Union that it will neither discuss nor negotiate any limits on Europeanbased American fighterbombers in the current round of talks on limitation of strategic arms, a wellplaced Administration official said today.

title: Common Market Reaches FarmPrice Compromise
description: LUXEMBOURG, May 1 After one of the bitterest and most protracted sessions in the history of the Common Market, agriculture ministers of the nine member states agreed today on a new level of farm prices for the coining 12 months and instituted a radical new policy of consumer subsidies to bring down the cost of butter.

title: Equity Financing
description: American General Insurance Company reported its tender offer for 2.5 million of its own common shares at $19.50 (net to seller) per share was oversubscribed and that it will acquire on a prorated basis only the 2.5 million shares sought. The company's stock was down  at 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Colson Knew Hunt Wrote Fake Cable
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Charles W. Colson, former special counsel to President Nixon, has confirmed that four months before the Watergate burglary he discovered that one of the conspirators, E. Howard Hunt Jr., a friend he had recommended for a White House job, had written a fake cable implicating President Kennedy in the assassination of South Vietnam's President Diem.

title: Ruling in Suit on Stock Trading Could End Mass Class Actions
description: A (threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that a person who files a classaction suit must pay the cost of notifying each person on behalf of whom the suit was broughteven if that means notifying millions of people.

title: Thieu Is Planning to Give Provinces More Autonomy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu plans a reform of the national structure in an effort to streamline and decentralize the South Vietnamese Government, a Government spokesman said today.

title: 6,000 Tires to Be Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that the Delta Tire Corporation had agreed to recall some 6,000 tires manufactured for it by the Uniroyal Tire Company in February, 1970. The tires involved bear the letters YN in the middle of the serial number.

title: NIXON EXPECTED TO ACT ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 President Nixon intends to issue an economic policy statement tomorrow that is expected to include selective tightening of his wageprice stabilization program.

title: And Now, the 99th Kentucky Bumbury
description: And Now, the 99th Kentucky Bumbury

title: Broken Confidence
description: The Watergate scandal has become a crisis of Presidential authority. In his address to the nation Monday evening, President Nixon tried but failed to resolve that crisis. The whole trend of future events remains in doubt.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City nights are getting brighterand not only because of the extra evening hour under Daylight Saving Time. New sodium street lamps are rapidly being installed under a city program to make the streets safer after dark. So far, 11,433 of the new highpressure sodium lamps with their yellowish glow have replaced the bluewhite mercuryvapor lamps that no longer meet higher lighting requirements now in force. Brooklyn has received 3,716 of the new lamps, the Bronx, 2,617, Queens, 2,330, Manhattan, 1,649 and Staten Island, 1;121.

title: Impeachment Urged
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 1 (UPI)The threestate Central Area Conference of the Nation al Association for the Advancement of Colored People urged Congress yesterday to begin impeachment proceedings against President Nixon because of his budgit cuts and impoundment of education funds and the criminal breakin and bugging of the Democratic headquarters in the Watergate apartments.

title: Prisoner Release Postponed By Saigon for Second Time
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 2 (AP)Tlhe Saigon Government canceled scheduled release of Vietcong civilian prisoners at Loc Ninh today.

description: College and School Results

title: Hunt. Got Fee for Day of Coast Theft
description: WASJIINGTON, May 1 E. Howard Hunt Jr., convicted Watergate spy, billed the White House for a consultant's fee for the day of the breakin at the Beverly Hills, Calif., office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: Books of The Times
description: You have to hand it to Kurt Vonnegut Jr. In his eighth novel, Breakfast of Champions, or Goodbye Blue Monday, he performs considerable complex magic., He makes pornography seem like any old plumbing, violence like lovemaking, innocence like evil, and guilt like child's play. He wheels out all the latest fashionable complaints about Americaher racism, her gift for destroying language, her technological greed and selfishnessand makes them seem fresh, funny, outrageous, hateful, and lovable, all at the same time. He draws pictures, for God's sake  simple, rough, yet surprisingly seductive sketches of everything from Volkswagens to electric chairs. He weaves into his plot a dozen or so glorious synopses of Vonnegut stories one almost wishes were fleshed out into whole books. He very nearly levitates. Yetastonishinglythis fiction is also a factual announcement of his intention to give up fiction. And what mars the book is that one believes the fiction, but not the facts.

title: Mrs. Nixon: Sad Time For Wives of ExAides
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon feels it is a very tragic time for the families of White House aides who have been implicated in the Watergate scandal, her press secretary said today.

title: Ridder Sets Acquisition
description: Ridder Publications, Inc., said it had completed acquisition of The Wichita (Kan.) Eagle and the Beacon Publishing Company with the purchase for cash of 100 per cent of the $40.5million.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 1 (AP)Danny Edwards, phe defending champion, led four other former winners through today's second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament, but two top contenders, Dick Siderowf and Bobby Wadkins, were upset victims.

title: Other Contests Fade But Miss Subways Keeps Rolling Along
description: Miss Rheingold has gone the way of Ebbets Field, but Miss Subways, with a history dating back to 1941, rumbles on, below ground and above it, on three divisions, through 459 stations, in 6,600 cars, supported by umpteen million tokens. Three or four girls a year get to rule above the graffiti. They ire frequently secretaries, invariably racially balanced and usually hope to become models. Sometimes they do; more often they do not. Meet one of the Miss Subways, four years later.

description: Everything you could dream of went wrong  it's chaos, said a policeman at Public School 63, 121 East Third Street, in School District 1.

title: Nixon's Lawyer No Longer
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 1For the last five years Herbert Warren Kalmbach has quietly served President Nixon as a political confidant and his personal attorney on the West Coast.

title: California to Honor Drake
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May (U.P.I.)The California Legislature has started planning a celebration of the 400th anniversary of Sir Francis Drake's landing in the state. The Assembly approved creation yesterday of a joint committee on Sir Francis Drake to oversee celebrations scheduled for 1979.

title: Military Tightens Its Rule in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 1In a mood of barely controlled anger, regional military comnaanders took complete power today in the capital and in Argentina's five largest provinces, where a state of emergency was put into effect.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (UPI)Following is a report of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed at the Pentagon papers trial today, on an interview on April 27 with John D. Ehrlichman, then assistant to the President for domestic affairs:

title: HOUSE BACKS CURB BUDGET AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 The House striking back at, President Nixon's widespread impoundment of appropriated funds voted today to require Senate confirmation of his top White House budget officials.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, MAY 2, 1973
description: Government and Senate investigators say they now have evidence that highranking officials of the White House and the Committee for the Reelection of the President conspired after the June, 1972 Watergate breakin to arrange a careful cover story designed to obstruct the Federal investigation. The investigators say that the evidence shows that the obstruction of justice was coordinated by President Nixon's two closest advisers, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, who resigned Monday, and former Attorney General John N. Mitchell. John W. Dean 3d, the former counsel, was also said to be among several others involved in the [1:8.]

title: $500,000 in Jewels At Kennedy Airport Taken by Gunmen
description: Three gunmen dressed in work clothes escaped with an estimated total of $500,000 in jewels in a robbery at the AirIndia cargo terminal at Kennedy International Airport Monday night, the police reported yesterday.

title: NeoNazi Escapes Bomb
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP) A neoNazi leader, Charles Kress, escaped injury yesterday when a homemade bomb failed to explode after being hurled into his North Philadelphia apartment. Mr. Kress, 37 years old, is president of the National Socialist White People's Party.

title: Kleindienst Sees a Halt To Wave of Lawlessness
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Richard G. Kleindienst, who resigned yesterday as Attorney General, said today that a national wave of lawlessness has been broken during the Nixon Administration.

title: Hanoi Films Show No CarpetBombing
description: Aerial photographs of the results, of the heavy United States bombing of Hanoi last December show damage to military targets, to a hospital near a military airfield and to a commercial and residential area close to the main railroad station and yards.

title: 74 Interruption Seen In YaleHarvard Race
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 (UPI)  The HarvardYale heavyweight crew regatta will not be held in 1974, at least not in its traditional form, it was announced today.

title: WELFARE AIDES OUT A 2D DAY IN ESSEX
description: NEWARK, May 1 (AP)The eight field offices of the Essex County Welfare Board were closed today as welfare workers remained off the job for second day to protest the state's failure to approve wage increase.

title: Workmen Flee a Fire At New Police Office
description: A fire broke out before noon yesterday on the 13th floor of the new Police Headquarters, which is still under construction, trapping two workmen inside an office as flames raced through the hall outside.

title: NIXON ROLE CITED
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1John D. Ehrlichman has told Federal investigators that the breakin at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist came as a result of a secret White House investigation he ordered at the request of President Nixon.

title: Postal Panel Chief Quits
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The White House said today that President Nixon had accepted the resignation of William J. Crowley as chairman of the Postal Rate Commission. Ronald L. Ziezler, the Presidential press secretary, said Mr. Crowley was returning to private life with Mr. Nixon's appreciation for his service on the the panel, which regulates postal rates.

title: People and Business
description: It was a big day yesterday for Dr. Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel Prizewinning economist and professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The 57yearold former economic adviser to President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson was honored at a cocktail party at the M.I.T. Faculty Club in Cambridge celebrating the 25th anniversary of his monumental college textbook, Economics.

title: U.S. Aid Rejected By Missouri Town
description: STOUTSVILLE, Mo.  If anyone went out hunting for towns that looked as if they could use a little help, Stoutsville would surely have to wind up pretty high on the list. This hamlet tucked among the hardwood ridges and scrubby bottomland along Buck Creek is about as down as a town can get. Situated in Mark Twain country, just off, Highway 24 some 35 miles southwest of Hannibal  and the Mississippi, it has watched more in resignation than in anger over most of the last 50 or so years as its population dwindled from over 600 to about 30.

title: Traces of Red Tide Found
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP) Traces of the toxic red tide were spotted yesterday near Gloucester, according to Massachusetts Public Health Commissioner William J. Bicknell, but he said there is definitely no implied threat to the public.

title: The Dance
description: The National Ballet of Canada gave Rudolf Nureyev in two new guises at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Here we had Mr. Nureyev, the company's very special guest star, offering his first performance in New York of the hero James in La Sylphide and also, with a ballet more than a century later, giving his New York debut as the Moor in Jos Limn's great The Moor's Pavane.

title: Schaefer Goes in Red, Two Unions Skip Raise
description: In a highly unusual labormanagement move, two teamster locals and the F.&M. Schaefer Brewing Company announced yesterday they had signed a new threeyear contract that provides for no increase in the wage rate.

title: Factories Inventories And New Orders Surge
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Manufacturers new orders and inventories both surged in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Warren Assails Proposal to Screen High Court Cases
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren last night denounced a recent proposal by a study group that would set up within the Federal judicial system a national court of appeals to screen petitions for review by the United States Supreme Court.

title: DeKorte, Former Assemblyman, Is Appointed Counsel to Cahill
description: TRENTON, May 1 (AP)Governor Cahill announced today that former Assemblyman Richard W. DeKorte would succeed Pierre P. Garven, the State Supreme Court Chief Justicedesignate, as his counsel.

title: BLYTH FIRM AND AIDE CENSURED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission has censured the firm of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., and one of its salesmen for allocating newly issued stock to an official of the state of Washington in return for brokerage business from several state funds.

title: Merits of Hot Dog Tax Spur Fiery Debate Between Leaders of Assembly.
description: ALBANY, May 1  The Assembly began and ended a fourhour meeting today with an exchange of charges by Republican and Democratic leaders of irresponsibility. But little happened in between this floor, said Mr. Steingut, who was first elected to the Assembly in 1952. He noted that the Detriocrats had also proposed legislation this year to increase state revenuesharing with localities.

title: Dance: Martha Graham Brings Back Clytemnestra
description: Much of what is now being done in the theater and film was done by Martha Graham in the past. It is hard to believe that any young director or actor today will not rush over to the Alvin Theater, wnere the Martha Graham Dance Company opened a twoweek season last night with Miss Graham's fullevening masterwork, Clytemnestra.

title: Two Cheers For Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 1There is more, much more, to be uncovered in the current Washington scandal, but much has been accomplished in the last few days, and this may be a good time to pause and recognize what has been done.

description: A sharp decline in the stock market was arrested yesterday when the White House announced that President Nixon would make a statement today on the economy following a meeting with his economic advisers.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was suspending trading in the stock of the Investors Funding Corporation of New York for 10 days.

title: Von Bothmer Quits Archeology Unit
description: In the wake of controversy over the Metropolitan Museum of Art's sale of 345 Roman gold coins last year at auction and the purchase of the $1million Euphronios krater Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan's curator of Greek art, has resigned from the New York chapter of the Archeological Institute of America, it was learned yesterday.

description: Major League Baseball

title: PACING TRIAL WON. BY HILARIOUS WAY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 1Sailing Race and Hilarious Way captured their respective trials tonight to lead eight 4yearold pacing qualifiers into next Saturday's $90,000 Realization at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which is building the giant sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, hired Col. James W. Barnett of Alexandria, Va., yesterday as director of construction at $55,000 a year. The authority also hired John A. Flynn of Moorestown as controller at $40,000 a year, and Francis W. Werneke of Woodcliff Lake as project manager at $30,000.

title: I.T.T. NET SOARS 45% IN QUARTER
description: The upward march of firstquarter financial results continued with reports yesterday from companies in a variety of fields across the country.

title: Conservative Party Ready to Drop Biaggi if He Has Lied to Us
description: Conservative party leaders declared yesterday that they would seek to deprive Representative Mario Biaggi of the Conservative mayoral designation either through the courts or the Legislature if it Is determined that he has lied to us.

title: Music: Journey to Past
description: The Fromm Music Foundation, which is known for commissioning new works, put on a program of old ones Monday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Not exactly ancient, but old. The three pieces played by a chamber orchestra under the baton of Gunther Schuller had been given their premiere performances last year, and by most contemporarymusic standards last year is nowhere. The Fromm Foundation had commissioned the three works for its 20th anniversary in 1972.

title: Camden Market Cleared
description: CAMDEN, May 1 (AP)Leone's Meat Market, which is selling horse meat for human consumption, got a clean bill of health today and remained open for business. Camden County health officials had given the store 24 hours to correct nine violations cited during an inspection yesterday.

title: A Code of Loyalty
description: PITTSBURGH  In addressing the Massachusetts Legislature in July, 1951, after his return from the Far East, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur drew a distinction, as he then seemed to view if, between the loyalty and obedience owed by a soldier to his Commander in Chief and the loyalty owed to country and Constitution.

title: PRICES OF BONDS GENERALLY FIRM
description: Bond prices moved indecisively yesterday but with a generally firm undertone as a large amount of securities went through various stages of the underwriting process. Bidding on new corporate and taxexempt issues was described as aggressive, although there was somewhat less interest in the Treasury's auction of $2billion of 6 per cent notes due in 1980. The announcement that president Nixon would speak today on economic matters provided some additional upward impetus, but, as one trader of corporates declared, it was already standing on its awn two feet.

title: Freeways Leaving Their Mark on the Cities
description: CHICAGO, May 1  We don't have rush hours any more, said Charles H. McLean, who runs the world's busiest road. We just have rush periods. And they keep getting longer and longer and longer.

title: Roundup: Braves Lose Despite 2 Aaron Homers
description: Before the start of the 1973 major league baseball season, Henry Aaron of the Atlanta Braves said he hoped he would remain healthy the next two years so that he might have a better chance to break Babe Ruth's home run mark of 714.

title: $200Million Planned
description: DALLAS, May 1  The RCA Corporation expects to spend a record $200million on expansion this year, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman, said after the annual meeting in Convention Center here today.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS IN SLAYING OF BR
description: Scattered violence broke out in the South Jamaica area of Queens last night as bands of youths protested the fatal shooting of a 10yearold black boy by a white police officer last Saturday morning.

title: RATERISE TIEN WORRIES BANKERS
description: The Nixon Administration has left the nation's largest banks in a quandary over how soon they can increase their minimum interest charge on loans to the biggest and most creditworthy corporations to 7 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: May Day Rally Draws 800
description: It was a May Day of signs, I speeches and oratory as 800 people turned out for the annual May Day rally at Union Square. Those in the audience, ilmost of them older people, heard speeches on the themes of corruption in the Nixon Administration, the struggle against capitalism the farm workers fight and welfare reform.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED ON WORK INJURIES
description: TRENTON, May 1The special counsel for the State Commission of Investigation charged today that there was widespread collusion among physicians, lawyers and compensation judges settling claims for injuries or disabilities under New Jersey's Workmen's Compensation system.

description: Minor Leagues

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 3 EXBANK AIDES
description: NEWARK, May 1 (AP)Three former bank officers were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges they operated a complicated, fraudulent loan scheme to divert about $1million from the Middlesex County Bank.

title: RIGHTTO4VORK UNIT SUED BY 10 UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Ten labor unions filed suit today to block the National Right to Work. Committee and its legal arm from bringing legal action against union shop agreements.

title: Biaggi Now Asks Release Of Jury Record, butin Full
description: In a sudden legal maneuver reversing his past positions, Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday asked a Federal Court judge to allow full disclosure of his 1971 grandjury testimony, including the names of lall other persons. The judge quickly rejected the bid.

title: Role of Citibank at Equity Scored by Insurance Aide
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1Lawrence C. Baker, California's deputy insurance commissioner, charged today that the condupt of the First National City Bank indicated that the bank had a very friendly relationship with the principal perpetrators of the fraud in the Equity Funding Corporation of America scandal.

title: TAXLAW REVIEW URGED BY SHULTZ
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz has asked Congress to review the whole question of how the tax laws apply to political parties, candidates and contributors.

title: Runaway Youth Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)  The Senate Juvenile Delinquency subcommittee approved today legislation to provide temporary shelters and counseling services for an estimated million American youths who run away from home each year. The bill, which now goes to the Senate Judiciary Committee, was passed by the Senate last year but died in the House.

title: Coast Doctor Says F.B.I. Tied Teamster Health Plan to Mafia
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Dr. Bruce Frome, the Los Angeles physician who was to provide medical services to teamsters union members under a prepaid health plan, said today that six weeks ago the Federal Bureau of Investigation told him the persons who presented the plan to the union on his behalf were members of the Mafia.

title: Cathy Almeida, on 4,928, Leads Bowling Qualifier
description: GARDEN CITY, L I., May 1Cathy Almeida, 22yearold Fall River, Mass., pro, won the qualifying round of the United States women's bowling championship tonight at Garden City Bowl with a 24game total of 4,923. Second after 18 games, she finished with a 234, while Pat McNeill of Durham,: N.C., scored a 190 for 4,920. In the stretch duel Cathy scored 23, 215 and 210.

title: Williams Downplays Role Of Needham Over Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The chairman of the Senate Securities subcommittee told a cross section of the securities industry today that James J. Needham no longer spoke for the New York Stock Exchan;e on the issues of fixed commission rates and institutional membership.

title: Easier Wiretaps Tabled by Hartford Senate
description: Easier Wiretaps Tabled by Hartford Senate are those involving drugs, gambling and felonious crimes of violence. Even then, the state's attorney who seeks the authorization for tapping a suspect's telephone must show evidence gathered within 15 days of his request.

title: FLORIDA AREA VOTES FOR LAND PURCHASE
description: SARASOTA, Fla., May 1 (AP) Sarasota County voters overwhelmingly approved a $7.7million bond issue today to buy 270 acres of dwindling undeveloped waterfront land on the Gulf of Mexico.

title: EUGENE A. BUZZELL
description: BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., May 1  Eugene A. Buzzell, public relations director for the American Federation of Musicians from 1958 to 1965, died today in St. Andrews hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: U.S.SOVIET SERIES BEGINS TO HEAT UP
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1 (UPI)After a wild ending last night that resembled last summer's fiasco in the Munich Olympic Games, representatives of the United States and Soviet Union basketball teams unleashed a barrage of charges that also recalled last summer's hysterics.

title: Moscow Power Shift
description: The latest Politburo changes in Moscow are as sensational and important in their context as are the latest Watergate developments in this country. The Kremlin orchestrators of Soviet propaganda have gone to great pains to minimize the significance of these historic new shifts, and particularly to protect Leonid I. Brezhnev's public image from injury. But their camouflage cannot conceal the unprecedented nature of the Politburo shakeup, much less the enormous political importance that must be attached to it.

title: Chart of the Derby Trial
description: Chart of the Derby Trial

title: State Awards Bus Contract
description: TRENTON, May 1 (AP)The State Transportation Department today awarded $931,097 in contracts for the manufacture and delivery of 27 airconditioned buses as part of its capital improvement program for the bus industry.

title: JORDAN H. STOVER
description: Jordan H. Stover, a former official of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization; died Saturday in Nashua (N.H.) Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at Minute Man Farm, Pepperell, Mass., and at Waibling in Erwinna, Pa.

title: Grand Jury Opens Inquiry Soon In 2 Narcotics Raids in Illinois
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A Federal grand jury will begin in the next few days to investigate raids that narcotics agents made last week on two Illinois families who were allegedly subjected to violence, threats and obscenity in what turned out to be cases of mistaken identity.

title: Brooklyn Is Getting a New Prepaid Health Plan
description: A new prepaid group health insurance plan that will offer physician house calls and psychiatric care, in addition to the standard health services, will open in downtown Brooklyn this fall.

title: TROOPER WOUNDED ON JERSEY TURNPIKE
description: EAST BRUSWICK, N. J., Wednesday, May 2 (UPI)A New Jersey state trooper was shot and wounded in an exchange of gunfire, early today when he stopped a car for routine check on the New lersey Turnpike near here, the state police reported.

title: Shultz Sharply Raises G.N.P. Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Administration revised sharply upward today its forecasts for the performance of the economy this year.

title: NIXON ROLE CITED
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1John D. Ehrlichman has told Federal investigators that the breakin at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist came as a result of a secret White House investigation he ordered at the request of President Nixon.

title: Congress Pressing Drive For a Special Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Congress, prodded by Republican members, pressed today for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to take charge of the Nixon Administration's Watergate investigation.

description: The chief judge of the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the extradition of Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan to West Germany to face charges that she had murdered inmates ofl a Nazi death camp.

title: CARPENTER UNION STAGES WALKOUT
description: Thousands of carpenters, supported by other craftsmen, struck construction sites throughout New Jersey's 21 counties yesterday, an action that could shut down major projects in the state by the end of the week.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Robert C. Odle Jr., director of administration for President Nixon's reelection committee, has testified that he spent $3,000 to $4,000 in campaign cash to help organize demonstrations in support of Mr. Nixon's order in 1972 for the mining of Haiphong harbor.

description: A neck, a head and a nose were all that separated, the first four horses at the wire yesterday in the Relic, the featured allowance race at Aqueduct.

description: PEKING, May I (Agence FrancePresse)  May bay was celebrated here today in an informal style for the second year, with the focus more on entertainment than on ideology.

title: Exxon Gives WNET A $1Million Grant For Drama Series

description: Governor Rockefeller has picked Michael F. Amstrong, the chief counsel of the Knapp Conunission, as the likely replacement for Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, according to sources in New York and Albany.

title: U.S. Downs Italy, 30, in First Round Of Federation Cup
description: BAD HOMBURG, West Germany, May 1 (AP)The United States, led by Patti Hogan and Linda Tuero, swept Italy, 30, in the Federation Cup tennis competition today. The Americans will meet South Korea, a 30 victor over Norway, in the second round.

description: Bobby Murcer's fourth home run of the season and Sparky Lyle's first save helped the New York Yankees defeat the Kansas Royals, 61, last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: People in Sports: Time For Handing Out Rewards
description: Basketball, hockey and baseball players were rewarded with new contracts and a bonus yesterday. Bob Lantier of the Detroit Pistons and John Bucyk, the elder statesman of the Boston Bruins, received new contracts and Steve Busby, the Kansas City Royals rookie pitcher, was promised a bonus for his nohitter last Friday against the Detroit Tigers.

title: F.B.I. Guard Put on Files Of 3 Departing Nixon Men
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation moved into position today to guard the files of three senior Presidential assistants who are leaving because of the Watergate case.

title: Amtrak, on Birthday, Blows Its Own Horn
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Amtrak, the National Raroad Passengers Corporation, celebrated its second anniversary today with a birthday statement saying that rail travel was regaining public favor.

title: 4 TEAMSTER AIDES GET PRISON TERMS
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI)The four top officers of the largest pure freight teamsters local in the nation have been sentenced to prison terms for giving themselves unauthorized pay rises totaling $102,800.

title: Candidate for City Council Reports Assault in Office
description: A Democratic candidate for City Council nomination in the Bronx said yesterday that he had been hit over the head from behind while working alone in his storefront campaign headquarters.

The outcome was a surprise as Larry Adams rode Settecento to a 1length triumph. Mr. Prospector, the 3to5 favorite with the crowd of 14,518, finished second.

description: Incumbents won easily in most suburban schoolboard elections held yesterday in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties.

description: New York has chosen an approach different from Chicago's in, the use of computers to speed traffic, Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said yesterday, but he praised Chicago's as a beautiful system!

description: Mets' Records

description: Governor Rockefeller presented Society of Silurians medallions last night to 13 members of the news media honored by the association for outstanding journalistic achievement in 1972.

title: Westchester Antiques Fair Is Showing Paintings, Too
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 1One of the most conspicuous developments at antiques shows in the last several years has been the growing interest in paintings, a trend amply reflected in the fair that opened here yesterday at the Westchester County Center off the Bronx River Parkway.

title: Fraud and Collusion Charged In Jersey Compensation Cases
description: TRENTON, May 1The special counsel for the State Commission of Investigation charged today that there was widespread collusion among physicians, lawyers and compensation judges settling claims for injuries or disabilities under New Jersey's Workmen's Compensation system.

title: Roller Derby Tickets on Sale
description: Tickets for the tripleheader world championship of Roller Derby for the Gold Cup at Shea Stadium on Saturday, May 26, will be available through all Ticketron outlets and the Shea Stadium box office. Reserved seats are priced at $5, $6 and $7. The Pioneers face the Jolters in the opening game, and New York Chiefs battle the Bombers in the second game.

title: FARM PLAN'S COST PUT AT 45MILLION
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., May 1Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein disclosed today that he would seek to acquire 9,000 acres of prime Suffolk farmland at a cost of $45million over the next three years in his program to prevent the destruction of the agricultural industry on Long Island.

title: Women's Interclub Golf
description: Women's Interclub Golf

title: India Plans to Buy More Grain Abroad As Crisis Continues
description: NEW DELHI, May 1  The Indian Government is planning to import two million to five million tons of additional food grains to meet the persisting shortage that has caused riots in some areas of the country. An official source said that this would be in addition to the two million tons already bought In the United States, Canada and Argentina, most of which has been used up.

title: MAY DAY IN PARIS HITS A NEW NOTE
description: PARIS, May 1  Tens of thousands of workers sloshed through central Paris today under a drenching rain in a May Day parade that was different from those that have gone on here since 1890.

description: A few hours after saying Giddap! to his Kentucky Derby Special, Howard Samuels granted permission yesterday for a horsemen's group to place WHOA! signs in the windows of 109 OTB shops.

title: FrenchGerman Plan to Bring Shift in Europe's Space Effort
description: BRUSSELS, May 1The European space effort, floundering for years because of technical failures and lack of funds, has reached a turning point with a broad agreement by its two main financial supporters, France and Germany, on mutual commitments for future programs.

title: Congress Pressing Drive For a Special Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Congress, prodded by Republican members, pressed today for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to take charge of the Nixon Administration's Watergate investigation.

title: Hudson Review Marks Its Silver Jubilee
description: In the spring of 1948, in the heyday of the New Criticism and the iambic line in poetry, three recent Princeton graduatesFrederick Morgan and Joseph Bennett, both Princeton 43, and William Arrowsmith, Princeton 45brought out the first number of what quickly became one of the most prestigious of American literary quarterlies, The Hudson Review. Now the 25th anniversary number of the review has just appeared, under the editorship of Mr. Morgan, and its content and outlook afford a vivid glimpse of the changes that have overtaken the world of the serious literary quarterlies in the quartercentury since The Hudson was first established.

title: 3 Hold Illinois Pupils Hostage; One Theft Suspect Slain, 2 Held
description: PEORIA, Ill., May 1 (UPI) Three gunmen held gradeschool children hostage today until the police killed one gunman and the two others surrendered without harming their captives.

title: 154 Compdnies Dividends Up
description: The number of companies increasing their dividends in April totaled 154, up 31 per cent from the year ago levels, Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday. This lifted the total to 773 for the first four months of the year.

title: Connally Will Join Republicans Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally will announce at a news conference in Houston tomorrow his longexpected switch from the Democratic to the Republican party.

title: Haughton Optimistic
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., May 1Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, assured stockholders at their annual meeting here today that the worst is over on the company's L1011 commercial jet program and that the company was making a strong comeback.

title: Castro Favors Latin Group That Would Exclude U.S.
description: MIAMI, May 1 (Reuters)Premier Fidel Castro said tonight that Cuba was willing to join an organization of Western Hemisphere nations that excluded the United States.

title: Watergate Is Harming the U.S. Abroad
description: LONDON, May 1The Watergate scandal appears to have damaged the reputation of the United States abroad, but at the same time many see it as a demonstration of the basic value of a system that can expose skulduggery in high places.

title: Gilliam Caldwell, President Of St. Regis Paper, Dies at 56
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 1  William E. Caldwell, president of the St. Regis Paper Company for the last two years, died yesterday. He was 56 years old and lived at 38 Turtle Back Road.

title: New YorkMontreal Air Shuttle Begins on a High Business Note
description: MONTREAL, May 1Montreal and New York were bridged today by the first international airshuttle service, a reflection of the fastgrowing community of interests between the two cities.

title: RHODESIAN COURT BACKS A NEWSMAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 1The conviction of a journalist for having published secrets harmful to Rhodesia was set aside by the appeals court today, but he remained in jail for the time being under a preventive detention order.

title: GOINH OUT Guide
description: FOLLOW THE LIEDER If you have fallen behind on this subject and want to become au courant on The German Lied and Its Poetry, you should go to Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 83d Street (7448310), tonight at 7:30. There will be a free lecturerecital, including music by the New York Kantorei Soloists and commentary by Profs. Elaine Brody and Robert Fowkes.

title: S.E.C. Staff Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Alan F. Blanchard, formerly on the staff of Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, today was appointed to the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He will become executive director later this month.

title: British Cabinet Still Power Center but Is Subtly changing
description: LONDON, May 1He has remained so obscure that most British reporters who regularly cover government have never shaken his hand. He never appears on television; pictures of him are almost as hard to find as those of Howard Hughes. And the recent news of his retirement was reported sparingly in the British press.
