title: Soviet is Regrouping Its 15 Republics Regions.
description: MOSCOW, May 3The Soviet Union has quietly begun a controversial consolidation of its national planning regions that may ultimately erode the significance of individual Soviet ethnic republics as economic planning and management areas.

title: JOHN. J. M'GINNIS
description: WASHINGTON; May 3John J. McGinnis, a former special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury for National Security Affairs in the Nixon Administration, died today after a heart attack in Montclair, N. J. He was 45 years old.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Bonnie Cashin has fun at her work. She picks new colors, she devises new shapesand the old ones go on and on. So a Cashin style never really becomes obsolete. It just becomes an old friend.

title: F.D.A.Finds Four Vaccines Contaminated With Probably Harmless Viruses
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Scientists of the Food and Drug Administration have found evidence that all four of the livevirus vaccines most widely used in the United States are contaminated with extraneous, although probably harmless, viruses.

title: TV: Special by Mostel
description: Zero Mostel, who almost makes it bearable, might think twice before trying another television musical special like Saga of Sonora, a wretchedly strained and stale Western spoof shown last night over the National Broadcasting. Company.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: Mrs. Philip D. Wilson, 86, A Civic Leader, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Germaine Blanche Porel Wilson, a leader in welfare activities here, died Wednesday at her home, 177 East 75th Street. She was 86 years old.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRICES SPURTED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 The biggest increase in industrial prices since early 1951 more than offset an, unaccustomed dip in farm and food prices last month to produce another sizable jump in the wholesale price index, the Labor Department reported today. Wholesale prices overall rose much less in April than in March. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the index increased 2.3 per cent in March and 1 per cent in April.

title: Late Easter Helped Lift Store Totals by 16% to 30%
description: Consumer buying of apparel, home furnishings and related goods in April surged to one of the biggest monthly gains in several years.reported that department store sales last week rose 11 per cent to $890million from $800million in the same 1972 week.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The State Treasury Department announced yesterday that it would begin asking banks for more information about their community activities before determining how much they would get in state deposits.

title: Main Provisions of the Narcotics Bill
description: ALBANY, May 3Following are the major provisions of the Assemblyapproved drugpenalty program, twice revised downward from the Governor's initial sweeping demand for life imprisonment without parole:

title: Simon Refines'Art Collection by Selling
description: Norton Simon, the West Coast industrialist and art collector, whose impressionist and postimpressionist canvases racked up record auction prices Wednesday night, said that he sold many of his choice paintings in order to obtain a greater balance and refinement in his collections as well as to accommodate his changing tastes in art.

title: Aussie Sets U.S. Cycle Mark
description: ENCINO, Calif., May 3 (UPI) Danny Clarke of Austrialia set an American record of 29.8 seconds for 500 meters last night in a prelude to this weekend's sprint finals in the United States cycling grand Prix. Clarke broke Jim Sime's record of 30.4 seconds as did Daniel Morelon of France, who finished second.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, concerned over the steady rise of about 15 per cent a year in the city's budget, disclosed that it planned to analyze every city agency so that it could recommend where cuts could be made and services improved.

title: HEALTH SERVICES FACING CUTS HERE
description: Health services in New York City, both public and private, stand to lose more than $568million in Federal funds, according to a local study of the Nixon Administration's budget proposals for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: People and Business
description: Among the items in the Washington rumor mill is the report that James E. Smith, Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, will become the next Controller of the Currency, succeeding William B. Camp.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music Dance

title: Nixon Medical File Ransacked in 1972, His Physician Says
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 3A Long Beach, Calif., physician who has accompanied President Nixon during most of his political campaigns said tonight that his office was burglarized twice in September, 1972, and that the President's medical file had been disturbed, but not stolen.

title: RollsRoyce Cars Stock To Be Offered to Public
description: LONDON, May 3The common stock of RollsRoyce cars is to be offered for sale to the public because bids for the company failed to reach the reserve price, it was announced here today.

title: ParaGlider Pilot Killed
description: CENTERVILLE, Utah, May 3 (UPI)A 27yearold father of three was killed yesterday when his lightweight paraglider plunged 200 feet to the ground. The victim was yen H. Gleed of Bountiful, Utah.

title: Red Smith
description: PARIS, Ky., May 3If you want to see where it all began, all the planning and striving and dreaming and plain hard work that will culminate Saturday afternoon the twominute melodrama of the 99th Kentucky Derby, then the best place to look is here on the sweet green acres of Claiborne Farm. Here in the earthfloored breeding shed, the favorite, Secretariat, was conceived four years ago. Up there in that black barn on the hill, Secretariat's prime challenger, Sham, was born to the mare Sequoia on April 9, 1970. These are the fields where Sham played as a yearling, growing into the handsome colt that New York's Sigmund Sommer bought for $200,000 last November in the dispersal sale that followed the death of the master of Claiborne, Bull Hancock. Here is Somethingroyal, Secretariat's 21yearold mother, who belongs to the Meadow Stable Doswell, Va., but keeps coming back for dates with Claiborne stallions. She never beat a fat man in a race, but she has been bearing winners for years and years. Secretariat was her 13th foal. After him she gave Meadow Stable a son of First Landing named Capital Assets, now 2 years old, then a colt by Norther. Dancer, and that foal at her side now is by Jacinto.

title: LEBANESE JETS AND TANKS. ATTACK PALESTINIAN UNITS AFTER A CEASEFIRE FAILS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, May 4The Lebanese armed forces attacked Palestinian guerrillas yepterday with jet aircraft and tanks as heavy fighting continued in this capital for the second day.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The formation of a Fine Arts Committee to encourage black artists and to commission works of art for the New York State Harlem Office Building now being completed was announced yesterday. Its primary responsibilities will be to choose a monumental piece of sculpture to be placed on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 125th Street and to purchase smaller works for permanent display throughout the building.

title: Mother Plans Fight for Battered Baby
description: Lorraine Cruz, whose 3monthold baby was put in hospital after the police stopped the father from trying to sell her so he could buy narcotics, said yesterday that she would fight to have her baby returned.

title: Chotiner Concedes Interceding With Haldeman on Hoffa Parole
description: >WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Murray M. Chotiner, a former White House aide, acknowledged today that he had interceded, with key Presidential assistants to seek a parole for James R. Hoffa, former president of the teamsters union, I did it, I make no apologies for it, and frankly I'm proud of it, said Mr. Chotiner, now In private law practice.

title: Vesco Warrant Issued
description: A warrant for the arrest of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who secretly gave $200,000 to President Nixon's reelection campaign, was issued in Federal court here yesterday. Details on Page 19.

title: Television
description: 6:30 (2)Sunrlse Semester (4)New Approaches (5)Read Your Way Up (7)Listen and Learn

title: It's Shaping Up as a Lively Governor's Race, After All
description: TRENTON, May 3Now that the campaigns have been primed in the Republican and Democratic primary elections for Governor, the pervasive gloom and silent anger that has gripped Governor Cahill for nearly a year has begun to shown signs of easing. In his first major political appearance of the primary campaign last night, before more than 500 Republicans in Essex County, the Governor's feisty proclivity for political combat, clearly missing here for a long time, was back again. He was his old, jaunty self, his friends said, a cocky, highly independent liberal incumbent determined to salvage what he regards as a progressive record from the political corruption created by some of the men he chose to have around him.

title: BIACK AID APPEAL LINKED TO CENSUS
description: WASINGTON, May 3 Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz was urged today to provide additional revenuesharing money to cities because of the undereount of blacks reported last week by the Census Bureau.

title: WOMAN IS FOUND SLAIN IN A STUDIO
description: A 47yearold seamstress who had worked late on a rush job was found dead yesterday morning in an Upper East Side photographic studio where she worked, apparently killed by a blow on the head.

title: Londonderry Sharpshooter Kills Third British Soldier in 6 Days
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 3 (120A British soldier today became the third victim in six days of a sharpshooter in Londonderry.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: NIXON GIVES STAND ON CUTS IN FORCES
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 President Nixon disclosed for the first time today the basic American approach to the talks between the North Atlantic alliance and the Soviet bloc on mutual reductions of forces in Central Europe.

title: PRICES OF BONDS IN BROAD RETREAT
description: Bond prices retreated yesterday along a broad front, reflecting some disappointment that the tightening of economic controls was not more severe.

title: A.H.L. PLAYOFFS
description: A.H.L. PLAYOFFS

title: In Washington, Not All the Old Doubts Are Overcome
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Not since World War II have United States relations with the Soviet Union seemed more promising and freer from rancor than they do today as viewed from Washington.

title: Bunker Optimistic, Citing Drop in Level. Of Vietnam Conflict
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 (AP)The United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, made a public speech today for the first time in 15 months and said that although fighting continued in South Vietnam, the number of large battles has fallen off sharply, and casualty figures continue to inch downward.

title: Dates Listed for Hope Golf
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., May 3 (AP)Dates of Feb. 6 to 10 were set today for the 15th annual Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament in 1974, with four courses to be layed. Ernie Dunlevie, presiuent of the Classic and tournament chairman, said Indian Wells would be the host club for the 1974 event.

title: Magnavox Co. Reduces Its Quarterly Dividend
description: The Magnavox Company said yesterday that its board of directors had reduced the quarterly dividend from 30 cents to 15 cents a share. The new rate is payable June 15 to holders of record May. 21.

title: Durocher Resting at Home
description: HOUSTON, May 3 (UPI)Leo Durocher, recovering from an intestinal infection, rested comfortably at home today and said he would rejoin the Houston Astros May 11. Durocher had been in Hermann Hospital since April 20 with diverticulitis of the colon. He was released last night.

title: ELLSBERG JUDGE ORDERS HUNT DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3The judge in the Pentagon papers trial ordered today that the grand jury testimony E. Howard Hunt Jr. gave yesterday in the Watergate case be turned over to him immediately.

title: Connally to the Rescue
description: The timing of John B. Connally's formal jump to the Republicans is hardly accidental. By coming to the aid of the Grand Old Party in its time of trouble he puts its leaders, especially President Nixon, heavily in his debt. At this stage it was the best way to keep alive his prospects for obtaining, with Mr. Nixon's backing, the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976.

title: 50% in Gallup Poll Think Nixah Helped in Watergate Cover Up
description: Half the American votingage public thinks President Nixon took part in covering up the Watergate scandal, according to a special Gallup Poll on Watergate reactions.

title: Recently Published Books
description: An Eye for a Bird: The Autobiography of a Bird Photographer, by Eric Hosking with Frank W. Lane (Paul S. Eriksson, $10).

title: Parke Bernet Continues Auction Of Art Works by Impressionists
description: A continuing art auction last night that began Wednesday with $6,782,900 worth of paintings and sculpture from the Norton Simon collections lacked the superstars of opening night, but not quality works and customers for them.

title: College, School Results
description: College, School Results

title: The 13 Horses Who Will Run
description: RESTLESS JET: Strong finisher who makes it once in a while, but usually winds up with closebutnocigar effort. Won 1 Everglades with late rush, finished fourth in Flamingo and third in Florida Derby at same distance. With No. 1 post, will probably drop back early, stay on rail at least until backstretch.

title: Humphrey's Mother Dies
description: HURON, S. D., May 3 (AP)Christine Humphrey, mother of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, died here yesterday at the age of 89 at the Violet Tschetter Memorial Home, where she had lived the last 10 yeari. Beside,s her son, she is survived, by two daughters, Mrs. Frances Howlard and Mrs. Fern Baynes.

title: Commodity Price Index Up From the WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial material rose to 155.5 from 153.5 last week.

title: ELLEN JUDGE ORDERS HUNT DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3 The judge in the Pentagon papers trial ordered today that the grand jury testimony E. Howard Hunt Jr. gave yesterday in the Watergate case be turned over to him immediately.

title: Cawley Promotes Aide
description: Police Commissionerdesignate Donald F. Cawley yesterday appointed Assistant Chief Michael J.A. Lonergan as chief of field services of the Police Department. Chief Lonergan, 54 years old, takes over the post held by Chief Cawley, for whom Chief Lonergan was executive aide, immediately. He will be executive head of 72 precincts in the five boroughs.

title: EXCHANGE TO SEEK BROKERS FEE RISE
description: Plans to raise commission rates and possibly other brokerage charges that would affect all small and some large investors were, endorsed yesterday by directors of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Layoffs Disclosed At Equity Funding
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3The scandalridden Eauitv Funding Corporation of America has trimmed its staff to 767 from 950 people in the wake of its courtordered bankruptcy proceedings, Robert M. Loeffler, trustee, said today in an interview.

title: Textile Union Signs Individual Contracts With 60 Concerns
description: The head of the striking textile workers said here yesterday that the union was, no longer seeking negotiations with the two major employer groups but Was presing eforts to sign up individual concerns.

title: Business Briefs
description: Sales of E anud H Savings Bonuds in April totaled $562million, down 6.2 per cent from the level of sales in March but 11.8 per cent above sales in April of 1972, the Treasury Department said yesterday. Sales last month were the highest for any April since the H Bond was introduced in June of 1952. Sales of E bonds accounted for $535million of the total and H bond sales came to $27million.

title: Warrant Issued for Vesco in Campaign Gift Case:
description: A warrant for the arrest oft Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who secretly gavel $200,000 in cash to Presidenti Nixon's reelection campaign, was issued in United States Pistrict Court here yesterday after 30minute hearing.

title: 5 in Various Fields Chosen for Awards By Einstein College
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University announced yesterday the names of the five recipients of the 1973 Albert Einstein Commemorative Awards.

title: LEBANESE JETS AND TANKS ATTACK PALESTNI AN UNITS AFTER A CEASEFIRE FAILS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Fridaft, May 4The Lebanese armed forces attacked Palestinian guerrillas yesterday with jet aircraft and tanks as heavy fighting continued in this capital for the second day despite a ceasefire agreement.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Rise
description: OTTAWA, May 3 (Canadian Press)New 91day Governmen Treasury bills issued today, totaled $220million issue at an average price of 98.780 and an average yield of 4.95 per cent. Last week, $220million were issued at 98.792 and 490 per cent. For 182day bills $45milion were sold at an average price and yield of 97.329 and 5.5 per cent, compared with 97.394 and 5.3 per cent last week.

title: Advertising: Covering the Money
description: When an advertiser switches his advertising spokesmen from Leonardo da Vinci, Columbus and Nero, to Jack Webb, you really know that law and order is an important issue.

title: People in Sports: A $20,000 Party in the Backyard
description: Ever wonder what a nice little backyard cookout would cost? Bob Whitehouse, a Louisville painting contractor, who has been hosting a threeday Kentucky Derby party for friends since 1952, has it all figured out. He figures it will take about $20,000 for the 72 hours of fun, which began yesterday with a continental breakfast and will end tomorrow after the 250 guests climb aboard chartered buses headed for the 99th running of the Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: U.S. Alters Casualty Listings
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Pentagon changed today the listing of six Southeast Asia war casualties from missing or captured to dead by hostile action. None were from the New York area. The action reduced the number of American servicemen still unaccounted for to 1,341.

title: Reds 6Run 4th Beats Mets
description: Reds 6Run 4th Beats Mets

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Lindsay and his wife, Mary, arrived in Moscow for a week's visit. After the Mayor told reporters at the airport that he would privately discuss the question of Jewish emigration Irom the Soviet Union with Government officials, he chatted with Mayor Vladimirty Promyslov of Moscow.

title: Hawks Down Canadiens 74
description: CHICAGO, May 3With the memory of a proud playoff tradition that comes with the uniform, the Montreal Canadiens nearly executed an impossible comeback tonight only to fail in the closing seconds and lose Ito the Black Hawks, 74. It was Chicago's first victory after two Josses.

title: VIETCONG BLAME U.S. IN COPTER INCIDENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 (Reuters)The Vietcong said today that they had opened fire on a United States reconnaissance aircraft misusing a flight corridor for the Vietnam truce commission just below the demilitarized zone.

title: Martha Mitchell Testifies in Civil Suit
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell, clutching a worn, childhood Bible, said again yesterday that she trusted and prayed that her husband, the former Attorney General, was not guilty of wrongdoing in the Watergate case.

title: Radio
description: 8:0510 A.M., WNCN. String Trio in B flat, Schubert; Skaters Waltz, Waldteufel; Fantasy for Violin and Harp, SaintSaens; Egmont Overture, Symphony No. 8, Beethoven; Piano Concerto, Grieg.

title: Revised Narcotics Measure Is Voted 8065 in Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 3The Assembly passed tonight by 80 65 a newly altered version of Governor Rockefeller's already modified legislation dealing with drug traffickers, after Mr. Rockefeller had agreed to the changes to have the bill brought up for a vote.

title: GUNFIGHT SUSPECT CAUGHT IN JERSEY
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 3After a 36hour manhunt, state troopers and local policemen today arrested a man they had sought as a fugutive in the, shootout yesterday morning on the New Jersey Turnpike they, had sought as a fugitive in which a state trooper and a fanner leader of the Black Panthers were killed.

title: Monroe Eisner, .80, bead; A Civic Leader in Jersey
description: Monroe Eisner, president of the Sigmund Eisner Company of Red Bank, N. J., for many years a leading manufacturer of military uniforms, died Wednesday in Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, N. J. He was 80 years old and lived at 190 Prospect Avenue, Red Bank, and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Energy Crisis Stressed At Corporate Meetings
description: The energy crisis and problems of United States corporations operating in South Africa occupied much of the time at several annual meetings yesterday.

title: Crumbling Idols
description: Beirut is again rocked by gunfire and death in its streets. This time it is not Arab defenders combating Israeli raiders, but rather Arabs clashing with Arabs in yet another futile eruption of Palestinian frustration.

title: WARNKE BACKS A.CUT IN FOREIGN ARMS AID
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) A Defense Department official under the Johnson Administration said today that the United States militaryaid program is wholly disproportionate to any demonstrated need.

title: Martha Mitchell Testifies in Civil Suit
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell, clutching a worn, childhood Bible, said again yesterday that she trusted and prayed that her husband, the former Attorney General, was not guilty of wrongdoing in the Watergate case.

title: Urban League Gives Posthumous Award To Jackie Robinson
description: Before an overflow assemblage of 1,500 people, the New York Urban League last night presented its eighth annual Frederick Douglass awards to the late Jackie Robinson anct to Robert A. Bernhard, who had served as president of the league.

title: VIETNAMESE TALKS IN PARIS FAIL AGAIN
description: PARIS, May 3 (Reuters)Representatives of the South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong failed today to break the deadlock in their negotiations for settlement of South Vietnam's political future.

title: Books of The Times
description: Spring. Sunshine. Balmy zephyrs. And the mind begins to turn to butter. So after lazily browsing through a pile of comparatively light entertainments, I recommend for your reading pleasure Russell H. Greenan's The Secret Life of Algernon Pendleton, a specimen of what might be called cheerful gothica, and Dorothy Uhnak's Law and Order, a good oldfashioned yarn about life in the New York City Police Department. Russell H. Greenanwhose previous novel was the estimable It Happened in Boston?Is very good at creating the sort of lovable lunatics who murder so charmingly in Arsenic and Old Lace. The trick in Algernon Pendletonthe thing that makes you sympathize with the dotty old gentleman who is recounting his misadventuresis that at first you're not absolutely certain he's all that mad. Sure, he's descended from a family of eccentrics, the most prominent of whom was a famous Egyptologist with an aberrant sense of humor and a vast collection of tomb artifacts that now decorate Algernon's old house in Brookline, Mass. Sure, Algernon got conked on the head during World War II and has heard strange sounds in his ears ever since. Sure, his closest friend is a Worcester porcelain pitcher named Eulalia, with which he carries on intimate daily dialogs.

title: Barefooted Mrs. Court Beaten by Mrs. Gunter
description: SEA PINES, S. C., May 3Playing without her shoes in the final set to combat serious leg cramps, Mrs. Margaret Court was finally beaten today by an equally courageous Mrs. Nancy Gunter in one of the most dramatic matches on the women's tennis tour in recent years.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TABLE HOPPING Horn & Hardart, whose main involvement in show business had once consisted of putting food on revolving platforms behind little glass, windows, has had its eye on the big time for quite a while now. It has presented concerts, hoedowns, soloists, piano players and other musical events designed to soothe the customer in search of a table. Now there's more to come. Starting tonight, there will be jazz and folk concerts every Friday and Saturday from 10 P.M. to 2 A.M. at H. & H.'s place at 104 West 57th Street (489.1414).

title: Text of Conclusion of Nixon Message
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Following is the text of the conclusion of President Nixon's message on foreign policy:

title: The Whole Story
description: The apparently imminent appointment by Attorney Generaldesignate Richardson of a special prosecutor the Watergate case would be only half of what needs doing. The much more important half is that the person chosen be of professional stature and demonstrable independencetotally free of any ties to President Nixon or Mr. Richardson.

title: Government Lifts Wounded Knee News Blackout
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., May 3Federal negotiators lifted a twoday news blackout on negotiations over the seizure of Wounded Knee here today and denied Indian assertions that a substantial buildup was under way to retake the village by force.

title: House, 29762, Backs Bar On Jobs for Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The House approved by 297to62 vote today a bill to prohibit employment of illegal aliens, despite arguments the legislation would discriminate against Americans of Mexican and Asian descent.

title: Senators See Richardson, Expect Special Prosecutor on Watergate to be Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Elliot L. Richardson refused today to commit himself to name a special prosecutor in the Watergate case, but Senators who met with him got the impression that he would appoint one.

title: VOGT IS MEDALIST AT 71 IN L.I. GOLF
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 3 Marten Vogt, a Federal Bureau of Investigator agent stationed in New York City, took the afternoo noff to shoot excellent tolf in terrible weather and win the medal in the annual William D. Richardson amateur tournament by two strokes today.

title: Knicks Win and Even Series, 11
description: INGLEWOOD Calif., May 3Hanging on through a harrowing finish of a closely fought game, the New York Knicks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 9995, tonight, and achieved their hope of getting a 11 split here in the first two games of the fourofsevengame series for the National Basketball Association championship.inger restricted Gail Goodrich to 14, and McMillan's 261 matched Bradley's total. Wilt Chamberlain, with 20 rebounds, was his usual defensive terror, but he missed eight of nine freethrow attempts and that hurt the Lakers this time.

title: RESERVE REPORTS RATES IN UPTURN
description: Key shortterm interest rates moved upward sharply this week, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. Leading bankers said this would create new pressure for an early increase in the prime lending rate of the major banks to 7 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Miss Martorella Captures U.S. Women's Bowling
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 3 Millie Martorella of Rochester, N.Y., captured the United States women's bowling championship tonight at the Garden City Bowl.

title: First Pittsburgh Is Seeking Pennsy Unit
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company, which has been in bankruptcy since June, 1970, announced yesterday it had received a letter from the First Pittsburgh Corporation indicating interest in a possible purchase of the 93 per cent interest owned by the Penn Central in the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company. The Penn Central said that the First Pittsburgh Corporation mentioned a figure of $136 a share for the 656,272 shares of Pittsburgh & Lake Erie stock held by Penn Central. Based on that price the transaction would be valued at $89,252,992.

title: Senate Called Back to Vote A gain on Environment
description: TRENTON, May 3Governor Cahill this afternoon announced that Alfred N. Beadleston, president of the State Senate, would call a special session of the chamber next month to reconsider three administrationbacked environmental protection measures that were defeated in the Senate's final session before it adjourned a week ago.

title: A DEFENSE FUND SOUGHT FOR LEVY
description: Former political workers for the John V. Lindsay Association, city employes and officials are among those being solicited for $100aticket contribudons to a legal defense fund for Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission who is under indictment on charges of fixing parking summonses in Brooklyn.

title: Enter Big John, Softly
description: WASHINGTON, May 3John Connally of Texas has entered the Presidential race by denying that he was doing anything of the sort, I seek no office, political or appointive, he said in a deception almost worthy of the Watergate.

title: COLONELS DOWN LEAD, 211 PACERS,
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 3 (AP) Artis Gilmore scored 28 points and blocked a key shot with 20 seconds remaining tonight to pace the Kentucky Colonels to a 9288 victory over the Indiana Pacers, giving the Colonels a 2I edge in the fourofsevengame American Basketball Association championship series.

title: L. Marsden Hubbard Dies; Headed Connecticut Bank
description: L. Marsden Hubbard, who retired in 1952 as president of the Travelers Bank and Trust Conwany of Hartford, died Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz., while on vacation. He was 91 years old and lived in Newtown, Conn.

title: Couple Withdraw Their Offer Of Mansion for Chief Justice
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Impatient with what they consider Congressional dawdling, Mr. and Mrs. G. Howland Chase have withdrawn their offer of a $340,000 Washington mansion to be the official residence for the Chief Justice of the United States.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AFTER LATE RALLY
description: An afternoon rally enabled shares on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market to finish higher yesterday after declining earlier in the day.

title: Bridge: World Press Group Honors Dean of American Writers
description: The dean of American bridge writers recently received a signal honor from his professional colleagues. Alphonse Moyse Jr. of New York, known throughout the world of bridge as Sonny, has been elected honorary member of the International Bridge Press Association, and is the first American to be so honored.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A.M.A. ASKS STUDY ON DOCUMENTARY
description: The American Medical Association formally asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to investigate the alleged distortion and slanting of news in a National Broadcasting Company television documentary called What Price Health?

title: State, Citing Audit Block, May Hold Up District 9 Aid
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist notified the District 9 school board in the Bronx yesterday that he would withhold all special state funds given to the districtamounting to *1.3million a year unless the board promised by no later than Monday to cooperate with a state audit.

title: COURT BACKS PERMIT FOR QUEENS PROJECT
description: ALBANY, May 3In a 4to3 decision, the Court of Appeals upheld an Appellate Division ruling that the Lefrak Organization can proceed with the construction of twin 18story apartment buildings in the Forest HillsKew Gardens area of Queens in New York City.

title: Deaths
description: BEEBEFrederick 5, On May 1, 1973 beloved husband of Liana (Petzl.Bazny), toy ins father of Walter H. and Michael. Dear brother of Emily Williams. Service Riverside Church, 122nd St. & Riverside Drive, N Y City, 12 Noon Friday, Mar 4th. Interment Private. In lieu of flowers coiltributlons may be made to the American Cancer Society In his memory.FRIEDMANMorris. The pnvelling of the monument for Ms late Morris Friedman will take niece at the New Monteflore Cemetery. Pine Lavin, L.1., Sunday, Mar 6 at 1:00.

title: KODAK SEES GAINS IN QUALITY OF FILM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it had informed photofinishers and processing equipment manufacturers of development programs that could result in significant improvements in the quality and processing of Kodachrome and Ektachrome films.

title: Gooks, Slopes
description: In Winthrop, Mass., last January, fifteen armed men burst into the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Pine, terrorized them and their daughter for what the family said was fifteen minutes, then abruptly left. They were state, police plainclothesmen, raiding the wrong house in search of a drug operation.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS CUT IN SALES LEVY
description: PARTFORD, May 3  The Connecticut General. Assembly approved a $1.2billion budget todsy and gave the state its first cut in a quarter of a century. It also approved the First major tax reform in 25 years.

title: Youths Rampage After Slain Boy's Rites
description: Scattered incidents of looting and attacks on whites flared along New York Boulevard in South Jamaica, Queens, yesterday following the funeral of a 10yearold black boy who was shot and killed by a white policeman last Saturday.

title: REA Express and Union Agree on Labor Contract
description: REA Express, Inc., and the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks reached agreement early yesterday on a new contract running through Dec. 31, 1975.

title: Moorer Honors Adm. Dewey
description: Speaking at dedication services for the Adm. George Dewey Memorial at Battery Park, Adm Thomas H. Moorer chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said yesterday that the United States must continue the sort of preparedness advocated by the SpanishAmerican War hero if it was to remain strong. The memorial is near the sea wall where Dewey made a triumphal return to New York in 1899.

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary and Index

title: Citizens Commission Plans Steps to Limit City Budget
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, concerned over steady rise of about 15 per cent a year in the city's spending, disclosed last night that it planned to expand its own budget and activities in efforts to keep down the city budget.

title: PRICES OF FUTURES SHOW BUOYANCY
description: President Nixon's decision not to make another acrosstheboard price freeze nor to roll back, prices while tightening controls over price rises was greeted with enthusiasm by livestock and soybeangrain traders in Chicago yesterday.

title: Haldeman and Ehrlichman Testify Before Grand Jury
description: WASHINGTON, May 3H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, who resigned recently as senior advisers President Nixon, appeared at length today before a Federal grams jury investigating the Watergate affair.

title: College Drug Arrests Rise
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 3 (UPI)A maintenance worker and a football player were arrested on narcotics charges yesterday at the University of Nevada Las Vegas, bringing the total of drug arrests in two days to 22. Arrested yesterday were Charles Benza, 20 years old, a maintenance worker, charged with three counts of selling narcotics, and John Beseda, a football player, on six counts of selling narcotics.

title: Delta Empress Is First
description: Apparently all William M. Bridgforth's Delta Empress needed for a winning effort was a race over grassat a distance. The 3yearold daughter of Delta Judge thrived under such conditions at Aqueduct yesterday in scoring first success in almost a year.

title: Druse Is Sentenced to 30 Years By Israeli Tribunal in Spy Case
description: TEL AVIV, May 3  A Druse who organized a spy ring from Syria against Israel was sentenced to 30 years in prison today by a military tribunal in Quneitra.

title: OPEC Postpones Meeting In Tripoli on OH Accord
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 3 (AP) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has postponed an extraordinary meeting it had scheduled in Tripoli for May 7, the Nigerian Government announced today.

title: Two Killed in Quebec Blast
description: QUEBEC, May 3 (Reuters)At least two persons were killed and several injured today in an explosion and fire in a former hospital

title: COMPANIES SHOW BIG PROFIT GAINS
description: Sharply higher firstquarter earnings were the feature again of most financial corporate re ports issued yesterday, some of which were announced at annual meetings.

title: Ovation for Solti Gotterdammerting
description: A couple of years ago, Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall with a concert performance of Wagner's Das Rheingold, and people are still talking about it. Judging from the reception that greeted his performance of Act III of Gotterclammerung on Wednesday night, that performance also will pass into Carnegie Hall and New York musical legend.

title: Proxmire Wins Point as Pentagon Cuts Limousine Usee
description: Washington, May 3 Senator William Proxmire, who generally is dismissed as a bothersome gadfly by the Defense Department, has finally managed to sting the Pentagon brass at one of its most sensitive points  the use of military servants and limousines.

title: KISSINGER VIEWS CAMBODIA PARLEY AS POSSIBLE SOON
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Henry A. Kissinger said today that the situation in Cambodia had improved both militarily and politically in recent weeks and that there was a possibility that negotiations might begin in the near future to end the fighting there.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRICES SPURTED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The biggest increase, in industrial prices since early 1951 more than offset an unaccustomed dip in farm and food prices last month to produce another sizable jump in the wholesale price index, the Labor Department reported today.

title: POMPIDOU MEETS NIXON ON NIAY 31
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) President. Nixon will meet with President Pompidou of France in Iceland on May 31 and June 1 to review AmericanEuropean relations.

title: Draft System Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The National Council to Repeal the Draft told Congress today that the standby draft systern was a waste of money because the machinery could be revived in plenty of time in wartime emergency.

title: HILL AHEAD BY 2 SHOTS ON 67
description: HOUSTON, May 3Mike Hill, whose lone 1972 victory on the pro golf tour was in Texas, led the $205,000 Houston open by two strokes today with a fiveunderpar 67.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows
description: ANDROMACHE by Racine; translated by Lionel Abel; directed by Martin L. H. Reymert. At 8 P.M., Fridays, Satdays, Sundays; through May 20. REETY IN HELL by Stephen Holt; score by Donald Arrington; directed by Peter Schneider. At 8 P.M., Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays; through May 24. WPA Theater, 333 Bowery (2280900, 4739345).

title: Equity Financing
description: Two offerings were made yesterday by newly formed closedend investment management companies. CNA Income Shares Inc, offered 4.6 million common shares at $15 per share through underwriters managed by First Boston Corp.; duPont Glore Forgan; Shearson Hammill, and Walston & Co, with Continental Assurance Co., a unit of CNA Financial Corp, as the investment adviser. The Excelsice Income Shares Inc., offered 2.2 million common shares at $25 per share through underwriters headed by Kidder Peabody; Bache; Clark Dodge; Harris Upham; and Hayden Stone UST Advisory Co., a subsidiary of U.S. Trust Co., is the investment adviser.

title: In Moscow, the New Mood Drowns Out Even Watergate
description: MOSCOW, May 3  With Henry A. Kissinger due at the Kremlin tomorrow, the atmosphere of SovietAmerican relations could hardly be more hospitable: This is the one big world capital where a Nixon Administration official can escape the Watergate nightmare.

title: 8 Indicted in BoysforSale Ring
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 3Eight men, including a former organizer for Big Brothers of New York and a noted child psychiatrist from Northern Ireland, were indicted today in connection with what was described as an international homosexual ring, that operated out of Suffolk County.

title: News Council Head Defends Project and Suggests That Critics Are Shortsighted
description: The chairman of the National News Council says that editors and publishers who oppose the new organization may be very shortsighted.

title: Revised Narcotics Measure Is Voted8065 in Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 3The Assembly passed tonight by 80 to 65 a newly altered version of Governor Rockefeller's already modified legislation dealing with drug traffickers, after Mr. Rockefeller had agreed to the changes to have the bill brought up for a vote.

title: Ickx Sets Mark in Trial For Belgium Race Sunday
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium May 3 (AP) Jacky Ickx of Belgium averaged a record 162.222 miles an hour today in the first day of trials for Sunday's 1,000kilometer auto race.

title: French Assembly Chief Foresees More Heed for Public Opinion
description: PARIS, May 3Edgar Faure, who has been a Premier and a Cabinet minister and who has now become President of the French Assembly, has come to the conclusion that modern democracy requires new methods to match the new public awareness of national problems.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fishing Time
description: Now is the time for saltwater anglers from New Jersey north to rehabilitate their fishing tackle.

title: NIXON MAY NAME INTERIM ADVISER
description: MIAMI, May 3President Nixon is expected to announce this weekend the appointment of an interim adviser to fill to White House staff vacancies created by the resignations of H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman.

title: Records for Month Posted by Foreign and U.S. Models
description: DETROIT, May 3  Newcar sales topped the million mark in April for the second consecutive month.

title: Pope Orders a Study of the Role of Women in Church and Society
description: ROME, April 3Pope Paul VI today set up a study commission on the role of woman in society and the Roman Catholic church.

title: 25.76Point Swing Is One of Sharpest Analysts Recall
description: The stock market rebounded yesterday from a spate of selling and posted a solid gain on rising turnover.

title: Maritain Buried in France
description: KOLBSHEIM, France, May 3 (UPI)  Jacques Matitaln, the Catholic philosopher, who died Saturday at the age of 91, was buried today in the town cemetery. Mr. Maritain, a Protestant, converted to Roman Catholicism after marrying a Jewish woman. His body was taken to this small village in eastern France, where he, spent his childhood.

title: Major League Leaders
description: BATTING HOME RUNS RUNS BATTED IN PITCHING

title: TV: Strauss Family Explores Waltz King's Life
description: The Strauss Family, produced by England's Sir Lew Grade, has several points in its favor. The production is, if not lavish, clever enough to give the appearance of 19thcentury Vienna lavishness. The music, all those waltzes by Johann Sr. and Johann Jr., can still, as one German observer recorded at the time, stir the blood like the bite of a tarantula. The lilting melodies are effectively given the counterpoint of a biographical story that is almost leadenly seedy.

title: NASSAU VOTINGNAN APPROVED BY COURT
description: ALBANY, May 3The State Court of Appeals today overturned a lower court's decision that had declared unconstitutional a weighted voting plan adopted by the floard of Supervisors of Nassau County.

title: Justice Department Criticizes Rules of Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Department of Justice asked a Federal District Court today to abolish the New York Stock Exchange's system of fixed minimum commission rates.

title: R.O.T.C. Credit Restored
description: AMHERST, Mass., May (AP)  University of Massachusetts trustees have voted to restore academic credit to Army and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps programs. Credit was withdrawn in May, 1972, after the Haiphong mining began.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: PHILADELPHIASigned Allan Bristow, VII, ginla Tech forward, to threeyear contract,

title: PERONIST LEADER BACKS CIE RULE
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 3After a crucial threehour meeting today with military leaders, Dr. Hector J, Campora, Presidentelect of Argentina, announced that his Peronist Government would assume office as scheduled on May 25 and that the armed forces would remain subordinate to the national authorities.

title: GOODMAN BANKS
description: HARTFORD, May 3 Goodman Banks, founder and president of Loring Studios, a photographic chain in New England and Pennsylvania, died Tuesday. He was 70 years old.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tentative plans for a $30million industrial park near the Southern State Parkway and Nassau Read in Roosevelt, L. I., were announced yesterday by Francis T. Purcell, the town's Presiding Supervisor. But construction depends, he said, on the ability to obtain $3million in seed money from the state and Federal governments, with the rest obtained from private sources. He estimated that the plan for light industry, commercial and retail properties and an office complex on 40 acrescould create 2,500 jobs a mostly black community.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, May 3Even the nondrinkers were intoxicated by looking at the sight on a table at St. Peter's College here today. Intoxicated because the model of new sports recreation facility, which will cost $5million, was on a tablebut it will be for real on the campus by October, 1974.

title: That Year, in Jerusalem
description: Eliahu Elath was the agent for the provisional government of Israel in Washington in May of 19413.when the State of Israel was proclaimed. He was the first Israeli Ambassador to the U.S. and later president of Hebrew University. This article is an excerpt from a memoir of Washington events of the day, 25 years ago, when a Jewish state was proclaimed in Palestine, and was recognized by the U.S. Government.

title: JETS WIN AND TRIM WHALER LEAD TO 21
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 3 (AP)Bobby Hull's second goal of the game at 18 minutes 56 seconds of the third period tonight gave the Winnipeg Jets a 43 victory over New England and reduced the Whalers lead in the fourofsevengame World Hockey Association championship series to 21.

title: Muskie Says Many Incidents Could Have Been Sabotaged
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that a number of incidents occurred during his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination that could have been the result of political sabotage.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS CAMBODIAN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The House Appropriations Committee defeated a bid today to deny funds for the bombing of Cambodia setting the stage for a major floor fight over the Administration's Cambodian policies.

title: U.S. Issues 17 Import Licenses To Ease the Gasoline Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 The Government issued to 17 independent gasoline dealers today the first licenses to import gasoline without paying the new import tax of 1 cents a gallon.

title: ADA BONI
description: ROME, May 3Ada Boni, coauthor with her husband of one of the bestknown books on Italian cuisine, died here yesterday at the age of 92.

title: Vesco Hired Nixon Nephew After U.S. Inquiry Began
description: BOONTON, N. J., May 3In July, 1971, one month after the Securities and Exchange Commission began investigating Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier, Mr. Vesco approved the hiring of Donald F. Nixon, the young nephew of President Nixon.

title: GoodBy Dr. Cuozzo
description: CHICAGO, May 3 (UPI)Gary Cuozzo, starting quarterback for the St. Louis Cardinals said tonight he was retiring from football to become an orthodontist. He will graduate from the school of orthodontics at Loyola University in June, completing 14 years of schooling in the profession.

title: EZRA STILES, HEADED FAMILY LUMBER FIRM
description: Ezra M. Stiles, president of the Stiles Lumber Company of Paterson, N. J., since 1946, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 394 Lincoln Avenue in Hawthorne, N. J.

title: KALMBACH LINKED TO DESTRUCTION OF CAMPAIGN DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Herbert W. Kalmbach, who was President Nixon's personal attorney until a few days ago, has told Government investigators that he destroyed all his campaign finance records before the new Federal campaign finance law took effect April 7 last year, sources close to the case said today.

title: DR. JOHN M'KINNEY
description: Dr, John McDowell McKinney, former attending neurologist at St. Luke's Hospital and the Neurological Institute, died Sunday in St. Luke's. He was 80 years old and lived here and in Bridgehampton, L. I.

title: 2 NEWSMEN SHARE THE BERGER PRIZE
description: Metropolitan news reporters for The New York Times and The New York Post have won the Columbia University's 1973 Mike Berger Award, it was announced yesterday by Elie Abel, dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Feeble Price Restraint
description: President Nixon still refuses to unleash the stick in the closet he promised to wield if Phase 3 became the disaster it now clearly is. Despite an alarming upsurge in industrial prices on top of the meteoric climb already recorded in the cost of food, Mr. Nixon proposes nothing more than a minimal tightening of the restraints he loosened so prematurely last January.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Kurosawa Finishes First In Japan Grand Prix Race
description: GOTEMBA, Japan, May 3 (AP) Motoharu Kurosawa of Japan defeated four foreigners and seven other Japanese drivers today to win the 120mile Japan Grand Prix Formula Two auto race in 1 hour 8 minutes and 55.15 seconds.

title: How It Is Now With the People of My Lai
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Not far from Quang Ngai City the Muc Tien refugee camp lies on a sandspit on a river. Some 20,000 people live in the eongenies of tents and tinroofed shacks, each tent sheltering ten or more families, and each family with only the space for a bed and a bundle of belongings.

title: City Seeks Mortgage Unit to Curb Slums
description: In a major move to prevent transitional neighborhoods from degenerating into slum areas, the city plans to submit a bill to the Legislature within a week that would create a local F.H.A. type of agency to insure bank mortgages.

title: Excess Profits Units Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reuters)The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a twoyear extension of the Renegotiation Board, the agency that has authority to recover excess profits from defense and other Government contractors. Yesterday representatives of the machine tool industry urged The committee to kill the board, which has been In existence since 1951.

title: Musikie Says Many Incidents Could Have Been Sabotaged
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) ASenator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said today that a number of incidents occurred, during his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomation that could have been the result of political sabotage.

title: OLIVER'S 2 HOMERS ROUT GIANTS, 145
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (UPI)  Al Oliver drove in six runs today with a tworun homer and a grand slain, and Milt May added a threerun homer to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 145 rout of the San Francisco Giants.

title: Floyd M. Simmons, 90; Was Coach at Davidson
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 3 (AP)Floyd M. Simmons, who coached strong Davidson College football teams in the early nineteen hundreds, died Wednesday at the age of 90.

title: G.A.O. Asks an Inquiry Into Ad Paid for by Nixon Election Unit
description: WASHINGTON May 3The General Accounting Office today referred to the Justice Department for further investigation and action the placing in The New York Times, of an advertisement that was secretly paid for by President Nixon's reelection committee, in apparent violation of Federal law.

title: InflationHit Germans Raise Bank Rate
description: BERLIN, May 3The Bundesbank today announced an increase of one point, to 6 per cent, in the West German bank ratea move aimed at stemming runaway inflation.

title: THEY LIKE SHAM IN TIMES SQUARE
description: It's all E, a ticket seller at the OTB shop in Times Square reported yesterday an hour after the start of offtrack betting on the Kentucky Derby. Believe it or not, I haven't had too many L's.

title: Communists Renew Phnom Penh Attack
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 3 (Reuters)  Communist troops renewed the attack on 'Phnom Penh's southern defenses today and fresh fighting was reported along the Mekong River supply route.

title: BEAME PROPOSES PROGRAM ON FARE
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday proposed al sixpoint program, including substantial financial aid from the state and Federal governments, to maintain and per haps even reduce the 35cent transit fare.

title: Agnew Gets Award, Calls No Plays
description: Vice President Spiro Agnew received the Pop Warner Little Scholars Award from the Touchdown Club of New York last night at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt. The Vice President made several witty remarks, the most cogent of which concerned the suggesting of plays to pro football coaches.

title: American League Friday, May 4, 1973
description: Western Division

title: GEN. EDMUND HILL LED U.S. AIR MISSION
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me., May. 3Maj. Gen. Edmund W. Hill, retired, who was head of the air section of the United States Mission to Moscow, and the commanding general of the American Air Forces'in the Soviet Union from December, 1944, to May, 1945, died Tuesday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

title: 4 in Mackell's Office Got Free Car Use, Avis Says
description: The AvisRentACar Sys tern, Inc., permitted at least four employes in the office of former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens to use cars free at a time the office was prosecuting a case whose outcome benefited Avis, according to documents presented to the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: Wired Jaw Fails to Silence a Humble Ali
description: He spoke through clenched teeth, a habit that developed when his broken jaw was wired shut. He wasn't as loud as he used to be. He even professed to be humble now. But eventually Muhammad Ali reverted to the form that made him famous.

title: Clean Auto Engine Held Feasible With U.S. Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  A Senate subcommittee was told today by a succession of innovators that, if Federal funding was provided, a lowpollution, lowfuelconsumption alternative to the conventional automobile engine could be fully developed in three to four years. Most agreed that mass production would take several years longer.

title: Dave Anderson
description: As the United States and Soviet basketball teams elbow each other across America, capitalism leads, two games to one, despite itself.

title: 52 Feared Dead Near Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 4 (Reuters)  Fiftytwo people were feared drowned when a bus, waiting for a ferry, plunged into the Bansi River 19 miles west of here yesterday, it was reported today.

title: FEELS CONFIDENCE MUST BE RESTORED
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Henry E. Petersen, who is in charge of the Federal investigathin of the Watergate case, has told associates that he would like to have a special, outside prosecutor appointed to oversee the entire inquiry.

title: MRS. JOHN J. NEWBERRY
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May, 4Mrs. Alice Malloy Newberry, widow of John J. Newberry, founder and chairman of the J. J. Newberry Company, a national organization of variety stores, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital. She was 85 years and lived here.

title: Mrs. Nixon's Aide Disputes Mrs. Mitchell
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's press secretary denied yesterday Mrs. John N. Mitchell's testimony that lies and rumors galore about her had been leaked by the White House to the press after the Watergate bugging came to light last June or that Mrs. Nixon had ever said that Mrs. Mitchell was very, very ill.

title: Ilinois Blocks Amendment
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 4 (UPI)The Illinois Senate rejected yesterday a move to free the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution from a hostile Senate committee that had voted to hold, the proposal. On a 2819 vote, the Senate defeated a motion to remove the bill from the Senate Executive Committee. The motion needed 30 votes.

title: WINE TALK
description: LONDONStanding before you are two pairs of white wines, a pair of ross and three pairs of reds, all in unlabeled bottles. One wine in each pair is from a recognized French district. The other wine in each pair is not from France.

title: Timber!
description: The skyrocketing price of lumber has induced the Nixon Administration to appoint a task force whose job will be to plan an increase in the timber cut of the national forests; and it is all too predictable that any increased timber cut will be at the expense of the forests themselves. Such a course would , be indefensible and unnecessary.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Tale of Indestructible Chinese Heroine
description: "Deep Thrust," one of the latest Chinese-made features bristling with "martial arts" that appear to be fighting for the local popularity of, say, chow mein, is decidedly a departure from the norm of the genre.Its most feared kung-fu and karate expert is a pretty, if lethal, little miss, who can grimace and shout and chop and kick any dozen male experts into a gory mess single-handedly before you can say "Gung Ho!"Neither Hallmark Pictures, which imported it from Hong Kong, nor American International, the distributors, have come up with either writing credits or character listings for the unfamiliar cast.It does not much matter, "Deep Thrust," a title, we suspect, that was not dreamed up in the Orient, has been dubbed into colloquial English that is often unwittingly funny. And, the adventures of our indestructible heroine who, we can only assume, is Angela Mao, are either simply muscular or unintentionally comical.

title: ARMY MAJOR HELD IN FAMILY SLAYINGS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 5 (AP)Army Maj. Arnold Levine, a quartermaster officer here at Fort Sam Houston, was charged early today with, beating to death his Vietnamese wife and fouryearold son.

title: Notes on People
description: President Tito of Yugoslavia, who will be 81 years old May 25, has been canceling official appointments lately, apparently because of physical exhaustion. The President met Edward Gierek, the Polish Communist party leader, at an airport in Slovenia yesterday after the meeting had been scheduled for Belgrade. A state dinner in honor of. Mr. Gierek was also canceled in Belgrade.

title: Deaths
description: Inveilings

title: Music: Kubelik Conducts
description: Since the death of Goeran Gentele, who named him music director of the Metropolitan Opera, Rafael Kubelik has become one of the key figures in New York's musical life. And yet, few conductors of international reputation can be as little known to audiences of our major musical organizations. Mr. Kubelik will make his Metropolitan debut only next fall, in fact, conducting Berlioz's Les Troyens, and until Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert he had not appeared with that orchestra since his debut in 1958.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Five midtown greenswardsMadison Square, Herald Square, Greeley Square, Union Square and Bryant Parkswill be a little shadier and a lot greener, under a corporate AdoptAPark plan announced yesterday by a businessmen's group known as the Association for a Better New York, and the city's Parks, Recreational and Cultural Affairs Administration.

title: GRAND JURY DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4The plot to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's phychiatrist was conceived, supervised and paid for in the White House, and the Central Intelligence Agency supplied the camera and disguises for the job, according to testimony by E. Howard Hunt Jr. before the grand jury investigating the Watergate breakin.

title: Vacations for the Aging
description: Inside every old person, so the saying goes, there is a young person trying to get out. This tug is especially visible in summertime when the buses leave the serried edges of the city for weekends in the green countryside. Forlorn, many elderly citizens are Only pavementbound witnesses. But not all, for through Vacations for the Aging and Senior Centers Association at least 5,000 older people can spend two weeks in cooperating camps in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut this summer. To see their hearts lifted as they participate in arts and crafts classes, swimming, boating and biking, is to be inspired by the joy of others. These vacation experiences often ripen into yearround friendships in programs at senior centers.

title: People and Business
description: Jean Monnet, considered the father of the European Common Market, proposed yesterday that the United States and Europe appoint two very wise men outside government to evaluate the trade and monetary issues that divide the two blocs.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Reflections at 842 Madison Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets, is a small shop made to seem larger than it actually is by the nature of the merchandise on display. Chrome, nickel, glass and everything that reflects, but through silver like a mirror is what's on hand, explained Helene Lickdyke, who manages the store.

title: SOME U.N. ENVOYS REBUKED ON DEBTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4The United States has rebuked some foreign diplomats for not paying rent, loans, chargeaccounts and other bills and has warned that they would henceforth risk the embarrassment of being identified to their fellow diplomats.

title: Hilarious Way 52 Choice in Realization
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 4 Hilarious Way, a bay son of Bret Hanover, is the 52 favorite in tomorrow night's 12th running of the $90,000 Realization Pace for 4yearolds at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Sham, Laurin Entry 21 in First Derby Action
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 A record preDerby Day crowd of 39,540 witnessed today's racing program at Churchill Downs, which was featured by the $67,150 Kentucky Oaks, which began in the same year as the Derby. In an upset, C. V. Whitney's Bag of Tunes won by five lengths. Second in the 1 116mile race for 3yearold fillies was the heavily favored La Prevoyante, who finished 1 lengths ahead of Coraggioso.

title: Newmont to Widen Its Cement Holding
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation announced yesterday it had reached an agreement to acquire for $38,500,000 the 50 per cent interest in the Atlantic Cement Company now held by the Cerro Corporation.

title: Cawley Sets Up Panel to Screen Officers Showing Chronic Violence
description: Police Commissioner  designate Donald F. Cawley, responding to the unrest over the fatal shooting of a 10yearold boy by a policeman in Queens last weekend, created a special panel yesterday to screen out members of the department who have shown tendency toward chronic use of force in their work.

title: Earnings Up 11.7% at Travelers Corp. in Quarter
description: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's second largest stockholderowned insurance organization after the Aetna We and Casualty Company, reported yesterday firstquarter net income of $37.3million, or 81 cents a share, up 11.7 per cent from $33.4million, or 72 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: College President Honored
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., May (AP)Thomas E. O'Connell, president of Berkshire Community College, Pittsfield, has been named to receive the 1973 Alexander Meiklejohn Award for Academic Freedom, given by the American Association of University Professors in Washington.

title: BUCKLEY ADMITS IDENTITY ERROR

title: Screen: 'You're Lying'
description: Whatever their subjects, the feature films of Vilgot Sjoman"I Am Curious (Yellow)," I Am Curious (Blue)"tend to share a common form: the not-exactly documentary. In "You're Lying," which was made in 1969 and opened this week at the First Avenue Screening Room, the form persists, though with changes. "You're Lying" begins as a straight documentary about the Swedish penal system, becomes a fictionalized documentary about a young man who is not rehabilitated in Swedish prisons, and ends as a psychological study about what seems almost a symbiotic relationship between a prisoner and the imprisonment he cannot quite bring himself to escape.As a documentary, "You're Lying" intends to expose Swedish prisons. Much of this may be lost on American audiences, for whom the lot of the Swedish prisonerconsiderable privacy, personal freedom, leave privileges, etc.will probably look like summer camp.The prisoner in question is Lasse (Stig Engstrom), a would-be artist, a would-be writer, a well-developed alcholic who steals a bit to keep in booze. Lasse is the special concern of Bjorn (Borge Ahlstedt), a young art teacher who respects Lasse's talent, who writes newspaper pieces protesting his imprisonment and who tries to provide for him when he does win parole. But he is beyond providing for, and he breaks parole and returns to jail, leaving behind him broken promises, personal abuse and bitter memories. The indictment of the prison system has turned into an indictment of a man for whom there is, in a sense, no imprisonment absolute enough to satisfy him.Though the later parts of "You're Lying" are much more interesting than the earlier parts, Sjoman is so deadly earnest about everything in his movie (and about his own involvement as a film maker) that he treats the drama as if it were an illustrative annex to the documentary. This is manifestly unfair.Sjoman has shot "You're Lying" largely in close-up. Indeed, he is the kind of director who cannot achieve distance without suggesting alienationand though this may be right for his subject, it is a real limitation in the experience of seeing the film. This is too bad, because "You're Lying," possibly despite its intentions, is a work of some integrity.

The museum bought the firearm last November at a Sotheby auction in London, but the purchase was never announced.

title: 4Star Diplomat in White House Alexander Meigs Haig Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Before taking off on another delicate troubleshooting mission to Vietnam early in January, Gen. Alexander Meigs Haig Jr. posed for pictures with President Nixon outside the Nixon home in Key Biscayne, Fla. As the men turned back toward the House, the President suddenly reached over and fingered the four bright stars on the general's shoulder. The gesture perhaps best symbolized the affection and the pride that the President has for the 47yearold career military officer whom he chose today as his White House chief of staff.
