title: Daley's Ally With Stock in Bank, Indicted Over Chicago's Deposits
description: CHICAGO, May 4Mayor Richard J. Daley's closest political associate, Alderman Thomas E. Keane, was indicted today on charges of conflict of interest, official misconduct and conspiracy.

title: GRAND JURY DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4The plot to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's phychiatrist was conceived, supervised and paid for in the White House, and the Central Intelligence Agency supplied the camera and disguises for the job, according to testimony by E. Howard Hunt Jr. before the grand jury investigating the Watergate breakin.

title: When Is 6.85% Not 6.85? Bond Men Face the Issue
description: VIENNA, May 4When does a bond that yields 6.85 per cent not yield 6.85 per cent? The answer: When it yields 7 per cent.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Trenton will be No. 1 in America tomorrow, when it holds its 44th allbreed show at Washington Crossing State Park. The event has drawn 3,830 dogs, making it the largest show thus far this year. Last year a crowd of 50,000 came to watch the spectacle at the 1,000acre park, where Washington's Army crossed the Delaware nearly two centuries ago to rout the Hessians.

title: Supreme Court Refuses To Permit Abortion Now
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to permit an immediate abortion for a woman who asserted that a Green Bay, Wis., hospital was denying her constitutional rights and endanger ing her health with its antiabortion policy.

title: ALAN CARNEY DIES; COMEDIAN WAS 63
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., May 4 (UPI)  Alan Carney, film and stage comedian who was at one time under contract to both R.K.O. and Disney Studios, died Wednesday of a heart attack after having won the daily double at Hollywood Park. He was 63 years old.

title: Prices of Stocks Rebound In Active Trading Session
description: The stock market continued to rebound yesterday in the most active trading since the dollar was devalued Feb. 12.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Saigon Says Fear of Eleition Makes Reds Stall at Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 4 (AP)  President Nguyen Van Thieu's top adviser.accused the Vietcong today of stalling at the Paris political talks because, he said, they know they cannot win a national election.

title: JERSEY SURROGATE ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: JERSEY CITY, May 4Hudson County Surrogate John J. Lemken and two other persons were indicted by a county grand jury today on charges of swindling more than $23,000 from two aged sisters in Meadowview Hospital, a county mental institttion.

title: DEMETRIOS GALANIS, HEADED GREEK BANK
description: ATHENS, May 4Demetrios Galanis, Governor of the Bank of Greece and the Government's chief negotiator for foreign loans, died tonight of a stroke at the age of 73.

title: Passaic Goes to Polls Tuesday
description: PASSAIC, May 4When the electorate goes to the polls here Tuesday it will be voting directly for a mayor for the first time in 64 years.

title: A.C.L.U. Assails Searches Of Passengers on Airplanes
description: The American Civil Liberties Union assailed the nation's fivemonthold program of mass airport searches yesterday as completely inconsistent with constitutional principles.

title: New Truce Halts Fighting By Lebanon and Guerrillas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, May 5A ceasefire was arranged yesterday between the Lebanese Army and Palestinian guerrillas, ending more than two days of heavy fight ing in and around this capital.

title: Four at City Ballet Give a Fine Display Of Dancing Power
description: The New York City Ballet flashed a quartet of ballerinas on Tuesday evening in works drawn mainly from last year's splendid Stravinsky festival. It was an understated but unmistakable display of dancing power.

title: AUSTRALIA REACHES TENNIS SEMIFINALS
description: BAD HOMBURG, West Germany, May 4 (UPI)Australia Advanced to the semifinals of the 11th Women's Federation Cup tennis tournament today, beating Indonesia, 30. Australia, which won the cup in 1964, 1965, 1968, 1970 and 1971, will meet West Germany, finalist in 1966 and 1970, in the semifinals tomorrow.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A luxury hunting gun, made for Louis XIII of France in the 17th century, has been purchased by the Metropolitan Museum at reported by the highest price ever paid for a firearm. Although the museum did not reveal the price, sources said it was $301,000. The museum bought the firearm last November at a Sotheby Parke Bernet auction in London, but the purchase price was never announced.

title: Amtrak Fares Protested
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) Representative Ella Grasso, Democrat of Connecticut, asked the National Railroad Passenger Corporation today to reconsider its decision to discontinue reduced rate commuter tickets on runs between Boston and New York. Commuters on Amtrak trains between Boston and New York now have to pay full fares, she said.

title: Trade Accord Bid Is Being Postponed By Japan, E. E. C.
description: BRUSSELS, May 4  Japan and the European Economic Community decided today to abandon stalled efforts to reach a bilateral trade accord and let the outstanding issues between them be handled in the multilateral GATT trade talks that will begin this September.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, MAY 5, 1973
description: In the second truce worked out since the fighting began Wednesday, a ceasefire was arranged yesterday between the Lebanese Army and Palestinian guerrillas, ending more than two days of heavy fighting in and around Beirut. Egypt, Iraq and Algeria were mediators. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Blast Site Cleared of Bombs
description: ROSEVILLE, Calif., May 4 (UPI)A total of 1,233 TNT bombs that did not explode in a series of weekend blasts that were felt 100 miles away have been safely removed from the railroad yard where the explosions took place, a military spokesman said today. The recovered bombs were part of a shipment of more than 7,000 explosives destined for Cambodia. The explosions injured nearly 50 persons, damaged 700 houses and destroyed more than 200 boxcars. Damage has been estimated at $10million.

title: JESSE SOLOMON
description: Jesse Solomon, a manufacturer of hair accessories and other notioncounter items, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Beth Israel Hospital on Thursday evening. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and had formerly lived in New York.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT CONTINUES TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) Installment credit reached a high in March for the third straight month, showing that American demand for goods and services continued at a reoord rate, Federal Reserve Board statistics showed today.

title: Officer Arrested in Robbery. Of Man He Lost To in Game
description: A policeman who allegedly held up a friend and took money he lost playing shuffleboard in a tavern was arrested yesterday and suspended, the police reported.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Box Scores

title: Spirit Behind Yale Paper Since 1923 Saluted
description: NEW HAVEN, May 4For a time it seemed that the generations of students who have passed through The Yale Daily News since 1923 and gone on to successful careers would inadvertently leave Francis M. Donatie to retire this summer without a pension.

title: U.S. APPEAL COURT UPHOLDS RELEASE OF BIAGGI MINUTES
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a decision to disclose the grand jury testimony of Mario Biaggi on the ground that the Bronx Representative had waived his right to secrecy.

title: Premiere of Voyage
description: Martha Graham's newest work Is about a stockbroker whovants to go off to Tahiti. Well; not really. But that is the image that appears to, lie behind Myth of a Voyage, her latest treatment of Greek legend, whose premiere was given by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Thursday night at the Alvin Theater.

title: Bronx Beginning Celebration Of Its Cultural Renaisiance
description: The Bronx? No thorax. Ogden Nash, 1931

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Tickets may be obtained at the public desk, main lobby, United Nations Headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: Spaceship Nearing Jupiter
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 4 (UPI)  The spaceship Pioneer 10 is now so far away from earth that it takes a radio signal more than an hour to get out there and back. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that the unmanned space laboratory, launched more than I year ago, is 400 million miles along its journey to Jupiter, with only 100 million miles more to go. The spaceship is scheduled to reach Jupiter next December.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on whether to close debate on voterregistration bill. Vote on April 30 was 56 to 31, short of required twothirds.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: DR, A, B, GUTMAN, A CANCER EXPERT
description: Dr. Alexander B. Gutman, noted medical researcher and professor emeritus of medicine at the Mount. Sinai Hospital.

title: Auction Brings $13Million
description: A marathon art auction that began Wednesday night and will end today, has so far brought in $13,279,850 and has become even before its close, the most remunerating public sale of its kind.

title: Campora Said to Tell Military He Will Crush Argentine Rebels
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 4A wellplaced Peronist official says that the Presidentelect of Argentina, Dr. Hctor J. Campora, assured military leaders at a meeting yesterday that he would not tolerate guerrilla attacks on the armed forces, after he takes office on May 25.

title: Chotiner Files Libel Suit Against The Union Leader
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 4 (AP)Murray M. Chotiner, a former aide to President Nixon, filed a $3million libel suit today against The Manchester Union Leader and one of its reporters, Arthur C. Egan Jr., for an article that linked Mr. Chotiner to the Watergate affair.

title: Nixon ReElection Unit Got $1Million to $2Million in Cash Destroyed Records
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Top officials of President Nixon's main fundraising organization here, the Finance Committee tc Reelect the President, solicited $1million to $2million in large cash contributions during 1971 and early in 1972 and then destroyed the records through which the contributors could be identified.

title: I.R.A. Company in Belfast Said to Lose All Its Top Men
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 4 (Reuters)  A top company of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army in Belfast has been temporarily disbanded after a crackdown by the British army, an army spokesman said today. He said that eight of the company's officers had been arrested or shot by army paratroopers in the stanchly republican Ardoyne area of the city in the last two months.

title: Ozark Strike Cietinues
description: ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP)The strike by mechanice of Ozark Air Lines entered its third week today with both sides communicating through a Federal mediiator but no immediate end to the walkout in sight.

title: College Baseball
description: College Baseball

title: Business Briefs
description: VIENNA, May 4 (AP)Talks between representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and of major oil companies on price increases for crude oil will resume in Tripoli on Monday, an OPEC spokesman said here today. Yesterday there were reports the talks would be delayed.

title: DEAN SAYS HE TOOK WATERGATE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 4John W. Dean 3d said today that before his dismissal as counsel to President Nixon he removed documents dealing with the Watergate scandal from his White House office to prevent their illegitimate destruction.

title: Historic Albany Residence Wins a Stay of Demolition
description: ALBANY, May 4 (AP) Walsh House, built in the eighteenforties on the estate of a former Albiny Mayor, Ambrose Spencer, will stirvive for at least six more months under an agreement reached between the Hudson River Valley Commission and the board of directors of Albany Hospital.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: May 1L.A. 115, Knicks 112. May 3Knicks 99, L.A. 95. May 6At Garden, 2:10 P.M., ticket K7. May 8At Garden, 8:30 P.M., ticket K8. May 10At L.A., 10:30 P.M. May 13At Garden, 2:10 P.M., ticket K9*. May 15At L.A., 10 P.M.* *If necessary.

title: Major Disclosures By Dean to Senator Reported in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 4John W. Dean 3d, the ousted White House counsel, outlined major new developments in the Watergate case yesterday in a secret meeting with Senator Lowell P. Weicker, the Connecticut Republican, it was reliably learned today.

title: British Soccer
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: 4 SEASONS CASE SPLIT BY JUDGE
description: The United States Court of Appeals upheld by a twotoone vote yesterday a Federal judge's decision dividing the massive Four Season Nursing Centers of America stock case into two parts  leaving one defendant for trial in New York and five others transferred to Oklahoma.

title: SHORTAGE FEARED IN FRIERS FUEL
description: ALBANY, May 4 (AP)A 10 per cent shortage of farm fuel could strike Schenectady County at about June 1, according to a survey by the county's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Committee.

title: Son Of Tango
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Confession written after a harrowing experience under the hypnotic influence of having just seen Last Tango in Paris:

title: Bahnsen Victor 7th in a Row by White Sox
description: CHICAGO, May 4The largest White Sox crowd of the season was treated to free fireworks and tree cushions tonight and the Yankees were treated to a lot of gift baserunners.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Pegs 41

title: Derby Fever Epidemic Hits OTB Patrons Here
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 (UPI)The National Weather Service had good news today for Derbygoers. The forecast for tomorrow was for sunny skies and temperatures in the upper 60's.

title: Spirit Behind Yale Paper Since 1923 Saluted
description: NEW HAVEN, May 4For a time it seemed that the generations of students who have passed through The Yale Daily News since 1923 and gone on to successful careers would inadvertently leave Francis M. Donahlie to retire this summer without a pension.

title: A Black Artist's Ideas Put Into Allegory
description: Having decided that the 1976 national Bicentennial will be a celebration of White America, the black artist Benny Andrews has already begun some bicentennial works of his own. The third and latest of his largescale allegorical paintings, Circle, together with its related oilstudies and drawings, is on view at the ACA Galleries, 25 East 73d Street.

title: Excerpts From Hunt's Grand Jury Testimony About Ellsberg Raid
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4 (AP)  Following are excerpts of testimony by E. Howard Hunt Jr. before a. Federal grand Jury looking into the Watergate affair in Washington. The excerpts were released in Federal Court here today.

title: New York: The Burdens and the Glories.
description: BOSTONI've been asked to be a twoday expert on. New York and its Mayor. It's like asking an editor to fix the wiring in a 747. I don't have to wrestle with the garbage pickup, the transit system or the problems down at police headquarters.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WEST IN RUSSIA AND CHINA. Religious and Sccuiar Thought in Modern Times. Vol. 1, Russia 14721917, and Vol. 2, China 15821949. By Donald W. Treadgold. 324 and 251 pages, Cambridge University Press. $12.95 and $11.95.

description: Aqueduct Jockeys Aqueduct Entries Roosevelt Entries Roosevelt Results

title: Fists of Fury, a Karate Movie, Arrives
description: Perhaps it is because his male cousins begin disappearingmysteriously and forevertwo by two. Perhaps it is because he discovers that the blocks of ice have plastic bags frozen into them, bags full of a suspicious white powder. But for whatever reason, young Cheng does come to realize that things are not right at the old icehouse down by the river, where he and his cousins have been working.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Dispute Delays Indian's Burial
description: PORCUPINE, S.D., May 4 Funeral services were held here today for Lawrence Dean Lamont, the second Indian to die during the 66day seizure of the nearby hamlet of Wounded Knee.

title: STABBING VICTIM DIES OF WOUNDS
description: James Freehill, the 16yearold son of a New York City policeman stabbed in a fight in Carl Schurz Park near Gracie, Mansion two weeks ago, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: L L UNIT ACCUSED OF BUSINESS RAID
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens accused Nassau and Suffolk Counties of trying to raid Queens and lure business and industry away by holding an open house to talk about the advantages of relocation.

title: Broker Halts Business
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that B/W/A, Inc., a brokerage concern based in San Marino, Calif., has ceased to do business as a member firm. The firm had two other offices in California and one office in New York City.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Why Would Anyone Be an Italian Soccer Referee?
description: ROME, May 4Some of the most harried men in all Europe are Italian soccer referees.

title: College and School Results
description: BASEBALL College Baseball LACROSSE TENNIS BASEBALL

title: FILLY IS CHOICE OVER COLTS TODAY
description: A filly, Rokeby's Summer Guest, is scheduled to oppose 11 colts in this afternoon's 30th running of the Grey Lag Handicap at Aqueduct. And the only female in the 1mile event is listed as the overnight 3 to 1 favorite.

title: DEANSAYS HE TOOK WATERGATE DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 4John W. Dean 3d said today that before his dismissal as counsel to President Nixon he removed documents dealing with the Watergate scandal from his White House office to prevent their illegitimate destruction.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary distribution of 92,210 shares of L S. Good & Co. common at $7 a share was announced yesterday by Bache & Co. and Eppler Guerin & Turner, Inc. The company's stock closed unchanged at 6 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: AIDE TO NIXON ERRED ON OSTEOPATH'S BILL
description: A White House spokesman said yesterday that he had erred in saying last April 10 that a New York City osteopath who had treated President Nixon had been privately paid by the President.

title: Governor Expected to Modify JudicialAppointment Request
description: ALBANY, May 4Governor Rockefeller is expected to introduce legislation next week giving him the power to appoint additional judges to handle any Influx of court cases resulting from enactment of his legislation for dealing with drug traffickers, sources in the Legislature said today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX GAIN FOR 3D DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter registered their third consecutive advance yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: TORTURE MED IN ST. CROIX USE
description: ST. CROIX, V. L, May 2 A soft rain hurried shoppers along the narrow streets of Christiansted today in the search for dutyfree bargains, and as they darted into the shops and arcades along King Street, they passed several young men and women handing out leaflets.

title: Size of U.S. Copper Profits in Chile Disputed Here
description: An official of Codelco, the Chilean Government's copper corporation, charged here yesterday that the Kennecott Copper Company and the Anaconda Company had taken exorbitant profits out of Chile. Both United States companies denied the charge.

title: Jobless Rate Stays at 5% for 2d Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The nation's unemployment rate remained at 5 per cent in April, the same as in March and basically unchanged for the fifth month in a row. The Labor Department reported today that total unemployment in April, after seasonal adjustment, remained at 4.4 million, roughly the same as the levels that have prevailed since last November.Total employment, meanwhile, which had risen sharply in the two previous months, was also unchanged in April at 83.9 million after adjustment.

title: Segretti Indicted in Mailing Of Bogus Muskie Letter
description: ORLANDO; Fla., May 4A Federal grand jury today indicted Donald K Segretti, a national campaign worker for President Nixon, on a charge of political espionage in Florida last year. The grand jury ac cused Mr. Segretti and a Tampa accountant, George H. Hearing, of arranging for the mailing of a fictitious letter on the stationery of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, who was a candidate in the Florida Presidential primary at the time.

title: SALES OF WALGREEN AND GRANT INCREASE
description: The Grant Company and the Walgreen Company reported yesterday large sales gains in April compared to the yearearlier month. As in the case of other major retailers that also reported big monthly gains earlier this week, a portion of the rises is attributed to the Easter shopping season this year falling in April while in 1972 it fell mostly in March.

title: Rogers Sets Latin Trip
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers will leave on May 12 for a twoweek visit to seven or eight Latin American countries. The Secretary is expected to stop in Mexico, Argentina, Brazil, Nicaragua, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia and possibly a Caribbean country.

title: Nixon Signs Weaker Version Of Bill Assisting the Aged
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 4 (AP)With praise for Congress, President Nixon announced tolay the signing of a scaledclown aid bill for older Americans that replaces a measure he vetoed last year.

title: U.S. Indicates It Opposes French ATests in Pacific
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) The State Department Indicated today that It opposed the French nuclear tests In the South Pacific.

title: 3 SESSIONS ARE SET BY PRINTERS, PAPERS
description: Typographical Union No. 6 and Manhattan's three major daily newspapers have scheduled bargaining sessions on a new contract for Monday, Wednesday and Friday next week.

title: INTERIM CHOICE
description: MIAMI, May 4Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. was named Assistant to the President today as President Nixon began to redesign a White House staff devastated by the Watergate scandal.

title: Roundup: Frank Robinson, An Angel, Haunts Orioles
description: Frank Robinson, a former longtime resident of right field in Baltimore's Memorial Stadium, made his first appearance in that ballpark since the Orioles traded him after the 1971 season and helped to defeat his old teammates last night.

title: Handcuffing the Police
description: It is grimly appropriate under the circumstances that Governor Rockefeller's deceptive drug program won approval in the State Assembly onlyafter Mr. Rockefeller himself issued a palpably false message of necessity. This abused device permits hasty passage of measures and avoids the embarrassment of reasonable delay and full debate. Gubernatorial dominance has been linked with legislative submissiveness in Albany; good government is the loser.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co. Expands
description: Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it would spend more than $10million to expand and convert its chloralkali plant in Longview, Wash. The conversion calls for change from the current mucurycell process to a diaphragmcell process.

title: American League
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS TODAY'S PITCHERS National League TODAY'S PITCHERS

title: Burns Gains Richardson Golf Semifinals
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 4George Burns, a strong 23yearold athlete who was married last Saturday and spent a four  day honeymoon in Bermuda, returned to his other love today, golf. The Metropolitan and Long Island amateur champion defeated two opponents to reach the semifinals of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament.

title: MURROW FELLOWSHIP AWARDED FOR 73'74
description: The Council on Foreign Relations has chosen James Oliver Goldsborough, European correspondent of The International Herald. Tribune in Paris, as its Edward R. Murrow Fellow for 197374.

title: Huntington Dump Plan Arouses Residents
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I.The Huntington Town dump is running out of space, and residents here are concerned that a new proposal to buy 7.2 adjacent acres will bring it within 200 feet of $65,000 homes.

title: TROY AND BEAME HEDGE AND FENCE
description: Still shadowed by Representative Mario Biaggi's court case, the New York City mayoral primary campaign entered its final month yesterday, a sometimesdreary Saturday that saw one of the candidates, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and the Queens Democratic leader, Matthew J. Troy Jr., fencing over a possible endorsement.

title: State of the World
description: In its examination of the crucial importance of this country's security alliances and international economic relationships, President'Nixon's fourth State of the World report to Congress was similar in approach to his trade message last month. His emphasis throughout was on the enduring value of these partnerships with Western Europe and Japan in what he called today's changed international environment.

title: All Sells Philadelphia Home
description: PHILADELPHIA, Mar. 5 (AP) Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, has sold his Philadelphia home for a reported $67,000. The boxer's parents lived in the rambling, contemporary styled house, but a friend said they returned to Louisville, Ky., where the former champ was reared.

title: Canada's Bilingualism: Cacophony and Complaints
description: MONTREAL, May 5  O Canada, this country's unofficial national anthem, has both a French text and an English text, and tradition holds that a person can sing it in whichever language he prefers.

title: ROSSETTI OUSTER AS LEADER SOUGHT
description: Reform Democrats in Manhattan are planning another attempt to oust former Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti as the county leader after the June 4 primary, but they are not optimistic.

title: Educators See Schools In England
description: Ninetyfive Long Islam teachers, administrators am students of education Mx Went to England for a wed tb view the open classrooms system there, returned recently impressed with what they had seen.

title: Chess:
description: Joseph Henry Blackburne, the greatest player in England's long chess tradition, was wont to dub the French Defense the King'sPawnSneakOne Opening. While a contemptuous term at once prompts the suspicion that an underlying fear is being masked, it would be difficult to unearth any reason for that in Blackburne's games.

title: Over 100 Women Runners Ex in Miniarathon
description: More than 100 runners are expected to compete in the second wolnen's marathon over a sixmile course in Central Park next Saturday, starting at noon.

title: If Not God, Old Scratch
description: The Ouija board next to the Scrabble set. A voodoo grigri bristling pins like a porcupine between Barbie and Ken. Simon Magus, Cagliostro and Madame Blavatsky sharing honors with Archie Bunker, Snoopy and Mark Spitz. The unpleasantness in 17thcentury Salem more familiar than the 20thcentury shenanigans of Joe McCarthy. Horoscopes and kaleidoscopes. Tarot decks and Old Maid decks. Doctor Faustus and Doctor Seuss. Dracula and Disneyland. Telepathy and Terrytoons. It is no secret that in the world of the teenybopper, Rosemary's baby and Sybil Leek are giving the likes of Huck Finn, Holden Caulfield and the Hobbits of Middle Earth a run for their money. And it is no wonder either.

title: Lebanon
description: BEIRUT  When Lebanese Army tanks surrounded the teeming Palestinian refugee camps here last Wednesday, a stark battle order from the Palestinian command came over the loudspeakers to the guerrilla fighters quartered in the camps: You have no place to go, so this is where you are going to die or live.

title: School Election
description: Charges of administrative gaffes and voting irregularities cast a shadow over last week's elections for the city's local school boards.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board ART
description: BrooklynBrooklyn Museum exhibitions include The Art of the Dogon, and a tribute to Picasso. Hours: 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., today and Wednesday through Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Poland Protects Wildlife
description: WARSAW, May 5 (Reuters) More than 384 kinds of rare animals and birds, including aurochs, chamoiS, marmots, tarpans, eagles and cranes, are protected under a wildlife preservation program dating from 1868.

title: Tour of the Brownstones in Park Slope
description: Park Slope Is mown among architects and house fanciers for street after attest of brownstones from the eighteeneighties and eighteennineties. This afternoon, however, the 14th annual house tour focuses on the outstanding rows of brownstones dating from the eightten sixties and eighteenseventles on Sixth Avenue in the lower part of Park Slope.

title: Rusty Coat Triumphs
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., May 5 (AP)Rusty Coat, driven by Ben Webster, eked out a halflength victory in the $8,000 Commander Robert It. Doremus Pace at Freehold Raceway today and paid $6.40, $3.40 and $2.40 for $2 across the board. The time for the mile was 2:02 4/5.

title: British Drop Topless Poster
description: LONDON, May 5 (UPI)Britain's Royal Academy of Art has decided to withdraw the picture of a barebreasted model on a poster promoting its 250th anniversary. The move came after transport authorities warned that the poster would encourage graffiti.

title: Burns Captures Richardson Golf Tournament on 3and2 Victory Over Vogt
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I. May 5  George Burns estab dished himself as the area's golfer to beat again this year as the 23yearold Metropolitar and Long Island amateur cham  pion took the 26th annual Wil  Liam D. Richardson tournament today.

title: America No Free Lunch
description: The quality and staying power of American civilization remains a basic matter in the world today.

title: Columbia Alumni Unit Cites 4 for Their Achievements
description: The alumni association of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons has cited two alumniDr. Virginia Apgar of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Anthony DeAngelis of Yonkers and two members of the college's class of 73 for outstanding achievements.

title: Labs Test Purity of Drugs Sent by Unidentified Users
description: An increasing number of laboratories across the country will analyze, without asking embarrassing questions, any illicit street drug that the user would like to know more about.

title: ST. JOHN'S CAPTURES 3TEAM TRACK MEET
description: FIELD EVENTS TRACK EVENTS

title: JOHN E. WALSH
description: John E. Walsh, formerly of Freeport, L. I., who retired in 1962 as supervisor of the spareparts department of the Grumman Corporation in Bethpage, L. I., died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. His age was 76.

title: TwoDay Festival Of Bach Planned
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I. There is something quite unfathomable about the music of Johann Sebastian Bach, says George Rose, founder and conducter of the Waldorf Choral Society. Once you do it, you feel you must perform it again and again because you can never do it justice.

title: Homer Bigart Gets A. J. Liebling Prize At a Press Parley
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Homer Bigart, twice winner of the Pulitzer Prize, received the 1973 A. J. Liebling Award today at the Liebling II counterconvention.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: A new development in the apparel industry presents a possibility of reviving the socalled couture fashion business, which has been losing ground in the last five years.

title: TAX CUT ASSURED BY MICHIGAN VOTE
description: LANSING, Mich., May 5Michigan taxpayers are looking forward to the first general tax cut in state historya twoyear, $380million reduction effective in 1974.

title: Feuerbach Puts Shot? 17 Javelin Record Also Falls
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 5Al Feuerbach, a 25yearold local athlete, broke the world shotput record today with a heave of 71 feet 7 inches at the San Jose invitation track and field meet.

title: Brandeis U. Proposes a Permanent Exchange of Students With Leningrad U.
description: WALTHAM, Mass., May 5Brandeis University has proposed a permanent exchange program between its students and students of Leningrad State University in the Soviet Union.

title: Wilt the Key as Knicks And Lakers Meet Today
description: Wilt Chamberlain, who isn't hard to spot wherever he happens to be, will be the man to watch at Madison Square Garden and on the nation's television screens today when the New York Knicks and Los Angeles Lakers resume their National Basketball Association playoff. They are tied 11, in the fourofsevengame competition for the league championship.

title: Mrs. Gurfein Has Son
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 5A son was born April 20 to Mr. and Mrs. James Gurfein in the White Plains Hospital. Mrs. Gurfein is the former Miss Dorothy Weinstein.

title: Raymond Welpott Jr., 58, Dies, ExPresident of N.B.C. Division
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C. May 5Raymond W. Welpott Jr., who retired in 1971 as president of the National Broadcasting Company owned  stations division, died last night of a coronary thrombosis at his home here. His age was 58.

title: Edward W. Clucas 3d Weds Anne Bachman
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 5 Miss Anne Kathryn Bachman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Bachman of North Plainfield, was married here this afternoon to Edward Welch Clucas 3d. He is the son of Edward W. Clucas Jr. of Oldwick and Mrs. Diana, R. Schley of New York.

title: In Hackensack, New Hope for Renewal
description: HACKENSACKTwo privie developers have brought nay life to an urban renewal program here that had been stalled for several years while the city agencies argued over planning and financing.

title: PHILIP H. WEISSMAN
description: Philip H. Weissman, whq retired last month as a principal of the accounting firm of J. K. Lasser & Co died Friday in New York Hospital, after having undergone surgery. He was 67 w years old and lived at 329 St. John's Avenue in Yonkers.

title: STATE POOR FOUND SHIFTING TO CITY
description: Despite largescale spending to combat poverty here during the nineteensixties, the city by 1970 had a larger proportion of the state's poverty families than a decade before.

title: Rangers Beat Celtic, 32, For Scottish Soccer Cup
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 5 (Reuters)  The Rangers ended Celtic's reign as the undisputed masters of Scottish soccer today when they beat their Glasgow rivals, 32, in the final of the Scottish Football Association Cup at Hampden Park.

title: Court Voids Plans to Sue On Welfare Allotments
description: MOUNT HOLLY  New Jersey's welfare boards, which had been hoping to use a new way to recover overpayments to clients, must return to conventional methods.

title: Miss Casals's Drop Shots Help Win $30,000 Final
description: SEA PINES, S. C., May 5Using the drop shot with amazing effectiveness, Rosemary Casals won the richest prize iri the history of Women's sports today with a 36, 61, 75 victory over Mrs. Nancy Gunter in the final of the $100,000 Family Circle Cup tennis tournament.

title: NURSING HOME FIRE NOW CALLED ARSON
description: HONESDALE, Pa., May 5A fire that claimed 15 lives in a nursing home near here on Oct. 21, 1971, was termed the work of an arsonist as a result of a coroner's hearing that ended here today.

title: Price Controls
description: WASHINGTONIn a cliffhanger 11thhour debate replete with a minifilibuster in the Senate, Congress last Monday extended for 12 months President Nixon's sweeping authority to regulate wages, prices, dividends, interest and profits.

title: More Newsmen Permitted To Attend G.O.P. Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Organizers of next week's $1,000aplate Republican fundraising dinner have agreed to provide tickets to 25 newsmen with Congressional credentials in addition to those with White House credentials.

title: AUSSIES CAPTURE DAVIS CUP SERIES
description: MADRAS, India, May 5 (AP) Australia clinched the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final today when John Newcombe and Geoff Masters defeated the Indian team of Premjit Lall and Vijay Amritraj, 46, 6.2, 75, 63.

title: Costs May Increase For Private Carting
description: PATERSONThe cost of having garbage collected by private refuse companies is expected to increase as the result of a decision handed down by a Superior Court judge here last Wednesday.

title: Law Enforcement Officials Evaluate Impact of Murphy's Reforms
description: Patrick V. Murphy led the Police Department for 949 days in which, according to many of his supporters and some of his critics, he began a revolution in the way the 30,000man force serves the millions of people who live and work in New York City.

title: Sri Lanka: A Victim of Own Generosity
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 5Teenage youths marched along the beach the other day and shouted, We don't want free rice! Women in saris shrieked, We will eat curries without chilis! Even children scampered beside the surf and yelled, We will drink our tea without sugar!

title: Television This Week
description: Morning

title: The Derby: Secretariat Wins in Record Time, With Sham 2d
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 Secretariat was the real goods in the Kentucky Derby today, and Sham was second best. The Meadow Stable colt flew to a recordbreaking victory in the 99th running of the famous stakes, covering the 1 miles in 1:59 2/5.

title: WALTER W. FOSKETT
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., May 5Walter W. Foskett, a lawyer here for 52 years, died Thursday at the age of 87.

title: Suffolk Picks Branch Site for Community College
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. In a reversal of previous strategy, Suffolk will build the first satellite center of its ocemnunny college on the West End of the county, rather than on the East End.

title: The Use Of Adversity
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Nothing moves this city to action like a thumping big scandal or a disaster. It took the scandals of the indirstrial expansion at the turn of the century to produce Teddy Roosevelt's reforms. It took the economic Depression to produce the New Deal, the Soviet Sputnik to shove us to the moon, the murder of Jack Kennedy to get his program through Congress. So maybe, the hateful Watergate will demonstrate once more the uses of adversity.

title: Teachers Challenge Diocese
description: Classes at the nine high schools operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn returned to normal late last week after a oneday work action by lay teachers, but there were strong indications that the contract dispute would continue.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Soviet Union
description: Well before the first moan landing in 1969, when it became apparent that the triumph would be American, Soviet officials began publicly emphasizing their nonlunar objectivesparticularly the value of giant space stations. Accordingly, in April, 1971, Salyut 1 was launched into an orbit of the earth. It was hailed as the first space stationan orbiting research facilityand the beginning of a new era of space flight.

title: Mass Transit
description: The biennial transit crisis awaits. On Jan. 1, the city subsidies that have kept the subway and bus fare at 35 cents for two years will end. And on March 1, the, transport workers contracts will expire.

title: South Africa Acts On Tribal Control In Adjacent Area
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 5South Africa has announced new constitutional measures to move SouthWest Africa's most developed African homeland, Ovamboland, toward separate bantustan independence.

title: OpenSpace Zoning Plan Advanced in East Hampton
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. How much should a community pay for retaining its open space and ruralresort character?

title: Japanese Department Store Opens a 4Story L.I. Branch
description: CARLE PLACE, L. I. Following the lead of American counterparts who have already learned there's more gold than crabgrass in the suburbs, Takashimaya, Japan's largest department store chain, last week opened a fourstory $2.5million bnInch across from Roosevelt Raceway.

title: PASARELL AND ROCHE SEMIFINAL VICTORS
description: KANSAS CITY, May 5(AP) Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Tony Roche of Australia scored straightset victories today and reached the final of the $15,000 Glenwood Manor tennis tournament.

title: Watergate and Its Lessons of Morality
description: MONTREAT; N. C.No thoughtful American can held but ponder the implications of the sordid Watergate affair for our nation's future. The hatter is not only important because it demonstrates the apparent disregard for law and morality by some people who had been trusted. It is also important because if it is not dealt with firmly and fairly it could encourage continuing cynicism and disillusionment concerning the Americen political process. Anyone charged and found guilty should be punished.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Last week it was Ian Mowatt's Just Sheaffer, the year's contribution to the light touch in mystery fiction. That book was more a comedy of manners than a situation comedy, and it had a cosmic black humor. Now comes Justin Scott's MANY HAPPY RETURNS (McKay, $5.95), and it too goes for the light touch. But Scott is less ambitious than Mowatt. More interested in situation than character, he has worked up what in effect is a burlesque routine, very New York in style and spirit, very TV sitcom.

title: PARK SERVICE PLANS CAMP RESERVATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The National Park Service will test a computerized system this summer for reserving campsites in six of the nation's most popular parks.

title: Shore Resorts Put $20Million Into Expansion
description: TRENTON  Municipal officials, hotel and motel owners and others associated with the resort industry along the Jersey coast are spending more than $20million to expand and improve their facilities in anticipation of a heavy influx of vacationists this summer.

title: State Hosting Career Parley
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Capt. Ronald Evans, an Apollo 17 astronaut, will be the special guest tonight at the annual career development conference of the Distributive Education Clubs of America.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I N Harold Schonberg's appraisal of our paper on Mahler's illnesses, he states our case fairly. He is perhaps less objective in discussing our disagreement with his review of Mahler's Sixth, in which he characterized the symphony as compulsive notespinning that contains more neuroses than music. Now really, how does he know that? Why neuroses? Why not psychoses? Or psoriasis? Or leukemia?

title: PSYCHIATRIST DENIES SEXABUSE CHARGES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 5Dr. Morris Fraser, the Belfast psychiatrist who was indicted along with seven other men in New York on Thursday on charges of commiting sexual offenses with boys, said today that my innocence is beyond question.

title: Air Fares
description: For parents who have watched the cost of sending children to college climb out of sight (see article, page 11), one of the few factors softening the economic pinch has been the cutrate airline youth fares

title: Mrs. Court Has Received Warning: Don't Fall for Riggs's Hustle Tricks
description: SEA PINES, S. C., May 5 Is Mrs. Margaret Court strong enough, mentally and physically, to survive the anticipated rigors of a match against, Bobby Riggs?

title: Sir Cecil spills the beans
description: Honey, murmurs the man into the phone. Hohneychile, coos back one of the planet's most legendary voices.

title: The New Power
description: Gabe Paul, the mild man who replaced Michael Burke as the power behind the throne of the New York Yankees, denied yesterday that he was the Rasputin of Yankee Stadium.

title: Indians Get Pledge by White House
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., May 5A courier from Washington delivered today a letter to Indian headmen here from an assistant to President Nixon. It contains a promise to dispatch at least five White House representatives to discuss Indian grievances if the armed seizure of the historic hamlet of Wounded Knee is completely ended by May 11.

title: BLACK YOUTH TRIED IN SHOTS AT POLICE
description: DETROIT, May 5A 19yearold black youth named Hayward Brown, charged by the state with shooting four members of the Detroit Police Department's most lite crimefighting force last December, went on trial here this week.

title: MEPHAM WINNER IN SPRINT RELAY
description: Mirk Belger made it and Matt Centrowitz just missed victory in two of the outstanding performances yesterday on the concluding day of the New Uric lelays at Downing Stadium, Rendalls Island.

title: Guitarist Eyes Big Time
description: BRIELLESince last fall, Bix Martin has been strumming his guitar and singing his songs every Friday, Saturday and Monday night at the Red Ranch, hard by the Manasquan River. At the same time, he has been wondering how long it will be, if ever, before he makes the move from rooms like this to the Big Time.

title: Commander Fayette Wins
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)Commander Fayette, the 9.5 favorite, rallied in the stretch to win the $9,000 National Handicap at Suffolk Downs today. The time for six furlongs was 1:11 4/5.

title: Court Tradition Goes On
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)For almost 60 years the judge of the Provincetown District Court has been a member of the same family. Now forced to retire on reaching the age of 70, Judge Robert A. Welsh who succeeded his father in 1933, is being succeeded in turn by his son, Robert A. Welsh Jr.

title: La Scala Official Says He Declined Job at Net
description: MILAN, Italy, May 5 (UPI) An official of Milan's La Scala Opera House said today he had been offered the directorship of the Metropolitan Opera tin New York but had turned it down because of duties at home.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Yesterday's running of the Kentucky Derby in Louisville and the Indianapolis 500 race on Memorial Day are oneday sports and social affairs that have become yearround operations. Increasingly they are being tapped by local civic and business interests as valuable adjuncts to yearround economic development efforts.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Prophets new and old
description: This anthology has fallen into the hands of a reviewer who does not read Hebrew and therefore cannot scold the decisions of the editor and the work of the countless translators. I cannot scold but I can applaud. This is one of the richest poetic feasts set before me in a long time.

title: A ThreeAlarm Bronx Fire Damages Three Buildings
description: A threealarm fire raged through three nearby buildings in the West Farms section of the Bronx yesterday afternoon, fire officials reported.

title: Johnson Memorial Plans
description: WASHINGTON DURING a recent spring visit, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson spent several busy days in the nation's capital including three days of meetings of the National Parks Advisory Board, of which she is a member. She visited a site overlooking the Potomac River for a proposed living memorial of trees to her husband, President Johnson, who died in January.

title: Imogen Cunningham at Ninety: A Remarkable. Empathy
description: IMOGEN CUNNINGHAM took her first photograph, in Seattle, in 1901, a year before Alfred Stieglitz founded the PhotoSecession in New York. Her career is thus one of the longest in the annals of American photography. It reaches back to the period of findesiecle estheticism, when the pictorial artifice of the nineties was still a paramount force, and yet continues to prosper in the very different world of the nineteen  seventies. Like Paul Strand's, her work has a double claim on our attention. It belongs to history, and at the same time it is part of contemporary scene. On both counts, it is of exceptional interest.

title: Recordings
description: WAGNER never intended Parsifal for the roughandtumble of an opera house's repertory systemms consecrational festival play, he felt, could only make its proper effect in carefully conceived productions at his own Bayreuth Festspielhaus, and performances elsewhere were forbidden (the Metropolitan was the first to rape the Grail, 21 years after the premiere, in 1903). Oddly enough, complete recordings of the opera have respected Wagner's wishes, and rather than prepare studio versions, three companies have pilgrimaged to Bayreuth for onlocation authenticity: Decca/London in 1951, Philips in 1962 and Deutsche Grainmophon in 1970. London's new edition (OSA 1510, five disks), taped last year in its Vienna studios with Georg Solti condutting the Vienna Philharmonic, breaks the precedent and this Parsifal has a sound and a flavor totally unlike its perdecessors.

title: FORD BEATS HARVEY IN NORTHSOUTH GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May (AP)Mike Ford knocked in fourfoot putt for a par on the 38th hole today to beat Bill Harvey, 1up, and win the North and South amateur golf tournament in a recordequaling marathon.

title: Students Make History in Grave send
description: Some people might think it odd that two college students would collect 20,000 signatures urging that the United States Pavilion on the World's Fair site be transformed into a Queens cultural center.

title: Concerns That Se Research to Students Are Under Attack
description: TRENTON  Two Bergen coutry corporations are being monitored closely by a variety of state agencies and college administrations.

title: In Kentucky
description: IN July hundreds of men who, in Stephen Vincent Benet's phrase, could fiddle all the bugs off a sweetpotato vine, will bring their instruments to the green hollow called Renfro Valley for three days of unremitting Jam sessions and for fiddle, banjo, string band, guitar and buck dance contests. It is only 50 miles from Lexington to Renfro Valley, but that, in Kentucky, is the distance from mint julep and thoroughbred country to moonshine and coon hound ground.

title: MRS. RANKIN SHARES RALEIGH GOLF LEAD
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 5 (AP) Jo Ann Prentice and Mrs. Judy Rankin tied for the lead today after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf, Association $30,000 Raleigh tournament.

title: Walking All Alone Among the Elephants, Unarmed, Unharmed
description: IN Africa's vast Zambezi River Valley, a hot, hazy, graygreen wilderness of baobabs and jessebush and Peter's wildfig trees and Natal mahoganies, is a game preserve called Mana Pools. It is on the Rhodesian side of the great river, across from Zambia. Sometimes a wind rushes up the river from the Indian Ocean, bringing a bit of cool.

title: Friday's Fight
description: Milan, ItalyJose Miguel Duran, 152 pounds, Argentina, knocked out Mario Calro,152, Italy, 5 rounds.

title: Watergate Government
description: The Watergate case is significant because it is more than an isolated scandal. The revelations thus far cast new light on all the political operations and much of the domestic policymaking of the Nixon Administration. What can be seen is profoundly disturbing.

title: The Adventures of a Hassled Soul Brother in Haiti
description: PORT  AU PRINCE, HaitiI knew I was in for a time the minute I stepped off the plane at Francois Duvalier Airport and a young dude on the observation deck stuck a fist in the air and yelled:

title: Sunderland, 2501, Tops Leeds in Cup Soccer, 10
description: WEMBLEY, England, May 5 David put on his soccer boots today and slew Goliath. That is to say that Sunderland, a oncederided soccer team in the Second Division of the English League, beat Leeds, one 01 the best in Europe, 10, to win the cherished Football Association Cup.

title: Democratic Organization Sees Chance of Defeating Jordan in Jersey City Election Tuesday
description: JERSEY CITY, May 5The Hudson County Democratic organization, which was rocked by the convictions of eight city and county officials on extortion and conspiracy charges two years ago, now believes it can recapture City Hall from the popular young physician who has served as Mayor the last 18 months.

title: Tuition: Up, Up & Away
description: As it has every year for the last decade, the cost of going to, college will rise sharply again next fall. Tuition generally will be between $150 and $200 more than it was this academic year, with other expenses correspondingly higher, a survey by The Times showed last Week.

title: Masle
description: HE 197273 season of the New York City Opera has passed into history, and Julius Rudel, who guides the destinies of the company, would fervently argue that the season just ended has maintained the ratio of familiar against unfamiliar Works that (he says) sets his company apart from all others. There were 25 productions, and of these the following would have to be classified as breadindbutter operatic works:

title: KISSINGER CONFERS WITH SOVIET LEADER
description: MOSCOW, May 5 (UPI) Henry A. Kissinger and Leonid I. Brezhnev secluded themselves in a country dacha today to discuss the Soviet Communist party chief's planned trip to Washington next month.

title: Word for It Had to Be Clockwork:
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 Secretariat was the first tO get up in the barn at 4 o'clock this morning. He was the first to get home at 5:39 this afternoon in the 99th and richest Kentucky Derby. It was also the swiftest, the most lavishly supported by the betting public, and easily one of the most melodramatic as 1972's horse of the year rushed from last to first and ran the last quarteermile in 23 1/5 seconds.

title: Pakistan Issues Stamp
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 5 (Reuters)Pakistan has isSued a postage stamp depicting a child's face and prisoners behind barbed wire to draw attention to 90,000 Pakistani solders and civilians held prisoner in India.

title: U.S. Ends News Briefings in Cambodia; Embassy Cites Protest by Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 5The United States Embassy in Phnom Penh, which about two weeks ago started briefings for newsmen on Cambodian military and political developments, announced today that they were being discontinued because of being plaints from the Khmer Government on our briefing facts.

title: Headliners
description: Some aging spies will be out in the cold if James R. Schlesinger, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has his way. In Congressional testimony he supported legislation that would increase the number of former overeas agents whom the C.I.A. may retire at age 50 after 20 years of service. His goal: To remove older agents who have come to look upon their jobs as a sinecure and make more room at the top for ambitious young spies. The intelligence community of the United States, he declared, is not designed to provide cushy positions for timeservers.

title: New Device Guarantees 000 Shooting Average
description: Ken Hayden of Avon, Ohio, frustrated basketball player, has invented a frustrating gadget that prevents the ball from going through the basket.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Fred Berney (under a Right Turn heading in this space) is so correct! I, too, have noticed your scandalous gyration rightward. Howin a literary revieware you capable of having rightists D, Keith Mano and C. David Heymann write for you? Do you even begin to comprehend the danger?

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK JETSSigned Bob Spicer, Indiana linebacker, ninthround draft choice; Jim Krempin, Texas A. and I, offensive linemen, 10thround draft choice; Joe Schwartz, Toledo running back, 14thround draft choice, and Jim Foote, Delaware State punter, 17thround draft choice. Released Mahlon Williams, tight end for failing physical.

title: Monzon Stops Dale in 5; Brother Shot and Killed
description: ROME, May 5 (UPI)Carlos Monzon, the world middleweight champion from Argentina, knocked out Roy Dale of Cleveland in the fifth round in a nontitle bout tonight. Monzon's 46yearold brother, Zacarias, was shot and killed on the eve of the bout in Argentina during an argument with a 76yearold fellow worker.

title: Ebony Jr! Introduced; First Such Magazine
description: The first national allblack children's magazine, Ebony Jr!, made its debut last week.

title: Carolyn Shelley Will Be a Bride
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 5Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Shelley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Jane Shelley, to Phillip Greig LeBel, son of Mrs. Lee A. Gordy of Hebron, Md., and L. Edward LeBel of Clearwater, Fla. The couple plan to marry here next month.

title: 350 Stage a Rally in Midtown To Protest Against High Prices
description: About 350 people, most of them young, marched through midtown and held a rally yesterday near the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street to protest rising prices.

title: M'GOVERNER DENIES MAGAZINE REPORT
description: Senator George McGovern depicted in today's New York Times Magazine as so dejected at the failure of his Presidential campaign that he thought of moving to England  has denounced the article as full of inaccurate and fabricated quotations.

title: Cats Best of Show as Travelers
description: Carts are better travelers than dogs. This conclusion has been reached by Bruce Gebhardt, the director of cargo sales and service for United Air Lines.

title: the traveler's world
description: DETROITIt is hard to believe that the most difficult thing to do in the contemporary push to make automobiles safer, both inside and out, is to build a dummy biomechanically equal to the humans who drive and ride in them. It was only recently that safety engineers realized, and finally convinced Department of Transportation officials, that much of the crash testing of automobiles, both Production models and experimental safety vehicles, and most of the standards for seat belts and other safety devices were not really valid because dummies used in testing them did not respond the same way live people do.

title: George Taloumls
description: IN AN ERA when the owner doubles as yard man, the subject of minimum maintenance is of wide interest. On the new property it is important to design for minimum maintenance and, on established places, to replan with easy care in mind.

title: The diary of a writer
description: I have been a fan of John Williams ever since I read his brave, underrated, The Man Who Cried I Am. Flashback, his recent collection of essays, is not nearly so impressive a book. But in the headnotes to each piece, Williams describes his relationship with the magazine editor who commissioned it, and the sum of those accounts make the book, flawed as it is, a series of fascinating case studies.

title: THE: ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME good news has begun to emerge on the economic front, indicating, perhaps, that the pendulum of public opinion may soon swing back toward the positive side, if it has not already started to move in that direction. One key barometer the stock marketseems to have done so with its rather strong rally last week, its best weekly gain since last November.

title: Miss Sparks Wed to B. F. Emmert
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 5Miss Elizabeth Geraldine Sparks, an account manager with the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company in New York, was married here this noon to Barrett Farley Emmert of New York, president of Burlington Formed Fabrics, a division of Burlington Industries.

title: N.H.L. Playoff
description: April 29Montreal 8, Chicago 3. may 1 Montreal 4, Chicagb 1. May 3Chicago 7, Montreal 4. May 6At Chicago, 3:05 P.M. May 8At Montreal, 8:05 P.M. May 10At Chicago, 8:35 P.M.* May 13At Montreal, 4:05 P.M.*

title: China's Birth Rate Now Under Control, Congress Unit Told
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Chinese apparently have brought their oncehigh birth rate under control through combination of social pressure and free birthcontrol programs, Congress was told yesterday.

title: Biaggi
description: 1973A Vintage Year for Biaggi heralded the flyers for a $5perperson wine  and  cheese tasting fund  raiser for Representative Mario Biaggi in Queens last Friday evening. But even ardent Biaggi followers agreed that it wasn't a vintage week for the embattled Bronx Democrat.

title: Ballet to Start Season at 5 Schools
description: CALDWELLThe Garden State Ballet will institute its fourweek spring season this week with a threeday residency program at five Caldwell and West Caldwell public schools.

title: Medicare Resolution Voted
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (UPI)The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union has adopted a resolution asking that the costs of Medicare be paid from the Federal income tax base instead of through the Social Security payroll tax. Delegates to the union's convention yesterday called the Social Security tax grossly regressive.

title: The Women  Bed, Boredom, Bitchery
description: THE best antiSemites, it's often been noted, are selfhating Jews, an observation that can be made of another ethnic groupwomen. The thought flashed through my mind while watching Clare Boothe Luce's 1936 play, The Women, whose revival (at the 46th Street Theater) adds to the dreary evidence that Broadway, on yet another nostalgia trip, believes that there's a serious future in its past.

title: Lefty Reid Is an Important Man; He Keeps the Stanley Cup on Ice
description: CHICAGO, May 5Presumably the Black Hawks will have recovered from their victory last Thursday when they face the Montreal Canadiens tomorrow in Game Four of., the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Lindsay, in Moscow, Drops In At a Children's Hobby Center
description: MOSCOW, May 5Mayor Lindsay dropped in at Moscow's Palace of Pioneers today as he kept up his rapidly paced exposure to the Soviet Union.

title: W.H.A. Playoffs
description: New England vs. Winnipeg

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 128th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M.

title: Retiring Prof. Morris Will Stay Busy
description: At a farewell dinner last week for Prof. Richard B. Morris of Columbia University, a colleague, Prof. Henry F. Graff, called him a Picassoan man.

title: Federal Reserve Proposes TruthinLending Change
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board has proposed an amendment to its truthinlending regulation that would require all creditors to disclose whether their installment contracts provide for a rebate of finance charges in the event of prepayment.

title: Dance
description: LTHOUGH the National Ballet of Canada is only 23 years old, it is one of the oldest classic dance companies in North America. Indeed, offhand can think of only American Ballet Theater, New York City Ballet, the San Francisco Ballet and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet as predating it among stillexisting organizations. Nevertheless, in terms of history, 23 years is not very long, even though the company is already five years older'than Britain's Royal Ballet was when it made its American debut at the old Metropolitan Opera House in 1949. Yet, for various reasons, the Canadian company has not had as easy a path to the top as its British godparent.

title: One Council Group to Meet
description: This week's only scheduled public meeting of a New York City Council committee will take place tomorrow when the Committee on Buildings holds an open hearing at 10 A.M. on bills relating to the licensing of master plumbers and various changes in sections of the building code. The City Council itself stands adjourned, subject to call.

title: Innovation Key to Nassau Art Show
description: GARDE/CITY, L. I.Innovative compositions  a sculpture of crochet, another combining wood and macrame, and ceramic wall hangings  are among the displays at the current exhibition of fine crafts at the Firehouse Gallery at Nassau Community College.

title: Two poets with diversity and vitality
description: Publication of the seminal West Indian works of literature in English is a fairly recent development in the United States. Derek Walcott is one of the few whose names may be familiar. His plays, TiJean and His Brothers and Dream on Monkey Mountain, have already earned him a certain distinction in the New York theater. Another Life is his fourth book of verse, a single poem which extends over some 4,000 lines of selfinquiry and cultural assessment in the context of a Caribbean life. It is the history of an imagination. They melt from you, your sons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am not surprised that Christine Samurovich was successful in her effort to defeat a cooperative conversion attempt in her building. Her pro article [The Coop Battle: 35 Per Cent vs. 51 Per Cent, April 22] was lucid and stated the very real objections to cooperative conversions. Donald MacDonald, on the other hand, leaned wholly on the negative, whining about the tenants power and overlooking the real problems inherent in conversions.

title: Middlebury Gets Grant
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 5 (AP)The Kresge Foundation of Birmingham, Mich., has awarded Middlebury College a $150,000 grant to be used toward the construction cost of a new fieldhouse on the private college campus.

title: 4 DAYS AT SOTHEBY BRING 13.8MILLION
description: A fivepart, starstudded auction that ended yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet tallied receipts of $13,806,525 for some 350 works  paintings, drawings and sculpture.

title: Old San Diego: The Past in Present Tense
description: SAN DIEGOBrowsing through old housing has become such a national pastime that we can soon expect to see a replica of some postWorld War II Levittown. There tourists could stand agog at a genuine Early SplitLevel. In other restorations it might be a restored nineteenthirties bungalow, all glowing in stucco, with the cute dormers and the dwarf cedars by the doorway, that would pack them in. Even today you could discover a Woolworth's, say, with its name in raised golden letters, or a White Tower shortorder restaurant in its pristine fortiesera plastic whiteness, and not be sure, without a program, whether you are in a real town or an updated Williamsburg. Such, in fact, is the feeling you may get in San Diego, where the original heart of the city, Old Town, is indeed a restoration project and does have a printed program to help separate past from present, even thoughto what fatuously used to be called Eastern eyesthe place at first glance looks like much of the rest of the real California.

title: Mount Sinai Appoints Dean
description: The appointment of Dr. Hans Popper as dean of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, City University of New York, has been announced by the school's trustees. Dr. Popper has been acting dean since the death of Dr. George James in March, 1972, and had previously served as the first dean when the school was in its early planning stages.

title: Kent School Emerging in Show World
description: Kent School started its riding program back in 1960, but until last year it was lowkeyed and designed primarity for the students. We always had in mind running a good horse show sanctioned by the American Horse Shows Association, said Sidney N. Towle, the headmaster, the other, day. We did conduct some small shows but we wanted to wait until we were ready before we took on the task of running a recognized show. Kent, a school more noted for its participation in the Henley Royal Regatta in England and for its equestrian feats, is located in Kent, Conn. about 110 miles north and slightly east of New York City. It ran an A.H.S.A.; recognized show for the first Time last spring.

title: Haldeman the fierce, Haldeman the faithful, Haldeman the fallen
description: WASHINGTON. Ever since he came to Washington, people have been comparing Harry Robbins (Bob) Haldeman to Sherman Adams. As Adams did under Dwight D. Eisenhower, Haldeman made himself into a latterday Janus, a guardian of the gateway to President Richard M. Nixon, a god of the going and the coming. He decided whom and what the President should see, and so helped to determine how Nixon thought and what he decided. Like Adams, Haldeman functioned with such bloodless, hardeyed efficiency and shielded his boss from so much unpleasantness, that he earned trust and respect from most of those within the White House and enmity and contempt from many of those outside. Like Adams, he was called the second most powerful man in Washington. And like Adams, who was forced from office by his acceptance, in return for small favors, of a vicua coat, a $2,400 Oriental rug and $3,000 in free hotel rooms from a Boston textile tycoon, Haldeman's career came to an abrupt halt in the midst a major scandal. He was driven from his White House job, along with John D. Ehrlichman and John Wesley Dean 3d, after several weeks of reports that White House officials were involved the Watergate bugging and breakin, and after two weeks of backbiting among White House aides.

title: Woman Physicist At Colimbia Gets First Pupin Chair
description: Dr. Chien Shiung Wu of Columbia University recently achieved two firsts: she was named the first Pupin Professor of Physics at the university, and was chosen to become the first woman president of the American Physical Society.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Those attending Friday's annual meeting of the Connecticut River Watershed Council in Northfield, Mass., learned of an organization formed to hasten restoration of Atlantic salmon spawning runs in New England rivers. To be known as R.A.S.A. (Restoration of Atlantic Salmon in America), the organization was, according to Richard A. Buck, chairman of the council's fisheries committee, conceived by the principals of C.A.S.E. (Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency), which spearheaded conservation organizations in the successful movement to get the Danes and Norwegians to agree to phase out their indiscriminate high seas netting of Atlantic salmon off West Greenland. (Salmon stocks from North America and Europe congregate off Greenland.)

title: Maybe Lakers Should Vote a Share to Jim McMillian's Mom
description: Jim McMillian lives in a fiveroom splitlevel condominium in residential West Los Angeles. The houses are pastel colored and neatly kept. The streets are clean and lined with palm trees. Nearby are plush clubs where McMillian spends many hours playing tennis when he isn't playing basketball with the Los Angeles Lakers for $80,000 a year.

title: Inflation
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Administration tightened its pricecontrols mechanism a notch hitt week. The move was more restrained than had been expected. It reflected tile President's willingness to accept a few more months, as he put it, of price rises higher than we would like, and his strong aversion to returning to Phase 2 type controls.

title: A Portlier Ambassador Protests
description: TO THE EDITOR: As a civil libertarian, I regret that the American Film Institute canceled the showing of CostaGavras State of Siege.But, also as a civil libertarian, I was shocked by Vincent Canby's reasoning in his review of the film. I speak feelingly on the subject since I was privileged to represent President Kennedy as his ambassador to Peru where our major purposes were to discourage the military overthrow of a democratic election and to assist Peruvians in their efforts to improve their standard of living.

description: HOUSTON, May 5  Sometimes golfers can do unusual things in Texas and today Bruce Crampton had one of his most unusual golfing experiences.

description: The following song is to be sung in a slow, mournful manner, accompanied by occasional strums on a poorly tuned guitar. After each verse, a harmonica should be blown for at least 64 bars. The singer, a tired male of any race, should wear a denim shirt, railroadworkers overalls and a pained expression. He should carry a copy of TV Guide.

description: Because formal education is not reaching masses of youngstem in Asia, Africa and Latin America, countries on those continents should build extensive networks of nonformal instruction, a report commissioned by the United Nations Children's Fund urges.

title: News of the Rialto
description: CAN a murdermystery musical be successful? Evan Hunter, Jerry Bock and Stuart Ostrow may have the answer to that question in an item called Caper. Of course, others have tried the blend before, but Hunter and his friends think they may have the clue to success. According to Hunter whose novels include The Blackboard Jungle and who, under the name Ed McBain, turns out mysteries almost as fast as his fans can read them, the problem is that suspense and mystery seem to disappear the minute someone opens his mouth to sing.

title: Jacques Maritain
description: Tens of thousands of persons the world over could have joined with Pope Paul last week when he said of Jacques Maritain, He was my teacher. For more than half a century the French Catholic philosopher was the world's foremost exponent of the teachings of Thomas Aquinas, which he brilliantly developed and updated the light of modern conditions. Maritain roamed freely over the entire terrain of contemporary culture in his fifty books. He wrote treatises on religion, science, politics, education, psychology and esthetics. As an oldfashioned metaphysician there was no aspect of life that did not intrigue him.

title: Oxygen to Purify Water at Spruce Run
description: CLINTONThree large containers of oxygen were towed by helicopter and gently, lowered into the Spruce Run Reservoir here last week in a project designed to improve the quality of the water and increase the supply of fish.

title: KEYSTONE PEBBLE WINS REALIZATION
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 5In one bold move with a strange horse, Herve fillon won the $90,000 Realization Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. It was the first time harness racing's most successful driver guided. Keystone Pebble.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP)Susie Kincade broke a sex barrier this year and competed on what was once the University of California, Los Angeles men's swim team.

title: A Book Of Jesus
description: Why read yet another life of Jesus? In hopes of gaining new scholarly information about the man whose dimly viewed life splits the history of the world; or, for inspiration, when the familiar objective facts are retold by one who can tell them or comprehend them if not better, at least subjectively, This latter group would include Francois Mauriac's Life of Jesus (1937) and Robert Graves's King Jesus (1946). To that list add William Goyen's A Book of Jesus.

title: Seton Hall Acts to Safeguard Open Campus Against Crime

As a result, the 6,000student school has revamped its security force and has instituted defensive measures designed to safeguard the campus in the future.

title: Mackerel A Succulent and Timely Dish
description: Mackerel cannot be mistaken at the fish market. They are the prettiest fish on the ice. Their streamlined shapes are smooth and silver. Wavy, black markings, as if from a felt pen, accent the upper portions. And if good looks do not impress the buyer, the price should. Boston mackerel is one of those rare species selling for less than a dollar a pound.

description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Barbara Hahn and Lois Newman were recently named Nassaus first policewomen sergeants. But they want to be just plain sergeants  without any qualification.

title: and in Vermont
description: CRAFTSBURY COMMON, Vt.The fresh stubble in the field being used as a parking lot was prickly, and the girl was clinging to the longhaired boy beside her to take the weight off her soft, bare, citybred feet. Both of them were laughing. Nearby a woman, about 60, wearing cotton slacks and blouse and with her grayblonde hair carefully arranged, looked up when she heard them. Her husband, straw hat on head, handed her an aluminum folding chair and then he, too, looked at the young couple.

title: Movies
description: A NEW CANAAN, Conn. DARK Mercedes Benz pulls up to the train station here on a sunny Saturday morning, and the woman behind the wheel looks the way you might expect a 54yearold suburban mother of three to look: Blond hair slightly awry, sunglasses, blue denim pants suit, white tennis shoes. But then she begins to speak, in that distinctive foghorn voiceits huskiness is due more to a case of youthful whooping cough, she insists, than the cigarettes she chainpuffs  and I know right away that this is the woman I have come to spend the day with, New Canaan's current NQ. 3 wife / mother / career woman: Eileen Heckert, the surpitse Oscar winner of 1973, for Butterflies Are Free.
