title: The occupation:
description: TEL AVIV. In the Six Day War in 1967, Israel occupied the West Bank of the Jordan River, an area previously controlled by Jordan, and when hostilities ended, the Palestinian Arabs who live in the area followed the Middle Eastern habit of blessing their new master and cursing the old one. The instinctive gesture of hundreds of East Jerusalem Arabs, after waking up to the Israeli victory, was to strike the word Jordan from the license plates of their cars.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor Obviously, the Mary to whom Jean Mayer writes A survival letter: Watch your diet and live (April 8) has a couple of problems other than nutrition: Her mother and two older children can't read, and her husband is not merely illiterate but an irresponsible slob, to boot. Illiteracy is the only justification for Dr. Mayer's pouring all his advice on diet and exercise for three generations through Mary the Funnel. (Dr. Mayer never explains how a literate woman, who knows enough to ask intelligent questions, came to be enmeshed in a den of nitwits who communicate by cave drawings, but never mind. Accidents happen.)

title: The Reckoning Begins
description: THE WATERGATE WEEK: President Nixon accepts responsibility but pleads ignorance as new disclosures multiply / John Ehrlichman, H. R. Haldeman, John Dean are out, Gen. Alexander Haig Jr. is id / Haldeman, Ehrlichman, Dean and John Mitchell face indictment for coverup / Dean gives judge keys to safe deposit box with Watergate documents / Republican dirty tricks expert indicted / Watergate defendant says he got camera froin C.I.A. for use in burglary at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist / Ehr lichman knew of burglary, did not report it / Judge in Ellsberg trial reveals that last month, White House discussed directorship F.B.I. with him; defense calls it a bribe offer. Trial continues, but court weighs mistrial motion on other taints.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The big number in Willie Maya's life has been reversed. For more than two decades, he has worn 24 on his uniform, as if he would be that age forever. But today he's 42 years old.

title: S. J. Lacey France Of Jane C. Everett
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Andres of New York and Southampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Andres's daughter, Miss Jane C. Everett, to Stanley J. Lacey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lacey, of Jackson Heights, Queens. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Open Classes Pass the Test in Plainfield
description: PLAINFIELDThe sounds of excited voices fill the classroom. Four youngsters sprawl on the floor, their fingers covered with paint and sawdust as they work energetically on a miniature town. In the corner, a little boy reads a book, while a phonograph provides a rhythmic beat in the background. Three children giggle noisily as they share an educational game.

title: True exile has no topography
description: Vassilis Vassilikos earlier novel Z was based on the murder of the Greek Socialist deputy Lambrakis in Salonika before the advent of the regime of the colonels in 1967. Its strength was based on a shrewd understanding of the dynamics of coldblooded behindthescenes political manipulation. At the end of that book, the fates of those involved in the affair are told: evil was handsomely rewarded and ordinary decency carried a heavy price.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: BOSTONIn one of its frequent lapses into shortsightedness, Who's Who in America doesn't have a word in print about Edward Gelsthorpe, who became president and chief operating officer of the Gillette Company two weeks ago. Yet though hardly a household name, he has been a legend for nearly a decade in the world of consumer product marketing.

title: Couple to Receive A Hospital Award
description: NEWARKMr. and Mrs. John Padavano Jr. of South Orange will receive the 1973 Distinguished Service Award of St. James Hospital. It will be presented Wednesday at the 12th annual Oharity Ball of the Friends of St. James at Thomm's eRstaurant here.

description: STONY BROOK, L. I., May 5 C. W. Post scored in 17 of the 20 events and easily won its fifth consecutive Collegiate Track conference championship today. The Pioneers tallied 102 points, more than twice the 45 totaled by the runnerup Adelphi.

title: District Attorney
description: On April 26, 1971, a small band of Queens County detectives and employes of the AvisRentACar System, Inc., descended upon a company that had been repairing cars for the corporation for more than eight years. Armed with what later was determined to be an illegal warrant, the detectives seized the company's records while the Avis men took 32 of their cars that were at the company for repair.

description: Spring is flowering everywhere. There is only one way to enjoy itget out and see it.

title: Secretariat Wins Derby
description: Secretariat scored a 2length victory yesterday in the 99th Kentucky Derby at Louisville, America's premiere horse race. Sham finished second and Our Native third. Secretariat ran the 1 miles in 1 minute 59 seconds, a Derby record, and paid $5. Details in Section 5.

description: ASHAROKEN, L.I.  The Eaton's Neck lighthouse, hidden from the public by a private estate, is now a national historic landmark.

title: AirPollution Parley Slated for Paramus
description: PARAMUSThe third annual Industrial AirPollution Control Seminar will be held at the auditorium of the Garden State Plaza on Tuesday. The allday session will include 16 speakers on airpollution and related problems.

title: Numismatics
description: I AM not collector but have been casually reading your column off and on for.the past couple of months and I think I would like to get into collecting. go began a recent letter from a reader. There was only one more sentence in this letter, and it was a beaut: Will you please tell me everything I should know about collecting coins and paper money.

title: Letters: Hunting. At the V. 04
description: To the Editor. I would like to register my extreme distaste for the article by Roy Bongartz, (about hunting exotic animals on the Y.O. Ranch), Why Not Try a Hunting Vacation in Texas? You Can't Miss, in the April 1 Triivel Section. Your acceptance of such an article seems an editorial endorsement of a socalled sport which is steadily gaining illrepute in all the more civilized areas of the world.

title: Antioch College in Ohio Is Shut By Student Strike on Aid Funds
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 5Antioch College's classroom and administration buildings, chained shut for two weeks by students fearful of cuts in financial aid, remained closed this week in a strike that has given no sign thus far of when or how it will be settled.

title: MANY CANDIDATES FOR REAGAN'S JOB
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5One of the most expensive primery election campaigns in the history of California will probably take place next year as powerful candidates fight it out in both major parties for the nomination for the governorship.

title: BRAVES WIN, 70; AARON CONNECTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (UPI) Hank Aaron, moving within homers of Babe Ruth's record, cracked three hits tonight, including the 681st homer of his career to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 70 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and Steve Carlton.

title: Miss Frazier Wed To Gerald Tyrrell
description: Miss Callie Joan Frazier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dock Crudup Frazier Jr. of Oxford, N. C., was married here yesterday afternoon to Gerald John Tyrrell of New York, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and vice president of F. S. Smithers & Co. The Rev. Norman Stanton performed the ceremony in the, Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Most Are Bad
description: Milton Glaser, 42, is a leading graphic designer and the artist for number of notable children's books, among them Cats and Bats and Things With Wings, Help, Help, the Globolinks and Fish in the Sky. He was the cofounder of Push Pin Studios in 1954, a New York team that at one time or another has included many famous designers such as Seymour Chwast (the other cofounder and a present partner), Jim McMullin, Paul Davis, Isadore Seltzer, Tim Lewis, John Alcorn and Sam Antupit  and has inspired not a few imitators. Mr. Glaser is chairman of the board of New York Magazine and its design director. He recently redesigned ParisMatch magazine. The Book Review asked Mr. Glaser for observations on what has been happening in children's books.

title: PACERS TRIUMPH, TIE SERIES AT 22
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 (AP) George McGinnis and Darnell Hillman led Indiana to a 90.86 victory over the Kentucky Chlonels today, tying the American Basketball Association championship playoff series at two games apiece.

title: HONG KONG FACES RISING DISCONTENT
description: HONG KONG, May 5 Soaring living costs and a shrinking industrial growth rate have prompted gloomy forecasts of labor unrest and even civil disorder this summer in this British crown colony.

title: Bacallao, Holmes Teams Gain Squash Tennis Final.
description: The two topseeded teams in the National Squash Tennis Association doubles championship gained the final yesterday at the Lone Star Boat Club.

title: Home Improvement
description: A LTHOUGH textured surfaoes for inside walls and ceilings are by no means newtextured finishes were very widely used 30 and 40 years agothere has been a great surge of new interest in this type of finish during the past decade or so, at least partly due to the fact that several new and improved forms, of paint that en this type of surface have been introduced.

title: Two Women Bowlers Gain the Hall of Fame
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 5 (AP)Connie Powers of Detroit and Pearl Switzer of South Bend, Ind., have been inducted into the Hall of Fame of the Women's International Bowling Conference.

title: The Crush Gets Worse & Worse
description: New York's transportation problems are like no other city's. Every day more than a half million autos, buses and trucks pour Into an area of only a few square miles Manhattan's central business district below 60th Street. And the sumber of vehicles entering the city grows by 4 per cent every year.

title: Residents In Suffolk Warned On Ticks
description: YAPHANK, L. L  A mild winter has caused a bumper Imp of ticks in Suffolk County, end alOng with it, to possibility of an increase ft Rocky Mountain spotted itner, which is transmitted toy ticks.

title: Soviet Hijacker Is Foiled, Kills Pilot and Himself
description: MOSCOW, May 5Soviet officials have privately confirmed that a Soviet man killed himself and an airline pilot 10 days ago after an unsuccessful attempt to hijack a TU104 Aeroflot airliner and to force it to fly him to Stockholm.

title: Two Italians Reach Summit of Mt. Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 5 (AP)An Italian Himalayan expedition conquered Mount Everest today, putting at least three men on the summit of the world's highest peak.

title: A Break in Wyoming Oil Pipeline Poses Threat to Migratory Birds
description: CASPER, Wyo., May 5An Amoco pipeline break that has dumped hundreds of barrels of oil at the Soda Lake wildfowl refuge three miles north of this city of 40,000 is imperiling thousands of migratory birds.

title: Town Girds for Jungle Crowd
description: WEST MILFORD  Put a wildanimal park, one whose exotic inmates draw more than a halfmillion visitors during a twomonth inriod, next to a rural Northern New Jersey community whose population of 20,000 doubles during those 60 days, and long, hot summers may lie ahead for both.

title: Job Enrichment: Nice but No CureAll
description: Worker boredom job alienation, the bluecollar blues and the whitecollar blahs have been the subjects of cover stories in national magazines. A Senate subcommittee is examining the problem and the Ford Foundation will spend half a million dollars to see what is being done about it.

title: Harvey Rawlinson Fisk Fiance Of Miss Mary Storer Fishier
description: RMGEWOOD, N. J., May 5 The engagement of Miss Mary Storer Fishier to Harvey Rawlinson Fisk has been announced by Mr. and Mr. Bennett H. Fishier Jr. of Ridgewood and Dennis, Mass., pareztts of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pliny Fisk Jr. of CrotononHudson, N. Y.

title: Mailbox
description: To the Editor:

title: WHALERS BEAT JETS AND LEAD SERIES, 31
description: BOSTON (UPI)Mike Byers scored two goals on passes from Tom Earl tonight as the New England Whalers whipped the Winnepeg Jets, 42. Thel Whalers took a commanding 31 lead in the fourofsevengame series for the World Hockey Association championship.

title: BAR UNIT TO MONITOR RACE FOR JUDGESHIPS
description: A committee has been established by, the New York State Bar Association to monitor the coming elecetion campaigns for judges, according to Robert MacCrate, the association's president.

title: Teen Arts Festival To Open in Trenton
description: TRENTONA giant inflatable bubble will rise above the plaza between the State Museum and the State Library here this week. The 40  by  60  foot bubble will cover exhibits and Workshops of the State Teen Arts Festival, which is scheduled to open tomorrow and run through Friday.

title: Olympian Awakening
description: Last summer Wayne Collett, one of the world's finest track and field athletes, took a leave of absehce from job as executive trainee with a savings and loan association in West Los Angeles to try out for the United States Olympic team.

title: Born with a silver slipper on her foot
description: When Oklahoma opened on Broadway 30 years ago this spring, it became a bright marker along the often wayward path of the musical theater. One reason was that thousands of uncouth types learned that properly administered ballet could be fun, not just exercises indulged in by effeminate young men and masculine young ladies for their private amusement. Credit this to Agnes de Mille, the choreographer.

title: Best Seller List
description: FICTION

title: Summer Guest Triumphs In Grey Lag, Pays $6.20
description: Just before yesterday's 30th running of the Grey Lag Handicap at Aqueduct, Jacinto Vasquez, who had the leg up on Rokeby's favored Summer Guest, joked: If my filly can run as fast as I can ride, she should be the winner.

title: Sports Week
description: BASEBALL

title: Class Actions
description: WASHINGTONSeveral of the Supreme Court's most significant decisions in the last 20 yearsthe desegregation of the public schools and the oneman, onevote reapportionment rule among themwere produced by a legal mechanism that is old but obscure to the public: the class action lawsuit.

title: Teamsters
description: WASHINGTONTwo months ago, courtauthorized telephone taps and a bug, Installed by the Federal Burean of Investigation to help learn of a Mafia plan to reap millions of dollars in payoffs from the welfare funds of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, were shut off.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: North Carolinaborn M. Moran Weston is rector of St. P'hilip's Church in Harlem, one of the nation's largest Episcopal parishes. He is also one of the nation's busiest men, involved in a score of educational, financial, housing, health, youth and seniorcitizen projects. The firm religious belief and commitment undergirding these manifold activities are revealed in his slim volume of meditations, Who Is This Jesus! Each of the first six forthright meditations deals with a particular view of Jesus that has been put forth by opponents or supporters of Christianity: Jesus as Superstar, cult leader, demagogue, charlatan, paranoid or failure. Three final meditations offer Father Weston's interpretation of Jesus as liberator and what Jesus as liberator means to the individual in every circumstance, in every country, in every culture. These brief, simply writ keyed to our own time and place: black and white racism, war, nationalism, space travel, business fraud and other contemporaneities are among topics touched on.

title: COPYRIGHT VICTOR IN SUFFERN SHOW
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., May 5Lynn Ann Faulkner's Copyright made an auspicious debut as fox chaser today when he captured the limit working hunter championship at the Catamount Hunt Club horse show.

title: Tennysse Major Wingfield's invention
description: Lawn tennis will be 100 years old late this year, and it will be a time for recounting the game's history and recalling the triumphal scenes of its pastthe great games for the Davis Cup, the matches at Forest Hills and Wimbledon; and the great names, starting back with America's Clark brothers (Clarence M. and Joseph S.), England's Renshaw twins (William and Ernest) and the Doherty brothers (Reginald and Hugh); and the peak years of a Bill Tilden, a Helen Wills, a Rene Lacoste and a Suzanne Lenglen. But also worth recalling is the ancestry of the game and of its often baffling terminology, since the origins of a number of the most familiar words connected with it cannot be traced decisively.

title: CHANGES PLANNED IN HOUSING ZONING
description: Plans for a major new approach to zoning that would make it economically feasible to build lower structures rather than the highrise towers that often contribute to neighborhood opposition to new housing are being developed by the Lindsay administration.

title: 21 at Brooklyn Museum May Quit Over a Dismissal
description: Twentyone Staff members of the Brooklyn Museum, protesting the dismissal of the museum's curator of decorative arts and charging widespread demoralization among employes, have threatened to resign.

title: Indians
description: Far from the protests and gunfire of Wounded Knee, S.D., Indian leaders have been knocking insistently on the White House door. They've been trying to pry loose $18million which congress last year earmarked for the education of Indian children. To date, President Nixon has refused to spend it; in fact, he has formally asked Congress to rescind the appropriation.

title: Cautious OTB Bettors Gain a Bonus
description: Cautious offtrack bettors who backed Secretariat to finish second in yesterday's Kentucky Derby wound up with an unexpected windfall. The victorious Meadow Stable colt paid more to place ($6.20) in OTB's separate Derby pool than he did to win ($5.80).

title: The Danger of Misjudgment
description: PARISThe Watergate scandal isn't even remotely concerned with United States foreign policy. Nevettheless, should the affair result in perceptible weakening of President Nixon's position, misinterpretation of his powers, or misjudgment of hid intentions, overseas crises could suddenly develop.

title: ELIZABETH HUDSON
description: Elizabeth Hudson, a collector of art and books, died Wednesday at her home, 157 East 72d Street. She was 88 years old and also lived in Syracuse, N. Y.

title: Trees and Birds
description: One reason for national parks and national forests, and for parks in cities, is that trees grow there, and birds Build nests in the trees. Every now and then we hear that birds are a dirty or noisy nuisance, and that trees lire just for lumber, or paper, or something like that. But there is another side to the story.

title: Rennie Davis, Antiwar Activist, Now Focuses Life on Guru, 15
description: Rennie C. Davis the antiwar activist, held a news conference here the other day to explain the new focus of his life: a 15yearold guru in India called Maharaj Ji.

description: FREEPORT, L.I.  James Stefano dropped the brush beside the sandpaper and chisel, wiped the varnish from his hands and stepped back to survey his work.

description: The New York tesmos begin defense of their title today when they meet the Rochester Lancers in a North American Soccer League season opener for both clubs. The game Wili get under way at 3 P.M. at Hofstra University stadiuin in Hempstead, opposite the Nassau Coliseum. On hand News before the game of should be one of the biggest pithSoccer erIngs of futtire American soccer talent, Coaches exptt about 5,000 boys id meter Uniforms to take part in the Cosmos' Youth Day,parade.

description: BEEMERVILLEMr. Campanius, it would appear, stretched the truth a bit.

title: Suspect in Killing of a Teacher On West Side Hangs Himself
description: John Wayne Wilson, the Indiana drifter held for five months on murder charges in the New Year's Day killing of Roseann Quinn, a 28yearold teacher, hanged himself yesterday afternoon in his jail cell, officials at the Tombs said.

title: Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The movement to end racial discrimination in America's factories and offices has been a slow, seemingly interminable effort to chip away at an accumulated mountain of abuses. Last week, however, a Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., struck what may turn out to be a sledgehammer blow at the residue of discrimination in the steel industry.

title: Oil Concerns Said to Agree To Talks in Libya on Prices
description: VIENNA, May 5 (Reuters)Western oil companies have agreed to negotiate with major petroleumproducing countries over higher crudeoil prices on Monday in Libya, informed sources said today.

title: ANGELS TRIUMPH OVER ORIOLES, 31
description: BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP)Bob Oliver drove in two runs, one with a homer, and Bill Sidger pitched a twohitter as the streaking California Angels defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 31, tonight.

title: Miss Zunz Has Nuptials
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y. May 5  Miss MurielAlix Zunz, daughter of Mrs. LouiseMarie Noel of Brussels and Henry L. Zunz, was married here this morning to Christopher Nelson Darlington. The Rev. Richard E. Mayberry performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Point of View
description: All serious candidates in this year's municipal election should address themselves to several matters concerning development policy. Chief among several cases in point is incentive zoning. The theory is that various causes can be championed only by giving developers floorarea bonusesallowing them to build more square feet of building if their plans meet certain criteria. Special zoning districts are set up, and city planning officials begin to act as power brokers.

title: WELL STREET
description: To many inveators, even those With y years experience the nd market remains a subject almost as forbidding as nuclear physics or championship chess.

description: Today's paper contains special section SALUTE TO ISRAEL ON ITS. 25TH ANNIVERSARY (Section 14). There is an error in the Government of Israel, Coins and Medals ad, (Page 8).

description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I. Plans for the Children's Medical Center of New York, to be built in affiliation with the Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, have been submitted for state approval. They include proposals for the establishment of two new programs for the are of shortterm psychiatric problems and chronic disorders.

description: HAUPPAUGE, L. LWe are finally getting away from the bricks and mortar syndrome, Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein said last week as he presented the second capital program of his tenure as County Executive.

description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)A Federal judge has put Henry Matthews on six months probation, with a warning that he could be resentenced if he fails to stay with the New England Patriots this year.

title: More on Watergate
description: Even if the President is not guilty in the Watergate affair, what is to be done about the damage done by his postelection acts undertaken with a hubris born of an exaggerated majority achieved via a corrupt election? Indeed, was not the size of that majority repeatedly used as a justification for measures not otherwise justifiable?

title: 18,000 Farm Operators Paid $20,000 Each to Cut Crops
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) More than 18,000 farm operators were paid $20,000 or more each in 1972 for curtailing or halting production of certain traps or for complying with Department of Agriculture conservetation program.

title: 16Pound, 2Ounce Girl Born
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., May 5 (UPI) Mrs. Phyllis Osborne gave birth to a 16pound 2ounce baby girl here Tuesday, Mrs. Osborne and her husband, Jesse, have had two babies who weighed in at 11 pounds each. The smallest of their six other children was eight pounds six ounces.

title: N.F.L. Schedule Seen Toughest for Cardinals
description: Pity the poor St. Louis Cardinals and watch out for the Atlanta Falcons.

title: BOY 10 IS DROWNED IN A BROOKLYN PARK
description: A 10yearold Brooklyn boy drowned near the boathouse on the Prospect Park lake yesterday after he and two friends lumped from a rowboat that they had taken as an apparent prank.

title: Medical School Without Wails
description: NEWARK  The president of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry is expected to recommend to Governor Cahill that a medical school without wallsone that would use existing classroom and, ospital facilities  be established in the southern part of the state.

title: Hanoi Believed Planning Attack in Northern Area
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May Highranking American and South Vietnamese officials say that North Vietnamese troops are preparing for an eventual offensive in the two northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

title: U.S. MOVES TO CURB BOGUS HAMBURGER
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) The Agriculture Department, saying that Americans have the right to know whether their hamburger is all meat or part soybean, proposed today a new rule on meat patties.

title: What Price Research?
description: WASHINGTONA few years ago, medical scientists in Helsinki injected rubella vaccine into 35 pregnant women who were scheduled to have abortions. The doctors wanted to find out what effect the live virus in the vaccine would have on the fetuses.

title: Cast Thine Eyes Upon the. Waters
description: OVER the rivers that guard Manhattan the steel tide of commuters ebbs and flows from home to office and back again. Hours on the road, on the trains, in transit: drivers profiles grimly perpendicular to surroundings. Ulcers flicker. Migraines grab. Engines overheat. Sudden pellets of anger form. Work is difficult enough, but getting there is often worse.

title: Jamaica Renewal Supported
description: The head of the Greater Jamaica Uevelopment Corporation told the City Planning Commission last week that the development of Jamaica as a regional commercial center offers residents of the borough new jobs within easy reach of the transportation system.

title: Richard Uhl Weds Miss Janet C. Buge
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 5Miss Janet Carol Buge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Buge Jr. of Wayne, Pa., was married here this afternoon to Commissaryman 3d Cl. Richard George Uhl of the Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Uhl of Mineola. The ceremony in the Lutheran Church of Our Savior was performed by the Rev. John Marschhausen.

title: Irene Ryan 190273
description: I FIRST met Irene Ryan on the stage waiting to audition for Pippin. of the Imperial Theater. She was The auditions were running behind schedule. There were actors all around thebackstage area, waiting. I was called to the backstage telephone. As I crossed the stage to reach the phone, I recognized her. Feeling guilty about; having kept her waiting, I hung my head as I passed her and mumbled something about being sorry. She reached out and touched my hand, smiled (ever so graciously) and said, That's perfectly all right. I do understand. I even think she called me Mister Fosse.

title: The Man and the Medium Made History
description: HE completed only six films during his halfcentury on earth. But from 1925, when the second of them, The Battleship Potemkin, burst upon the world until he died in 1948, Sergei M. Eisenstein was, by common consent of creators and critics alike, the second great creative giant in movie history.

title: Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES  Two months ago, during the closing days of their victorious Presidential election campaign, Peronist leaders predicted that the leftwing urban guerrillas active in Argentina since the late 1960's would soon wither away. The guerrillas, argued former President Juan Domingo Perlin and his handpicked Presidential candidate, Dr. Hector J. Campora, represented popular reaction to violence from above the autocratic measures of an unpopular, sevenyearold military government. The guerrillas reason for existence would disappear, the Peronists said, at the prospect of a new popular regime.

title: Now He's Preakness Pick
description: RENO, May 5 (AP)  The Reno Turf Club said today it was making Secretarig the favorite in the Preakness Stakes.

title: I almost moved to England after the election
description: One morning during the last week of March, two men came to George McGovern's office to take pictures. They told him to sit on a telephone book so he would look taller behind his desk. The pictures were intended for use in his 1974 campaign. Before he sat, he moved a Sioux flag out from behind the desk so it would not show in the pictures. I'm afraid this has become controversial, he said. George McGovern was running for the Senate again; it was different from running for President.

title: Banker Is Called the Key Man Behind Biaggi Campaign Effort
description: A politically unknown banker with little campaign experience has been Representative Mario Biaggi's principal strategist and confidant in the mayoral campaign, including the tumultuous last two weeks of controversy over the candidate's appearance before a Federal grand jury.

title: Television
description: WHAT'S to be made of television and The Lie? Produced by Lewis Freedman and directed by Alex Segal, the hourand45minute drama used an original TV script by Ingmar Bergman, the Swedish film director, an unlikely candidate for popularity with a mass audience. Yet, much to the surprise of the Columbia Broadcasting System and professional TV observers, The Lie clobbered its competition in the ratings.

title: Camera World
description: A NEW Super 8 movie camera just introduced by Braun, North America, 55 Cambridge Parkway, Cambridge, Mass. 02142, offers several professional features previously available only in higher priced models. These include a builtin automatic lapdissolve, a builtin intervalometer to simplify accurate timelapse and motion study filming, and an automatic fadein/ fadeout device that is actuated by a button on top of the camera. When the button is depressed the scene fades gradually for 3 seconds, then the film is automatically rewound and reset to forward motion so that the next scene can fade in while being superimposed on top of the previously exposed film.

title: Portrait of a woman, a city and modern Germany Heinrich Bll's best novel
description: Although 11 of his books have been published here to good reviews, the award of the 1972 Nobel Prize for Literature to Heinrich Bll for his contribution to the renewal of German literature has made little impression in America. Solzhenitsyn, Beckett, even Neruda  among recent prizewinners  seem closer to home. Bll's many novels, stories, articles and plays have won him a large popular following in both West and East Europe, and he is also a conspicuous political gadfly in Germany. But for most Americans, and for many writers and critics in Europe, the more aggressive and innovative Gnter Grass is certainly as wellknown and often more admired. And though they are less familiar here, Jakov Lind and Peter Handke of Austria, Uwe Johnson of Germany and Max Frisch of Switzerland are also impressive literary figures who have helped resuscitate the German language.

title: AudioVisual Aids: Ea'flout From the McLuhan Galaxy
description: The orbiting of Sputnik in the fifties was viewed in the United States as a kind of handwriting on the sky: our educational system must be thoroughly reformed. Among those who hastened to make the most of the crisis were the advocates of audiovisual aids. Claiming successes with military training films and language labs during World War II, they intensified their campaign to revolutionize teaching methods. It was old hat to require students to use their imaginations while reading, they argued. Such devices as slides and filmstrips, films and television would motivate students to read and increase their appreciation of literature.

title: HONDA WILL OPEN FACTORY IN ITALY
description: ROME, May 5  It seems only yesterday that sleek Italian motor scooters made millions of people here mobile and conquered the world. Now, roaring Japanese motorcycles are the rage here.

title: Union Coed Is Fighting Bias in Tennis
description: CRANFORDDid Dr. Oscar Smukler deprive 19yearold Ellen Magliaro of her constitutional rights in ruling her ineligible to compete with men on the Union College tennis team?

title: Master keys
description: DOWN ACROSS

title: SHOP TALK
description: SADDLE BROOKThose women looking for bargains in smart, wearable clothes in sizes 38 to 52 (and in half sizes 14 to 32) should know about Roaman's MailOrder Outlet Store, at which surplus catalogue merchandise is offered at a fraction of its original price.

title: Mary J. Mason, F. E. Johnson 3d Wed in Jersey
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., May 5St. John'sontheMountain Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Johanna Mason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Mason Jr. of Peapack, to Francis Edgar Johnson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Far Hills and Edgartown, Mass.

title: The message is Not much
description: At the end of the sixties, I would sometimes meet old friends who, almost 20 years earlier, had worn long hair and dirty jeans, rejected conventional notions of morality, and spent their time in Greenwich Village coffee houses and bars to the despair of their middleclass parents. In the intervening years, these friends had gotten older but continued living a semibohemian life. They were careful to bring up their children to be free of the old sexual and social repressions, sent them to benign schools and communicated endlessly with them.

title: Tax Would Affect Big Cars
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (Reuters)A member of the House Ways and Means Committee has proposed an unusual tax designed to force large American autos off the road by 1976. Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, introduced legislation to impose a graduated excise tax on newautomobile sales with a high rate of lax on those large cars that consume a lot of gasoline.

title: Canada's OldStyle Bush Pilot Becomes Casualty of Development
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories  The Canadian bush pilot, a daring and stubbornly selfreliant hero in the conquest of the frozen North, has become largely a figure of history.

title: Both Sides of the Watershed
description: HE last several years have brought us such frequent exhibitions of Jean Dubuffet's tricolored jigsawpuzzlish Hourloupe inventions that to write about them once more would mean that a critic has to get down to absurdly fine points or settle for cannibalizing his own recent reviews. But what is interesting and unexpectedly fresh and revealing in the massive Dubuffet retrospective now at the Guggenhelm Museum, is the richness, the beauty, and above everything else the elegance that the preHourloupe work takes on within the context of Dubuffet's total career.

title: MEMBER OF SECT IS ABDUCTED HERE
description: A woman member of a religious group was kidnapped on the street near Columbia University yesterday morning and then found eight hours later with two of her alleged captors in Pennsylvania, according to the police.

title: Sunday Observer The honker at the Pentagon
description: This is a Pentagon story, and you will probably not believe it. The truest Pentagon stories are never believed until it is too late. Remember the C5A? Remember the TFX? Remember the electronic wall around Vietnam? Remember Vietnam?

title: Pop
description: IF I WERE shipwrecked on a desert island, I'd be happy if I could hear just one album: Paul Simon's second solo LP, There Goes Rhymin Simon (Columbia KC 32280), scheduled to land in the record stores this week. Ever since he and Art Garfunkel hit the nation's airwaves with Sounds of Silence in 1965, Paul Simon has been one of our best and most popular artists. But There Goes Rhymin Simon clinches his position as the top singersongwriterproducer in contemporary music and Mr. John Lennon and Jamaican reggae playe's (Mother and Child Reunion). Now, however, he consolidates his knowledge into music that blends the energy of rock, the eloquence of contemporary folk, the soul of rhythm and blues the sensuality of reggae, the spirit of gospel and the sophistication of jazz.

title: Special Jobs for Vegetable Harvest
description: GARDEN upkeep belongs to nearly every month of the year, but late spring upkeep of the vegetable garden means some special jobs to do, including careful early weeding, bobster feeding of the soli, some judicious mulching and plant protection. Now is also the time to stretch the growing season and harvest by resowing some of the early crops, and the time to put out the last tender vegetables that need warm soil and warm weather to survive.

title: Fabric Workers Settle With the Woolen Jobbers
description: David Livingston, president of Distributive Workers District 65, said yesterday that his fabric workers union had settled a contract dispute with one of several employer groups who were struck last Tuesday.

title: Music in Review
description: Lukas Foss's MAP, a Musical Game, which the Composers Showcase put on at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Wednesday night, gave one a slight turn. Was this really 1973, or had we been hustled back a decade or more in a time machine? The piece, dated 197273, proved to be a rerun of such experiments in music theater and games theory as Xenakis's Duel and Strategie and of similar pieces by John Cage and his followers in the late nineteenfifties and early sixties. This was the work's New York debut in its definitive version.

title: Miss Bacon Fined $50 For Abusive Language
description: Mary Bacon, one of the few female jockeys at Aqueduct, was fined $50 yesterday by the track stewards. The official report read for using foul and abusive language to admissions personnel at the track.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Japan Pays Debt to U.S. For Food Aid Given in 40's
description: TOKYO, (UPI)  Japan has wiped out its debt for food supplied it by the United States in the postwar occupation era, with a lump sum payment of $175million.

title: 3,000 AT FUNERAL OF SLAIN TROOPER
description: More than 3,000 policemen from scores of law enforcement agencies gathered in East Bruitswick, N. J., yesterday afternoon for the funeral of Werner Foerster, the New Jersey state trooper who was killed Wednesday in a gun battle with black militants on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: The Nation
description: COLLINSVIILLE, Ill.There was a surface calm last week in this town of 19,600 near St. Louis. The fragrance of freshcut lawns was in the air, and neighborhood dogs slept in the sunny streets.

title: Tigers Conquer Ringers, 20 Giving Coleman His Sixth Victory of Season
description: DETROIT, May 5 (AP)Joe Coleman became the major league's second sixgame winner this season when he and John Hiller limited the Texas Rangers to five hits odak in a 20 victory for the Detroit Tigers.

title: Rider College to Try Coed Housing Units
description: TRENTONThe board of trustees of Rider College has approved the establishment of two coeducational housing, units on a oneyear experimental basis.

title: Teaching Children's Literature
description: Recently, a young English professor of a large university asked to teach children's literature.

title: MAFIA BASE SEEN SHIFTING UPSTATE
description: BUFFALO, May 5The 24 men indicted here earlier this week in a Federal drive against organized crime were said by Federal information to have one thing in commonthey all knew Joseph Zito Sr., 45 years old, of Batavia, N.Y.

title: Best at Bucks County Show Goes To Shandown's Touch O'Kings
description: ERWINNA, Pa., May 5A magnificent, muscular pointer, Ch. Shandown's Touch O'Kings came up with the right touch today at the 32d Bucks County Kennel! Club Show in Tinicum Park and led a field of 2,718 dogs.

title: Living Like Howard Hughes Is Not as Great as You Think
description: LONDONHere I am in the same city as Howard Hughes, finally in position to satisfy my curiosity about how rich people live.

title: Memorial Day, or Days, Set in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 5 (AP)Memorial Day in New Hampshire may be a bit different this year.

title: PENN CENTRAL PUT NO. 1 IN TAX OWED
description: The bankrupt Penn Central a large realty concern and owners of hundreds of relatively small and scattered properties in poor neighborhoods are the city's leading realestate tax delinquents, a Finance Administration study has found.

title: New Yorker May Direct Watergate Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The search for a special supervising prosecutor in the Watergate case is being quietly pressed by unidentified Government officials.

title: Harness Writers to Cite Levy, 85, Fearon, 90
description: The New York Chapter of the United States Harness Writers Association will honor the two oldest active track presidents in the sport at its annual dinnerdance at Roosevelt Raceway, May 27.

title: New York Tech Wins, 14 2
description: John Scannello had four goals and one assist and Alan Weinberg scored three times as New York Tech defeated City College, 142, in a Met Conference lacrosse game yesterday afternoon at Lewisohn Stadium.

title: JERSEY RACE TAKEN BY NORTH BROADWAY
description: CHERRY FULL, N. J. May 5 (AP)  Tamao Tamashita's North Broadway, rallying from last place under a sharp ride by Tommy Wallis, captured her first stakes victory today, winning the $26,625 Jersey Belle Handicap by a nose from Tommy's Girl at Garden State Park.

title: The Great American Novel
description: Philip Roth, who has lately seemed an author in search of a subject, turns to an old interest in Ms new novel. Oh, to be a center fielder, a center fielderand nothing more! was the yearning cry of Alexander Portnoy, condemned like the rest of us to be a great deal morea son, a sexual creature and a human being, among other things. For thinking men, nonperformers, sports offers a tempting glimpse of grace, of the merging of self into pure and formal function. The Great American Novel is a book about baseball and its power as heroic and pastoral myth, but savingly tempered by Roth's understanding of the awkward contradiction at the heart of the dream, the fact that upstairs, so to speak, there's the thing itself, the girlfriend's older brother in Goodbye, Columbus, Big Ron Patimkin, the Mantovani put aside for the Columbus record, while the jockstraps dry in the bathroom.

title: Saigon May Hand ExOfficial to Reds
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 5The South Vietnamese Government plans to release Tran Ngoc Chau, a former official and valued friend of many American advisers in Vietnam, to the Communists in the next few days, according to a Government spokesman.

title: Gourmets to Dine Royally
description: WEST ORANGE  The conversation and wine will flow, and the food will be worthy of a banquet at Buckingham Palace. The occasion? One of the semiannual dinners of the Gourmet Society of New Jersey, whose next function will be held at The Manor here on Tuesday night.

title: LOUIS J. ALTIERI
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., May 5Louis J. Altieri, a former New York lawyer who lived in retirement here, died Thursday at Community Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Acquisition by Ridder
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP)Ridder Publications, Inc., said it had completed acquisition of The Wichita Eagle and Beacon. Addition of the Kansas newspaper brings the number of papers in the Ridder group to 19 daily and 12 Sunday.

title: ROBERT G. PATT Special to The New York Time
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 5 Robert G. Patt, director of marketing and advertising for AveryKnodel, Inc., broadcasting station representatives, died yesterday of a heart attack in Lawrence Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 50 Elm Rock Road.

title: Police
description: March 19, 1972: Three offduty police officers were drinking in a West Side bar. In the course of the evening, according to the police account, they assaulted and shot at neighborhood youths. One of the officers, a 36yearold plainclothesman named Thomas Shea, was charged by the department with hitting a 14yearold boy with his revolver.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 5 (AP)  The Cambodian military command reported today that its troops defending the embattled southern provincial capital of Takeo had recaptured three villages on the city's northern outskirts.

title: The barrier that exists in Greece
description: This is a Greek's book about Greece, and it has the merit of being prompted less by The Glory That Was than by the depopulation, poverty and petty persecution which is. The walls of the title are symbolic. They bound a section of Athens within which lie Palace, chamber, Ministries, residences of premiers past and present, theaters, cinemas, newspaper chains, airlines, tourist offices. The life of life itself is regulated by them. Within these walls lives the Greek Establishment  members both in and out of power and the vested interests of business, church, and the professions (interested in preserving the status quo, shutting out intruders, and making money).

title: Elvis Presley Sells Ranch

A spokesman for the Boyle Investment Company confirmed Wednesday that it had bought the Circle G Ranch. The price was not announced but it was believed to be more than $500,000.

title: Newark Day Center: 170 Years of Help
description: NEWARK  The earnest women who organized the Newark Female Charitable Society in 1803its purpose was to help the poor and distressed of the villageWould be in for a few surprises today. Not only has the society's name been changed as a result of a merger but, even more surprising, there are men on its governing board and a black woman is its executive director.

title: James Decker, 61, Retires; Headed Syracuse Athletics
description: SYRACUSE (AP)James H. Decker, director of athletics at Syracuse University since 1964, has retired for medical reasons at the age of 61. He had been on leave of absence since last December.

title: Edwardians at play by day and night
description: For over four centuries the British upper and lower classes have been united by a love of sport, and often also by a dislike for work. It is the middle classes who, from the time of Queen Elizabeth I to that of Queen Elizabeth II, have labored at a variety of avocations which they not only did well but patently enjoyed. In this, way evolved the great art and literature, the defense of the realm (by the Services, Army, Navy, Air Force), the Church, the Law, Medicine, the City, commerce and the civil services by which the British Empire (upon which the sun never set until World War II) was run.

description: The counting of ballots from the 32 community school board elections here last Tuesday was so badly hampered by logistical problems that by yesterday the bulk of the winners had not been determined.

description: MANVILLEFifteen teenagers in central New Jersey, are trying their wings, thanks to an unusual club sponsored by the Somerset County 4H.

description: TRENTONThe plan of a Cahill administration commission to preserve one million acres of New Jersey farmland, has been described as a scheme to permit farmers to have their cake and eat it, too.

title: A guide for students to their own recent past
description: Students for a Democratic Society (S.D.S.) was the epitome of a decade of confident turbulence. The best and the brightest were outsiders as well as insiders, and both were sustained by the conviction that America contained both a knowledge of the good and the means to make it effective. Students protested hypocrisy as often as they did because they refused to allow parents and society the excuse of moral ignorance or the plea of inability. But S.D.S., like its opponents and counterparts in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, has submerged in a sea of defeat and recrimination, newfelt weakness and selfdoubt. And America proved emptier than was supposed: ByeBye Miss America pie/ Drove my Chevy to the levee, but the levee was dry. But despair has its own illusions. S.D.S., like its official adversaries, may have looked for the river of national moral strength in the wrong place.

title: dh: Hart Goes Into Slump
description: Jim Ray Hart, the exNational Leaguer who started off so well as the Yankees designated hitter, managed only one hit in 12 times at bat last week and saw his dh average drop from 429 to .303.

title: 2 Eras Mesh on Japanese Children's Day
description: TOKYO, May 5A Japanese grandmother, dressed in a gray kimono, stood before site altar of the Meiji Shrine this afternoon with her newborn grandson bound in her arms with a black ceremonial sash.

title: Dictionaries: From
description: The best dictionary for a child who is just beginning to read has a warm lap, lots of patience and speaks most times only when spoken to. But parents can't be expected to do all the work, and most of us have likely paused before a display of children's books and thought about a dictionary for the little tyke. After all, we've had it drilled into us that dictionaries are part of the world of organized knowledge, and an early introduction into them doesn't seem like a bad idea. So, I've looked over 15 that would seem appropriate for a child between the ages of 4 and 8.

description: HELMETTA  This tiny Central Jersey borough is about to lose 35 per cent of its land to a county park, despite protests to those officials who hold the town's fate in their hands.

description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 5 Miss Susan Elizabeth Turner, who has just begun her third year at the University of California School of Law at Berkeley, plans to be married here to Stefan Jovanovich, who has entered his second year at the same law school. description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 5 (AP)Fishing for haddock in the Browns Bank area will be closed beginning Tuesday for the rest of the year, the National Marine Fisheries Service announced Thursday.

title: Picasso's Nature and Art
description: On Sunday, April Sth, Pablo Picasso died, Last fall there appeared a slim volume devoted to his remarks on art, Picasso on Art: A Selection of Views, edited by Dore Ashton, (Viking, 1972). Like his death itself, this event was momentous, for with it Picasso joined the ranks of those outstanding estheticians of the art of Western painting Delacroix, Constable, Fromentin, Van Gogh who were themselves all painters. Of this group only Fromentin produced a book, The Old Masters of Belgium and Holland, of which Flaubert remarked that it constituted a new literary form. Picasso gives a simple reason why the others held back: But say it with brushes and paint. Constable gave another. I would write a book, but I recollect the saying, O that mine enemy would write a book! Nevertheless it is in the journals of Delacroix, the letters of Constable and Van Gogh, Fromentin's book, and now Picasso's mots that the art of painting is most genuinely illuminated. Meyer Schapiro claimed that among the painters who wrote about art only Fromentin gave his thoughts a decided literary form. But the letter has long been recognized as a fecund department of literature; the epistolary style, as T.S. Eliot called it, puts the reader immediately in close connection with the writer like no otherwhat have so many scholars of Shakespeare's sonnets done, but search in vain for precisely that which would have been revealed in those hypothetical letters mankind would love to read?

title: Miss Anne Herlinda Goldfinch Is Wed in Texas to Scott Fuller
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 5  In St. Mark's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Anne Herlinda Goldfinch, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Canales Goldfinch of New York and Prof. Charles Goldfinch of Kitchener, Ontario, was married to Geoffrey Scott Fuller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Fuller of Larchmont, N. Charles Henry Tinsley, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Tinsley of London. The Rev. David Bruce Jenkins performed the ceremony.

title: Ballet
description: Although Rudolf Nureyev is appearing every night (and on Saturday matinees) in his guest stint with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House, his premier danseur favors are shared by five ballerinas. His ballerina of the evening in Erik Bruhn's Swan Lake Friday night was Vanessa Harwood, and she did very nicely indeed.

title: Of Blanche the Victim and Other Woman
description: I FIND myself thrice surmised this week. The first two surprisesthey come together in a single tangle, reallyoccurred as I watched Ellis Rabb's visually sensitive production of Tennessee Williams's A Streetcar Named Desire at the Vivian Beaumont. Mr. Williams's play has always seemed to me the finest single work yet created for the American theater, there is nothing about the current revival to make me alter that opinion by so much as a strand of Blanche DuBois's ash'blond hair, and I looked forward eagerly to seeing Rosemary Harris, an actress I am ready to salute in any and all weathers, as Blanche.

title: WALTER HOAG

title: Some loaded questions answered, and the answers exploded
description: The theme of government as cheat and liar has a fashionable incandescence in our times, and is often invoked to add color to otherwise bland, if thorough, historical research. In refuting the myths, lies and confusions which surround the torpedoing of the Lusitania in 1915, Colin Simpson, a journalist with The London Times, has reached beyond institutional failures and coverup to erect a new framework of devil theories.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON ordered 600 large corporations to apply to the Cost of Living Council 30 days in advance for approval of price increases of more than 1.5 per cent. The wholesale price index in April rose 0.8 per cent to 130.7 per cent of the 1967 base. Industrial prices jumped 1.4 per cent to 124.4. Farm products, feed and processed food components dropped 0.8 per cent to 147.9.

title: Was Hitler clever or Stalin blind?
description: What can I say about a book that is elegant, urbane, witty, gaily insouciant, preposterous, presumptuous, almost as exciting as Frederick Forsyth's The Day of the Jackal The Odessa File, a book whose enigmatic and sophisticated graphic design (by the author, himself) enhances one's pleasure, a book complete with saucy reading instructions (intelligence specialists can skip Chapters 3, 4 and 5; social scientists will find Chapters 1 and 9 most rewarding; mystery buffs may peek at the ending first)? What to say when the core of the authors superb hypothesis lies a worm.

title: Adamowicz Sure He's on Title Track
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 5 Having survived a couple of lean years with mediocre equipment and inadequate financing, Tony Adamowicz is riding the comeback trail supremely confident that he will again win the L&M Championship, the Formula 5000 series that he captured in 1969.

title: Andre KostelanetzMiddlebrow Toscanini?
description: ANDRE KOSTELANETZ is an anachronismone of the last of a dying breed of elder statesmen of the podium who are Institutions Unto Themselves. The maestro is fully aware of his singular status, and does not for a moment take it lightly; Kostelanetz is important; Kostelanetz has responsibilities; and Kostelanetz is ceremoniously serious about the mighty burden he himself has placed upon his slightly stooped 71yearold shoulders.

title: Woman in Religious Sect Abducted on West Side
description: A.M., when the escort arrived at 435 West 119th Street, where the mother and daughter lived, they were told the daughter would join them later. So they left without her.

title: It's like getting a raise
description: Even in these days of flyaway meat prices, you can have your meat (and eat it) without mortgaging the split level or raiding the kiddies college fund. Even beef. Not sirloin, not filet mignon, but good tasty blade or bonein chuck steak, full of protein and tastier than many more expensive cuts. Mary Dunham of Issaquah, Wash. (it's a suburb of Seattle), is a working wife and mother who has to budget both time and money and whose family has gourmet tastes. She has worked out ways to provide, variety and interest at minimum cost by shrewd shopping, cooking in quantity and stashing away partly prepared dishes in the freezer. Not only does this do away with the daily frustrations of menu planning, food buying and cooking from scratch, it also provides cash savings.

title: Signs of Age Are Evident in Rahway
description: RAHWAYIn a fact sheet prepared by administration leaders here, Rahway is described as the city of homes and industry. The visitor finds the description apt, but is not too surprised to discover that industry and commerce have been separated from residences as a natural course of development. The signs of age are evident herefrom the contrast in the carpeted City Hall, which is in need of new walls, floors and offices, to the modern houses and stores on the western fringes of the community. And new construction emphasizes this contrast.

title: ITALY'S CABLE TV SHOWING PROMISE
description: ROME, May 5About 30 million Italians have a choice between the two channels of the state television monopoly, but now some 2,000 can switch to a third one.

title: ONCERT WILL HAIL PIATIGORSKY AT 70
description: Gregor Piatigorsky was 70 years old April 20, and on May 20 a belated birthday concert at Tully Hall will celebrate the event for the benefit of the chamber Music Society of Lincoin Center.

description: A complex directive issued nine months ago should have resulted in slight rent reductions in thousands of rentstabilized apartments in the city. But how many of the mandated cuts, which average between $1 and $2 a month, have been made seems to be a matter of guesswork.

J., fleet, won the opening race of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet's annual eyeopener series today by 8 minutes 9 seconds after seven miles off Larchmont Y. C. The typical preseason prospectus, written by the club publicity director, is essentially optimistic in its positionbyposition analysis of seasoned players, the rookies, and those obtained through trade.

title: Notes: Brookfield Celebrates
description: IN Brookfield, Mass., 15 miles southwest of Worcester, they have their own ways of keeping down the cost of living, and a night on the town there doesn't eat up all the housekeeping money. When Brookfield opened the observance of its 300th anniversary a few weeks ago with a costume ball and buffet supper in the Town Hall for 500 people, the price was only $3.50 a head. It is true that the community is spending $5,000 in town money to finance the various anniversary celebrations, nit don't imagine that the $5,000 is simply going to disappear. The anniversary committee, which has been planning the whole operation at bimonthly meetings in the firehouse, feels fairly confident that it will be able to recoil) most of the, money by selling decorated beer mugs, towels and other anniversary souvenirs and through the proceeds of flea markets and auctions. The souvenirs will be on sale at the events that have been scheduled for the next few months. Visitors are welcome to attend of them.

title: Helstoski Assesses His District's Problems
description: EAST RUTHERFORDFew people know that Elbridge Gerry was a signer of the Declaration of Independence and that he once served as Vice President of the United States. But Representative Henry Helstoski could probably tell you thatand more.

title: Girls' Liberation
description: feminist and a parent I try to overlook male bias in books that are overwhelmingly literate and durable. Instead of banishing Peter Pan from the shelves because Wendy flies back to Neverland every year to do Peter's spring cleaning, it seems more constructive to engage my daughters in some bedtime consciousnessraising. That way, a literary classic survives while the stereotype of the domestic female doesn't filter into their dreams unchallenged.

Sachs galleries Bernice Rose, the museum's associate curator of drawings has mounted an expert if somewhat understated survey of modern drawings and works on paper from the Modern's extensive holdings.

description: WASHINGTON  Whatever the domestic impact of the Watergate scandal, President Nixon went out of his way last week to create the impression that the affair was not affecting the running of foreign policy.

title: Tex Reform
description: WASHINGTON  The recommendetions for changes in the tax laws that the Nixon Administration sent to Congress last week were almost more notable for two things they omitted than for what they contained:

title: Libraries Plan a Protest on Funding
description: CHICAGO, May 5 (UPI)Librarians will demonstrate on Tuesday by dimming their lights to protest the Nixon Administration's decision to cut back library subsidies from $140million to zero.

title: 501 SHOT IS FIRST IN 2,000 GUINEAS
description: NEWMARKET, England, May 5 (AP)Mon Fils, a 501 shot ridden by Frank Durr, edged the Americanowned Noble Decree by a head today in winning the 2,000 Guineas race and spoiling an American double in the British spring racing classics.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Mexican Government has told the United States that it will accept the demands of the leftwing guerrillas who kidnapped Terrance G. Leonhardy, the United States Consul General in Guadalajara, the Vice Consul there, Joseph Hayes, said yesterday. Mr. Hayes said, This position of the Mexican Government has been conveyed to us. Mr. Leonhardy, 58 years old, was kidnapped Friday night by guerrillas who demanded 30 political prisoners be allowed to fly to Cuba in exchange for his life. [Page 1, Cols. 12.]

title: Miss Patricia Scheyhing Wed To Jackson Edgeworth Peddy
description: In St, Thomas More Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Patricia Scheyhing became the bride of Jackson Edgeworth Peddy. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Lebanon W arns Guerrillas On Kidnapping and Terror
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5 President Suleiman Franjieh said today that Lebanon was not prepared to allow Palestinian guerrillas here to terrorize and kidnap people as if they were above the official authority.

title: Where Does Flamingo Road Lead?
description: STANLEY, Jr., the son of my film industry friend, walked into the office last week wearing what seemed to be a weird disguise: gray flannel slacks, yellow turtleneck sweater, dark blue blazer with gold buttions, black loafers fitted with smart little tassles. He was combed out and shaved. Gone were the Marjoe curls, the jeans, the Screw Magazine Tshirt, the sneakers tied with shoe laces bought to benefit the Vietcong. Even more confusing, he looked healthy.

title: Music: 2 Student Pieces
description: The Camerata Singers and Symphony Orchestra, directed by Abraham Kaplan, played a couple of student pieces in its concert in Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, but since the students names were Wagner and Puccini the program scarcely sounded like a graduation exercise.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Wall Street has been so full of gloom all year that it was nice last week to see stock prices advance for a change.

title: Den Uyl, Socialist, Forms A Cabinet in Netherlands
description: THE HAGUE, May 5 (AP)Joop Den Uyl, a former Economics Minister, is to become the Netherlands first Socialist Premier in 15 years under an agreement worked out last night.

title: Bridge
description: A popular delusion among inexperienced players runs something like this: If I play against an expert, he will be baffled and confused by the unorthodoxy of my bids and plays. In this context unorthodox is a euphemism for bad, and this line of thought has no validity. In defense, for example, the unorthodox play is often one that hides useful information from partner or gives it unnecessarily to the declarer.

title: Minter's Rally Beats Posey In Lime Rock TransAm
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 5 (AP)Milt Minter of Tarzana, Calif., passed Sam Posey of Sharon, Conn., at the end of the front straightaway on the final lap today and won the $6,000 top prize in the TransAm auto race at Lime Rock Park.

title: Baby Beating Stirs Call for Added Methadone Care
description: Threemonthold Kim Cruz has been in critical condition for more than a week at St. Vincent's Hospital, suffering from cerebral hemorrhaging apparently caused by a beating. Both of her parents are former heroin addicts who were metha donemaintenance patients, and her father allegedly tried to sell her to buy narcotics.

title: Sister Attends Maryl C. Walker At Jersey Bridal
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May. 5 In the First Congregational Church of Montclair tonight, Miss Maryl Chase Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Yates Gholson Walker Jr. of Great Notch, became the bride of Winslow Lewis Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Lewis of Penllyn, Pa., and the late Mr. Lewis.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: Today  Saratoga, Saratoga Race Track, Saratoga Springs, N. Y. Championships in all divisions. 9 A.M.

title: Cunningham Dancers Offer Home Event
description: Event No. 80 at the Merce Cunningham studio Friday evening offered a rare opportunity to see the company in its own studio. What was lost in overall design was more than made up for by the nearness of the dancers.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: To state the obvious, a good magazine ad salesman today is not the same animal of a few years ago. Then we had a circulation figure, a rate card and not much else except the gift of gabno regionals, test markets, split runs, Zips, Vips, Top Tens, Simmons, demographics or computers.

title: Paterson Coalition Lists Goals
description: PATERSON  What similar peoples groups have done successfully in San Francisco, Minneapolis and New York, the new Paterson Coalition intends to do here: Let many people act as one by giving them a strong voice in the decisionmaking processes.

title: A Message About Messages
description: San Francisco Saturday Children's Book Editor, New York Times Book Review Dear George, It's Saturday morning, and not bad day,. Saturday is the day when working men have a nice, long stretch of time to do whatever they want, if they want to do anything. They can go ahead and do it, not just try to squeeze it in between 5:00 and dinnertime. Still, it may turn out that on Saturday they have something laid on them, or have laid it on themselves, an interference, a demand, a commitment. So it is now.

title: Coptic Patriarch, in Rome, Invites Pope to Visit Egypt
description: ROME, May 5 (AP)Pope Paul VI was invited today to visit Egypt by Patriarch Shenouda III of Alexandria. The invitation was made during the first meeting between a Roman Catholic Pope and a spiritual leader of 22 million Coptic Christians, the largest Christian group in the Arab world.

title: Growing Up Embooked
description: She does not want to be disturbed. She is reading. I am glad she does not want to be disturbed. She is five and a half. I am an intellectual listening to The Lone Ranger in the kitchen. She comes in and humorously tries to turn off the radio; I invite her to listen to my childhood, but she thinks it's weird getting a story this wayneither off a screen nor on a printed page; she goes back and closes her door. TV time over. Supper is ready and she is hungry, but she wants to read on. I am glad.

title: Joyce Verhalen, F. P. Pandolfi Plan Nuptials
description: LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., May 5Mr. and Mrs. James P. Verhalen of Pickerel Point have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Mary Verhalen, to Francis P. Pandolfi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Pandolfi of West Hartford, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 16.

title: Barry Successor Sought in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  The maneuvering has begun for the slot of Suffolk's top policeman, vacant now for the first time in 11 years.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:I MADE a special trip into New York recently to visit the exhibition called The Painterly Photograph 18901914 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. When I got to the Metropolitan, the North Gallery was closed for lack of guards, and I lost my chance to see the exhibit.

title: SPRING IS MARKED DESPITE THE CHILL
description: The Jolly Green Giant shivered and the sky was overcast, but about 1,000 people joined him on Staten Island yesterday for an allday celebration of spring, the arts and nature.

title: Legal Wiretaps Up 43% in Two Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Courtauthorized wiretapping by law enforcement officials rose 43 per cent from 1970 to 1972, despite a recent decline in antigambling activity for which electronic survelliance has proved particularly effective.

title: Miller, Astros Finally Meet54 Days Later
description: It took 54 days but Marvin Miller, executive director of the major league baseball players association, finally completed, meeting with the Houston Astros yesterday.

title: The Greeks and The. Turks Had A Name for Them
description: TULIPS from Tarkey, amaryllis from South Africa, steliated magnolias from Mt. FujiYanathese familiar spring plants were strange and exotic when first introduced to Europeans in the course of the last 500 years.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON Attention, 130,000 doctors, lawyers, highly paid business executives, big investors using borrowed money and the taxshelter departments of investment advisory firms: Life is likely to become more difficult.

title: Pragmatism
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Gallup has found that 50 per cent of those who responded in a special national poll believe that President Nixon particio pated in a coverup of the Watergate situation. Yet, in the same poll 58 per cent of the respondents said they saw little difference in the corruption of the Nixon Administration and that of Its predecessors.

title: LaborIndustry Building Board Assails City's Minority Hiring Rules
description: New city regulations aimed at more effective integration of the construction industry were denounced yesterday as unconstitutional, and court action was threatened by the Board of Urban Affairs of the New York City Building and Construction Industry.

title: Levitt to Correct Freehold Defects
description: NEWARKLevitt & Sons, Inc., has agreed to correct construction defects in some of the homes in its Freehold complex, or to buy back the buildings from their owners at the original sale price.

title: PENN CENTRAL PUT NO. 1 IN TAX OWED
description: The bankrupt Penn Central a large realty concern and owners of hundreds of relatively small and scattered properties in poor neighborhoods are the city's leading realestate tax delinquents, a Finance Administration study has found.

title: 8 Dissident Professors at Belgrade University Fear Dismissal as Party's Pressure Grows
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 5A noted scholar at Belgrade University, one of a group of professors under Communist arty attack as anarchoberets, qualified himself recently to drive a taxijust in case.

title: A Bo in Warren Yields a Mastodon
description: BLAIRSTOWNThe hilly reaches of northern Warren County have long been known as a paradise for those hunters in quest of squirrels, rabbits, deer and pheasant. One hunter has gone them a step further; he has recently run to ground a mastodon and a mooselike creature.

title: Lighter Side of Watergate Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, May 5For years, Richard Nixon has been the target of hundreds of jokes by his political rivals. The Watergate scandal has given his opponents new material, and they have devoured it. Here are a few of the jokes that can be printed:

title: 3 SOLDIERS BILLED AT ULSTER BORDER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 5Three British soldiers were killed in two mine explosions near the Irish border in County Armagh today. The Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the blasts.

title: Gas Shortage Is Hurting Independents
description: FARMINGDALE  After 20 years in business, the Octane Petroleum Company has begun to close its discount service stations in Monmouth and Ocean Counties It is simply, the victim of an everworsening gasoline shortage and soaring wholesale prices.

title: Gas Leak Holes Are Drying Up, But Michigan Town Keeps Vigil
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., May 5There is an old Indian legend around here told by whites but unconfirmed by Ottawa Indians to the effect that a person should not live in Williamsburg because it will sink.

title: Photography
description: IF she were not much too busy to spare time for such tomfoolery, I would be sorely tempted to nominate Imogen Cunningham for the post of Elder Statesperson of Photography.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONJohn B. Connally put the brayeet imaginable face on his belated conversion to the Republican party last week. Indeed it was one of the handsomest faces, Most persuasive manners and certainly the best tailoring in American politics that stood before the microphone in Houston on Wednesday and declared that this prize pupil from the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Texas Democratic Politics was charting a new course at the age of 56, clearly, if not explicitly, aimed at the Presidency itself.

title: PROSECUTORS ACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 54he Federal prosecutors in the Watergate case have summoned officials of the Central Intelligence Agency to discuss that agency's role in the plot to break into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, sources close to the case said today.

title: EXHIBITIONS
description: EXHIBITIONS

title: $1 Political Gifts Approved
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 5 (AP)The Rhode Island Leg'slature early today followed the Federal Government's lead in approving the use of $1 of each person's income tax as a political contribution.

title: 18 Korean Miners Killed
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 5 (AP)  Six carts carrying 36 miners to work in coal pits near Changsong about 100 miles east of Seoul, ran out of control and overturned today, killing 18 miners and injuring the 18 others.

title: Drive to Aid Poor L.I. Jews
description: A drive is under way to identify and find ways to aid Jews living in poverty on Long Island.

title: Old Ironsides Wanted
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)The State Senate passed a resolution Thursday urging Congress and the Secretary of the Navy to keep the U.S. Constitution, Old Ironsides, in Boston harbor after it is overhauled.

title: A.I.A. Announces Award Winners
description: The American Institute of Architects has announced the winners of its 1973 honor awards, which will be presented at its annual convention this week in San Francisco.

title: Rosemary Neaher to Be Bride Of John M. Niehuss, a Lawyer
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 5Miss Rosemary Neaher, a member of the National Security Council Staff in Washington, and John M. Niehuss, a lawyer with the World Bank there, will be married in the summer.

title: The ki bbutz:
description: JERUSALEM. After Israel's recent raid into the streets of Beirut, military funerals were held in two Negev Desert kibbutzim. That the two young Israeli commandos killed on the mission were kibbutzniks was nomere coincidence. Accounting for only 3 per cent of Israel's total population, the kibbutz nevertheless provides 40 per cent of the officers in the army's elite combat units; an almost equally high percentage of kibbutzniks serves as combat air force pilots. The price in casualties paid for this distinction is so high that young kibbutzniks themselves often make macabre jokes about being the nation's cannon fodder.

title: Robin Cohen Affianced
description: WHITE PLAINS,. May 5The engagement of Miss Robin Jill Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard O. Cohen, to Scott B. Cutler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul J. Cutler of Newton Centre, Mass., has been announced by her parents. Miss Cohen and her fianc are students at Boston University. Mr. Cohen is president of Hartley Chemists, Inc., in New York.

title: C.T.C. Summaries
description: FIELD EVENTS TRACK EVENTS

title: Arthur Daley
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5When Col. Edward Riley Bradley was a dominating force in the Kentucky Derby four and five decades ago, he was fond of saying, If you give me a horse who can, run the last quarter mile in 24 seconds, I'll give you a Derby winner. He never had a colt that fast but still took four of the bourbon belt classics. The colonel's eyes would have popped if he had been around for the 99th running of America's premier of racing event at sunshinedrenched Churchill Downs today. Secretariat, a big and handsome redcoated powerhouse, came charging down the homestretch with such blistering speed that he set a record of 0:23 1/5 for the final quarter on his way to a record of 1:59 2/5 for the total distance. Riding him spectacularly was Ron Turcotte, who had been accused of giving him a rather inferior ride in his disastrous defeat in the Wood. That setback removed the tag of 'superhorse from the Meadow Stable standard bearer. In all probability, the Kentucky Derby restored every last superlative.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles

title: Jacobsons Have Son
description: A son was born last Sunday to Dr. and Mrs. Lenard E. Jacobson of New York in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Jacobson, known professionally as Dr. Bonnie Jacobson, is consulting psychologist at the Manhattan Day School. Her husband, a urologist, is on the attending staff at Lenox Hill. The child has been named Brad Ari.

title: New & Novel
description: We hated the Japanese because they were so terrifyingly efficient; we hated our generals for precisely the opposite reason. So reflects a British veteran of the 1942 debacle on the Malay Peninsula. ExCapt. David Cornish is the only survivor of a rifle battalion, cut off and surrounded irr the jungle after the fall of Singapore. The Last Hill is a recapitulation, some 30 years later, of how and why some men died.

title: Jazz/Rock/Folk/Pop
description: FRIDAY THURSDAY SATURDAY TODAY WEDNESDAY TUESDAY MONDAY

title: The National Book Award in Fiction: A Curious Case
description: Gentlemanly warfare is what Jonathan Yardley, in a letter to his four fellow judges, called the process by which they decided who should win the 1973 National Book Award for fiction. The names of the five men on the fictionprize panel were made known on Dec. 27, 1972, by the National Book Committee, which administers the $1,000 award as well as nine other annual prizes for books in other categories. Besides Yardley, the fiction judges were Evan Connell, Leslie A. Fiedler, William H. Gass and Walker Percy. What they finally decided was made known 15 weeks later, on April 10, after their deliberations had gone through these phases:

title: Green Thumbs Work an Oriental Garden: A Good Deal for Both
