description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: President Spends the Day In Bahamas With Friends
description: GRAND CAY, Bahamas, May 6 (UPI)As President Nixon secluded himself with three close friends on this resort island today, a spokesman said Mr. Nixon talked frequently by telephone to aides who remained at the Florida White House in Key Biscayne.

title: Today's Events
description: Historical panorama of Riverdale and Kingsbridge. Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association, 275 West 231st Street. Through Friday during banking hours.

title: Scheckter Takes Coast Car Race
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 6His fishtailtwitchy driving style is as brash as his manner, and it is criticized as much as it is praised by other drivers.

title: Ellsberg Judge's Act Cited In Plan to Ask End of Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6Defense attorneys in the Pentagon papers trial plan to ask a Federal appeals court to dismiss the case immediately on the ground that the White House tried to compromise the trial judge.

title: Catherine Artel Is Wed
description: Catherine Artel Is Wed Special to The New York Times

title: Guns Banned in Chile Capital Under State of Emergency
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 (UPI)The army revoked all civilian gun permits in Santiago Province today in the first day of a state of emergency decreed by Chile's Marist Government to prevent further bloodshed in the capital.

title: BALANCHINE'S AGON IS DANCED'BRIGHTLY
description: Agon, George Balanchine's masterly amalgam of contemporary sportiveness and classic form, was given a vibrantly lucid performance Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. Karin von Aroldingen made her first appearance in the Second Pas de, Trois and Peter Martins partnered Allegra Kent in the Pas de Deux for the first time.

title: Area Youth, After a Week's Ordeal, Now Happy Over Rescue From Sect
description: Shortly before midnight on Wednesday, April 25Marcus Manecke left the Boston headquarters of a religious sect known as the Children of God.

title: White House and Watergate: Some Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 There are still more questions than answers about the Watergate scandal. What follows is an attempt to suggest the often inconclusive dialogue between newsmen and the most knowledgeable sources, specifically on the matter of how high and how broadly the Nixon Administration was involved in the Watergate bugging and the ensuing coverup.

title: MRS. MEIR OUTLINES POSITION ON LEBANON
description: if other Arab nations moved to send in forces to help the Palestinians.

title: Pentagon Plans $100Million MissileDetection Radars Despite Success of Spy Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Defense Department is planning to spend at least $100million to build two missiledetection radars at a time when it already has a highly reliable satellite system for detecting the launching of any Soviet ballistic missile.

title: Possibility of Nixon Being Summoned Indicated by Ervin
description: NEW HAVEN, May 6Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities, indicated at a news conference at Yale University today that his group would call President Nixon to testify about the Watergate incident if it felt he had important knowledge concerning it.

title: METS BOW, 148; 5TH LOSS IN ROW
description: METS BOW, 148; 5TH LOSS IN ROW when Watson's high bouncer to right just missed providing an inning ending forceout by inches. Instead, it went for a single and May's jackpot homer insured the Astros victory.

title: Enterex Commodities Corp. Opens Four New Branches
description: The Enterex Commodities Corporation has announced the opening of branches in Des Moines, St. Louis, Minneapolis and Los Angeles. Enterex, formed last Oct. 1, is based in New York and previously had one branch, in Chicago.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ESSEX FELLS, May 6College baseball coaches are like farmers when it comes to checking the weather reports. During the season, the coaches seem to be continually looking skyward because rain, sleet or snow can cause turmoil with scheduled games and practice sessions.

title: Coast Town, Undeterred by Watergate, Pushes for Shrine at Nixon Birthplace
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif., May 6 The residents of this agricultural community where Richard M. Nixon was born seem reluctant to talk about the Watergate scandal. But they are showing an eagerness to demonstrate their faith in, the President.In interviews, many of the town's 16,000 residents seemed concerned about Watergate, some were distressed and a few such as Yorba Linda's energetic woman Mayor, Mrs. Caroline EWing, conceded they were ashamed of the activities brought to light involving some of Mr. Nixon's close White House associates.

title: Hoover Files Vanish
description: Official documents authorizing wiretaps on the telephones of reporters and White House aides reportedly disappeared from J. Edgar Hoover's files in 1971 after he threatened to disclose that taps existed. Page 46.

title: Dance:Diverse Fare
description: The sheer diversity of New York, dance is almost bewildering. This weekend, for example, I went twice to Martha Graham at the Alvin Theater, once to the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House and finished up last night with New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. Still I missed 10 dance con certs, to say nothing of the last New fork performances of Marcel Marceau. Next week, with the arrival of the Alvin Ailey Company at the City Center 55th Street Theater, we shall have four major dance companies in town. It looks as though there will never be a last tango in New York.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 600 homosexuals from groups in New York and New Jersey marched in single file and handinhand along the north walkway of the George Washington Bridge in midafternoon yesterday in what they called a Hold Hands demonstration of solidarity.

title: Hoboken, Camden, Passaic Also Will Choose Mayors in Elections Tomorrow
description: JERSEY CITY, May 6A man with a harmonica leaned out of a secondfloor window of the Plaza Hotel today and played Sweet Rosie O'Grady to the crowd below, but no one could hear him.

title: MISSISSIPPI FLOODS DELAYING FARMERS
description: Farmers were still watching and waiting yesterday as the Mississippi River, which has flooded some of the nation's best farmland, continued to hold up spring planting, The Associated Press reported.

title: Connally 'Strong Contender' For Nomination, Dole Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, former Republican national chairman, says he considers John B. Connally already strong contender for the party's Presidential nomination in 1976.

title: Roundup: Fists Fly as GiantsWin Two
description: The Giants and the Chicago Cubs, the National League's division leaders, gave the customers something extra in the first game of their doubleheader yesterday at San Francisco.

title: Victory Tactic for New York: Drive at Wilt
description: Even though the Knicks played another superb defensive game to take an imposing 21 lead in the series for the championship of the National Basketball Association, the talk in the winning dressing room yesterday revolved magnetically around one member of the losing Los Angeles LakersWilt Chamberlain.

title: CULTURE SEMINAR SET FOR TOMORROW
description: What is Culture? And Do We Have It? is the theme of a seminar to be held tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Now Cultural, Center in Columbus Circle under the sponsorship of Fairileigh Dickinson University. The panelists will attempt to define culture, review current fashions in culture and appraise the state of the counculture in general.

title: CLYDE WEED, 82, OF ANACONDA DIES
description: BUTTE, Mont., May 6 (AP)Clyde E. Weed, former board chairman of the Anaconda Company, died today in a Phoenix, Ariz., hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: ARTHUR B. COLWIN
description: Arthur B. Colwin, a lawyer specializing in immigration cases, died yesterday at his home, 125 East 72d Street. His age was 70.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 40; Lead, 31, in Cup Series

title: Knicks Defeat Lakers
description: The Knicks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 8783, at Madison Square Garden yesterday and gained a 21 lead in the fourofsevengame National Basketball Association championship series. The fourth game will be played at the Garden tomorrow night. Details on Page 55.

title: Diplomat and a Professor Beaten by 5 Youths Here
description: A deputy minister of Liberia and a Rutgers University professor, also from Liberia, were set upon and beaten by five white youths early yesterday morning before an offduty policeman rushed from his apartment to rescue the two visitors, the police reported.

title: 500 Top Concerns Showed Best Sales In 1972 Since 1968
description: The nation's 500 largest industrial corporations recorded their best sales increase in four years in 1972 and their largest jump in profits since 1959, according to the May issue of Fortune to be published tomorrow.

title: Court Clerk Shot to Death Grappling With Gunmen
description: A man identified as a Criminal Court clerk was shot to death last night when he tried to preven ttwo holdup men from escaping after they had robbed a midtown hotel clerk of $50.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Things are looking up in the fashion world. A new style for the nineteenseventies is struggling to be born. It's based on such rockbottom virtues as simplicity, comfort, practicality. There's a stripping down of gewgaws and gimmicks, apparent not only in the multitude of sweaters that are heralding the new age, but extending right down to the underwear.

title: HANOI BUILDING UP HIGHWAY IN SOUTH
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 4Several thousand North Vietnamese laborers have been sent into the northwestern part of South Vietnam to build roads and airfields and to move supplies, according to senior American and South Vietnamese officials.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 (AP)A helicopter of the International Commission of Control and Supervision was fired, on today over a contested area in the Mekong Delta, commission sources reported.

Since then the Nenana Ice Classic has been the greatest game of chance in the 49th state and has led to direct involvement by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO the Editor: Authorities on carcinogenesis (cancer formation) tell us that most human cancers are caused by manmade, avoidable environmental agents. Nevertheless, when the Food and Drug Administration recently banned the treatment of beef cattle with DES, a known carcinogen, the F.D.A. was criticized with unfounded charges that meat prices would rise and that the quantities of DES in beef were infinitesimal anyway [Editorial April 30].

title: Roundup: Astros Shut Oat Expos, Extend Streak to 9
description: Dave Roberts, Houston's 28yearold lefthander, helped the streaking Astros continue their relentless pursuit of first place in the National League's West Division last night by pitching a sixhit, 60 victory over the Expos in Montreal. Roberts also contributed a runscoring single in his third victory of the season against one defeat.

title: GOODRICH WORKERS STRIKE AKRON PLANT
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 7 (AP) United Rubber Workers Local 5 struck the B. F. Goodrich Company plant in Ak'on at 10 o'clock tonight while negotiations continued in Columbus M an effort to forestall a nationwide strike.

The Japanese Maritime Safety Agency said three crewmen from the 503ton vessel Kae Tong Ho were rescued by patrol boats. The 11 others were missing.

title: Tokyo Pandas in New Home
description: TOKYO, May 7 (AP)Tokyo's pair of pandas from China moved into their new $150,000 airconditioned home today at the Ueno Zoo. They like it, said a zoo official as the bears frolicked, rolled and squatted on the, floor. The pandas, Lan Lan, a 5yearold female, and Kang Kang, a 3yearold male, were presented to Japan last September, when China and Japan established diplomatic relations.

title: Screen: A Profound Japanese Film:' An Autumn Afternoon' Was Ozu's Last Work
description: "An Autumn Afternoon," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, is Yasujiro Ozu's last film, completed shortly before his death in 1963 at the age of 60. Whether or not this great Japanese director knew he was dying of cancer while he was making the film, "An Autumn Afternoon" is such a completely realized example of the Ozu art that it seems impossible he did not intend it to be a kind of testament.What Ozu left us is not a style of film-making. That style is so unmistakable that anyone who dared imitate it would risk exile to a faculty position at an obscure institution for film education. He left something a good deal more important, an appreciation of the possibilities of all films.Although Ozu's films are realistic  they're usually about relationships within upper middle-class families  they evoke emotions not only through identification but also through methods more commonly associated with music and other nonrepresentational forms of art, through rhythms and patterns that express the essence of things.Ozu's titles are impossible to keep straight, and one should take care not to confuse "An Autumn Afternoon" with "Late Spring," which he made in 1949 and which was released here last midsummer (July).Both films, however, are about aging widowers hanging on to only daughters who have reached marriageable age. There is possibility for even further confusion since Ozu's favorite actor, the lean, handsome, deliberate Chishu Ryu, plays the father in each film.Though the films overlap to important ways, "An Autumn Afternoon" is more benignly contemplative and more beautiful than the earlier work. And never for a minute does one mix up its awareness of man's lonely state with anything on the order of pity.Like all of the late Ozu films, "An Autumn Afternoon" is about the accommodations we make, not necessarily to get ahead in the world but simply to get along in it with a certain amount of dignity intact. For the aging Chishu Ryu, this is the acknowledgement that his 24-year-old daughter is not indeed, the mere child he has called her, but a woman who must live her own life apart from him. For the daughter, it is the acknowledgement that she has lost the man she wanted to marry and must settle for someone else.Ozu treats these matters coolly, without sentimentality, keeping them at the middle distance at which he photographs them. Yet Ozu's middle distance allows for a kind of metaphorical deep focus. The images are full of odd and disturbing details that often have a kind of delayed-action effect.When, near the end, we see the daughter, a sweet, spirited, very 20th-century girl, dressed in her elaborate, traditional wedding costume, it seems, at first, that Ozu is indulging himself: the very prettiness of the bridal dress conveys a sense of impending damage. Nothing that fragile can survive. Yet Ozu's characters are not fragile. They do survive, and often with a good deal of humor.In one of the nicest sequences iin the film, Ryu, a former naval officer, runs into the man who had been his chief petty officer during the war. They get drunk together and the man, now plump and not entirely dissatisfied with his life as a mechanic, allows himself to speculate on what would have happened had Japan won the war: "We'd be in New Yorkthe-real thingand the blue-eyed ones would be wearing wigs and chewing gum while plucking their samisens!"In "An Autumn Afternoon," the old culture is giving wayas old Ryu isto time and inevitable change. Ryu's elder son and his wife are scrambling for refrigerators, vacuum cleaners, golf clubs and white leather handbags. There's nothing particularly cheering about that, but it is possible, Ozu seems to suggest, to face these changes without despair. Despair would not just be bad form. It would guarantee defeat that might otherwise be held at bay."An Autumn Afternoon," which was shown for one performance at the first New York Film Festival in 1963, is a profoundly simple, profoundly moving film.

title: No News Is Bad News
description: Under normal circumstances, diplomatic courtesy might offer some justification for the decision of the United States Embassy in Phnom Penh to discontinue briefings for newsmen on Cambodian military and political developments, as requested by the Cambodian Government.

title: CONNALLY VISITOR
description: MIAMI, May 7  The White House proclaimed anew today the President's innocence in the Watergate breakin and in an alleged subsequent highlevel White House coverup.

title: 4 Killed in Suicide Shooting
description: DALLAS, May 7 (UPI)  A doctor, depressed since heart surgery a year ago, shot and killed three of his sleeping children with a pistol, wounded his wife and another child, then killed himself, the police said today. The victims were Dr. Waldemar F. Henniger, 50 years old; his daughters, Teresa, 6, and Mary Frances, 9, and one of his twin sons, Mark, 7.

title: EDWARD WILLARD, A PHILATELIST, 68
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May, 7Edward L. Willard, a lawyer and past president of the American Philatelic Society, which has its headquarters here, died today at his home. He was 68 years old.

title: For Public Service
description: The award of the Pulitzer Prize to The Washington Post for public service in first uncovering some of the sqrdid details of the Watergate affair is as highly merited as it was fully expected. Through dogged reporting and fearless investigation in the face of bitter opposition at the highest levels of Government, The Post did indded perform a memorable service for the people of the United States. What The Post and other newspapers have done in this affair is to prove once again, and at a particularly timely moment, the absolute necessity of a free and untrammelled press if American constitutional democracy is going to be preserved.

title: Court Upholds ObscenitySometime
description: TRENTON, May 7 (UPI)The State Supreme Court held today that obscenity used at a public meeting could be constitutionally protected speech, but not if it was likely to cause a disturbance. The matter came before the court in two cases.

title: Sir Ernest MacMillan, 79, Dies; Toronto Symphony ExDirector
description: OTTAWA, MAY 7  Sir Ernest MacMillan, composerconductor who directed the Toronto Symphony Orchestra from 1931 to 1956, died yesterday in Toronto General Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Challenge and Crisis
description: The Whitt House has come to grips with some of the energy problems which faced the nation in the 1960's. What still seems to elude the capabilities of the Federal Government is the crisis nowbuilding for the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Jersey Candidates To List Fund Donors
description: TRENTON, May 7The new state commission created to enforce New Jersey's tough campaign financial disclosure law declared today that it would require a full accounting of all funds collected and spent in the  June 5 primary election campaign.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., May 7 (AP)The Little League office in Williamsport, Pa., revoked the Ypsilanti. Little League's charter today because the local chapter voted to defy a rule barring girl players. Bob Taylor, the vice president of the local Little League, said the Ypsilanti chapter was advised that its charter was being revoked, effective immediately, because Carolyn King, 12 years old, was being retained as a team member. Little League rules prohibit participation by girls.

title: SOVIET IS SEEKING A LOAN IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, May 7  The Soviet Union is hoping to borrow $1billion from a group of banks in Europe but is seeking to hold the interest rate to a point where the lenders would barely cover their costs, international banking sources said today.

description: Restrictions that New Jersey plans to put into effect this summer on the dumping of New York City's garbage there could force the city into shortterm disposal alternatives costing up to three times the present disposal costs, city officials said yesterday.

title: Dr. Harmon Chapman Dies; ExProfessor at N.Y.U., 72
description: Dr. Harmon M. Chapman, professor emeritus of philosophy at New York University, died Sunday at his home on Cow Hill Road in Clinton, Conn, He was 72 years old.

title: 2 CAPITAL NEWSMEN WIN HILLMAN PRIZES
description: Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, investigative reporters for The Washington Post, have named recipients of the 23d annual Sidney Hillman awards for their coverage of the Watergate affair.

title: Lillian Reis, ExShowgirl, Held on Drug, Gun Counts
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) Lillian Reis, the former showgirl, and a male companion face a hearing July 12 on drug possession and weapons charges.

title: China Signs Deal to Use SOHIO Production Process
description: CLEVELAND, May 7 (UPI) China has signed an agreement with the Standard Oil Company Ohio (Sohio) to use the company's acrylonitrile production process, it was reported Monday. Acrylonitrile is the basic material in acrilan, orlon and other manmade fibers.

title: CONNALLY VISITOR
description: MIAMI, May 7  The White House proclaimed anew today President Nixon's innocence in the Watergate breakin and in an alleged subsequent highlevel White House coverup.

title: Candidates Day
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi was now irrelevant as a mayoral candidate, and that some of Mr. Biaggi's former supporters had switched their allegiance to Ills own campaign in recent days.

title: Soviet Computers
description: The utility of computers in a highly centralized, complex economy such as that of the Soviet Union is selfevident. It is dizzying to contemplate the vast volume of information from tens of thousands of enterprises with which the central directors and planners must grapple in the effort to make intelligent decisions. Naturally, a longtime dream of some Soviet leaders has been of a computerized economy in which billions items of data about production, consumption; inventories, employment, etc., would be collected and processed rapidly in order to give the managers in Moscow complete and uptodate information each day. Yet until comparatively recently, the abacus was the most widespread computing instrument in the Soviet Union and even small computers were scarce.

title: Murder Trial of an Alleged Mafia Figure Opens Here
description: Robert Bongiove, said to be a highranking member of the Mafia family, of the late Joseph Gallo, went on trial yesterday charged with a murder planned and carried out because of the feud between the Gallos and the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime family.

title: Canadiens Still Puzzle For Hawks
description: MONTREAL, May 7There will be another Stanley Cup hockey game here tomorrow night and the Chicago Black Hawks problem is that they don't know what to do about it.

title: 2 ATTEMPTS CITED
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 President Nixon, invoking national security, sought on at least two occasions within the last two weeks to prevent the release to the court of details of the burglary at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, sources close to the Watergate case said today.

title: Jersey Demands Listings Of Spending for Primary
description: TRENTON, May 7The new state commission created to enforce New Jersey's tough campaign financial disclosure law declared today that it would require a full accounting of all funds collected and spent in the June 5 primary election campaign.

title: EFFORT ON TRADE URGED BY CASEY
description: The State Department is in the forefront of trade negotiations that would make it possible to expand the use of, American technology in Communist and nonCommunist countries, William J. Casey, Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs, said yesterday.

title: Ozark Air Line Talks Go On
description: ST. LOUIS, May 7 (UPI)Three days after agreeing on tentative contract, negotiators for. Ozark Air Lines and the striking Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association conferred today on details to end a walkout that began on April 19. Some progress was reported in efforts to resolve differences over a backtowork agreement. Ozark flights to 62 cities in 15 states have been grounded by the walkout.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: 5,000 Rightists Stage AntiCabinet Protest in Madrid
description: MADRID, May 7 (AP)  Rightist demonstrators marched through downtown Madrid today demanding that the Spanish Cabinet resign and calling for more power for the army and the police.

title: Bond Yields Rise Home Loan Sale DueBills Cut
description: Most interest rates continued to rise yesterday in a capitalmarket session marked by some significant financing announcements concern of the Committee on Interest and Dividends that rates adjust slowly, to avoid disruptive effects in the money markets.

title: Pollution Action Pledged
description: GARY, Ind., May 7 (AP) The United States Steel Corporation pledged today to have air pollution controls by Dec. 31, 1975  the Federal deadline  for the 10 coke oven batteries at the Gary Works here.

title: SALES GAIN SCANT AT STORES IN CITY
description: Despite a moderate statistical gain, departmentstore business in New York during March and April showed relatively little real advance over last year.

title: Milton Vander Veer, 72, Dies; Kings Lafayette Bank Chairman
description: Milton T. Vander Veer, retired chairman of the Kings Lafayette Bank in Brooklyn, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 175 Hartshorn Drive in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Penn, Adelphi Risk Probation in Weekend Meets
description: The University of vania and Adelphi University risk possible penalties and, probation from the National Collegiate Athletic Association unless the schools declare two top track and field athletes, Fred Samara and Dennis Walker, ineligible before major meets this weekend.

title: Test Finds Modified 707 10 to 15 Decibels Quieter
description: CHANTILLY, Va., May 7A Boeing 707 flew six times over the lush rolling hills south of Dulles International Airport today and, while more than 100 people strained their ears in a green pasture beneath, brought a billiondollar dispute nearer to a climax.

title: In the Home Stretch
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, the winterbook Secretariat of the New York City mayoral field, appears to have stumbled badly at the turn and a number of other prospective rivals have dropped out altogether. This has been the story of the mayoral contest so far. It is a story not so much of candidacies catching fire and taking off as of candidacies burning up and becoming ashes.

title: Lebanese Battles Resume; Martial Law Is Declared
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, May 8  New fighting erupted here last night between Palestinian guerrillas and the Lebanese Army, and the Government declared a state of emergency, placing the country under martial law.

title: Crimmins Convictions Upset by Court
description: An appeals court yesterday overturned the murder and manslaughter convictions against Mrs. Alice Crimmins in the deaths of her two children nearly eight years ago and ordered her retried again, but this time only for manslaughter.

description: LOS ANGELES, 7Following are excerpts from a transcript of additional grand jury testimony by E. Howard Hunt Jr. and from an affidavit by Egil Krogh Jr. as released at the Pentagon papers trial here today:

title: St. Louis Paper Resumes
description: ST. LOUIS, May 7 (UPI)Publication and delivery of the St. Louis PostDispatch returned to normal today after settlement of a strike that forced cancellation of editions Saturday and yesterday. The strike had been called by Local 4 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers against broadcasting stations owned by the company that also owns the PostDispatch. Teamsters Union members refused to cross picket lines, giving the newspaper no means of delivering its weekend issue.

title: Accolade for Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, May 7Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chairman, is enjoying his largest outpouring of personal acclaim in nearly nine years of leadership.

title: I. C. C. Denies Bids to Dismiss The Rock Island Merger Case
description: The Interstate Commerce Commissiion yesterday denied petitions by a number of railroads to dismisi the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad merger case.

title: Stadium Worker Killed
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (UPI) Lorenzo Cox, 19 years old, a maintenance worker at Veterans Stadium, was killed early yesterday when a motorized golf cart he was riding, crashed through a railing of an upper deck and plunged 50 feet to another ramp.

title: REARING DENIED IN BIAGGI APPEAL
description: An appeals court refused yesterday to grant a rehearing to Representative Mario Biaggi on his appeal against a decision to disclose his grand jury testimony.

title: Fragments Found in Italy Linked to Museum Vase
description: ROME, May 7Italian authorities said today they had found new evidence demonstrating almost conclusively that the Euphronios vase bought by New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art for $1million last year was dug up in Italy and smuggled out.

title: On Ceasefire Team, Women Find Saigon No Place Like Home
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam  A Canadian secretary misses mountains and snow. A Hungarian misses goulash. And the female Polish interpreter misses her husband.

title: BENJAMIN E. FRANKEL
description: Benjamin E. Frankel, vice president of Mead Packaging International, an Atlantabased division of the Mead Corporation, a diversified paper and packaging concern, died Sunday at his home in Atlanta. He was 55 years old.

title: Sale of Stolen Securities Brings 2Y ear Term
description: Godfred Fred Fugger, 54 years old, part owner of a business in New Jersey, was sentenced yesterday to serve two and a half years in prison for conspiring to sell $1.5million in stolen securities through a Bahamanian bank.

title: GIRLS FOUND SLAIN IN SOUTH IDENTIFIED
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., May 8 (AP)A New Jersey father has identified the bodies of two girls found slain last week as those of his daughters.

title: Immense Solar Flares in 72 Had Wide Impact on Earth
description: WASHINGTON, May (AP) Government scientists said today that immense solar flares bombarded the earth with such unprecedented levels of energy last August that they disrupted some defense communications and may have caused homing pigeons to become lost.

title: Tired Ink
description: WASHINGTON, May 7When newspaper people hold a convention they praise themselves as a class and engage in ritual selfcriticism. In this they are just like Elks, Moose, war veterans and the Democratic party. The Republican party is something else. Last summer when the Republican party held a convention in Florida it nearly died of treacle poisoning brought on by selfinflicted sycophancy, but next time will probably be different.

title: Congress Told It Can't Cut Off Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that the bombing of Cambodia would continue even if Congress refused to provide the Pentagon with additional spending authority.

title: ABDUCTED CONSUL IS FREED IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, May 7Terrance G. Leonhardy, the United States consul general kidnapped by a leftist political group last Friday, was released not far from his home In Guadalajara tonight.

title: A Runner Asks a Rider If He's Riding Officially
description: WASHINGTON, May 7It was early one fine May morning on Capitol Hill: the tulips were presumably nodding, the birds gossiping, the senior Senator from Wisconsin running in place, and the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission was on his way to work in his chauffeured limousine.

title: Statement by Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Following is the text of a statement by Elliot L. Richardson:

title: RICHARDSON VOWS NEW PROSECUTOR
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 Elliot L. Richardson announced today that if he was confirmed by the Senate as Attorney General he would appoint a special prosecutor to conduct the investigation of the Watergate case.

title: For the People
description: For too long the reins of the Watergate investigation have been held in the hands of the very people being investigated. The people of the United States have a right to demand that the investigation immediately be put into the hands of an independent, able, special counsel who will act for the people, in whom they can have full confidence and who will have full authority to look down every dark alley of the whole affair.

title: Senate Passes Assembly's Version of Antidrug Bill
description: ALBANY, May 7  Amid charges by seven dissenting Democrats that it was a fraud aimed at deluding the public, the Senate completed legislanye action today on the final version of Governor Rockefeller's legislation providing for harsher penalties for traffickers in dangerous drugs.

description: On any normal business day, Joseph M. Hreno and Robert H. Feld get on the telephones in their dingy office in the Municipal Building and, within a few hours, buy hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Federal and state obligations.

title: OFFICER IS ACCUSED OF ACCEPTING BRIBE
description: A policeman has been arrested on charges of having accepted protection money form a Bronx gambling opetation.

title: Need for Independence
description: The glimpse the country has had thus far into the systematic perversion of governmental process in the Watergate scandal and the Ellsberg trial emphasizes the need for a genuinely independent special prosecutor to uncover the full extent of this conspiracy.

title: Eudora Welty Honored By Native Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 7Eudora Welty, who received a Pulitzer Prize today, was honored last week by her home state as the nation's foremost lady of letters.

title: Pathet Lao Is Disengaged From Indochina Alliance
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 7 (UPI)A spokesman for the Communist Pathet Lao said today that the organization has disengaged itself from an alliance with North Vietnam, the Vietcong and Cambodian Communists because Laos and other nations of Indochina must now solve their own problems independently and separately.

title: EXAIDE IN CAMPAIGN IS DISMISSED BY BUTZ.
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) A former official of the Committee for the Reelection of the President, Robert C. Odle Jr., was abruptly dropped from an Agriculture Department post today less than a week after he was hired, officials said. Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz ordered the action.

description: WASHINGTON, May 7  In the summer and fall of 1971, President Nixon and members of his staff were disturbed and angry about a series of news leaks that they felt involved national security matters.

description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., May 7 Two leaders of American Conservative Judalsm today called on Israel's leaders and people not to denigrate or dominate the Diaspora (Jews living outside of Israel), emphasizing that the welfare of Israel depended on viable Jewish communities the world over.

title: New York Catches Up to MiamiRent a Date Here, Too
description: Erni (with an i, please) Adano is a Squire. But his kind of work has nothing to do with bearing armor for some modernday Don Quixote, or owning land in England.

title: SPENCER BRODNEY, 89, RETIRED EDITOR, DIES
description: Spencer Brodney, onetime editor and publisher of Current History, a former monthly review of world affairs, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He was 89 years old and lived in Berkeley. Heights, N. J.

title: The Elderly Take Part in Bronx Week Observance
description: A group of old people watched yesterday as 11 elderly men and women rehearsed the song Mathilda for a variety show to be presented in the Andrew Jackson Senior Center at 125 East 156th Street in the Bronx.

description: Schuyler G. Chapin, who has been acting general manager of the Metropolitan Opera since Goeran Gentele's death last July, is virtually a, certainty to be named today as general manager, with a threeyear contract.

description: Textile workers here and the two major employers bargaining groups reached a tentative settlement last night.

title: City's Vocational Schools Are Refuting Old Criticisms
description: Four years ago, Sylvan Harfenist, a teacher of airconditioning repair at Manhattan VocationalTechnical High School, had a logical idea. He proposed that the Board of Education permit him to move some of his teaching airconditioning units from the classroom benches to the roof terrace, where he could offer his students more realistic practice.

title: Speer Sees Steel Price Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7 The steel industry appears to be heating up to get increases, Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation told newsmen prior to its annual meeting here today.

title: Africans Honor Mosquito As Foe of White Settler
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, May 7 (Agence FrancePresse)The malariacarrying mosquito was honored in Sierra Leone today for making the country the whiteman's grave in past years and preventing Europeans from settling here and setting up another Rhodesia.

description: Voting from nine regional centers with points figured on a 2019.1817.161514131211 basis for the top 10.

description: CHECKPOINT CHEETAH, S. D., May 7Out here, said the United States marshal as he checked his revolver, time seems to stand still.

title: Tobin to Aid Labor Panel
description: Thomas W. Tobin, president of the 225,000member Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, has been appointed consultant to the Labor Management Advisory Panel of the New York State Mediation. Board, Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

title: Stereotypers to Try Again For Newspaper Contract
description: John Kennedy, president of Stereotypers Local 1 said yesterday that the union's membership had authorized the scale committee to go back to the bargaining table with the city's newspapers and make one more try to reach an agreement.

title: CAMBODIAN CHIEFS UNABLE TO AGREE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 7The fourman ruling council formed two weeks ago has still not been able to agree on a premier an a cabinet.

title: Mardian Is Ordered To Answer Queries On a Liddy Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Robert C. Mardian, a former offi cial of President Nixon's campaign organization, sought unsuccessfully today to invoke lawyerclient privilege in refusing to answer some questions posed to him by the Watergate grand jury.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Brown University has received a $900,000 grant from the Kresge Foundation for the reconstruction of several of the university buildings in Providence, R. I., as facilities for the performing arts. The university, however, must raise an additional $1.4million by June, 1976, to receive the grant. The Kresge Foundation, incorporated in 1924, has been making grants in educational, arts and health among other fields.

title: Jersey Law Could Raise Costs of Garbage Disposal for the City
description: Restrictions that New Jersey plans to put into effect this summer on the dumping of New York City's garbage there could force the city into shortterm disposal alternatives costing up to three times the present disposal costs, city officials said yesterday.

title: N.H.L. Playoff
description: April 29Montreal 8, Chicago 3.

title: NEW LIMIT IS SET IN SOYBEAN MART
description: As a result of continued heavy trading in and rising prices of soybeans and soybean meal, officials of the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday increased the daily permissible limit in trading on those commodities. The limit on soybeans went from 15 to 20 cents a bushel and that on soybean meal from $5 to $10 a ton.

title: 5 PHILIPPINE REBELS ARE REPORTED SLAIN
description: MANILA, May 7  Military headquarters yesterday reported a fourhour gun battle during the weekend with a 20man group of rebels near the town of San Antonio in Neuva Ecija Province 70 miles north of here. Five of the rebels were reported killed and one captured.

title: In Time of Inflation, Heed Call of the Wild Onion
description: Gabriel Hechtman has found a way to beat the high price of onionson his way into the city from New Jersey he picks wild ones he spots growing alongside highways.

title: Women's Golf Results
description: Women's Golf Results

title: People in Sports: Colts Sign Jones, L.S.U. Aerial Ace
description: Bert Jones of Louisiana State, who broke most of the college's passing records set by Y. A. Tittle, was signed yesterday to a multiyear contract by the Baltimore Colts. Joe Thomas, the Baltimore general manager, would not disclose the terms, but said, The figure was not out of bounds, but when you get a good commodity in any walk of life, you expect to pay for it.

title: Stock Prices Show Drop As Volume Also Retreats
description: The spirited recovery that carried stocks ahead late last week stalled early yesterday. Prices declined in the slowest trading in three weeks.

title: Flood Threat Eases in Denver As Crest Perils Farm Towns
description: DENVER, May 7 (UPI)The South Platte River receded here today, but down river the crest of its floodwaters, swollen by daylong rains and 20 inches of snow in the mountains, swept through small farming towns in northern Colorado, battering earthen dikes and trapping livestock.

title: SOVIET IS SEEKING A LOAN IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, May 7  The Soviet Union is hoping to borrow $1billion from a group of banks in Europe but is seeking to hold the interest rate to a point where the lenders would barely cover their costs, international banking sources said today.

title: SAIGON SENDS 196 BACK TO VIETCONG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7 (Reuters)A South Vietnamese military spokesman said that 196 civilian prisoners were released at Quang Tri city below the demilitarized zone today.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Lebanese Battles Resume; New Premier Steps Down
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, May 8  New fighting erupted here last night between Palestinian guerrillas and the Lebanese Army, and the Government declared a state of emergency, placing the country under martial law. Heavy cannon, rocket and automatic weapon fire was reported for more than an hour near the Shatila and Burj alBarajneh refugee camps.

title: Needham Names Advisers
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of a ninemember committee to advise him on securities industry matters affecting the Big Board's regional member firms. The committee has elected George M. Ferris Jr., president of Ferris & Co., Inc., of Washington D. C., as its first chairman.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Senate subcommittee investigating multinational corporations announced today a new questionnaire to these companies aimed at learning about their foreigncurrency operations during the international monetary turmoil earlier this year.

title: ALBANY APPROVES AIRPORT RAIL LINK
description: ALBANY, May 7The Assembly today gave final legislative approval to a bill permitting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to build an express rail link between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport in Queens.

title: CzechWest German Talks
description: PRAGUE, May 7 (UPI) Czechoslovakia and West Germany today started negotiations aimed at restoring diplomatic relations, severed since World War II. The Czechoslovak Deputy Foreign Minister Jiri Goetz, I said on April 16 that a treaty normalizing relations could be ready for initialing by the end of June, West German diplomats said the negotiations might produce a nonaggression pact similar to those signed by West Germany last year with Poland and the Soviet Union.

title: Jersey City's Vote Today, Will Affect Byrnes's Race
description: JERSEY CITY, MAY 7Municipal elections that will have an impact beyond their local boundries will be decided tomorrow here and in Camden.

title: EGON HOSTOYSKY, CZECH AUTHOR, 66
description: MILLBURN, N. J., May 7Egon Hostovsky, former Czechoslovak diplomat and the author of 14 psychological and symbolic novels, 7 of which have been translated into English, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 65 years old and lived here at 879 Ridgewood Road.

title: State Welfare Aides Said to Want a Unit To Determine Policy
description: A study of the New York State Board of Social Welfare released yesterday reported considerable support among public officials and social agencies for a restoration of some of the policymaking powers the board lost two years ago.

title: Reiser, Cub Coach, Leaves Hospital After Giant Brawl
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May (AP)  Pete Reiser, a Chicago Cubs coach who was knocked unconscious during a CubsSan Francisco Giants baseball brawl, was discharged today from hospital after spending a night under obeservation.

title: CLAIRE H. STRAUSS
description: Claire H. Strauss, secretary of the Craft Students League) Committee of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, died Sunday At New York Hospital. Her age was 67.

title: Notes on People
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, perhaps the most dashing Prime Minister in Canada's history, said that he intended to tone himself down, sartorially. On a, tour through Ontario, Mr. Trudeau recalled with some rue the time he appeared in the House of Commons in sandals and an ascot: It was a warm day and I happened to be dressed that way, so I went realized it caused a bit fir a flutter and the Speaker didn't like and I never did it again.

title: Voluntary Controls On Gasoline Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Administration expects to announce within a week a voluntary system of allocating scarce gasoline supplies and possibly other petroleum products, official sources disclosed today.

title: Ron Turcotte Goes 0 for 5 At Aqueduct
description: They cheered Ron Turcotte at Aqueduct yesterday when he detached his horse from the firstrace post parade and galloped her alone past the stands.

title: Search Finds Five Children
description: TOWNSEND, Mass., May 7 (AP)Five chidren of a Mason, N. H., family who wandered off into the woods near their home were found safe across the Massachusetts border in Townsend following a threehour search yesterday. The children of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Gendron became lost and more than 200 searchers including men and aircraft from Fort Devens took part in the search.

title: 20 Seized in Looting of Queens Store
description: More than 20 youths were arrested yesterday afternoon when they were allegedly found looting a supermarket in South Jamaica, Queens, that had been closed for a week because of neighborhood disturbances following the police shooting of a 10yearold boy.

title: GOSS OUTPOINS JOSE FERNANDEZ
description: Sammy Goss of Trenton, the secondranked junior lightweight in the world, won a unanimous 10round decision over Jose Fernandez of New York in the Felt Forum last night before an enthusiastic crowd of 2,576 fans.

title: PANTHER BURIED IN U.S. CEMETERY
description: Zayd Malik Shakur, a former minister of information for the Harlem chapter of the Black Panther party, who was killed in a gun battle with New. Jersey state troopers last week, was buried yesterday in a simple Islamic rite.

title: Cambodian Official Derides Sihanouk Visit as a Fake
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 7 (UPI) The spokesman for the Cambodian High Command said today that the reported trip to Cambodia in February by Prince Norodom Sihantouk, the exiled former chief of state, was a fake and that If he had come here he would not go back alive.

title: City Drafts Apology to Beaten Diplomat
description: The City of New York drafted a formal apology yesterday to the Liberian diplomat hospitalized after he was beaten early Sunday, by a group of white youths in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan.

title: No More Free Hand
description: American and South Vietnamese officials are making detailed charges of a substantial North Vietnamese military buildup in the northern provinces of South Vietnam. The most important developments alleged seem to be the construction of a major logistics base at Khe Sanh and a new road from there through the Ashau Valley to the vicinity of Da Nang.

title: 1954 Defeat of French Is Celebrated by Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 7 (Agence FrancePresse)  The North Vietnamese leadership today marked the 19th anniversary of Dien Bien Phu with exhortations for hard work, increased productivity and unending dynamic struggle for national liberation, the building of socialism, and reconstruction.

title: New Agency Will Enforce Mine Safety
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Interior Department took away from the Bureau of Mines today its mine safety inspection and enforcethent powers and transferred them to a new Mine Safety Enforcement Administration.

title: Negotiations to Resume Today In Statewide Carpenters Strike
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May (UPI)  A building contractor's spokesman said today that Federal intervention might speed up a settlement in the statewide carpenters strike, which enters its second week tomorrow.

title: C.M. Payouts in Half Are Highest Since 66
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday dividends paid in the first six months of this year were the highest in the first half since 1966.

title: Analysts Are Told That Fluctuation Will Be Less
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, lectured Members of the Financial Analysts Federation today about their pessimism concerning the economic outlook.

title: Cardinal Larraona Dies at 85; Vatican Expert on ChurchLaw
description: ROME, May 7  Arcadio Maria Cardinal Larraona, the first member of the Claretian Fathers to become a Cardinal, died here today. He was 85 years old.

title: 30 Doctors in Jersey City Stage OffDuty Job Action Over Pay
description: JERSEY CITY, May 7 More than 30 staff internes and residents marched in front of the Jersey City Medical Center today in what they said was the first job action protest by physicians at a hospital in New Jersey.

title: Strike Over, Deliveries Of Mail Resume in Italy
description: ROME, May 7  Many Italians found stamped letters in their mailboxes this morning for the first time in three weeks.

title: Attorney General Appeals To Court on School Funds
description: TRENTON, May 7  The State Attorney General challenged today the power of the State Supreme Court to redistribute legislative appropriations for public education in accordance with its finding a month ago that financing school aid solely through local property taxes was unconstitutional.

title: Time to Vote
description: For several iweeks an informal coalition of some Republicans and Southern Democrats has been conducting a quiet filibuster in the Senate against a bill to permit voter registration by postcard. Supporters of the bill have abundantly demonstrated that inconveniently located registration offices, inadequate time and arbitrary deadlines make it unnecessarily difficult for wouldbe voters to get their names on the registration lists. These manmade obstacles explain to a considerable extent why the United States has the lowest rate of political participation of any democracy.

title: India Reported to Foil Threat to Aussie Team
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 7 (UP)  Massive security precautions are believed to have foiled a planned attack on Australia's Davis Cup tennis team by proPakistan, terrorists in India, a journalist accompanying the team reported today.
