description: Things for Youngsters to Do and See

title: Men at Home in the Daylight
description: I don't want to read one more column or editorial expressing the belief that Watergate should be resolved in a way that enables us to keep on trusting in the Presidency.

title: Chinese Art Treasures Thrill Paris
description: PARIS, May 8A spectac ularly beautiful exhibition of ancient art treasures never before seen outside China had its world premiere here tonight. Tomorrow it goes on view to the public at the Petit Palais museum just off the ChampsElyses.

title: VIETCONG SAY SAIGON SPRAYED CHEMICALS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8 (UPI)The Vietcong charged today that Saigon troops fighting in a Communistheld area had sprayed toxic chemicals that ruined more than 1,500 acres of land and caused serious illness to large numbers of persons.

title: Inquiry on Compensation Told of Nontreatment Fee
description: TRENTON, May 8 A young woman injured in an automobile accident in 1969 testified before the State Commission of Investigation today that she had been referred to a physician who treated her six times by putting her in a closet with a heat lamp and dark glasses and then billed her law firm for 39 treatments.

title: F.B.I. Recovers $303,000 Extorted by Jet Hijacker
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the recovery of the entire $303,000 in extortion money paid to the hijacker of an Eastern Air Lines jet airline who bailed out over Honduras last May.

title: Bingham Urges New Election
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, called today for new Presidential elections as the best solution to the Watergate scandal.

title: Radio
description: 68:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Don Quichotte Suite, Telemann; Trumpet Concerto in D, Hertel; Symphony No. 2 in E fiat, C.P.E. Bach.

title: PRESSURE REPORTED ON KROGH TO RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Egil Krogh Jr., former White House aide, was reported under intense pressure today to resign as Under Secretary of Transportation because of his admitted role in the Ellsberg case.

title: Tropical Paradise Battles Urban Ills
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaA lot of people in the United States and Europe tend to think of the Caribbean as a lot of palmfringed islands where nobody has a care, said Moses Matalon, chairman of the Urban Development Corporation of Jamaica. Actually, we have massive urban problems in this part of the world.

title: IN EAST GERMANY, FRESH AIR IN ARTS
description: BERLIN, May 6A breath of spring air pervades the East German cultural scene these days, to the relief of millions.

title: Hod, Israeli Air Chief, Is Retiring Tomorrow
description: TEL AVIV, May 8Maj. Gen. Mordecai Hod, commandant of the Israel Air Force during the ArabIsraeli War of June, 1967, is retiring.

title: Union Victory Claim in School Vote Disputed
description: Andrew Donaldson, the superintendent of District 9 in the Bronx, yesterday disputed the claims of victory by candidates supported by the United Federation of Teachers in the local school board races although the results showed that five unionbacked candidates had won.

title: Girl, 16, and Fiance Die in Apparent Suicide Pact
description: A 16yearold girl about to graduate from a Lower East Side preparatory school for children of disadvantaged families was found dead with her 23yearold fianc is an East Village apartment yesterday.

title: A LAG IS REPORTED IN BIDDING ON GAS
description: Government purchasing officials in the metropolitan area and in other parts of the country have begun to look into contingency plans for rationing gasoline for official cars because oil companies have not been eager to bid on contracts for future gasoline supplies.

title: Libraries Put Out Lights In National Fund Protest
description: At noon yesterday, the lights went out in the Hunts Poin branch of the New York Pub  lic Library. In fact, lights were dimmed or turned off in libr  aries throughout the country thought not from a loss on power.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: KANSAS CITYOptioned Tom Burgmeler lefthanded relief pitcher, to Omaha the American Association. Recalled Jim Wohiford, outfielder, from Omaha.

title: Mitchell Contends 2d Ellsberg Study Was News to Him
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was quoted by the American Broadcasting Company yesterday as saying that he never knew the White House was conducting its own investigation of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's release of the Pentagon papers, and that the case might not have been prosecuted if he had.

title: Charles E. Canfield, Chairman Of Family Paper Concern, Dies
description: ARLINGTON, Vt., May 8Charles E. Canfield, board chairman of the Canfield Paper Company of New York, died Sunday at Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington. He was 72 years old and had lived here since his retirement in 1963.

title: Elderly Serenaded as Part of Bronx Week
description: About 150 members of senior citizen centers braved a chill drizzle yesterday to dance and clap to Dixieland music blaring from the gazebo of Poe Park as the celebration of Bronx Week continued with a salute to the elderly.

title: Hunt Was Given Access To 240 Vietnam Cables
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The State Department acknowledged today that E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate conspirator, was given access to secret Vietnam diplomatic cables in 1971 at the request of David R. Young Jr., then a White House aide.

title: ORDER AGAINST I.B.111. UPHELD ON APPEAL
description: The United States Court of Appeals; in a 4to2 decision, upheld here yesterday a Federal District Court order for the International Business Machines Corporation to produce some 1,200 business documents that I.B.M. says are confidential.

title: A. Cheerful Mentor of the Opera Schuyler Garrison Chapin
description: By, the time he was 13 years old, Schuyler Garrison. Chapin was quite sure that he wanted to be involved in music. Yesterday, in his 51st year, he was made the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. He is thus assured of being involved in music in the way that a boy who falls into a vat molasses may be said to be involved in molasses. A dozen years ago, in a moment of reverie, when anything is possible even when it is not probable, Mr. Chapin saw himself in the job he now occupies as top man at the Met. His secret thought was that if a genie rises out of a bottle and says, What do you want? I'd say, I'd like to be general manager of the Met.

title: Australian Workers Win Increases Averaging 4%
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 8  Australian workers were awarded substantial raises today by the National Arbitration Commission, the fiveman body that periodically reviews and adjusts pay levels for employes governed by federal labor standards. The action added fuel to the national controversy over inflation.

title: Silent Majority Injured And. Retired from Racing,
description: MONTREAL, May 8(Canadian Press)Silent Majority, the outstanding 4yearold pacer named Canadian horse of the year for 1972, will not race again.

title: DeBusschere the Hero On 'Lucky Shot in Clutch
description: It was the key play of the game, said Jerry West of the Lakers last night, looking back on Dave DeBusschere's 3pointplay, rebound that stopped a late Los Angeles rally and helped the Knicks to a 10398 victory last night.

title: Judge Delays Shift Of Vesco's Funds To Bahamas Bank
description: A Federal judge signed an order here last night delaying the transfer of $3,675,000 from Florida to the Bahamas by an associate of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who is being sought in connection with the funding of President Nixon's reelection campaign, until a Government challenge to the transfer can be heard.

title: The Novice: Another Day Another Long Shot
description: One of these days, Tom Campanelli and Diane Heiss are going to get to ride a horse with a chance of winning.

title: Terrorisin in Mexico
description: It is a great relief that the United States Consul General in Guadalajara has been released unharmed after his kidnapping and imprisonment for three days by a leftwing Mexican guerrilla organization.

title: DONALD PAYNE
description: Donald Payne, a retired vice president of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency, died Monday at his home, 960 Sycamore Avenue, New Shrewsbury, N. J. He was 78 years old.

title: ISADORE BOOKSTEIN, EXSTATE JUSTICE, 82
description: ALBANY, May 8 (AP)Isadore Bookstein, a retired Supreme Court justice, died today at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Italian Police Sources Describe Fragments Linked to Met Vase
description: ROME, May 8Police sources today described pottery fragments found in Italy and linked to the Euphronios vase in New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art as of the length of an average package of cigarettes and rather narrower.

title: 3 CharterFlight Bookers Cited on Criminal Charges
description: Charter Flight Promoters Cited on Criminal Charges available this year allowed members of the general public to fly legitimately on cheap charter flights if they signed up 90 days in advance.

title: Japanese Tourists Swarm Into Hawaii
description: LIHUE, KAUAI, Hawaii The scene seemed to be repeated endlessly. The young man placed the young woman so she had her back to the white foam on the surf, whipped up by the strong trade winds. He held a light meter to her smiling face.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal Appeals Court here set the week of June 4 to hear an appeal by Mrs. Hermine Braunsteiner. Ryan on a decision to extradite her to West Germany on charges that she murdered inmates in a Nazi concentration camp.

title: People and Business
description: Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that I don't think there will be any general or substantial tightening of the [wageprice] control system. Then he added, We can't keep changing the rules of the game.

title: Big Oil Companies Lead Price Declines on Market
description: Stocks of big worldwide oil companies declined sharply late yesterday after their negotiations in Libya with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were reported to have ended in failure.

title: Increased Albany Pay
description: Proposals now awaiting action in Albany to boost the salaries of members of the State Legislature are excessive under present conditions and should be scaled down sharply.

title: State Senate Votes to Cut Terms of Current Regents to Seven Years
description: ALBANY, May 9  The Senate voted today to reduce the terms of members of the Board of Regents from 15 years to seven. Present board members would be affected by the change.

title: Ziegler Says Reports That Nixon Tried to Block Ellsberg Data Are Unfounded
description: WASHINGTON, May 9After more than a day of silence, the White House sought today to put down reports that President Nixon had tried to prevent the Justice Department from providing to the Pentagonpapers trial in Los Angeles information on the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Tornado Kills Two
description: LAKEVILLE, Minn., May (UPI)A tornado tore through a trailer court in Lakeville today, causing two deaths and injuring more than a dozen persons, the authorities said.

title: CAHILL IS QUERIED ON FUNDS REPORT
description: TRENTON, May 9 (AP) A Republican booster club barred two reporters from its meeting today on the ground that their, presence would inhibit questions the members wanted to ask Governor Cahill, the organization's guest. Some of the questions, a G.O.P. official said later, centered on allegations of irregularities in Mr. Cahill's 1969 campaign.

title: SONESTA SHARES TARGET IN DEAL
description: Wellington Associates announced yesterday it was offering to purchase for cash up to one million common shares or the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation at $7 net a share.

title: Vote Held Aid to Hudson Coalition
description: JERSEY CITY, May 9Mayor Paul T. Jordan's overwhelming victory in yesterday's city election was viewed by political leaders here today as proof of a lasting desire for reform by city voters and as projecting the new county Democratic Coalition into a potent force in state party councils.

title: 2 TRACK ATHLETES FREE TO COMPETE
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association modified their stand yesterday against two track athletes who competed for the United Statets against the Soviet Union last March 16. As a result, Fred Samara of the University of Pennsylvania and Dennis Walker of Adelphi University can compete in major meets Saturday without fear of reprisal from the E.C.A.C. or N.C.A.A.

title: Group Asks EqualTime Data Of Networks on Children's TV
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The Media Access Project, a publicinterest law group, has written to each of the three major networks demanding information on how much if anything, the networks have broadcast concerning current controversies over children's programs and advertising aimed at children.

title: Workers at Rheingold Accept NoRaise Pact
description: A threeyear labor agree ment reached yesterday between Rheingold Breweries, Inc., and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Locals 3 and 46 calls for no increase in the wage rate.

title: Deaf Man Suffers A Loss of Memory In Bronx Mugging
description: A 42yearold deaf man lost his memory and his ability to speak when he was mugged on wandering through the Bronx Sunday and had apparently been for more than three days before he was brought into a hospital by a friend last night, hospital officials reported.

title: Noel A. Rhys, an Executive Of Keystone Broadcasting
description: Noel A. Rhys, executive vice president of the Keystone Broadcasting System, which includes radio stations in many parts of the country, died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 350 East 52d Street.

title: Saigon Says Chau Must Serve 7 Remaining Years
description: In an unrelated case yesterday, Nguyen Tan Doi, another member of the National Assembly and the head of South Vietnam's largest bank, was sent to prison despite his immunity because of charges that he had embezzled millions of dollars in investors funds. He was taken to Chi Hoa Prison, where Mr. Chau has been kept.

title: 10 TRUNK AIRLINES SEE HIGHER 73 NET
description: Earnings of the nation's 10 domestic trunklinesthe major carriersshould rise this year to about $250million from the 1972 level of $215million, according to George W. James, senior vice president economics and finance of the Air Transport Association.

title: New Atomic Shells Ordered by Army
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Unknown to Defenie Secretary Elliot L. Richardson, the Army has ordered several thousand new nuclear shells for its large cannons in Europe.

title: Six Missing Listed as Killed
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Defense Department announced today that six servicemen previously listed as missing in Indochina had been declared dead as a result of hostile action. There remain 1,329 men listed as missing. Among the six is Maj. George M. Jourdenais, of the Air Force, whose widow lives at Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York.

title: Yankees Redefine Burke's New Role
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 9George M. Steinbrenner 3d, who has avoided discussing the Michael Burke situation in the Yankee front office ever since Burke resigned as chief executive officer April 29, now says Burke is remaining with the club in a public relations role.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: 51st State and the Problems of Local Coverage
description: Half the reporting staff was dismissed last week. The current season, set to end next week, has been cut short by couple of weeks. And the budg et remains an object for juggling. But The 51st State ha: been committed to another season by the management of WNET/13. Behind that commitment is a tangle of strains and stress, News internal and exter. Analysis nal, that bring: into focus some of the problems of local news coverage on television in general and on public television in particular.

title: ROGAN CENSURES VANDEN HEUVEL
description: District Attorney Frank B. Hogan yesterday made his sharpest attack to date against William vanden Heuvel, his opponent in the coming Demo cratic primary, asserting that Mr. vanden Heuvel had math reckless and irresponsible charges about the way the District Attorney's office had handied a controversial murder case.

title: Dollar Off Again; Gold Price Rises On Free Market
description: LONDON, May 9 (AP)The United States dollar fell sharply on Europe's main money markets today and the price of freemarket gold rose to new highs.

title: People in Sports: Riggs Taking 'Side Action
description: I'm out to prove that a guy 55 years old, with one foot in the grave, can play with the best woman in the world and maybe beat her, said Bobby Riggs as he prepared for his twoofthree set, winnertakeall $10,000 tennis match on Sunday with Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in Ramona, Calif.

title: New Atomic Shells Ordered by Army
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 Unknown to Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson, the Army has ordered several thousand new nuclear shells for its large cannons in Europe.

title: Notes on People
description: Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General has left the law firm of Paul Weiss RifkindWharton & Garrison to devote all my time to matters that I thought were important, and that's a little incompatible with the general practice of law.

title: Four Vying for Court Run a Dignified Race
description: Three judges and a successful, trial lawyer are campaigning for the privilege of running on the Democratic ticket for the highest judicial post in the state  chief judge of the Court of Appealsin the first primary race for the office since 1916.

title: ExEnvoy Says U.S. Pays For 15,000 Thais in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A Nixon Administration official told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that despite the Vietnam and Laos ceasefires, 15,000 to 20,000 Thai Nregular troops  financed by the United Stateswere now based in Laos.

title: Prison Search Turns Up 170 Weapons and Whisky
description: ELMIRA, N.Y., May 9 (AP) A 24hour search at Elmira State Correctional Facility turned up 170 handmade weapons and 700 items of contraband including whisky, officials said today.

title: DRUG LAW SCORED BY A LINDSAY AIDE
description: Branding Governor Rockefeller's new narcotics law as cruel and regressive, the Lindsay administration predicted yesterday that it would cost the courts in the city an additional $127million in the first year and said it would promptly ask the state to appropriate that amount.

title: ENVOY WON'T REPLY TO FULBRIGHT QUERY
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, today ask e d Graham A. Martin, former Ambassador to Italy, whether he had recommended the use of secret United States Government funds to influence Italian politics.

title: Barzel Quits as Bonn's Opposition Chief
description: BONN, May 9Rainer Barzel resigned today as the Opposition leader in Parliament after a majority of his followers rejected his strategy for opposing ratification of the treaty to establish formal relations between the two Germanys.

title: Doctors Urged Not to Call Homosexuality Illness
description: HONOLULU, May 9 (AP)A highranking official of the American Psychiatric Association urged the organization today to stop labeling homosexuality as a mental illness.

title: 21 Mal TAKES TOBOGGAN SPRINT
description: Tentam of the Cragwood Stable won the $27,850 Toboggan Handicap at foggy Aqueduct yesterday, to the satisfaction of the form players in the crowd of 17,163 as well as to his rider, Jorge Velasquez.

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: British Movie Chain Drops Last Ten Days Screenings
description: LONDON, May 9 (Canadian Press)The film Hitler: The Last Ten Days, was banned by one of Britain's biggest movie chains today because its chairman considered it too sympathetic to the Nazi leader.

title: Arthur Daley
description: One expression that athletes favor for explaining spectacular performances is this: My hands felt thin.

title: Discipline of Saving
description: United States Savings Bond are tailormade for people who find it difficult to save money that is especially true for chose win vow they will take a little out of each paycheck and save it, but never do. United States Savings Bonds are easy to buy and are indestructible.

title: TEXAS GAS CALLS PROJECTS RISKY
description: The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation is going slow on liquefied natural gas and synthetic natural gas projects because they are too risky at this stage, W. M. Elmer, chairman, told about 70 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at 20 Pine Street.

title: Deputies Scuffle in Rome
description: ROME, May 9 (AP)  Members of the Chamber of Deputies, traded punches and kicks and swung chairs in a 10minute melee today. The scuffle between Communists and neoFascists began after sharp exchanges during debate over recent political violence in Italy.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CLEVELANDPlaced Mike Kilkenny, lefthanded relief nitcher, an waivers. NEW YORKSigned Randall Braxton, Short step, as free agent and assigned him to Oneonta,

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The New York City Ballet has announced that its two premieres of the season will be Cortege Hongrois, set to Glazunov music by George Balanchine, on May 17, and An Evening's Waltzes, to five Prokofiev waltzes, by Jerome Robbins, on May 24.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Connally Says Nixon Has Not Offered Job
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 9 (UPI)Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally said today that President Nixon had not offered him a post in Washington, but he indicated that he might accept a position if requested by the President.

title: Nixon Says Aides Will Get To Bottom of the Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, May 9President Nixon assured Republican leaders and contributors tonight that his appointees would get to the bottom of this very deplorable Watergate scandal, and that the scandal would not paralyze the Government.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: F.T. D. Has Left Telegraph Era
description: F.T.D., which used to be the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association, has becone Florists Transworld Delivery, because the 13,000 members now telephone their orders to each other. Soon the system expects to be transmitting by Teletype, telex, photocopier and even microwave.

title: Rap Brown Sentenced
description: H. Rap Brown drew a 5to15year prison sentence for his role in the armed robbery of a West Side bar in 1971. Two codefendants of the black militant received similar sentences. Page 12.

title: RICHARDSON SEEKS BURDEN OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 Elliot L. Richardson told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that, if he became Attorney General, he would maintain ultimate responsibility for the Watergate investigation and prosecution.

title: $200,000 DONATION
description: An indictment is expected here today against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans and Robert L. Vesco, a missing financier, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: 2 GROUPS DIVIDED
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Senate and Federal investigators say that, on the basis of extended interviews with John W. Dean 3d, they believe he has no evidence to link President Nixon either to prior knowledge of the Watergate bugging or to any subsequent coverup, reliable sources said today.

title: Marine Jet Crashes
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) A Marine attack jet crashed about 20 feet from a suburban Montgomery County house last night, but no injuries were reported, state police said. The plane, an A4 Skyhawk, was approaching Willow Grove when it crashed. The pilot ejected safely.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Yankees, Mayor's Trophy game, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (RadioWHN, WMCA, 8 P.M.) N.Y.U. at Fordham, 3:30 P.M. (RadioWFUVFM, 3:20 P.M.)

title: Earl R. Miller, Bodyguard For Smith and Roosevelt
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., May 9Lieut. Comdr. Earl R. Miller, U.S.N., retired, who wasa bodyguard to Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt when they were Governors of New York, died here last Wednesday. He was 75 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Yankees, Mayor's Trophy game, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stan are expected to be indicted today in connection with a secret $200,000 Contribution to, President Nixon's, 1972 campaign, sources close to the investigation said yesterday. The former Cabinet members are expected to be charged with participating in a scheme to obstruct justice by accepting the contribution from Robert L. Vesco in exchange for an effort to influence a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the financier. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, May 9 Carnegie Lake, which is owned by Princeton University, should soon be the center intercollegiate and international rowing for the East Coast, according to Peter Sparhawk, the Princeton rowing coach. Princetdn crew alumni have raised money to construct permanently buoyed Olympic race course on the lake.

title: Sailors to Be Deported
description: TACOMA, Wash., May 9 (UPI) Immigration authorities said yesterday that four Greek sailors who left the Liberianregistry Atlantic Falcon will be deported as soon as possible. The four left the ship Monday, alleging that they had not received promised pay and that the food was bad.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: With winners announced in all but one of the 32 districts, the May 1 local schoolboard elections in New York City showed a weak voter turnout of about 11 per cent of the 3.5 million eligible voters and a large measure of success by candidates backed by the United Federation of Teachers or parents groups, or both.

title: That Championship Season (II) Is Close
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9One more victory is all the New York Knicks need to win the National Basketball Association championship and to overcome finally the effects of a shock they suffered two years three Weeks ago.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BALTIMORE; May 9. (UPI)Neil Hellman said today there was a possibility he would enter Linda's Chief in the Preakness on May 19 as a challenge to Secretariat's bid for the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: ELECTION FUNDING BY PUBLIC URGED
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Senate Democrats unanimous ly adopted today a policy reso  lution calling for public finan  cing of all Federal elections.

title: Nixon Says Aides Will Get To Bottom of the Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, May 9President Nixon assured Republican leaders and contributors tonight that his appointees would get to the bottom of this very deplorable Watergate scandal, and that the scandal would not paralyze the Government.

title: Box Scores of Major League Gaines
description: Box Scores of Major League Gaines

title: Results of Equity Audit Are Expected by July 1
description: CHICAGO; May 9 (Reuters) The Illinois Department of insurance expects to know by July 1 how many of the Equity Funding Life Insurance company's policies are bogus, Fred A. Mauck, director of the agency, said today.

title: LEFKOWITZ CHIDES GASOLINE MAKERS
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he had received so little cooperation from major oil companies in his investigation into gasoline shortages that he might be forced to subpoena their records by the end of this week.

title: HANOI ACCUSES U.S. OF P.O.W. TORTURES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (UPI)North Vietnam today broadcast its first posttruce charge that Americans had tourtured Communist prisoners, alleging atrocities that ranged from brutal beatings to surgical experiments.

title: Once, Drugs Got Him Through the DayNow His Bakery Does
description: LOS ANGELESFor 17 of his 43 years, Robert Deal started  and ended  each day with bad stuff: narcotics.

title: Listing of Prices for Transactions in Commodity Futures
description: Cotton Markets Open Interest

title: Needham Says Needs of Public Outweigh Duty to Employers
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The head of the New York Stock Exchange urged the Financial Analysts Federation today to adopt severe disciplinary sanctions against members who advise investor clients on the basis of inside information.

title: Pakistanis Eject Arabs
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 9The Pakistani police removed Arab students today from the Lebanese Embassy in Rawalpindi after they occupied it for more than six hours and damaged furniture in protest against military action against guerrilla camps in the Lebanon.

title: Rule Backing Client Profiles at Pharmacies Lauded
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 9Court approval of a new rule requiring druggists to keep medical profiles of their customers was described as a great victory today by Millicent H. Fenwick, director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: The Adversaries
description: We have had our differences in the past, and I hope you give me hell every time you think I'm wrong. I hope I'm worthy of your trust, President Nixon told a few members of the White House press corps after he concluded his Watergate speech. The remark was widely reported and some thought it signaled a change in the ugly relationship between the White House and the Washington press corps.

title: People in Sports: Riggs Taking Side Action
description: Im out to prove that a guy 55 years old, with one foot in the grave, can play with the best woman in the world and maybe beat her, said Bobby Riggs as he prepared for his twoofthree set, winnertakeall $10,000 tennis match on Sunday with Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in Hernona, Calif.

title: U.S. Aides File Affidavits With Ellsberg Trial Judge
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9Four Justice Department officials, including Henry E. Petersen, an Assistant Attorney General, swore today that they did not know about the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsbergs psychiatrist until April 16 this year.

title: Major Stores Called Before Federal Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in Philadelphia is investigating Justice Department charges that several major stores in New York, Philadelphia and other cities conspired to fix prices on women's dresses and other apparel items.

title: Mrs. Marguerite Norton, 88, Directed Henry St. Nurses
description: Mrs. Marguerite Wales Norton, who was general director of nurses of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, now the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, from 1923 to 1936, died Tuesday in Joshua Tree, Calif. The day was her 88th birthday.

title: $200,000 DONATION
description: An indictment is expected here today against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans and Robert L. Vesco, a missing financier according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Bradley Hails West Point As He Gets Thayer Award
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 9 General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, the country's only living fivestar officer and one of the last surviving and most honored heroes of World War II, today received the honor he said he prized above all othersthe 16th Sylvanus Thayer Award of the United States Military Academy.

title: Korean Red Cross Talks Seek to Break Deadlock
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9  North and South Korea opened the sixth session of their Red Cross talks here today in an attempt to break a deadlock over basic principles in arranging family contacts between the two Koreas.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: NEW RULES URGED FOR DRUG TESTING
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  A consumer advocacy group petitioned the Food and Drug Administration today to revise its regulations on drug testing to prevent potentially dangerous drugs from being given to humans before animal safety testing is complete.

title: Vietcong Propose New Truce Plan; Saigon Rejects It
description: PARIS, May 9 (AP)The Vietcong proposed today threepoint plan for a new ceasefire to put an end to the fighting throughout South Vietnam. It was immediately rejected by Saigon.

title: Beach Insurance Rates Cut
description: TRENTON, May 9 (AP)State Insurance Commisioner Richard C. McDonough said today that the cost of obtaining public liability insurance for New Jersey's beaches that charge admission fees was cut in half this year. Most of the beaches are operated by

title: SEARCH IN MEXICO YIELDS SUSPECTS
description: MEXICO CITY, May 9 (Reuters)The Mexican police held five men in Guadalajara today in connection with the kidnapping of the United States Consul General, Terrance G. Leonhardy, authorities said here.

title: LAVER TRIUMPHS IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: DALLAS, May 9 (AP)  Rod Laver survived a shaky start and defeated his fellow Australian Roy Emerson, 75, 62, 75, in the opening match of, the $100,000 World Championship of Tennis circuit finals tonight. In the second match, Stan Smith, the favorite, crushed John Alexander of Australia, 64, 62, 75. Smith was so deevastating that at one point during the match Alexander climbed into the seats and sat down in a chair to join the crowd in applause.

title: Slack Performance
description: The Assembly passed last week a regressive little bill that would cripple efforts to expand voter registration New York City. Three of the city's boroughs now have such poor voter participation as to be technically subject to provisions of Federal voting laws designed to prevent discrimination against minority groups in the Deep South. Far from clearing the way for improvement in this disgraceful record, the Assembly's bill would prevent the Board of Elections from using voluntary registrars of the kind the League of Women Voters and Frontlash used last year to sign up many firsttime voters.

title: Bridge: New Exhibition Procedure Has Tones of 2Ring Circus
description: MEXICO CITY, May 9A new and significant idea in the presentation of exhibition matches was introduced into this hemisphere here Monday by the Mexican Bridge Federation, and is likely to find imitators in the United States.

title: CRIME IN SCHOOLS LAID TO INACTION
description: The Board of Education was criticized caustically yesterday by the Health and Education Committee of the City Council for what the committee said was inaction that contributed to the increase in school crime.

title: S.I.A. Members Favor No Fee Rise on Small Trades
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., May 9The Securities Industries Association said today that most brokerage firms that favor an increase in commission rates believe, however, that fees should not be raised on trades under $5,000.

title: Exit Mr. Barzel
description: Rainer Barzel's fate as leader of the Christian Democratic Union and candidate for West German Chancellor was probably sealed last November when Willy Brandt's coalition of Social and Free Democrats won an unexpectedly decisive election victory. Though Mr. Barzel was later reelected leader of the Christian Union opposition in the Bundestag, his displacement well in advance of the next federal election was regarded as inevitable.

title: Concert
description: The extent to which improvisation has returned to serious music, after an eclipse that lasted about a century, was demonstrated in an odd way on Tuesday night when Composers Theater began its fourth annual May Festival of Contemporary American Music at the New School. Getting the series under way was the Clevelandbased Performance Group, which according to a program note concentrates on exacting performances of completely notated new music rather than aleatoric, improvisational or indeterminate works so that each composer's intentions may be realized as precisely as possible.

title: Former Official Asks Not to Be Released to Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9President Nguyen Van Thieu is giving favorable consideration to a petition from Tran Ngoc Chau, a former member of the National Assembly and respected friend of many American officials, requesting that the not be released to the Communists, along with other civilian prisoners, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Judge Finds Ads For Chevron True, Voids F.T.C. Case

title: Screen: 'Last Ten Days':Guinness Plays Hitler in Bunker Episode The Cast
description: "Adolf," Eva Braun says to Hitler at one point during their last 10 days in the Berlin bunker, "you really are the most incredible person. . . ."The film is called "Hitler: The Last Ten Days," and it seems to be factually correct in all major matters. H. R. Trevor-Roper, the British historian and author ("The Last Days of Hitler"), has given it his seal of approval. As a historial re-enactment, however, "Hitler" is about as exciting as a high-minded, parent-approved comic book about the adventures of James Watt and his steam engine.It's only when the screenplay makes its little stabs at what I take to be fiction that it becomes at all interesting and, quite often, dimly funny. As when Eva, just before biting her cyanide capsule, becomes upset because it is apparent that Adolf doesn't give a hang about what happens to the citizens of Berlin, then being laid low by the advancing Soviet Army."Maybe I never knew you," she says with a tear in her eye. It's the sort of realization that in a cartoon would be indicated by the appearance of a light bulb over her head.It is possible that Eva did have such second thoughts. She was in love with Hitler but she wasn't the world's biggest brain. Yet the quality of the speculation in "Hitler" is not worthy of what we know and feel about the subject. The speculation is small and routine. It is as if Ennio de Concini, the Italian director who also wrote the Italian screenplay with Maria Pia Fusco and Wolfgang Reinhardt (son of Max), which was then adapted into English by Ivan Moffat, had set out to transform the banality of evil into a film style.The rise of the Third Reich is one of the most fascinating stories of all time, and its collapse one of the most thoroughly satisfying, supplying, as it does, the fundamental dramatic needs for irrevocable revenge and retribution. The written accounts of these eventsby Shirer, Speer, Trevor-Roper, Toland and othersnever cease to fascinate, even when the prose gets as gummy as a Sunday supplement's. It is curious, then, that a fairly serious-minded film should be so superfluous.One principal reason seems to be that no film can possibly present the accumulation of details and facts that make something like Shirer's "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich" so riveting. It can present only a pictorial view of things and a selection of details.In "Hitler: The Last Ten Days," it is almost impossible to keep the people straight, with the exception of Adolf Alec Guinness), Eva (Doris Kunstmann) and maybe the Goebbelses. The film doesn't seem to have been directed, or acted, as much as cast, in the waxworks sense. Actors play individual characters not because they are actors but because they resemble the people in life.Sometimes, however, they look very wrong. Adolfo Celi looks awfully Italian as General Krebs. Guinness looks right as Hitler, and that's about allbut then Hitler may be an impossible role. Almost anything even a good actor does with such a role risks prompting a certain amount of unintended hilarity. (There are times when Guinness's Hitler reminded me most of Jack Benny.) Those of us who knew Hitler from contemporary newsreels could, I suspect, respond only to a completely fictional character, not one pictured, as Guinness is, in a supposedly objective way. Miss Kunstmann is more successful, probably because we know less of Eva, and most of the other people are news pictures and studio portraits that have come to vogue life.The film covers the period from April 20 through May 1, 1945, and takes place mostly in the bunker under the Chancellery. For anyone unfamiliar with how Hitler got there, the film supplies a sort of "the story to date" outline of Hitler's rise and World II behind the opening credits.

title: A Watergate Casualty
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A former White House aide, Egil Krogh resigned today as Under Secretary of Transportation, saying that his overriding desire was to accept full responsibility for my acts and decisions and to assist in bringing all the facts and circumstances into the open. The 33yearold former top assistant to John D. Ehrlichman, former domestic adviser to President Nixon, assumed the Transportation Department post Feb. 2. In leaving, he said that he was making truth my guide. In his long letter of resignation, addressed to Mr. Nixon but released by the Transportation Department, he gave one of the fullest statements of motivation that have been forthcoming from any of those involved in the incidents growing out of the Watergate affair.

title: Scandal Is Dim Memory at Teapot Dome
description: UNITED STATES NAVAL OIL RESERVE No. 3 (Teapot Dome), Wyo., May 9The sky is wide and high over Teapot Dome, a rolling, even choppy, stretch of brown prairie about five miles south of the twin hamlets of Midwest and Edgerton in northeastern Wyoming. Antelope and deer, jack rabbits and rattlesnakes, outnumber the peoDome pie who frequent the somewhat more than 9,000 acres that comprise this naval reserve oil field. An aging St. Bernard named Clyde, who long since has given up chasing the larger, fleeter game, now contents himself with trying to corner a mischievous chipmunk in an old building put up by Harry F. Sinclair some 50 years ago before the courts made him yield the leases that they decided had illegally given him the right to exploit the oil at Teapot Dome.

title: City Sunset
description: Not enough has ever been said about sunset in the city. Little enough has been said about sunrise, either; few are up to see the sun rise except in the dead winter. But sunset is there, visible, sometimes insistent, every day of the year. Just turn your head and look down the street or across the roofs to the west, and there it is, over there beyond the river, beyond the Jersey shore, out there where the pioneers went a long time ago, and where quite a few of us came from to the city.

title: Residents of Wounded Knee, Stunned By Damage to Homes, Vow to Leave
description: WOUNDED MEE, S. D., May 9The blackbirds were back in Wounded Knee today, singing in the grass. The bunkers were bulldozed over. The prairie winds were smoothing down the dusty soil over a new grave up on the hill.And the first of the 250 displaced residents began to trickle cautiously back, hours after 120 Indian militants ended their 70day occupation of this historic hamlet.But the damage to private property here was so great and the personal shock so stunning that almost as quickly as the unbelieving residents saw what had been done, they vowed to leave.And tonight, the village of Wounded Knee seemed well on the way to becoming a ghost town.The trading post was a mass of burnt metal and cinders. Trash, dirty clothes and garbage were strewn about. The museum was vandalized. The bridge on the road to Porcupine was destroyed. The paved roads were rutted by the tracks of armored personnel carriers. Bullet holes were everywhere.No ElectricityYards were dug up and the foundations were breached by a network of tunnels and bunkers. There was no telephone service or electricity or water.Hungry and diseased dogs either followed the residents or hid meekly in dark closets. The carcasses of dogs and cattle were scattered throughout the town.We worked so hard for everything, said Mrs. Emma Lansberry, who is 69 years old, and we lost it all. When you're old, you know, you have more to lose. We just don't feel it's worth staying any more.She was standing with her husband, Orville, who is pastor of the Church of God here. The ruins of their home and garage smoldered at their feet. Both structures burned Monday night. And the Lansberrys were returning for the first time since they sneaked from their home the night of Feb. 27 as about 300 members of the American Indian Movement and their supporters seized the town, firing guns and beating drums.Washing Machine BurnedThat was my new washing machine, Mrs. Lansberry said, pointing to a blackened mass. The couple, who lived as missionaries in Chile for 26 years without incident, also lost their only photograph of their only child, a daughter who died when she was 21.Well, dear, Mrs. Lansberry said as she took her husband's arm, we still have each other.Down the town's street Jim and Jan Czywczynski were sifting through the wreckage of their trading post. Last night as darkness fell Mr. Czywczynski said, It's a total loss. I don't know what we're going to do. Maybe I'll know in the morning.Today he knew. We're not coming back, he said, we won't rebuild. We'll try for damages, try to sell and start all over someplace else.At the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church on the hill, the insurgents original headquarters, bullet holes pocked the walls. Spent shell casing littered the floor. Militant Indian slogans and obscene graffiti were painted on the wall. There were bullet holes in statues of Joseph and Mary.Margaret Red Eagle was born in Wounded Knee. Until February she lived here with her husband and children in their new home. But when she eagerly returned this morning, she cried quietly in a bedroom.Her house had been totally redecorated. All her furniture was gone and someone else's had been moved in. Indian paintings were hung on the wall and someone had replaced her curtains.Utensils StolenHer dishes and utensils were gone. The children's toys had disappeared along with a sewing machine, which Mrs. Red Eagle needs to replace the family's stolen clothing supply.This morning she started to clean one room, then quit. I'm getting out of here, she said. They said they wouldn't bother the Oglala people. I don't know why they did this to us.Late today the family left to live in Porcupine, nine miles away.Her nextdoor neighbors, the Red Elk family, did not return at all. They had heard what happened.Since the electricity and water supply were cut in February, their house was used as a toilet.Across the Manderson Road in Cecilia Little Moon's house the floor was ankledeep in trash, play money, ripped mattresses, soiled underwear and books.Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation combed the area today, taking pictures and noting such things as the license numbers of outofstate abandoned, burnedout cars.There was no damage estimate yet for Wounded Knee, but Federal officials said the Government's expense during the occupation by members of the American Indian Movement and its supporters were about $5million.

title: Trial of G.E. Suit Set
description: RICHMOND, May 9 (AP)The trial of a class action suit against the General Electric Company on behalf of all its female workers has been set for July 24. The suit seeks to have the company extend sickness insurance payments to cover pregnancies. The suit was filed more than a year ago by the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

The money is to help the small union in its struggle with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for control of the grape growers in the Coachella Valley of California.

title: Concert to Aid Library Is a Hit
description: James T. Flexner, whose fourvolume biography of George Washington won a Pulitzer Prize this week, happened to pass through the mall of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York yesterday. He stopped to listen to one of four special noontime fundraising concerts sponsored by the Bowery Savings Bank on behalf of the Research Library of the New York Public Library. But in a surprising finale to the hourlong concert, Mr. Flexner was invited to the podium to direct The Seuffert Band in The Stars and Stripes Forever. It was a first for Mr. Flexner and for the band. Quite an experience, said the historian, who doesn't read music. Several hundred onlookers, shoppers and tourists strolling 42d Street heard the program, which included Dixieland tunes and selections from Pagliacci sung by Sung Kil Kim, a Korean baritone, as well as a performance by the New York City Police Department's Pipe Band of the Emerald Society. Without the research department, Mr. Flexner said later jokingly, I wouldn't have been anything. It was a pleasure to help. Good weather permitting, the Bowery will sponsor its second concert next Wednesday, on the steps of the library, Fifth Avenue at 41st Street. If it rains, as it did yesterday, the concert will again be held in the mall.

title: ART EXPERTS COME TO AID OF MUSEUM
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 9The City administration is receiving assistance from art experts in Florida and New York in its efforts to authenticate paintings in the controversial John Bass Art Museum which it closed last week.

description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's Odalisque painting by Ingres, which stirred a controversy last January when it was believed that the museum had secretly sold the canvas, went back on display in Gallery 16 of the museum on Monday.
