description: The Royal Dutch  Shell Group, continuing its improved earnings pattern of the end of last year, had a 46 per cent increase in firstquarter earnings on a revenue gain of 14.4 per cent, the group reported yesterday.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 3.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial material rose to 158.8 from 155.5 last week.

title: Indicted
description: Although it may be difficult to bear in mind when so many sensational developments swirl into view each day, the essential fact remains that individualsincluding those at the highest levels of governmentare properly convicted only in a court of law and not in the press on television.

title: U.S. Will Study Rises on Scrap Steel
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Cost of Living Council, reflecting Government concern over rising prices of scrap iron and steel, said today that it would conduct a factfinding survey of the nation's largest producers and brokers of the items.

title: Mr. Nixon's Deplorable Incident
description: President Nixon, who has never been noted for understatement, now describes the Watergate scandal as a deplorable incident. This is the mildest use of the English language since somebody referred to the San Francisco earthquake as an unfortunate occurrence, and it suggests that Mr. Nixon still hasn't identified the source or measured the magnitude of the tragedy.

title: 35 Australian Unions Vote A Wide Boycott of France
description: SYDNEY, Australia May 10 Thirtyfive major Australian trade unions agreed today to boycott all French aircraft, ships, goods and communications as a protest against French nuclear tests in the south Pacific.

title: Mets Defeat Yankees, 84, And Win Mayor's Trophy
description: The Mets and the Yankees took time out from their other problems last night to stage their 11th annual game for the Mayor's Trophy and the Mets won it, 84, with five runs in the second inning.

title: Rockefeller Signs MassTransit Bills, Completing Bistate Pact on Facilities
description: Governor Rockefeller, with Governor Cahill of New Jersey at his side, signed legislation yesterday that will permit the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to undertake a $650million construction program for masstransoortation facilities.

title: G.O.P. Women Meeting To Choose a President
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 10The New Jersey Federation of Republican Women opened a convention here today at which it will decide the first contest for 20 years for president of the organization.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee on Pacific Ocean Territories10:30 A.M.

title: It's Hunts Point's Turn to Take a Bow
description: The civic pride of the Bronx in general and the Hunts Point neighborhood in particular were on parade yesterday.

title: Senate Confirms Callaway As Secretary of the Army
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of former Representative Howard H. Callaway of Georgia as Secretary of the Army, succeeding Robert F. Froehlke, who resigned.

title: POLICEMEN ACCUSED IN SEXABUSE CASE
description: A police officer accused of sexually abusing a woman he was questioning about narcotics was suspended from the force and arrested yesterday and a policeman with him at the time was also suspended.

title: The Stage
description: In 1970 Edith O'Hara brought her Plowright Players from a Pennsylvania barn to New York with the musical Touch. Now Mrs. O'Hara has a new company, called Mama Hare's Tree, and a new musical, Hot and Cold Heros, which she opened Wednesday at the 13th Street Theater. Where Touch honnored the sweet innocence of communal life, Heros tries to give an acerbic view of urban life. Its canvas includes everything from runaways to subways.

title: Baseball Transactions AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: CLEVELANDRecalled Steve Mingori, left  handed pitcher, from Oklahoma City of the American Association.

title: Business Records
description: JA FLOWERS, INC., operating C. Frida Mueller Costos Florist, also known as Costos of Madison Avenue, a retail florist, 289 Madison Ave., N.Y. Petitioners are The KERVAN COMPANY INC.; Holiday Plants Inc. Plants Inc.; and Frances and Morris Abramowitz doing business as A 8, S Ribbon Co.

title: POVERTY PROJECTS FAVORED IN A POLL
description: A television poll of the New York metropolitan region shows that citizens strongly favor a broad range of public programs to alleviate poverty.

title: Near a Nuclear Plant, Outdoor Laboratory Keeps Tabs on Environment
description: AIKEN, S.C.  Strange things are happening in the dark swamps and deep lakes around the Atomic Energy Commission's Savannah River plant near here.

title: Picasso Art Gift to Louvre Limited to 40 Top Works
description: PARIS, May 10 (UPI)Only the most important masterpieces by other artists in the late Pablo Picasso's collection of modern artabout 40 paintingswill be donated to the Louvre Museum, Picasso's lawyer said today.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: April 28Ind. 111, Kent. 107 (OT). April 30Kent. 114, Ind. 102. May 3Kent. 92, Ind. 88. May 5Ind. 90, Kent. 86. May 8Ind. 89, Kent. 86. May 10Kent 109, Ind. 93. May 12At Kentucky, 2 P.M.

title: 2 YOUNG MEN DIE IN JAIL INCIDENTS
description: An 18yearold former footballstar at Far Rockaway High School, arrested Wednesday night on charges of having taken part with other youths in a lobberybeating spree, died in the Queens Criminal Court detention pen yesterday afternoon after being subdued by correction officers, who said he had gone berserk.

title: RUSSIANS INVENT NEW WAY TO PLAY
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) Bob Cousy doesn't quite know how the American rules of basketball were changed When they reached the international arena, but he thinks the United States had better learn to adjust.

title: C.I.A. Doctors. Say Ellsberg Is First American Given Personality Assessment
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Two medical officials of the Central Intelligence Agency told a Senate subcommittee today that a personality assessment made on Dr. Daniel Ellsberg was the first that the agency had ever made on an American citizen.

title: Screen: The P.O.W. Story of a Disabled Veteran
description: Howie Kaufman, the hero of Philip Dossick's good but poorly titled The P.O.W. is a young New York veteran of the Vietnam war, permanantly disabled by a wound that has left him paralyzed from the waist down. The film picks him up shortly after his discharge from the hospital, and it leaves him, a few weeks later, at the end of a party given in his honor by several of his friends. Nothing too dramatic happens in between. Howie renews acquaintance with a girl he used to know, attempts two  unsuccessful  job interviews, sets up housekeeping in his own oneroom apartment; and without too much hope and without despair he begins to settle into a life of limited and difficult options.

title: City Studies Proposal to Divert Traffic From the West Village
description: The city is studying plans to divert heavy truck traffic in the West Village area in an attempt to prevent damage to historic homes in what has been designated a landmark neighborhood.

title: Bosman Sent to Indians By Rangers for Dunning
description: CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP)Steve Dunning got his wish and the Cleveland Indians added an experienced righthanded pitcher today in a trade that sent Dunning to the Texas Rangers for Dick Bosman and a minor league outfielder, Ted Ford. The Indians also recalled Steve Min gori, a lefthanded pitcher.

title: WALTER L. CRONKITE
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., May 10 (UPI)Dr. Walter L. Cronkite, a retired dentist and father of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television newscaster, died today. He was 79 years old.

title: 99% of Doctors in State. Accused of Padding Bills
description: TRENTON, May 10A former New Jersey physician who has surrendered his professional license told the State Commission of Investigation today that 99 per cent of the state's doctors and lawyers padded their bills in a practice that represents the American way of life.

title: SEC. WEIGHS AID TO MUTUAL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 a The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission told the mutualfund industry today that the agency was considering a number of proposals that would make it easier to sell mutual funds.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Several years ago Ellen Tucker, a young schoolteacher, was in Portugal and met an even younger law student, Joao Isabel. In 1970 Mr. Isabel came over here, married Miss Tucker and began teaching Portuguese to the personnel of Varig Airlines and at The New School for Social Research. But he still had spare time and, besides, he wanted to make some more money.

title: Bogs, Middleweight, Beats Mike Quarry by Decision
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 10 (UPI)  Tom Bogs of Denmark, the European middleweight champion, outpointed Mike Quarry of San Luis Obispo, Calif., in a 10round bout tonight. Bogs was awarded a unanimous decision over Quarry, who is a light heavyweight.

title: HoleinOne for Miss Albers
description: TOWSON, Md., May 10 (UPI) Roberta Albers scored a holeinone on the 17th hole today at Pine Ridge Golf Course during the proamateur round of the Lady Carling open. Miss Albers, 26 years old, from Tampa, Fla., used a No. 5 iron on the par3 hole, winning a Ford LTDthe prize for getting an ace during the fourday tournament. It was the third ace of her career.

title: 11 AMOCO ST4TIONS RATION GAS HERE
description: For the first time since World War II a major oil company began yesterday to ration gasoline to motorists in New York City.

title: Frank Berle, ExManager For Brother, the Comedian
description: Frank Berle, from 1930 to 1965 personal manager and road manager for his brother Milton Berle, the comedian, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 27 West 72d Street.

title: A Poseidon Missile Blows Up in Ocean As Russians Watch
description: ABOARD THE U. S. N. S. RANGE SENTINEL, May 10 (UPI)A Poseidon missile fired from a submerged submarine whipped violently out of control last evening, blew apart and hit the Atlantic Ocean in full view of a Russian spy ship and 200 guests of the United States Navy.

title: Laos Talks at an Impasse That Both Sides Tolerate
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 10Negotiations to bring a formal close to the war in Laos and reunite the country seem to have become deadlocked, but neither side seems to mind much. And in an increasingly relaxed atmosphere, fighting has virtually disappeared throughout the land.

title: Sevareid Asserts Mitchell Tried to Sway 2 Justices
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Eric Sevareid, a news commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, said on the CBSTV evening news tonight that early in 1969, the then Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, sought improper influence through an unidentified emissary, on two Sttpreme Court Justices in connection with a wiretapping case.

title: ExOptions Dealer Indicted on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP)  Harold Goldstein, former president of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., a large commodity option dealer, was indicted today on charges of mail fraud and perjury.

title: PBW Exchange Says Insurers Will Invest in Specialist Units
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10  The PBW Stock Exchange said today that two major lifeinsurance companies were expected shortly to place capital into two specialist units of the exchange.

title: People in Sports: Stasiuk Goes
description: The Vancouver Canucks finished seventh this season in the eightteam East Division of the National Hockey League. Yesterday their coach, Vic Stasiuk, was dismissed. The Buffalo Sabres qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs in their third year in the league. Yesterday their former coach, George (Punch) Imlach, signed a twoyear contract to continue as general manager. He also was given the title of vice president. Such are the fortunes of failure and success in professional sports. Lorne (Gump) Worsley was persuaded to end his fourmonth retirement and return to the Minnesota Stars next season. With 24 seasons of pro hockey behind him, the twotime Vezina Trophy winner will become 44 years old Monday and will be the oldest active player in the N.H.L.

title: JAMES E. BROCK
description: OMAHA, May 10 (UPI) James E. (Tom) Brock, president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations in 1971 and 1972, died today in an Omaha hospital after a, lengthy illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Developments in 3 Cases
description: Charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and to obstruct justice were handed up by a Federal grand jury against former Attorney General John N. Mitchell; former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

title: Nastase Grumbles Way to. Semifinals At Bournemouth
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 10 (AP)  Hie Nastase of Rumania, punctuating the match with verbal barbs and complaints, defeated Geoff Masters of Australia, 61, 86, today and advanced to the semifinals of the $67,500 British clay court tennis championships.

title: BRITAIN TO ASSIST SAUDI AIR DEFENSE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 (Reuters)  In a move of strategic significance, Saudi Arabia has granted a multimilliondollar contract to Britain to help operate Saudi Arabian air defenses.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTH ARLINGTON, May 10  Patrick Farrell, a hurdler and long jumper, has a rather unsettling problem to contend withhis hair has been ruled a safety hazard by North Arlington High's athletic department.

title: Brooklyn Courts Called in Deep Crisis
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday enjoined the overburdened Legal Aid Society from accepting the assignment of more criminal cases in State Supreme Court than it can handle.

title: Abel Green, Editor of Variety And Language Stylist, 72, Dies
description: Abel Green, who as the editor of Variety knew and reported the news of the great, the neargreat and the unknowns of Broadway and Hollywood, died of a heart attack last evening at his home, 55 Central Park West. He was 72 years old.

title: COUNSEL IS NAMED
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 President Nixon announced today another major reorganization of government and reshuffling of political power as a result of the Watergate scandals.

title: Shanker Expresses Satisfaction At Defeat of Fuentes Supporters
description: Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, yesterday expressed great satisfaction in the results of the May 1 local school board elections and said that the defeat of supporters of Luis Fuentes, the controversial District 1 superintendent, showed that the parents had rejected the politics of separatism and confrontation.

title: Notes on People
description: The first American to manage a British symphony orchestra, Harold Lawrence, is returning home to be manager of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Lawrence, who has been manager of the London Symphony Orchestra since 1967, is expected to take his new post at the Philharmonic in the fall. He is succeeding Helen M. Thompson as manager. In London, Howard Snell, the London Symphony's chairman, said: Mr. Lawrence's contribution has been crucial to the orchestra's growth.

title: College Baseball
description: College Baseball

title: Southern Comforter
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.The first term of the Nixon Administration saw the South change considerably and the South's image improve immeasurably.

title: OTB Placating Losers With an EGO Triple
description: The OTB horseplayer's Aqueduct daily double has gone down the drain, and his exactas haven't been close. His confidence is falling apart.

title: Teacher, 83, Closing Books on Her Career
description: SWEDESBORO, May 10 (UPI)  When the school bells sound for the last time next month, Mildred West would just like to collect her things and quietly go home.

title: Dean Charges Efforts to Prevent Testimony About White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, charged today that there is an ongoing effort to limit or prevent my testifying fully and freely in the Watergate investigation.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: A Time of Trouble Looms for Mitchell Firm
description: They tried to be lawyerlike about it, responding officially with No comment and unofficially with remarks like Life goes on and We're a law firm, after all.

title: Cotton Gives Blues Infectious Quality
description: The James Cotton Blues Band, at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street, through Monday, gives audiences a chance to see and hear a blues veteran who is still very much in his prime.

title: Death Follows Death
description: BELMONT, Calif., May 10 (UPI)Mrs. Ruby Smith, 58 years old arrived home from her job as shipping clerk to find her husband dead of a heart attack. As she telephoned for an ambulance, the switchboard operator who took the call said the telephone suddenly went silent. The police and ambulance crews found Mrs. Smith lying dead on the floor next to her husband.

title: Watergate TipOff Man Comes Up in the World
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)Frank Wills, the $80aweek Watergate security guard who discovered the breakin last June 17, has taken a job at another downtown Washington building and is making $85 a week and getting up to $300 for interviews.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 15%
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last year were an estimated $932million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $830million. Total retail store sales were about 59312billion, up 15 per cent from the yearearlier $8.450billion.

title: Dean Charges Efforts to Prevent Testimony About White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 10John W. Dean 3d, the deposed White House counsel, oharged today that there is an ongoing effort to limit or prevent my testifying fully and freely in the Watergate investigation.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Surge In 8th Downs Indians, 43
description: The Boston Red Sox, unable to get either a hit or a base runner for 5 1/3 innings from Dick Tidrow of Cleveland, rallied for three runs against Jerry Johnson zn the eighth and beat the Indians, 43, at Fenway Park last night.

title: Mental Patient Shot Dead After Assault on Family
description: A 34yearold mental patient was shot and killed by the police early yesterday in the Floral Park section of Queens after he allegedly attacked his mother and stepfather with a hammer as they slept.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their second consecutive losses yesterday in slow trading.

title: Gift to Northwestern
description: Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., has received second gift of $10million from Mr. and Mrs. Foster G. McGaw, who gave $10million to the nstitution in 1969. All $20milion is to be used in the development of the McGaw Medical Center. Mr. McGaw is the ounder and honorary chairman of the American Hospital Supply Corporation. He is a life trustee of the university.

title: PLOTS ALSO CITED
description: A special Federal grand jury yesterday indicted John N. Mitchell, former United States Attorney General; Maurice H. Stans, former Secretary of Commerce; Harry L. Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Rbert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier.

title: Television
description: 6:30 (2)Sunrlse Semester (4)All About Your Car (5)Read Your Way Up (7)Listen and Learn

title: Supreme Court Is Asked To Free Georgia Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  Georgia asked the Supreme Court today to order President Nixon to release Federal funds earmarked by Congress for highways, education and pollution control.

title: Muybridge, AA Pioneer in Photography
description: The Britishborn photographer Eadweard Muybridge (18301904) is one of the legendary figures in the early history of the medium. His photographic studies of animal locomotion radically alered both the scientific understanding of the subject and its depiction in pictorial art. His invention o fa device known as the zotipraxiscope, a variation on the lattern projector that enabled him to project a series of rotating images of animals in motion, established him as a pioneer in the art and science of moving pictures. And apart from all this, Muybridge was also one of the great landscape photographers of the 19th century. He was immensely influential in his own day, and has remained a complex, somewhat enigmatic figure whose manysided accomplishments are only now beginning to be fully documented and explained.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Byrne Favors Public Funds for Election Financing
description: NEWARK, May 10Brendan T. Byrne, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Said today that he opposed the traditional system of financing elections with political campaign contributions and that, if elected, he would lead a legislative drive to have such contributions outlawed in New Jersey.

title: Developments in 3 Cases
description: Charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and to obstruct justice were handed up by a Federal grand jury against former Attorney General John M. Mitchell; former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans; Harry Sears, former majority leader of the New Jersey Senate, and Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier.

title: Books of The Times
description: A RUSSIAN BEAUTY AND OTHER STORIES. By Vladimir Nabokov. Translated from the Russian by Dmitri Nabokov in collaboration with the author and by Simon Krlinsky. 268 pages. McGrawHill. $7.95.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: WNET to Add Live WatergateHearing Coverage
description: Public television station WNET/Channel 13 will carry gaveltogavel coverage of the Senate hearings into the Watergate affair live as well as on a nighttime delayed basis, beginning at 10 A.M. next Thursday.

title: Football Transactions
description: BALTIMORESigned Dennis Nelson, oftensive tackle; David Lee, punter, and Chuck Hinton, defensive tackle, Jamie Rotella, Tennessee linebacker, thirdround draft choice.

title: No Confidence
description: The House has taken a historic step toward restoring Congressional authority over warmaking and toward ending once and for all the United States military involvement in Indochina with its vote yesterday denying President Nixon the authority to transfer defense funds to pay for the bombing of Cambodia and for other Indochina activities.

title: People and Business
description: Bored shareholders have been asking for something new in annual meetings and yesterday they got it. At Burlington Northern's meeting in St. Paul, Minn., Norton Simon, one of 18 directors nominated for reelection to the big railroad conglomerate's board, voted against himself and his fellow directors.

title: 5 Youths on Bicycles Help Capture a Suspect
description: Five teenagers riding bicycles trailed a holdup suspect aboard a bus for 12 blocks on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday, hailed a passing police car and helped in the suspect's arrest and the recovery of $77.66 reported stolen from a milk bar.

title: Singer Expecting 1973 Net to Rise, Holders Are Told
description: Earnings of the Singer Company are expected to continue the upward trend of the first quarter during the balance of the year, which would mean an increase of about 12 per cent over the record 1972 net of $87.5million, or $4.82 a share, earned in 1972, Donald P. Kircher, president and chairman of the diversified producer, told some 400 shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, received $15million Navy contract for oceanographic research, it was announced yesterday.

title: Missouri Rejects Rights Bill
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 10 (AP)The Missouri House voted 81 to 0 today against the ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution. The bill was defeated earlier in the Senate. So far, 30 states have ratified the amendment. Thirtyeight states must ratify it before it becomes effective.

title: Biaggi Concedes He Refused To Answer Jury's Questions
description: After months of repeated denials, Mario Biaggi admitted last night that he had refused to answer questions when he appeared in 1971 before a Federal grand jury. Political leaders said the admission would damage his mayoral candidacy.

title: Impeachment?
description: Short of the sword [impeachment) is the extreme remedy, and was intended for the worst political disorders of the executive department. Nothing but treason, official bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors made so by law, and also in their nature of deep moral turpitude, which are dangerous to the safety of the state, and which palpably disqualify and make unfit an incumbent to remain in the office of President, can justify the application (of the impeachment provisions of the Constitution of the United States].

title: Tap Picked Up Calls Ellsberg Made in 1969'70
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10One year after the trial judge ordered that all information on wiretaps be handed over to the court, the Government disclosed today at the Pentagon papers trial that telephone calls of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg were picked up by F.B.I. wiretaps in late 1969 and in early 1970.

title: ISRAELI MANEUVER IS BEGUN ON GOLAN
description: JERUSALEM, May 10The Israeli Army began extensive infantry maneuvers on the occupied Golan heights today, apparently in an effort to discourage Syria from sending substantial forces into southern Lebanon.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bills on Mass Transit
description: Governor Rockefeller, with Governor Cahill of New Jersey at his side, signed legislation yesterday that will permit the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to undertake a $650million construction program for masstransportation facilities.

title: Chopped Lamb in a Barbecue Sauce
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: $300Million Fight Approved On Lead Paint Poisoning
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Senate has passed a bill authorizing the expenditure of $300million over the next four years to combat effects of leadbased paint poisoning in children.

title: SERGEANT DENIES KICKING G.I. AT DIX
description: FORT DIX, N.J., May 11 Army S. Sgt. John D. Layton testified in his own defense today against charges of abusing a recruit and denied that he had physically or verbally abused anyone, including the man in question, while conducting training exercises.

title: Thousands Cheer Knicks At Airport Homecoming
description: Several thousand New York Knick fans, who had stayed up late on Thursday night to watch their heroes win their second National Basketball Association title, beat the rushhour traffic to Kennedy Airport yesterday to welcome them home.

title: Nice Place, Called the Bronx, Continues to Mark Special Week
description: The Bronx is long neglected, but we feel we have something to celebrate because it's a nice place, Mario Vairo, administrative assistant at Damrosch Junior High School, said yesterday.

title: Singapore Chief Proposes Formation of Allied Fleet
description: TOKYO; May 11 (AP)Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore proposed today that the United States, Japan, Australia and Asian nations form a joint airnaval task force to keep the Indian Ocean and the western Pacific open to the commerce of all countries.

title: Head of Broadcasters Unit Scores Threats to Media
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The president of the National Association of Broadcasters said tonight that since the Government has the power of life and death over our facilities, threats from the Government can never be taken lightly.

title: Music: Kubelik's Dvorak
description: Starting the final weekend of the subscription concerts of the New York Philharmonic, Rafael Kubelik devoted his entire program (sans intermission) to the Stabat Mater of Dvorak. Mr. Kubelik is a Czech, and that of course gave the conducting a special impetus. The last few years have seen a great deal of choral music on Philharmonic programs. This was one of the happier events.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: (Knicks won championship, 4.1.)

title: Harvard Crew on Guard
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 11  Harvard and Northeastern rank as cofavorites, with Pennsylvania the unknown quantity but expected to be a formidable contender, here tomorrow at the annual sprint championships for the best Eastern collegiate crews.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW ORLEANSSigned bob Gresham and Arthur Green, running backs.

title: WILLIAM G. WELLS
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., May 11 (AP)William G. Wells, a retired Air Force colonel and the owner of radio station WTAN here, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Guerrillas in Lebanon Said to Pull Back
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, May 12Palestinian guerrillas who entered Lebanon from Syria earlier this week were reported pulling back toward the frontier yesterday as the ceasefire between guerrilla and Lebanese forces appeared to be holding.

title: Court Reverses Dismissal
description: FRESNO, Calif., May 11 (UPI) A state employe cannot be dismissed because he has been convicted of possession of marijuana, the Fifth State. District Court of Appeal ruled yesterday, It reversed State Personnel Board and Superior Court decisions slowing the Department of Human Resources Development to dismiss Charles K. Vielehr, a trainee who had pleaded guilty to possession of marijuana.

title: Quake Felt in California
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 11 (UPI)A mild earth tremor that registered 1.7 on the Richter scale rattled windows here last evening, but no damage was reported.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Watergate Investigation

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New Jersey Sports
description: There were eight finalists in the 100meter freestyle last July in Park Ridge, Ill., when the starter called the swimmers to the starting blocks. Mark Spitz was among them, so almost nobody noticed Kenny Knox, the fastest freestyler in New Jersey history.

title: Brezhnev Is Visiting Warsaw And Berlin Before Trip to Bonn
description: WARSAW, May 11Leonid I. Brezhnev, leader of the Soviet Communist party, arrived today to show the Soviet Union's solidarity with Poland before he meets next week in Bonn with Chancellor Willy Brandt. From here Mr. Brezhnev will go to East Berlin tomorrow in a similar gesture of solidarity.

title: Fiat Buys Into the Biggest Paper in Italy
description: ROME, May 11The Fiat Motor Company is broadening its publishing empire with the purchase of a onethird interest in Corriere della Sera of Milan, the Italian newspaper with the largest circulation.

title: National League
description: New York 4, Pittsburgh 3 (n.). Chicago 4, Philadelphia 3. Houston 5, Cincinnati 1 (n.).

title: CONNALLY TO TAKE LEAVE FROM FIRM
description: WASHINGTON, May 11John B. Connally announced today that he would take a leave of absence from his law firm and resign from all corporate boards during the time he will serve as special adviser to President Nixon.

title: FASHION TALK
description: There is fashion  and there are clothes. Fashion is a step into the unknown; it has a bit of shock value. It's an attempt to express the mood of this minute, or perhaps the next minute. Much of it is ephemeral. If it sticks around long enough it becomes clothes.

title: A Bit of Work on the Railroad
description: WASHINGTONSeveral years ago it became obvious that the nation's outmoded transportation system was headed for a collision with the demands of modern America. It is about to happen just around the next bend.

title: LEX BARKER DIES; TARZAN OF MOVIES
description: Lex Barker, the 10th actor to play the role of Tarzan in Hollywood films, collapsed and died yesterday.

title: Coast Guard Crews Excel At 35th Dad Vail Regatta
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11In fickle weather that made it impossible to estimate the merits of comparative winning times, the 35th Dad Vail Regatta began its twoday stand this morning with a record fleet.

title: GRAY CALL TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 L. Patrick Gray 3d has told Senate investigators that he talked by telephone with President Nixon about three weeks after the Watergate burglary last June 17 to express concern over White House obstacles in his path and confusion that was hampering his investigation, committee sources said today.

title: NIXON AGAIN ASKS LEGAL AID TO POOR
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 President Nixon resubmitted to Congress today, in slightly revised form, his proposals for providing free legal assistance to the poor through the creation of an independent Legal Services Corporation.

title: ROME A. BETTS DEAD; HEART UNIT OFFICIAL
description: SUMMIT, N. J., May 11 Rome A. Betts, executive director of the American Heart Association from 1949 to 1968, died yesterday at his home, 9 Twombley Drive. He was 69 years old.

title: HESS POSTS UPSET IN A. A.U. BOXING
description: BOSTON, May 11 (AP)Mike Hess of Albany, Ore., scored a stunning upset tonight by defeating Tim Dement of Lafayette, La., an Olympic boxer, in the 85th national Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships. They fought in the 119pound class in the semifinal round.

title: Art: The Poetic Vision of Miro
description: The Spanish artist Joan Mitt has long been recognized as one of the greatest of modern masters. His central place in the history of modern art is assured, and his influence on several generations of younger artists has been immense. At the age of 80, he remains one of the most vital and energetic artists on the contemporary sceneand, at times, also one of the most amusing.

title: Two Hurt in Plane Crash
description: WENHAM, Mass., May 11 (AP)Two men were injured early today when their twin engine Piper Aztec plane crashed in a wooded area while attempting to land in a heavy fog at Beverly Airport. The injured, were Richard Higgins, 30 years old of Gloucester and Carl Kokernalt, 19, of Boxford.

title: Residents of TreeLined Street Fight Intruding Glass and Steel
description: STAMFORD, May 11Beset on all sides by traffic and commerce and other signs of encroaching population, the people on Newfield Avenue here have taken a stand against the steady march of institutions up their gracious old street.

title: Corning Glass Takes Control Of Two Companies in Britain
description: Corning Glass Works announced yesterday that its subsidiary, Corning International Corporation, had acquired all of the equity interest in James A. Jobling & Co., Ltd., and in Electrosil, Ltd., both of Sunderland, England, through a cash transaction with Thomas Tilling, Ltd., of London. Tilling's 60 per cent in the glassmaking concern of Jobling, and Tilling's direct interest in the electronics concern of Electrosil were purchased for $18.7million by Corning.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the more interesting faux pas of the diplomatic season in Athens appears to have been made by the Chinese Ambassador to Greece, Chou Poping, at the residence of the Israeli Ambassador to Greece, Yehuda Gaulan. Mr. Chou arrived with his interpreter at Mr. Gaulan's house for a reception dedicated to Israel's 25th anniversary. Speculation began at once that the visit might mean that China was considering establishing diplomatic relations with Israel. Mr. Chou was asked about this and he said: Our position is very clear: We do not recognize Israel. Your question is bizarre, very bizarre. Then, upon reflection, Mr. Chou and his interpreter shook hands with Mr. Gaulan and left the party. It was a technical error, Mr. Chou explained later. I thought I was visiting the Kuwait Embassy  It was all a very regrettable error. And although there is no Kuwait Embassy in Athens, perhaps there should be.

title: BANK RATE RAISED TO 5% IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, May 11The Bank of Canada announced tonight that the bank rate had been increased by half a percentage point to 534 per cent, effective Monday. The rate had been at 5.25 per cent since April 9.

title: CONTROL OVER PRESS RELAXED BY MARCOS
description: MANILA, May 11 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today decreed the lifting of direct Government supervision of all local and foreign information outlets.

title: Miss Meehan Wedto B.G. Schaeffer
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Marcia Meehan to Bayard George Schaeffer: Msgr. James G. Wilders, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Hugh J. Reilly, pastor of the Sacred Hearts Roman Catholic Church in Southampton, L. I. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: Sports Today
description: Indianapolis 500 time trials.

title: BELLE MARIE PICK IN ACORN STAKES
description: George Steinbrenner, the managing partner of the New York Yankees, will be represented by the favorite in the feature race at Aqueduct today. Steinbrenner owns the Kinship Farm, in whose silks Belle Marie campaigns, and she heads the field of 13 for the Acorn Stakes.

title: For the Canadiens, It Was OldHat Trick
description: CHICAGO, May 11Nostalgia was perhaps the dominant emotion today in the wake of another Montreal Canadiens Stanley Cup triumph, fashioned last night against the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Italian Bank to Open Here
description: Credito Italigno of Milan, one of Italy's largest banks, antrounced yesterday that it had been authorized by the New York State Banking Board to open a branch in New York City. The new office, to be opened in the fall, will be located at 375 Park Avenue in, the Seagram Building.

title: American League
description: Saturday, May 12, 1973

title: Norton Simon Bought Smuggled Idol
description: Norton Simon, the West Coast industrialist and art collector, said yesterday that he had paid $1million for a bronze sculpture of a Hindu deity that Indian Government officials say was stolen from a South Indian temple and smuggled out of India.

title: Bomb Math
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 Wearing his Secretary of Defense hat, Elliot Richardson gave Congress the other day a fascinating glimpse into the mathematics of saving the hearts and minds of remote peoples from whatever our bombers save them from when they bomb their countries.

title: 86th St. Toonerville Tale: 3 Flee From a Police Van
description: Three prisoners, two of them handcuffed together, leaped from the back of a police van yesterday and ran off along West 86th. Street to freedom.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCFM, Sinfonia Pastorale, Tartini; Horn Concerto in D minor, Rosetti; Symphony in C minor, Boccherini.

title: CLARK LASHES OUT AT SCHOOL BOARD
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, making his first appearance at a public hearing of the Board of Education, yesterday accused the five members of fostering segregation in the guise of integration.

title: Cook Calls for Flexibility In Brokerage Commissions
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11G. Bradford Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called upon the securities industry today to consider changing its basic system of brokerage fees from fixed schedules to a more flexible approach.

title: Joyce Hearing Set June 4 On Marijuana Possession
description: LUMBERTON, N. C., May 11 (AP)Kevin Joyce, an Olympic basketball player, will get hearing June 4 in Robeson County General Sessions Court on a charge of possessing manjuana.

description: Second Semifinal1, Marietta; 2, Trinity; 3, Florida Institute of Technology; 4, Virginia; 5, Marist. Time6:26.

title: Grigory Kozintsev Dead at 68; Directed Shakespearean Movies
description: MOSCOW, May 11Grigory Kozintsev, a Soviet director known for his Shakespearean movies, died today in Leningrad. He was 68 years old.

title: BAN ON HITLER FILM ASSAILED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP) Legislators, intellectuals and movie critics in the British capital, which Hitler once tried to bomb into surrender, have rushed to defend a movie about the last days of the Nazi dictator after a Jewish theaterchain magnate banned it.

title: Hitachi Holders to Sell $28.9Million in Shares
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters)Three major shareholders of Hitachi, Ltd., of Tokyo, are to sell 42.6 million shares of common stock with an estimated value of $28.9million, the company announced today in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: COLEMAN SUFFERSFIRST PRO DEFEA
description: COLEMAN SUFFERSFIRST PRO DEFEA

title: Saving Innocents Abroad
description: PARISTwo years ago in an Arab capital I attended a dinner where several ambassadors and their wives discussed the increasing risk of the diplomatic trade, now a target for kidnapping, murder and other acts of violence because either an envoy represents a country whose policy is disliked or because terrorists wish to extort ransom or an exchange against imprisoned colleagues.

title: Tampa Accountant Enters Guilty Plea On Campaign Letter
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 11 (AP)An accountant pleaded guilty here today to charges of distributing during the Florida Presidential campaign a bogus letter charging two Presidential candidates with sexual misconduct.

title: Knicks Quiet Leader William (Red) Holzman
description: The man behind the Knicks speaks softly, occasionally tells a bad joke, likes good cigars and was thrilled when his name showed up in The New York Times crossword puzzle.

title: WINE TALK
description: A reader's letter inadvertently turned up what may prove to be a new and interesting trend in the wine world. The man wrote to say that he is moving to England soon and hoped to dispose of some of his personal effects before he goes: among them, 75 bottles of 1961 clarets.

title: Bunker, Personification of U. S. Role, Leaves Vietnam,
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 11Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker, who has presided for six contentious years as the paramount American authority in South Vietnam and has become the last major symbol of United States involvement here, left Saigon today.

title: A Large Show of Baskin's Sculptures
description: The everblooming reputation of Leonard Baskinprint maker, sculptor, illustratoris one of the minor mysteries of the art scene. Mr. Baskin's large exhibition of recent bronze sculptures and drawings at the Kennedy Galleries, 20 East 56th Street, offers the formula as before: a kind of armchair existentialism that deals with the woes of mankind. It is, largely, a matter of easy pieties, attitudinizing, angst for the asking.

title: Tax Liens Filed
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service has filed income tax liens against a former showgirl, Lillian Reis, and her longtime companion, Ralph Staino Jr. A $12,743 lien was filed on Thursday against Miss Reis and $10,276 against Staino, both of Philadelphia. The liens are for the tax period ending last Friday.

title: Zambia Honors Dr. Livingstone on 100th Anniversary of His Death
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 11  When the eerie cry of the fish eagle resounds in the Bangweulu swamps of northern Zambia, it is, as Dr. David Livingstone remarked a century ago, as though the large black and white predator were calling to someone in another world.

title: GODSPELL OPENS CANNES FESTIVAL
description: CANNES, France, May 11The 26th Cannes Film Festival opened here last night almost without ceremony, a gesture intended to stress more than ever that it isn't carnival and that the thousands of people who attend mean to concentrate seriously on the films.

title: MIDI GARTH DANCES MARKED BY REPOSE
description: Midi Garth's choreographic signature is that of stillness and repose. While such qualities have their lyric virtues, Thursday night's program at Kaufmann Concert Hall by the Midi Garth Dance Company carried them to the point of blandness.

title: 2SHOT LEAD TAKEN BY MRS. CORNELIUS
description: BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI)Mrs. Kathy Cornelius carded a threunderpar today and took a twostroke lead in the $30,000 Lady Carling open at Windy Pine Ridge golf course.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 11Her tears of joy had dried, but cheers still filled the courtroom when Patricia Ellsberg embraced one of many friends and said:

description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 11A reserve guard on the University of Minnesota basketball team admitted yesterday that he and some teammates had sold complimentary game tickets to prominent university alumnus for more than face value, a violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

description: 5:00 (4)Modern Farmer

title: GRAY CALL TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 L. Patrick Gray 3d has told Senate investigators that he talked by telephone with President Nixon about three weeks after the Watergate burglary last June 17 to express concern over White House obstacles in his path and confusion that was hampering his investigation, committee sources said today.

description: After a daylong secret meetmg at Governor Rockefeller's country estate, 17 Republican Governors issued a Watergate statement yesterday, saying: We support the President. We believe the President.

description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fa., May 11  The Skylab 1 astronauts passed their physical examinations today and were declared ready to embark on the nation's first space station mission next week.

description: ESystems, Inc., obtained a 20.5million Air Force contract to equip two Boeing 747 airborne commandpost aircraft with electronic equipment, it was announced yesterday.

description: THE HAGUE, May 11 (AP)A 16member Cabinet headed by Premier Joop den Uyl took office today, ending a 163day political crisisthe longest in the Netherlands history.

description: Methpath, Inc., has sold 135,000 shares of its common stock to the Corning Glass Works for $1,012,500, or $7.50 a share. E. Martin Gibson, vice president of Corning Glass, was elected a Methpath director.

description: Three Democratic and one Liberal party candidate for Mayor discussed issues of the campaign yesterday in a twohour, facetoface debate, the first since the primary race began.

description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Congress Ascending
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The White House is slipping and Congress is rising as the balance of power in Washington is being altered perceptibly by the Watergate conspiracy case. For the first time in six years the House of Representatives went on record News yesterday, by a vote of 219 to 188, Analysis in opposition to White House policies in Indochina. For the secand time in five weeks, the Senate declared yesterday, 66 to 24, that the White House was obligated to adhere to the directions of Congress on Government spending.

title: Jordan Flights Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)  President Nixon approved yesterday a Civil Aeronautics Board decision granting Alia, the Royal Jordanian Airlines Corporation, a twoyear permit, to operate passenger and cargo flights between Jordan and the United States.

description: FIRST PERIOD1, Chicago, Martin (8) (Mikita, Stapleton) 10:35. 2, Chicago, Martin (9) (Peppin) 1:31. 3 Montreal, Richard (6) (F. Mahovlich) 1448. PenaltiesRoberts, Montreal (3:40); Korab, Chicago (3:40); Martin, Chicago (8:21); Roberts, Montreal (10:43); Wilson, Montreat (12:29).

title: MARIAN OSTERHOUT, PHYSIOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Marian Irwin Osterhout, long associated with the Rockefeller University and the Marine Biological Laboratory as a researcher and assistant to her ilate husband, the late Winthrop J. V. Osterhout, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 84 years old and lived at 160 East 65th Street.

title: Football League Revived
description: HARTFORD, May 11 (AP)The Atlantic Coast Football League, which did not operate in 1972, was reactivated today and Cosmo Iacavazzi was reelected president. Iacavazzi said a 12game season would open the weekend of Sept. 1 and there would be six teams.

title: TREADWAY AWARDED $7,074,090 IN SUIT
description: NEWARK, May 11 (UPI)A Federal Court jury Friday awarded $7,074,090 in triple damages to Treadway Companies Inc. after finding that the Brunswick Corporation violated certain antitrust laws because of the many bowling centers it operated while making bowling equipment.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES CITE BEVERAGE COMPANY
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Securities and Exchange Commission asked the Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, its two subsidiaries and 22 other defendants from continued violation of the registration and fraud provisions of securities laws.

description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: MRS. ALICE KURUSU
description: TOKYO, May 11 (UPI)  A funeral service was planned tomorrow for Mrs. Alice Kurusu, the American wife of the diplomat who delivered Japan's declaralon of World War II to the State Department.

description: BatteriesAlfin and Mandeikern; Paladino, Hernandez (7), Raymond (8) and Unkle. Winning pitcherARM. Losing pitcherPaladino.

title: Air of Expectancy, Then Tears, Shouts, Embraces
description: Expectancy, Then Tears, Shouts years ago. One successful pursuer caught him, dressed in a stylish, Englishcut suit, as he entered the courthouse swinging his briefcase in apparent anticipation of the day ahead.

title: School Vote Chaos
description: Inadequate planning by the Board of Elections and the Board of Education, inexcusable bumbling by officials at the polls and a host of other problems reduced last week's community school board elections to the level of nearfarce. As in the first such balloting three years ago, depressingly few of those eligible to vote bothered to do so. The results, as tabulated by the slow proportional system of counting votes, reflect a disproportionate impact made by organized pressure groups. Such an imbalance of impact thwarts the aim of school decentralization.

title: 1973 RISE OF 45%, SEEN IN INFLATION
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 11 (AP)The rate of inflation is expected to increase between 4.5 and 5 per cent this year, but should taper off to about 3.5 per cent in 1974, economists advising the Business Council said today.

title: For a Sane Multilingual Policy
description: The ancient culture of France seems to be undergoing an identity crisis. Despite the traditional glories of the French language, it is not yet equal to the demands of the 20th century. This is not surprising: we are told that the last Government language decree was the edict of 1537, banning the use of Latin in the courts. Since then, les gadgets have proliferated, and French leadership in fashion, cosmetics and lifestyle is threatened by Madison Avenue. In 1537 a folksong was really a folksong. Le sexappeal was not yet expressed by an AngloSaxon term masculine, at thatl How can the French authorities possibly catch up with le snobisme underground that seems more and more to permeate daily life?

title: Dance: New Look in Ailey Repertory
description: Unlike most moderndance companies, the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater is determinedly eclectic. Mr. Ailey's own works do dominate the repertory, but he is always anxious to bring in outside choreographers. Mr. Ailey's concern is, very obviously, to build up a representative repertory of American moderndance.

title: Dave Anderson
description: I'll tell you what, Bobby Riggs suggested, I'll play you with a poodle tied to each of my legs.

title: Gold Price Climbs As Dollar Declines
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)The United States dollar dropped sharply in Europe's key monetary centers today as the price of gold in the open market soared to new peaks for the second time in two days in active trading.

title: Knicks Perfect Championship Blend: Teamwork and Poise Under Pressure
description: Soaring above America at 37,000 feet yesterday en route to a tumultuous welcome home, the New York Knicks, newly crowned champions of the National Basketball Association, radiated quiet satisfaction and wellearned pride, as befits a team whose accomplishment was built on maturity, intelligence, unselfish cohesion and maximum poise under maximum pressure.

title: James L. Fri, 81, ExHead Of Upholstery Association
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 11 James L. Fri, former president of the Upholstery and Drapery Fabric Manufacturing Association and the author of books on retail merchandising, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital. His age was 81 and he lived here.

title: Rosenberg Sons Seeking To Halt Nizer's Spy Book
description: A lawyer representing the two sons of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, the couple who were executed in 1953 after being convicted of wartime espionage, demanded yesterday that Doubleday & Co. immediately cease the printing, publishing and distribution of The Implosion Conspiracy, the bestselling book by Louis Nizer, released last February, that quotes letters written by the elder Rosenbergs.

title: To Die of the Roar
description: Elspet wanted to lock President Nixon up with her collection for one painful day and that was, in fact, why she was locked up herself now.

description: THURSDAY NIGHT

title: VARIG BUYS 8 JETS FOR $92MILLION
description: Varig, S. A., the Brazilian airline, announced yesterday that it had signed purchase contracts totaling $92million for a fleet of eight Americanbuilt aircraft, including two new McDonnellDouglas DC10 series 30 wide body threeengine jets, a flight simulator and ground support and line station equipment.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: TV: A Study of Mormons
description: Many television viewers probably and erroneously associate the Mormon faith with unworldly seclusion in and around Salt Lake City and, vaguely, polygamy. Some interesting, surprising light is shed on the subject in The Mormon Story, a halfhour documentary due at 1 P.M. tomorrow as part of the American Broadcasting Company news series, Directions.

title: Miss Biaggi: Very Much Her Father's Girl
description: Jacqueline Biaggi is one of the most vivacious and scintillating personalities I've ever met, said William Prattella, superintendent of the Mount Vernon, N. Y., public schools, where Representative Mario Biaggi's older daughter is a school psychologist.

title: Mets Defeat Pirates, 43; Grote's Wrist Is Broken
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11The New York Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 43, tonight in what may have been their most costly victory in years: Rusty Staub, Cleon Jones and Jerry Grote all were hit by pitched balls and Willie Mays was back home apparently sneaking up on retirement.

title: A Cheerful Horror Film Opens:The Cast
description: "Theater of Blood" is an extremely cheerful horror film about Edward Kendall Sheridan Lionheart (Vincent Price), the world's worst Shakespearean actor, who sets out to take his revenge on London's drama critics by murdering each in the rococo style of one of the plays featured in Lonheart's final and, apparently, most dismal repertory season.Thus Meredith Merridew (Robert Morley), who dyes his hair lavender and speaks of his miniature poodles as his little dears, finds himself on a bogus TV show called "Dish of the Week," eating an uncommonly tasty meat pie made out of  well  I shouldn't give away the plot of "Cymbeline." A critic, Trevor Dickman (Harry Andrews), is invited to take part in a sort of Living Theater production of "The Merchant of Venice," playing an Antonio who really does give up a pound of flesh. It's his heart and it's the suggestion of the people who made this film that critics' hearts, when exposed, steam like dry ice."Only Lionheart," scoffs another critic, "would have the temerity to rewrite Shakespeare."Anthony Greville-Bell, the screenwriter, and Douglas Hickox, the director, are hard pressed to maintain this nicely slapdash humor through nine murders, but they have the aid of some of England's most attractive character actors, including Robert Coote, Arthur Lowe and Dennis Price. Best of all, they have the extraordinary Diana Rigg, who does turn up in the oddest places.Miss Rigg plays Lionheart's beautiful, faithful daughter, a Cordelia who stands by dad through thick and thin, assisting at amputations, drownings, stabbings and what-not, sometimes disguised as a mustachioed motorcyclist in shades, sometimes as Marilyn Monroe, sometimes as herself. Miss Rigg is an actress of such wit that she succeeds in being both funny and legitimately moving, especially when Price is occupying screen-center, horrendously over-acting with her loving approval.

title: A Diversity of Antiques Offered by New Center
description: You won't find Dickensian ambiance at the newly opened New York Antiques Centre, 962 Third Avenue (at 58th Street). Anonymous cubicles stuffed with wares so crowd the interiors that there is no room for the sort of quaint charm that once characterized such Gotham curio centers as Ardlea Court. That turnofthecentury, Lshaped byway, formerly at 51st Street and Third Avenue, served as a favorite browsing and buying retreat for neophyte and knowledgeable antiques buffs until it was razed 20 years ago.

title: Brotherly Love Ends at Starting Gate
description: After the sixth race ended at Aqueduct yesterday, with Granny's Darling leading Sassy Cyane over the finish line in one, two order, the brothers Marco and Kelly Castaneda found themselves in a rare situation. Marco had ridden Granny's Darling and his brother was on the runnerup.

title: Infant Is Brought Home With His Pacemaker
description: Fiveweekold Jesse Rodriguez went home from Ba bies Hospital at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center yesterday, starting his new life with a pacemaker.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 3 editorial Rent Demagogy is good as, far as it goes, but it fails to condemn the inaction of landlords in living up to their responsibilities for improvements.

title: Albany Educator Resigns While Under Student Fire
description: ALBANY, May 11 (AP) The dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the State University of New York at Albany, who has been under fire this week from students protesting his role in the dismissal of several teachers, announced last night that he was resigning to accept a post in Oklahomo.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: NEW HEALTH CHIEF IS EXPECTED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Nixon Administration is expected to name Dr. Robert S. Stone, vice president for health sciences of the University of New Mexico, as the next director of the National Institutes of Health.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joanne Deborah Chesimard, identified as a Black Liberation Army leader, and Clark E. Squire were indicted charges of murdering a state policeman and a companion of theirs during a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2.

title: Reporting on Watergate
description: Senator William Proxmire's charge that the press has been guilty of McCarthyistic destruction of the President in its treatment of the Watergate case is an unfortunate overreaction to a problem that no conscientious editor or reader can afford to ignore.

title: U.S., MEXICO SPLIT DAVIS CUP POINTS
description: MEXICO CITY, May 11 (UPI) Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., defeated Joaquin LoyoMayo, 75, 64, 7,5, today to enable the United States to salvage a split of their opening two singles matches with Mexico in the Davis cup American zone section B finals.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, May 11Japan believes that the formation of a group of oilconsuming nations would constitute a  challenge to the interests of oilproducing countries, the Japanese Trade Minister said today.

title: Dow Index Falls 11.36 in Light Trading
description: The stock market continued to drop yesterday in light trading.

title: Votes in Congress
description: I. Vote on bill authorizing funds for Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which passed, 66 to 6, May 7.

title: OUTPUT POSTPONED BY CARTRIDGE TV
description: Cartridge Television, Inc., announced yesterday that it had laid off about 300 employes and had delayed production of its stand alone videotape player to await further market development for the unit. The player is designed to play prerecorded video cartridges through conventional home TV receivers.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 11 (AP)Jim Pattison of Vancouver said today he had purchased the Philadelphia Blazers of the World Hockey Association for $1.9million. He said he would move the club to Vancouver if he could obtain a lease on the Coliseum from the Pacific National Exhibition. The Vancouver Canucks of the National Hockey League play their home games in the Coliseum. Pattison said he also acquired W.H.A. rights to Seattle and would move the club there if the coliseum lease was unavailable.

title: White House Says Attacks Will Continue in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The White House said today that the United States would continue with the right policy of bombing in Cambodia in support of President Lon Nol's government, despite the vote yesterday in the House of Representatives blocking the transfer of military funds for such raids.

description: WASHINGTON, M a y 11 (UPI)Radio and television newsmen went on strike today against WTOP, the Washington PostNewsweek broadcast outlet here.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLOSE WITH LOSS
description: After a week of rises, many of them spectacular, soybean futures prices fell the 20centabushel limit yesterday in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. At the close, they had regained only part of the loss.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 11Citing what he called improper Government conduct shielded so long from public view, the judge in the Pentagon papers trial dismissed today all charges against Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.

description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters)The United States is doubling its sales of crude natural rubber from the national stockpile, it was announced here today.

title: LITTERERS FACE CITY CRACKDOWN
description: The city, with the assistance of unpaid civilian sanitation patrols, is cracking down on merchants and landlords who litter sidewalks persistently, Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton and Herbert Elish, the Environmental Protection Administrator, announced yesterday.

description: NEWARK, May 11  Two law firms alleged to have arranged the padding of clients workmen's compensation medical bills today charged that) the State Commission of Investigation had violated their constitutional rights.

title: Orioles Down Yanks, 30, As Palmer Doles 3 Hits

title: Vietcong Accuse U.S. of Bombing South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 12 (UPI)  The Vietcong charged today that United States warplanes had been bombing in South Vietnam since April in violation of the ceasefire.

title: 2d Solzhenitsyn Wedding
description: MOSCOW, May 11 (UPI)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn and his second wife, Natalya Svetlova, were married for a second time today in a church near the Kremlin, according to friends of the novelist. The Solzhenitsyns had been married in a civil ceremony on April 20.

title: 4 in Jersey Family Die In Two Suspicious Fires
description: PASSAIC, May 11 (UPI)Two fires believed to have been started by an arsonist swept through a row of crowded threestory frame tenements here today, killing four persons, including three children, and injuring one fire captain.

title: More Chilean Miners Out
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 11, (AP)Workers at Chuquicamata, the world's largest openpit copper mine, left their jobs today in sympathy with striking miners at another big Chilean field.

title: Price Weakening on American Exchange Linked to Reserve Board's Discount Rate Rise
description: Investors concern over the increase in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: CAMBODIAN STATES HE IS NEW PREMIER
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 11 (Reuters)In Tam, one of President Lon Nol's leading nonCommunist opponents, announced today that he had been appointed Premier of Cambodia's new Government.

title: MASUICHI MIDORO
description: TOKYO, May 11 (AP)Masuichi Midoro, a former president of Asahi Shimbun, Japan's influential mass  circulation daily newspaper, died of cancer last Friday. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S. Agency Plans Security Reduction As Bombings Drop
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) With antiwar bombing tapering off, the General Services Administration is drafting plans to reduce security in many Federal buildings across the country.

title: A U.M.W. DISTRICT HOLDS FIRST VOTE
description: UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 11Members of District 4 of the United Mine Workers, voting in their first election in the union's 84yearold history, have selected a slate of officers.

title: Norton Simon Bought Smuggled Idol
description: Norton Simon, the West Coast industrialist and art collector, said yesterday that he had paid $1million for a bronze sculpture of a Hindu deity that Indian Government officials say was stolen from a South Indian temple and smuggled out of India.

title: Roundup: Tiant Is Back on Top and Staying There

title: People and Business
description: Harrie E. Hart Jr., a 26yearold Los Angeles personnel consultant, took a chance on Thursday night and found out yesterday that he had lost. But he believes that it was all for a worthy cause.

title: Brennan Disputes Labor on Imports

He was indicted Thursday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice and defraud the United States. He was also charged with perjury before the grand jury.

title: Congress Ascending
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The White House is slipping and Congress is rising as the balance of power in Washington is being altered perceptibly by the Watergate conspiracy case. For the first time in six years the House of Representatives went on record News yesterday, by vote of 219 to 188, in opposition to White House policies in Indochina. For the second time in five weeks, the Senate declared yesterday, 66 to 24, that the White House was obligated to adhere to the directions of Congress on Government spending.

description: The dismissal of all charges of espionage, theft and conspiracy in the Ellsberg case is an indictment of the Government's resort to policestate tactics in its effort to discredit and intimidate critics of its Vietnam policy.

description: WASHINGTON, May 11A pay television system that is being patented offers a home box office. Patrons in their living rooms or motel quarters can insert printed tickets and get selected movies or special programs such as prizefights. Theatrevision, Inc., a New York company whose president is Dore Schary, the motion picture producer and writer, will receive patent 3,736,368 on May 29. The inventors are Ira Kamen, president of the Laser Link Corporation, Woodbury, L. I., and two television engineers, Joseph H. Vogelman and Will Baltin.

title: Screen: 'The Offence' at the Festival
description: Sidney Lumet's new film, "The Offence," takes place in a suburb of London, not an old suburb but one of those barren new suburbs still in the process of development, where lawns fade into scrubby fields that don't give one a feeling of space as much as emptiness, of vacant lots awaiting overnight transformation into bleak, middle-income housing blocks.The time (probably winter) and the place perfectly reflect the unacknowledged despair contained in almost every frame of this harrowing story, which seems to be about the search for a man who's been luring little schoolgirls into culverts and then raping them."Seems" is the proper word because, about halfway through, one becomes aware that the film is not about a manhunt. Rather it is a psychological striptease, about a tough, hard-drinking, hard-headed detective.For some time before the start of the film, Detective Johnson (Sean Connery) has been cracking up, remembering (even if against his better will) the way that suicides have looked when he has found them, the way a murdered child's arm dangled through the slats of a crib, the awkward position of a woman who had been tied to a bed and tortured to death. Other men put these things out of their minds. Johnson cherishes them.As it progresses, "The Offence," for all its elaborate setting of scene and for all its introduction of subsidiary characters (beautifully played by Trevor Howard and Vivien Merchant, among others), sort of gets smaller and smaller, instead of bigger. The entire film, it turns out, exists for a single sequence, a brutal station-house confrontation between the detective and his prime suspect (Ian Bannen), between a lower-class psychotic and a middle-class neurotic, between a closet sadist and an admitted masochist. In a sense, they are lovers, made for each other.It's highly theatrical  perhaps just a little too highly theatrical for the more or less realistic context  but it's been staged by Lumet for maximum effect. The revelations explode predictably, like the ingredients of a 24-hour cold capsule, but the dramatic impact is real while one is watching it. Connery and Bannen are so fine, and the feelings prompted so intense, that I wouldn't be at all surprised if the sequence could stand on its own, as if it were a one-act play. Everything that has gone before seems to have been so much vamping for time.Some of the things that have gone before also tend to detract from this climax. Since it's so clear to the audience that Detective Johnson has long since come apart, it's difficult to understand why the men who work with him haven't recognized the fact. That may be splitting hairs. "The Offence" has one big, carefully worked out, dramatic moment, which is more than most movies have these days.

title: Books of The Times
description: If astronomy was the first science to be constituted, it's beca'se the stars are so far from us that we could know only their movement and their mass. I think that is the profound justification of ethnol ogy: Because we have only an impoverished knowledge of these peoples, we are forced to perceive only certain essential properties.

title: 'The Harrad Experiment' Opens at Baronet
description: If I can believe the promotional material floating around, almost all the adults in North America who read anything have read Robert H. Rimmer's novel "The Harrad Experiment." The remaining half-dozen of you need only know that it concerns a special Eastern college, Harrad, where a super-bright group of special students live in a co-ed dorm with the express purpose of sharing meaningful sexual experiences.The book came out in 1966, and it was supposed to be prophetic. To an extent it was prophetic. Many Eastern college students do live in co-ed dorms now. The last group I heard of (college to be nameless), the girls were complaining that the boys had retreated to one part of the dorm and were plotting some nineteen-seventies version of panty raids.Nothing like that happens in the book; all the students are much too busy discovering themselves and exploring the miracle (I think I've got the prose right) of one another. Nothing like that happens in the movie that has just been made from the novel either; the students are all too busy working out lasting monogamous relationships. Despite the splendid opportunities offered, Ted Post's "The Harrad Experiment" isn't even soft-core pornography; it is something more like soap opera with a little frontal nudity. This is the kind of movie in which never does flesh touch flesh without a choir of dulcet strings on the soundtrack to sanctify the meeting.But into any bowl of mush a little sweetener may fall. The goodness in this case comes not from the students  a handsome though unexciting lot  but from their mentors, the kindly pipe-sucking, Nietszche-quoting Dr. Tenhausen (James Whitmore), and his lovely wife, Margaret (Tippi Hedren). Whether jointly conducting their class in human values, protecting academic standards ("Thank God, you screened Valerie Latrobe! I shudder to think what she might have done to Harrad. And she did so well on the writtens . . ."), or advising students of the need to disrobe for the 7:30 yoga seminarthey are the spirit that guides the school. They are so uncommonly, solemnly, unintentionally funny that they almost justify seeing "The Harrad Experiment," which opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater.

It's in all boroughs and done by four units: James Cunningham and Acme Dance Company, Trisha Brown and Group, Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company, Don Redlich Dance Company. title: A Connecticut chateau
description: Years of living in houses built by others for others caused architect Warren Platner to envision every aspect of his ideal home and to spare no expense when the time finally came to build it. And the site was as carefully considered as the house itself. Platner searched until he found a high open field with a view of a tidal river, salt marsh and woods next to a wildlife sanctuary in Connecticut. On the hill he placed the house, a series of three pavilions, the largest housing the living room and flanked on either side by the bedroom wing and the kitchendining room wing. All around the perimeter, Platner built fieldstone terraces some with insets of flower beds that surround the house in its own miniature park. The concept is similar to a chateau in the Loire valley, the architect says, but on a smaller scale. There is even a pond, scooped out and fed by a spring in the hillside, that catches the house in reflection (vignette, left). Platner resisted the trend to sculptural geometric architecture for his family's home. The wide roof overhangs that cap the pavilions, the deep bay windows and the cedar shingles on fieldstone foundations are forms and materials that blend with the New England landscape.

title: Monsieur Le Docteur Wins National Hurdle Handicap
description: FAIR HILL, Md., May 12 (AP) Monsieur Le Docteur, a 5yearold jumper owned by Jerome Tersney of Montclair, N. J., raced to victory in the National Hurdle Handicap at Fair Hill today after favored Minaccia fell at the ninth of 15 jumps.

description: EASTCHESTER, N.Y., May 12 Edward J. Murphy, who retired in March as freight traffic manager for the Norwegian America Line, died yesterday at his home here: His age was 67.

title: Patten s Key to Success Is Amiability
description: PERTH AMBOYTo learn why and how Representative Edward J. Patten keeps getting reelected, forget about using computers or elaborate surveys. Just take a walk with him on almost any street in the Fourth Congressional District, and the answer will become abundantly clear.

title: What is a woman of 45 to do?; The Summer Before The Dark
description: In Doris Lessing's work the arduous will and the ardent feeling are peculiarly combined. There is a sort of collision between the two, and the crash makes of her sensibility an interestingly splintered whole. The shape and design of her mind are identified by the seams and cracks. There is an enormously hard, driyen will working in her fiction, sorting out the intellectual and the political, the general and the personal. Her dour, hurt loveplots always have the lint of history and ideas clinging to them. She is very good at connecting characters with their work and their work with their feelings. Her men and women get up out of bed, after lovemaking that is flawed either by its circumstantial or its egotistic limits; they dash off to the hospital, the office, the typewriter, the drawing board, carrying with them, like cab fare, the bills of sexual and moral unease.

title: New Hope for Sunfish Pond Despite Senate Bill Rejection
description: TRENTONIn what is getting to be a familiar story, the State Senate, acting in the final hours of tits annual spring session, again defeated a measure directing New Jersey to purchase an environmental buffer zone that would praerve Sunfish Pond in Warren County.

title: Gardens

title: S. HurokLast Of the Red Hot Showmen
description: SOLOMON ISAIEVICH HUROK, the last of the red hot showmen, is 85 years old and still letting off as much heat as ever. The undisputed champion impresario of the world, the man affectionately known as Papa Hurok, is of sound mind and body as well. But it all conies to naught when the loneliness sets in. Hurok telfs of his solitary evenings. I just can't be alone. I'm so attached to people; I love people. So if I'm not doing anything one night, I call up somebody and say, come over to the house, let's have dinner, let's sit around, let's have tea. If I go to a concert, I come home, get undressed, read the newspaper or a book, and suddenly I feel that I'd like to talk to somebody, to tell somebody the bad things and the good things.

The Lord's work did not keep Mr. Stirling from improving his engine and taking out more patents in 1827 and in 1840. A 45horsepower air engine, built on his model, was used to drive the machinery at the Dundee, Scotland, foundry for three

title: Breakfast of Champions
description: Saint Sebastian has seemed more familiar of late. He sounds like an early Vonnegut character: surviving the arrows, he was later beaten to death by rods. His scenario rather resembles that of doomed Edgar Derby of Slaughterhouse Five"; Derby lived through the fire bombing of Dresden and then was executed by the Germans for helping himself to a teapot from a ruined cellar. A Vonnegut person may have a hysterectomy at 25, or prove irresistible to muggers, be swindled by termite exterminators, share an ambulance with a homicidal maniac, find himself shaking hands with Nelson Rockefeller in a grocery store, lose all his wealth in lawsuits and end up on Skid Row, have an unnecessary amputation, or die from rabies resulting from kincjpess to sick bat. But Vonnegut nearly always makes despair hilariousand perhaps that's part of the cosmic too.

title: Once in The Saddle The Cowboy's Frontier 18661896. By Laurence Ivan Seidman. 199 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $4.95. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Myths are the poetry of humanity. And how are myths made? By the passage of time, much time, and the longings of many people. If that is so, how, wonders the author of Once in the Saddle, could the world have created around the cowboy a seemingly deathless myth, when the cowboy's actual earthly chapter spanned a period of only 30 years? And that only a short hundred years ago? The first herd of cattle went up the trail from Texas in 1866, the last in 1896. Out of that brief period came the eternals of the myth: heroes by Owen Wister, romance by Zane Grey, action by Street & Smith, glamour by Hollywood, and songs by almost everyone.

Washington was taken in by Watergate, architecturally, long before it got taken in by the events inside.
