In these two memoirs, nurtured under stainedglass skies and in the powdery fragrance of moonflowers, two novelistessayists, Josephine W. Johnson and May Sarton prove the truth of this maxim.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION raised prices Of sheet and steel products by 4.8 per cent, effective June 15. The rise will increase the overall price of its steel products by 1.3 per cent, within permissible limits of economic stabilization program, the company said. The Cost of Living Council, however, will review the action and also will conduct a factfinding survey on rising prices of scrap iron and steel.... Henry Ford 2d said the Ford Motor Company planned to seek substantial price increase on its 1974 models.... Federal Reserve Board raised discount rate from 5 per cent to 6 per cent, the second such increase in three weeks. Bank of England lowered its minimum lending rate to 8 per cent from 8 per cent.

title: Recordings
description: IF the one thing you know about Olivier Messiaen is that he is a devout Catholic mystic, it becomes fairly easy to discover mystical transports in his music. By a similarly suspect kind of reasoning people easily deduce eroticism and narcotic delirium from the music of Scriabin, that other muchadvertised mystic. But it is interesting that Messiaen himself has denied mystical intent, saying he prefers to think of himself as a theologian of music. That widens the view considerably. Approached this way, the Frenchman's religiously inspired works become part of a scholastic effort to explain the universe to us. It resolves some apparent contradictions in Messiaen's work to think of him as a Thomist theologian continually struggling to reconcile the existence of both body and soul, to rationalize the physical world with the

title: Dozen in Belfast Are Injured By Bomb Blast in a Tavern

description: TOULOUSE, France, May 12 (UPI)Hooded members of a militant antitax group kidnapped a tax inspector here, dressed him in a white robe and tied him to a lamp post in a downtown square, the police said this week.

title: Climbers to Celebrate Ascent of Mt. Everest
description: NEW DELHI, India, May 12 (AP)Men who have stood on top of the world and others who have almost done so will gather in the Himalayan foothills Monday to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the first conquest of Mount Everest.

title: SUDAN SAYS A TRIAL IS DUE IN KILLINGS
description: CAIRO, May 12 (AP)A trial date for the eight defendants in the killing by Palestinian guerrillas of the American Ambassador to Khartoum and two other diplomats is expected to he announced within the next week or two, the Sudanese Minister of Information, Omer Haj Mousa, said in a telephone interview today.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When they first won the National Basketball Association championship three years ago, the Knicks were in the third ring of a New York circus that the Jets and the Mets had created with their victories in the Super Bowl and World Series. But the Jets and the Mets haven't been able to do it again. The Rangers haven't been able to do it at all. The Yankees and the Giants haven't been able to do what they once did so gloriously. As the N.B.A. champions again, only the Knicks have provided New York with a continuity of success. With most champion teams, the brains are imported. But a New Yorker has been responsible for the Knicks successWilliam (Red) Holzman, once a kid in Brownsville, once a City College guard, now the Knicks 52yearold general manager and coach, but often forgotten in the clamor for the players.

title: New Jersey
description: ACTORS CAFE THEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeWaiting for Godot. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Friday (through June 23). $3.5043.90; students, $242.90. (201) 6751881.

title: Scaling the Heights 63 Years Ago
description: In the Feb. 18 issue of the Travel Section there appeared an article set in the Adirondacks and reporting on mountainclimbing race against time that took the life of one of the two climbers. It was entitled The Challenging Mountains: Two Men Attempt 46 Peaks in 5 Days, and it drew an unusually large reader response. In the mail that the article elicited was the following reminiscence of a day's climbing in the Adirondacks in 1910. The author, Lawrence G. Brooks, graduated from Harvard Law School in 1905 and served as a district court judge in Massachusetts from 1928 to 1970. He is now 92 years old.

title: ACTION IS SOUGHT ON GATEWAY PARK
description: Twenty members of the House of Representatives from New York and New Jersey yesterday urged New York State legislators to expedite legislation needed to create the new Federal Gateway Area or risk losing Federal funds for the project.

title: Ryun Wins Pro TwoMile Run; James Breaks 440Yard Mark
Air Pollution
description: On April 11, the Environmental Protection Agency granted the nation's Big Four automakers a oneyear delay in meeting the 1975 pollution control standards mandated by the Clean Air Act of 1970. But at the same time the agency set Interim requirements that the companies also termed extremely severe, and a fight was threatened.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: 1. JONATHAN LIVINGSTON SEAGULL. Bach. Hail to thee, blithe spirit! Bird thou never wert!

title: Letters
description: My former politicalscience professor, Andrew Hacker, has pointed out to me that I might have mentioned in my article that the nation has about 523,000 law officers, any of whom can arrest any of the rest of us and give To the Editor:

title: A Poor Tomato Crop Forecast
description: TRENTON  New Jersey's commercial tomato growers will not have the usual good supply of highquality plants this year, according to William M. Cranstoun, director of the division of plant industry in the State Department of Agriculture.

title: BROOM VICTOR ON CALDER GRASS
description: MIAMI, May 12 (AP)Crown Stables Bazoom, the favorite with the crowd of 11,835, scored a convincing victory today in the $17,700 Boca Raton Handicap at Calder Race Course,

title: Perfume: A Defense Of Using the Civet
description: PHILADELPHIA  Under normal circumstances, the civet, or civet cat, manages to attract very little attention.

title: Bombing And Impeaching
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The latest word from the White House is that President Nixon is changing not only his staff but his style in hope of repairing the Watergate damage and blocking any move toward his impeachment.

title: Art Center to Gain From Home Tour
description: ENGLEWOODA tour of five Bergen County homes, an afternoon in which the participants will be able to inspect the works and studios of two of the country's leading artists, the architecture of Edward Durrell Stone and collections of Eskimo, African and Polynesian graphics, sculpture and art, will be conducted here next Sunday under the auspices of the Art Center of Northern New Jersey.

title: Experts Warn Governors on Impact of Energy Crisis
description: Energy experts told the nation's Republican Governors meeting. here last week that the United States faces huge trade deficits as it becomes increasingly dependent on foreign fuels and raw materials.

title: JEWS WILL FORM SAVECITY PANELS
description: The Rabbinical Council of America has called on Orthodox synagogues throughout the country to establish politicalaction committees to prevent the flight of Jews from the inner cities and safeguard the character and viability of the Jewish community.

title: Brown Team Captures Title in Ivy Lacrosse
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 12 Brown University ignored a steady rain today to defeat Dartmouth, 156, and clinch its first outright Ivy League lacrosse championship on Chase Field.

title: Three Poems by Andrei Voznesensky
description: He arrived with me from the other shore, lost, having wandered onto my boat. The ant heaps don't dig him. He's an ant from the other shore.

title: Justice Douglas Honored
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Supreme Court Associate Justice William 0. Douglas was named a commander of the Order of the Golden Ark this week in a ceremony at the Netherlands Embassy. The order recognizes outstanding service in the cause of conservation.

title: South Shore High Captures Track Crown of Flatbush
description: South Shore High School, in its third year of track competition, posted five victories yesterday and won the Flatbush championships held at its field in Brooklyn.

title: Israel
description: JERUSALEMIt was a tumultuous celebration. With 24 hours of nonstop street dancing, song festivals, bonfires, fireworks and a massive military parade on Monday morning, Israel last week celebrated its 25th anniversary as an independent nation.

title: Chinese Gymnasts to Visit Next
description: For the first time since before World War II, a competitive gymnastic team from mainland China will tour the United States.

title: MASTERWORK SINGS DURUFLE AND ORFF
description: The notes for the Masterwork Chorus's concert Friday night at Philharmonic Hall described the two works on the program as being in very different styles.

title: CHURCH AND STATE DUELING IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, May 12 (AP)Almost three years after agreein to improve relations, Poland Communist Government and the Roman Catholic Church are quarreling.

title: Clash Reported Halted at Florida Prison
description: BUSHNELL, Fla., May 12 (AP)Riot control guards halted a clash between black and white inmates at Sumter Correctional Institution tonight, freeing five whites who had been held hostage during the melee, officials said.

title: Tarangioli Wins at Prep Net
description: Neil Tarangioli of Fordham Prep won the 58th annual Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis championship from his teammate, Jim McNamara, 46, 64, 62, at Fordham University yesterday. Tarangioli also won in 1972.

title: Skylab
description: The era of the cost accountant has come to the space age. That is the hard reality behind the technical wiz ardry and marvels scheduled to be unveiled by the Skylab program whose first two rockets stand poised for launching at Cape Kennedy. Successful execution of this project will undoubtedly return a wealth of new scientific and technical data, particularly knowledge about the reactions of the human body to prolonged weightlessness in space. But a basic question has not yet been answered concerning the costbenefit ratios involved: the advantage gained by putting men into space worth the high price that must be paid?

title: American Talent Starts to Show
description: It was fantastic in Dallas and unbelievable in Miami when the North American Soccer League opened its season last weekend before large crowds. And it was shattering in Philadelphia Friday night as the Atoms, the league's newest member, set a league attendance reccord by attracting 21,700 fans. Ron Newman, the Dallas Tornado coach who is known as soccer's ambassador to Dallas, and Al Miller, coach of the Atoms and former coach of Hartwick College, field teams that, except for St. Louis, have the most Americanborn players. One of the reasons for the large crowd in Philadelphia was because those two teams were the rivals.

title: A Poisoned Politics
description: With the onset of the cold war more than a quartercentury ago, the American people and their Government encountered an unexpected and unfamiliar challenge. Although formally at peace with the Soviet Union, the United States and its friends abroad found themselves the target of a relentless Sovietcontrolled campaign of espionage, propaganda, political subversion, and intimidation. On the foundations of wartime intelligence organizations, the United States developed the Central Intelligence Agency, Radio Free Europe, and various fronts which subsidized magazines, student organizations, and political groups overseas to counter similar groups financed by the Soviet Union.

title: The Lure of Covers
description: You may not be able to judge a book by its cover but the cover may sell you on the book anyway. It is, after all, the package of the product, the advertisement for the contents.

title: Transit Hearing on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The Senate Surface Transportation Subcommittee will conduct a hearing May 29 in Los Angeles on proposals to study highspeed mass transit systems on the West Coast and into British Columbia, Canada.

title: STUDY WILL FOCUS ON WORLD CONFLICTS
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has appropriated $275,000 to start an experimental fellowship program on the subject of conflict in international relations and has hired a fulltime consultant to carry out the program.

title: News Summary and Index.
A Sabbath Visit To Mea Shearim
AN ATTACK BREAKS TRUCE IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12The ceasefire between the Lebanese Army and Palestinian (guerrillas was broken by one incident along Lebanon's northern border with Syria today when a group of armed men fired rockets and mortars at a customs post.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Peter F. Drucker's attack on technology assessment is uninformed about the concept and thoughtless in his projection of its impotence and hazards.

title: Son to the Harrises
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Keith Harris on April 15 in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Harris is the former Miss Helen Satterthwaite.

title: AROUND THE
description: Except for cooler northern regions, set out eggplants, melons, tomatoes.... Put out shallow pans of beer to prevent slugs from nibbling the young seedlings.... Sow lima beans... Keep up the garden spray routine on fruits and roses.... Mulch after watering and weeding.

title: U.S. Space Station No. I
description: Standing tall and somewhat aloof from each other, five miles apart on their launch pads at Cape Kennedy, two huge Saturn moon rockets await the signal to open up what NASA Administrator James Fletcher calls a new moment in space history. Rocket I, scheduled to be launched tomorrow, will send into orbit an instant officehomelaboratory, fully equipped to the last space handkerchief. Rocket II, due to follow the next day, will supply three astronauts trained to set up housekeeping and go to work. Together, earth man and space habitat will make up Skylab, the largest, most elegant, most automated, most complex, most habitable, most interestingand just possibly the most usefulmanned space vehicle ever launched into orbit by the United States.

title: Major League Averages
U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Americans, whose total annual expenditure on leisure and recreational activities is approaching the $100billion mark, are expected in record numbers this summer at vacation spots across the country.

title: Fire Stops Presses in Poland
description: WARSAW, May 12 (Reuters) Fire has destroyed the Polish State printing works here and unconfirmed reports said as many as 30 people were seriously injured. The capital was without most of its Morning newspapers today.

title: All 6 Australian States Challenge Whitlam
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 12 The readers of the six state governments of Australia announced today that they would make a joint appeal to Queen Elizabeth II on the issues of states rights and relations with the British Crown.

title: Thought Itself Is the Subject of This Art
description: CONTEMPORARY art, particularly that which strikes the public as outrageous, is welcomed in even the toniest of our academic institutions providing that it's used for educational ends. What better answers the student cry for relevance than to probe the most advanced contemporary art in terms of their own lives and on their own turf? Certainly, for more than a quartercentury in America there has been a strong link between the elusive nature of the experience of contemporary art and a support system in which the prestigious university museum can and often does play key role.

title: ENCORE PROGRAM PROVES A SUCCESS
description: There was a friendly, festive air about the second of the 6 o'clock Encore series presented at Town Hall last Tuesday before a large audience. The concert was thoroughly enjoyable, and its only fault was that the three excellent performers proved to be a crowd.

title: An Elite Circuit for Golfs Elite Goes on Drawing Board
description: A restructured United States pro golf tour that would allow more leeway for leading play. ers is forecast by Commissioner Joseph Dey of the Tournament Players Division of the Profes. sional Golfers Association.

title: USAC Puts the Brakes On Activities of Drivers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 A serious blow to the organization of American auto racing was struck here this weekend when the United States Auto Club withdrew from the Automobile Competition Committee of the United States, the liaison between American racing and the international governing authority, the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile. If the club remains adamant, its resignation means that driver interchange between USAC and other racesanctioning clubs will be severely curtailed, if not eliminated. As examples, world championship drivers from Europe could no longer run the Indianapolis 500, A. J. Foyt could not compete in Grand National stock car races, and Mario Andretti could not race in a Grand Prix or manufacturers chamevent. About poliship event. About Motor Sports

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Two fishless days on Connecticut's Housatonic and Farmington rivers provided a forceful lesson in humility, but also introduced this writer to a brace of fine trout streams only a few hours by car from New York City.

title: Mayor Back From Trip To See Soviet Premier
description: Mayor Lindsay, returning from the weeklong visit to the Soviet Union, said yesterday he had discussed the problems of Soviet Jews with Premier Alexei Kosygin. Mr. Lindsay called the talks useful and constructive.

title: Jailed Vietnamese Won't Get Degree Proposed at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 12The trustees of Yale University, citing a division of opinion, decided today not to award an honorary degree this year to Ngo Ba Thanh, jailed Vietnamese lawyer, despite a petition campaign by more than 1,000 faculty members and students to grant her the award. The petitioners had appealed to the trustees to honor Mrs.

title: Brooklyn Pretzel Vender Wins Honorary Degree
description: The man who has been selling pretzels and soft drinks to students at Brooklyn College from his post outside the campus gate has been awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Delectables for his years of service and his interest in the lives of young people.

title: Paperbacks
description: MY NAME IS ASHER LEV, by Chaim Potok. (Fawcett, $1.50.) The clash between the values of Hassidic Jewry and of modernism are dramatized in a deftly told story of a painter and his compulsion for art.

title: On a Spring Sunday, Budapest Is aBlessing
description: BUDAPEST, May 12 The lilacs have burst into bloom on the hills of Buda to match the chestnut blossoms along the embankment of the Danube. The sunshine and warmth of a precocious summer bring the people of Budapest out in swarms to join the clouds of tourists strolling about the city or cruising on the river.

title: A Tale of Censure and Censorship Weaves a Tangled Course at Cliton Library
description: CLIFTON  The Clifton Public Librarysmall angular and austere  stands at one end of a park that abuts Route 46. The noise of the traffic a few feet behind the building seems more symbolic of the library's involvement in controversy than do the park's tidy lawn and springgreen trees.

description: JACKSON, Miss., May 12 (AP)  The Southwestern Athletic Conference named Andrew Brown of Stanford University as its commissioner today.

description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 12Mr. and Mrs. George J. McGuirk have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Cheryl Ann McGuirk, to William Allen Haverinen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haverinen of South Paris, Me.

description: ROME, May 12The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has issued an urgent appeal for international aid to help stave off famine in six West African countries plagued by drought.

description: May 16Sisterhood of East End Temple. Tickets $11 and $13.50 from Mrs. Mac Burstein, 545 East 14th Street.

title: P.G.A. Moves Tourneys
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 12 (UPI)The Professional Golfers Association announced today it was moving its winter program of five tournaments to the St. Lucie Hilton Golf Club's Saints and Sinners golf courses. The P.G.A. moved out of its, former hearquarters at Palm Beach Gardens earlier this year because of an inability to reach a mutually satisfactory financial arrangement.

title: Australia Lifts Export Curbs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, May 12 (Reuters)  The Australian Government has relaxed controls on strategic Worts covering commercial trade with North Vietnam, North Korea, Cuba, the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has announcd.

title: Exotic World of Foreign Exchange
description: LONDONIt takes time and a keen eye to find 33 Lombard Street in the heart of the City of London.

title: Some like it boiled
description: Rice is a sneaky little grain, much more versatile than most people suspect. The two extraordinarily good dishes on this page should inspire cooks to think rice more often. Both should be made with longgrain rice. Indeed, the success of the mushroom risotto depends on using longgrain rice from Italy. The recipe couldn't be more authentic. It was given us by Perla Meyers who learned it while working in the kitchen of Colina Pistoiese, a restaurant in Turin.

title: Fire Investigators To Meet at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICKFire investigators will convene at Rutgers University June 48 for the university's annual Arson and Fire Investigation Conference.

description: The time Is ripe for fundamental reforms in the. assessment of real property in New York City.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE international economic status of the United States, which has been so precarious and unsettling in recent years, seems to have acquired new strengthquite suddenly and unexpectedly since the dark days of last winter.

title: Henry Sheedy Burden Weds Elizabeth Weekes
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 12Miss Elizabeth Blanchard Weekes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Underhill Weekes, was married here today to Henry Sheedy Burden, son of I. Townsend Burden of Locust Valley and the late Mrs. Burden.

title: J. LEONARD MOORE, PEDIATRICIAN, DIES
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 Dr. J. Leonard Moore, a prom inent pediatrician, died today in the Medical Center at Prince ton University. He was 73 years old and resided at 59 Westcott Road.

title: Rent Agitation Grows in Westchester
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y.When Day 2 of Phase 3 in the Nixon economy dawned on New Rochelle, the telephone in Anita Arbeitel's apartment began ringing right after breakfast. It was the Mayor's office. Rent complaints.

description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 12 Pennsylvania and Navy turned the 39th Heptagonal outdoor track and field championships into a nipandtuck dual meet today. With a gusty wind chilling the alsorans at Brown's Alumni Stadium, the Quaker runners overcame the early margin of Navy's superior weight men to win their third title in a row, 8280.

title: U.S. and Many Colleges Try to Recruit Students Among Indians
description: The Federal Government and many colleges have undertaken a major effort in the last few years to recruit American Indian students.

title: Ballet: A Dexterously Mixed Bag
description: The variety of New York City Ballet's repertory is of course remarkable. But it is all the more remarkable in that it is primarily the responsibility of just two men Jerome Robbins, and, most of all, the company's architect and resident carpenter, George Balanchine.

title: Bible Quiz In Israel Won by Girl From City
description: Last week in Jerusalem Leora Reich of Flatbush nervously entered the final session of a test of knowledge of the Bible that had originally drawn 60,000 contestants. After the session was over ZA'man Shazar, the President of Israel, was likening her to Preimer Golda Meir.

title: Head of Council of Churches
description: SYRACUSE, May 12 (AP)Dr. Jon L. Regier of River Edge, N. J., will succeed Dr. Kenneth A. Readarmel, who is retiring, as executive director of the New York State Council of Churches, the organization announced today.

title: Buddhists Enmeshed in a Zoning Suit
description: HOHOKUSThree Buddhist monks from Hong Kong have run into a legal snarl over the templemonastery that they have established in a ranch house here.

title: Drug Center Seeks To Shape Behavior
description: NORTH BERGEN  Staff members and residents of Harold House, a therapeutic community for adolescents involved in drug use and beset by a variety of behavorial disorders share a general sense of optimism as the program swings into its second year.

title: Major League Baseball
ATOMTEST BLAST SET IN COLORADO
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. May 12The third and so far largest experimental nuclear blast aimed at freeing natural gas trapped in deep underground rock formations is scheduled to jar the northwest Colorado countryside Thursday morning.

title: Hashish Worth $1.5Million Reported Seized in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 12 (AP)Customs agents reported the seizure of 750 pounds of hashish worth $1.5million in Boston's North End today. Five persons were arrested.

title: An opinion by one of those softheaded judges
description: President Nixon recently turned the glare of his Administration's intelligence onto the problems of crime and punishment, and showed us once again that the main thing is to identify the villains. Prominent among the night creatures thus exposed: the softheaded judge. Judges are too soft on criminals. Soft, mind you, not in the heart, a quality that might seem at least humane, though still a failing; but soft in the head, a condition of either severe disability or calculated subversion of the public interest. The time has come, the President said, for softheaded judges... to show as much concern for the rights of innocent victims of crime as they do for the rights of convicted criminals.

title: John J. Metzger Jr. Marries Miss Hall
description: TAMWORTH, ,N. H., May 12Miss Rebecca Welles Hall, daughter of Edward M. Hall and Mrs. Muriel Welles Hall of Freedom, N. H., was married here this afternoon to John Jacob Metzger Jr., a staff photographer for the Gannett newspapers in Rochester. The Right Rev. Edward R. Welles, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of West Missouri and uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's in the Valley Episcopal Church.

title: State Post to Hudson Dentist
description: JERSEY CITYMore than 50 years ago, Deckle McLean's dream was shattered by bigotry.

title: Jumping Coach Joins the Hunt
description: Bert de Nemethy, coach of the United States Equestrian Team's Prix des Nations (jumping) squad, will begin a nationwide search for new riders and horses next weekend at Lake Erie College in Mentor, Ohio.

title: ASHE JOINS SMITH IN $50,000 FINAL
description: DALLAS, May 12 (UPI) Arthur Ashe fought off a comeback attempt by Ken Rosewall last night and defeated the little Australian, 64, 62, 57, 16, 62 to set up an allAmerican final in the $100,000 World Championship Tennis tour windup tomorrow.

title: Screen: Festival Shorts
Weather Service Will Halt Overtime When It's Calm
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The National Weather Service has ordered its offices across the country to cut out services temporarily when the weather is calm rather than pay overtime.

title: PATFIET LAO SAYS NO FRONT  EXISTS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12The Communistled Pathet Lao today denied the existence of any formal Indochina Communist front, implying that it was free to negotiate a permanent political settlement in Laos independent of a settlement covering Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: Gain for Women in B.B.C.
description: LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) Women in Britain have achieved one more step on the round to equality: They may become television camera operators. The British broadcastIng Corporation has ruled that in the future none of its jobs will be barred to women. Women have held B.B.C. jobs, but operation of cameras and recording equipment was barred to them because it sometimes involved lifting heavy gear.

title: Texas Southern Increases Lead in Title Track Meet
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 13 (AP)Texas Southern increased its lead today over Southern University of Louisiana in the Southwestern Athletic Conference track meet. After 10 events, Texas Southern had 91 points and Southern 69.

title: The Green Miracle
description: MidMay and we have a green world again, lawns, pastures, parkland, meadows and woodland. We are particularly aware of the trees, in city, suburbs or countryside, for they have so swiftly changed from naked branches to soft green contours. Buds burst, inconspicuous blossoms hurried through their brief cycle even as the leaves themselves were appearing, at first tiny flecks of green, then a mist of every shade of green that is. The young leaves drooped on weak stems, infantile, but soon expanded, strengthened, and now are rustling the breeze, pattering in the rain, dancing in the sunlight.

title: Cinderella Is Discovered in Soviet Tennis
description: The fairy tale Cinderella is not unknown in the Soviet Union. And besides the stage version of Zolushka (Cinderella) playing regularly at Moscow's venerable Vakhtangov Theater in the 19721973 season there is at least one reallife Zolushka in the U.S.S.R. Her name is Evgeniya (Zhenya) Biryukova. Like the Vakhtangov's Zolushka, who is confronted with her stepmother's two daughters, Evgeniya has been overshadowed if not victimized by two female rivals. Their names are Olga Morozova and Marina Kroshina.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Those who remember Burman's Steamboat Round the Bend or who have read his Catfish Bend stories, will welcome this reprise of his love affair with the Mississippi. This is mostly anecdotes from the old days of steamboating; Mr. Burman was once a cub pilot himself and vividly recalls the characters who steered the big ships down the treacherous, boundless river. He eavesdrops on the roustabouts, rides a show boat and then, in his last chapter, boards one of the modern, radarequipped towboats that now ply the Mississippi. For all the mechanization, he concludes, the

title: Braves Win, 142, In 18Hit Assault On Padre Pitching
ABRAHAM W. SCHEFFRES
description: Abraham W. Scheffres, founder, chief executive officer and former chairman of the A. W. Scheffres Corporation, textile manufacturer, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Somerville Faces Progress Warily
description: SOMERVILLELike any of the 21 communities in New Jersey that are county seats, Somerville, the seat of Somerset County, finds that its population grows tremendously during business hours and tapers off as twilight arrives. Because of this, the 14,000 residents of this 2.4squaremile borThe Talk ough feel that they face problems they lems they would Somerville never have to cope with if they could remain the kind of suburban town they have dreamed of for many years.

title: Committee Hearings Of the Council Open To Public This Week
description: The following are City Council committee hearings this week open to the public. They will be held in the Council committee room.

title: Proposal To Study Pond on L.I. Is Opposed
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. It the trustees of this East End town have their way the $40,000 that Suffolk County allocated last week for a study of methods of preserving the fresh water in Georgica Pond will go down the drain.

title: Montreal Olympics Chief Appoints Two Top Aides
description: MONTREAL, May 12 (UPI)Roger Rousseau, president of the 1976 Montreal Olympic Committee, has announced the appointment of JeanPierre Cyr as sports director and Andre Kaltenback as director of information, communications division.

title: Unsentimental journey into the past
description: From meditations on baseball, primitive television and the dawn of rock n roll, this book fashions a smart personal history of our last 20 years. Its author coauthored, with Jack Newfield, A Populist Manifesto, an important book on populist politics and was an aide to Mayor Lindsay. Here he evokes some of the cultural forces that mandated his earlier work.

title: DR. WILLIAM H. NEWTON
description: UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 12Dr. William Howard Newton, veterinarian here for 30 years, died yesterday at the age of 58.

title: DOBERMAN TAKES TOP SHOW AWARD
description: LUDWIGS CORNER, Pa., May 12  A 4yearold Doberman pinscher, Ch. Andelane's Indigo Rock, owned by Charles A. T. O'Neill of Philadelphia, defeated 1,679 rivals yesterday and earned the bestinshow award at the 30th annual Chester Valley Kennel Club fixture at the Ludwigs Corner horse show grounds.

title: Miss Doscher Wed To Donald Spurdle
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 12Miss Diane Doscher, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Schulken Doscher of Riverside, was married here this afternoon to Donald L. Spurdle, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spurdle of Highlands, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. William J. Murphey.

title: Poor School District in Carolina Angered by Expected Loss of U.S. Funds
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., May 12At the Lion Street Elementary School here, located in a black residential neighborhood, 64 per cent of children enrolled are from low income families.

title: Cartoonist Excels As Musician, Too
description: PRINCETON  He's a former jazz musician who only whistles now.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market can't seem to decide which way to move. It's up one week and down the next. Recently it has started to swing like a pendulum in as short a period as a single day.

title: ExEnvoy to Lead U. S. Group for U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12Edward M. Korry, a former diplomat and journalist, has been elected president of the United Nations Association of the United States of America. He succeeds Porter McKeever, who has resigned.

title: Narrowing the gap of shame
description: All the visitors who come to see me in South Africa, many of them from the United States of America, some of them knowing more about our country than most of us who live there, ask me the question: What is your future? Which implies: Where are you going? Will white South Africa ever come to its senses? Or will she behave like the blind

title: ExReferee Has Surgery
description: MONTREAL, May 12 (Canadian Press)John Ashley, former National Hockey League referee, was operated on for appendicitis today and was reported in satisfactory condition at Montreal General Hospital.

title: Phase 3
description: WASHINGTON  Phase 3 of President Nixon's economic stabilization program, teetering close to the edge of failure, received a few brisk shoves toward the precipice from organized labor last week.

title: Russian jinx
description: The Russian version of Skylab is the smaller (271/2 tons vs. 100 tons) Salyut, which seems to have developed into a jinx ship. The first Salyut was orbited in April, 1971, and three cosmonauts in a Soyuz craft docked with it, but a hatch problem prevented them from entering; after fiveandahalf hours the mission was aborted and they returned home. Two months afterward, a fresh trio of cosmonauts linked up with the Salyut and spent a record 23 days in it. They were found dead on their return to earth, and it was discovered later that a hatch seal in the capsule had failed a half hour before landing, causing fatal decompression in the cabin.

title: Brezhnev's Summit Visit To U.S. Scheduled June 18
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, will visit the United States from June 18 to 26 for talks with President Nixon, the White House announced today.

title: Clinton Matmen Capture 5 Titles in P.S.A.L Event
description: Clinton High of the Bronx gained five titles to dominate the first Public School Athletic League individual wrestling championships at John F. Kennedy High yesterday afternoon. Wrestlers from 25 schools, 167 of them, competed in the twoday event.

title: Can We Now Forget the Evil That She Did?
description: THE falsification of history is one of man's most popular sports, ranging from Stalin's elimination of Trotsky to portrayals of our war in Vietnam as a peacemaking mission. A new chapter was added to this timehonored practice with the recent televising on WCBS's Camera Three of a twopart program about Leni Riefenstahlan unfortunate whitewash of a great and dangerous film artist responsible for one of the most notorious masterpieces of world cinema, Triumph of the Will.

title: ACUPUNCTURE DUE FOR STATE STUDY
description: ALBANY, May 12Governor Rockefeller named a special commission today to assess the merits of acupuncture and recommend measures for regulating the practice of the ancient Chinese technique of needle therapy.

title: Chess. Many a Practicer Forgets What It Was He Preached
Art Worth $11,700 Stolen From Residence of Dr. Salk
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., May 12 (AP)Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of the Salk polio vaccine, has reported four works of art with a total value, of $11,700 stolen from his home.

title: Emily Rooney Is Married
description: RENSSELAERVILLE, N, Y. May 12Miss Emily Rooney, a copy writer for radio station WBRK in Pittsfield, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Radford Berky Jr., a reporter for the same station. Justice of the Peace Eugene M. Kellam of Medusa performed the ceremony at the summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Rooney of Rowayton, Conn. Mr. Rooney is a writerproducer for C.B.S. News. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Berky of Washington.

description: TEANECK Elston HowTuesday through Saturday. and of the New York YanPrivate showings are availkees is better known as a able by appointment. phone: ballplayer and coach than as (201) 8367707. an art dealer, bust just wait. The Elston Howard Gallery. which specializes in Haitian

title: Northeastern Crew. Wins Eastern Sprint Title
PATH Riders Offer Thanks to Hoboken
description: HOBOKENThousands of PATH commuters will begin raising money Tuesday in order to send 120 underprivileged Hoboken children to summer camp. The fund drive will be the commuters way of expressing their appreciation for the cooperation they have received from the City of Hoboken and its residents during the sixweekold rail strike.

title: Roosevelt Industry Blocked
description: MINEOLA, L.I.A controversial preliminary plan to relocate 160 to 200 families in Roosevelt, a predominantly black community in the unincorporated area of the Town of Hempstead, as part of a $30million redevelopment program to help ease the tax problem, was killed last week because of objec tions from residents.

title: Brownstein Accuses Bar Group Of Harassment in His Campaign
description: Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein charged yesterday that the New York State Bar Association was trying to harass his drive for the chief judgeship of the Court of Appeals by criticizing his campaign efforts.

title: SANDMAN SCORED ON U.S.AID STAND
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., May 11 (UPI)Governor Cahill charged today that his opponent for the Republican gubernatorial nomination had turned his back on New Jersey when he refused to vote for the Federal revenuesharing program.

title: MRS. CHARLES H. HAIGHT
description: Mrs. Beverly Matthewson Haight, wife of Charles H. Haight, treasurer of the Grand Union Company, died Thursday aboard the cruise ship Victoria returning to New York. She was 52 years old and lived in Oradell, N.J.

title: Washington Crew Is First, With Junior Varsity Next
description: SEATTLE, May 12 (AP)The University of Washington varsity crew captured the Steward's Cup today, scoring a victory of more than a boat length over the school's junior varsity on the Lake Washington course.

title: Notes: New Bank GiftTravel
description: PHILADELPHIA bank Is giving away trips to Europe and the Caribbean as a way of attracting new deposits. It is the first bank in the nation to do so. The program is called fly now, pay never and the arrangements were worked out with Pan American World Airways.

title: Plan to Demolish the Santa Monica Pier Angers Residents and Brings Political Turmoil
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif, May 12"It is as good as Cannes, proclaimed 10yearold Penelope Sudrow as she glanced up from a hot chocolate long enough to compare the Santa Monica pier to that of the Mediterranean resort.

title: S. M. Beliveau Fiance of Miss Murray
description: BANGOR, Me., May 12Miss Cynthia Ann Murray plans to be married to Severin M. Beliveau of Rumford, former chairman of the Maine State Democratic party. The prospective bridegroom and his brother, Albert Beliveau Jr., are partners in the Rumford law firm of Beliveau & Beliveau.

title: East Germany Admitted To World Health Group
description: GENEVA, May 12Rebuffed regularly since 1968 in its bids for membershiplast year by a vote of 70 to 28 with 25 abstentionsEast Germany has been admitted by acclamation to the World Health Organization by the agency's annual assembly of member states.

title: R. S. Brach to Wed Vicki Seltzer
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., May 12Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Seltzer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vicki Lynn Seltzer, to Richard Stephen Brach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brach of Mexico City.

title: Forever Panting
description: Peter De Vries has got his new title from Keatsa cheeky yet apposite source. Doomed young pagans like Keats could well have special charms for this insufficiently lapsed Calvinist, who has often shown doom as dogging sensuality. And since what he writes are specifically parodiesburlesque versions of the lyricalit was sound pedantry to steal the name for this particular burlesque from Ode on a Grecian Urn. Keats's words, naturally, no longer have Keats's meaning: the panting you can hear in Forever Panting is of an ignominiods kind unthinkable in a 19thcentury ode. So the corrosion of lyricism starts on the title page, as De Vries sets out once again to prove that it's not high thoughts that make the world go round but low cunning.

title: Osteopaths to Meet For Medical Talks
description: McAFEEThe New Jersey Association of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons will hold its 72d annual convention here next weekend.

title: World Record of 7:10.4 Set in TwoMile Relay
Shaper Sails to Victory In 3d Star Class Race
The Knicks Through the Eyes of Youth
description: The spelling could stand some polishing, but the message is clear: Miss Kobbe's secondgrade class in Larchmont, N.Y., likes the New York Knicks. Especially Walt Frazier.

title: F.B.I. Watch on Nixon Aides Said to Be Sham
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have complained that their assignment to guard the offices of two recently resigned White House aides was a sham, The Chicago SunTimes said in its Sunday editions.

title: Rochester Institute Victor
description: ROCHESTER, May 12 (AP)Rochester Institute of Technology easily won its fifth straight team title today at the Upstate New York track and field championships. Albany took runnerup honors.

title: The Region
description: The toughest antidrug program in the nation was Governor Rockefeller's description of the new bills he signed Into law last week.

title: Sometimes It Pays to Be All Thumbs
description: TEANECKJohn Brown, an electrica6l engineer whose home is in Teaneck and whose job is in Lower Manhattan, was on the way to catch a commuter's bus on Route 4. Impulsively, he thrust his thumb out in a typical hitchhiker's stance and a passing motorist stopped to offer him a lift.

title: Miss Conkey Married to Henry R. Baker
description: OTTAWA, Ill., May 12Miss Elizabeth Holmes Conkey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Conkey of Ottawa and Naples, Fla., and Henry R. Baker were married here this afternoon at the home of her parents by the Rev. Curtis T. Schowalter of the Congregational Church.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynPhotographs of Coney Island by Harry Lapow, at the lobby gallery, Metcalfe Hall, Long Island University Brooklyn Center, Flatbush Avenue Extension at DeKalb Avenue. Hours: 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. today Saturday, Monday through Friday 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

title: Drug Raid Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, will hold a Senate subcommittee hearing, next Friday in Chicago on drug raids by law enforcement officials last month against two Collinsville, Ill., families.

title: The Life To Come
description: The Life to Come is the title of a short story that was written 70 years ago by E. M. Forster and is receiving its first publication today. The author himself valued it: it came more from my heart than anything else I have been able to turn out, containing a great deal of sorrow and passion that I have myself experienced. But because the sorrow and passion had a homosexual nature, the story has gone unpublished. Upon Forster's death, not quite three years ago, it was bequeathed to King's College, Cambridge, along with his other unpublished papers: two novels in substantial fragments (in addition to Maurice), and stories, plays, poems, essays, letters, notebooks, diaries. Of the total work of Forster, who lived to be 91, the reading public saw during his lifetime no more than perhaps onehalf. Now, The Life to Come is giving its title to one volume of what is being published in England as a new and as nearly as possible comedition of E. M. Forster.

title: Nixon Thanks Governors For Support on Watergate
description: Seventeen Republican Governors who announced their support of President Nixon in the Watergate case have received a telegram of appreciation from him.

title: Brustein in London
Solitude always excited her Hide and Seek
description: In a wise and artful work in autobiographical form, Jessamyn West explores not only her life but also herself as a woman who relishes solitudean uncharted seeking. Female solitaries suffer more than their male counterparts, she points out. They were not created, as man was, for their own sake, but to be a companion to man.... When a woman asks to be alone.. [she] feels wicked, unloving, defying God and man alike. Men, in this instance (as in most) consider themselves on the side of the Lord God. By way of echoes and the mirroring of images, with a style that suggests the athlete's easy power, she has produced a surprising, mysterious, haunting book. Also funny one.

title: OVERNIGHT SAILING DRAWS 53 ENTRIES
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 12The New York Athletic Club's 64th annual distance race for the Winged Foot Trophy drew 53 entries for tonight's start off Execution Rocks.

title: L.I. Sound Study Runs Behind Schedule
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.  The 3 Long Island Sound Regional Study is now some months behind schedule, but already early statistics show the increasing pressures of population on this area.

title: Biaggi Refused to Answer 16 Questions Before Jury
description: Representative Mario Biaggi's testimony before a Federal grand jury in 1971 was released yesterday, and it directly contradicted his assertions over several months that he specifically had not invoked the Fifth Amendment and that the questions had not been related to his finances. The minutes showed that Mr. Biaggi had refused to answer 16 questions by invoking his constitutional rights against selfincrimination.

title: Bergen Evans Still Has Last Word
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 12The course is listed in the Northwestern University catalogue as English B10, Introductions to Literature, but most of the students call it introduction to Bergen Evansthe man who has taught it for the last 40 years.

title: Skylab Set to Go Up Tomorrow; Astronauts to Follow Tuesday
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla, May 12 The two countdowns for Skylab launchings, one Monday for the space station and the other Tuesday for the Apollo ferry, continued to run smoothly here today.

title: Anne Harvey Wed to F. G. Davidson 3d
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa., May 12 Miss Anne McPherson Harvey, manager of price evaluation in the marketing department of Pan American World Airways in New York, was married here this noon to Frank Gassaway Davidson 3d of New York, a lawyer with the trust and estate department of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York.

title: Centrowitz, Masbach Win in Loucks Games
State's Greener Pastures Luring Major Companies
A Good Season Is Predicted for Home Vegetable Gardens
description: ALBANY  Home vegetable gardeners are looking forward to a big season this year, helped by the mild weather that has given the growers an earlier start than usual.

title: Suzanne Marquard Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Marquard Jr. of New York and Quogue, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne T. Marquard, to Paul A. Vernaglia Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Vernaglia of Winchester, Mass.

title: A HAPPY HARVEST IN EAST GERMANY
description: OHNA, East Germany, May 3At the luncheon table of the local inn, Gerhard Schimmel, a blond 45yearold, pushed the boiled potatoes to one side of his plate, explaining that he had to watch his weight.

title: The World
description: BEIRUT  The land of Lebanon, half Christian, half Moslem, has been vulnerable to national disunity since independence from France in 1943. In 1958 a virtual civil war that divided the country along coldwar lines was snuffed out only after the United States landed 15,000 Marines. In the past two weeks the Lebanese have again been faced with the specter of civil war, this time over the issue of Governmental control over the Palestinian guerrillas who use Lebanon as a base in their terrorist campaign against Israel.

title: RIZZO FIGHTS RISE IN SCHOOL TAXES
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12A political battle between Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and the City Council over proposed tax increases may make Philadelphia schoolchildren the losers.

title: Robert F. Wilson, 69, Dies; Assistant Counsel for City
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12Robert F. Wilson, a retired assistant corporation counsel of New York City, died yesterday in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 4004 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Golden Gate Suicide Barrier
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (UPI)The directors of the Golden Gate Bridge voted yesterday to proceed with studies for building a barrier to prevent suicides from the span. A total of 439 persons have jumped to their deaths from the bridge since it was completed in 1937.

title: News Summary and Index
He's Making a Big Numbers  Racket
description: WHEN Raymond St. Jacques was shooting Book of Numbers on location in Dallas, Texas, he discovered the emergence of a new social phenomenon: the White Uncle Tom. As producer, director and star of the highly praised milliondollar action movie, he found himself a Black bossman to a band of local union members, many of them bigoted Whites.

title: Vietcong Charge U.S. Truce Violations
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (AP)The Vietcong charged today that American warplanes had resumed bombing in South Vietnam in violation of the ceasefire.

title: Whites Fear of Black Rebels Spreading in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 12When the white farmers of northeastern Rhodesia make latenight visits to check the temperature in their tobaccocuring barns these days, they go armed, and never at the same hour twice.

title: Jazz/Rock/Folk/Pop
description: NEGRO ENSEMBLE COMPANY, St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, 2:30 P.M. Ruth Brisbane sings The Legacy of Bessie Smith, with the Revelations.

title: William Henry Todd 3d Weds Joan M. Dowling
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 12St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Joan Millicent Dowling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Dowling, to William Henry Todd 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Todd of Rye, N. Y.

title: Utilities Are Told They Must Set Up Complaint Process
description: ALBANY, May 12  The Public Service Commission said today it was requiring each utility in the state to set up formal procedures for resolving customer complaints.

title: Pomfret School Names A New Headmaster
description: Kenneth M. Deitch will become headmaster of the Pomfret School in Pomfret, Conn., on July 1, succeeding Joseph K. Milnor Jr., who is retiring after 12 years in the post.

title: Bronx Opera Goes South
description: The Bronx Opera Company traveled several miles south from its native habitat last weekend for two performances of Don Giovanni on Friday and Saturday nights at Hunter College. Since 1967, this group has been offering two annual productions, in English and with orchestra, for its uptown community, but this appears to be its first venture into the more competitive atmosphere of midtown.

title: Hunt's Wig Lives
description: If there is a saving aspect of the Watergate and related disclosures, it is that the affair is bound to dim the aura of infallibility and imperial sum, periority that had come to surround the Presidency, particularly in national security matters; for in addition to the lack of integrity and scruple now shown to have existed in the White House, those involved also demohstrated a virtually unmatched record of bungling, stupidity and hysteria.

title: Westfield to Survey Town on Education
description: WESTFIELDA survey to determine attitudes toward public education here will be undertaken, starting Tuesday, by a subcommittee of the Educational Studies Committee. The latter group is a standing unit of the Westfield ParentTeacher Council.

title: Jet Noise
description: In San Jose, Calif., officials decided recently to close a $700,000 school because the din of jet traffic at the city airport nearby made it all but impossible for pupils to hear the teachers.

title: Kissinger Hints He Saw Results of the Wiretap on Halperin in Pentagon Papers
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Henry A. Kissinger implied strongly today that he had seen the results of the wiretap that contributed to the dismissal of the Pentagon papers case.

title: Martha Millen, T.G. Brosnahan To Wed in July
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 12Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Millen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Ann Millen, to Timothy George Brosnahan of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent T. Brosnahan of Darien, Conn. July wedding is planned.

title: State to Require Morticians To Itemize Fees in Advance
description: TRENTON  New Jersey is about to curb what has been called the high cost of dying.

title: SHIELD, IN UPSET, WINS AAR TITLE
Rockefeller Is Seen Seeding Clouds for Possible 1976 Presidential Harvest
description: As President Nixon struggled with the Watergate scandal that has wracked his administration, Governor Rockefeller planted the first seeds of a possible Presidential candidacy in 1976 at the Republican Governors conference here last week.

title: Group Formed Here to Promote Shipping Safety
description: Progress in industry efforts to provide the port with a vessel traffic system to promote ship safety in local waters has been made with the recent formation of the New York Harbor Vessel Advisory Committee.

title: ROGERS IN MEXICO AT START OF TOUR
description: MEXICO CITY, May 12 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived in Mexico City today on the first leg of an eightnation tour of Latin America that he said marked a new era of interest and cooperation between the United States and its southern neighbors.

title: Atop the tiger atop the elephant
description: AND Now, the ringmaster roared, THE GREATEST ANIMALTRAINING MASTERPIECE EVER: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus takes pride in presenting for the first time anywhere in the world the most incredible animaltraining accomplishment of all time! Three snarling tigerstwo giant horsesa mammoth African elephantperforming together in the same giant cage! A fantastic, historic new chapter in wildanimal mastery that could have only been

title: Cahill, Dealers Vow Truth in Auto Ads
description: TRENTON  The Cahill Administration has drafted new regulations that are designed to protect car buyers from being misled by phony advertising.

title: Dance: Blue Mountain Paper Parade, Each a Star
description: Though it sounds like a pulping combine, the Blue Mountain Paper Parade is a dance company and a good one. The guiding spirit of the group is Barbara Roan, whose willing coworkers are Anthony LaGiglia and Irene Feigenheimer. Last Saturday evening at the American Theater Laboratory, the company performed The Continuing Dance Exchange and True Spirits.

title: Ah, To Be 18 and a Movie Mogul!
description: THERE aren't too many 18yearold movie producers around these days. As a matter of fact, we can think of only oneEdgar M. Bronfman Jr. He's the plucky lad who recently coproduced Blockhouse, a World War II drama with Peter Sellers, Charles Aznavour, Per Oscarsson and Jeremy Kemp.

title: Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY Nobody really knows how many rebel bands there are in Mexico, how many desperate men roam the dry and barren hills of Jalisco and Durango and the thick rain forests, of Guerrero, the state that surrounds.the plush resort of Acapulco. The Government says the guerrillas number only in the hundreds; some suspect there may be more.

title: 3 Mets Injured in 60 Victory at Pittsburgh
Growing up in Eastern Europe
description: Towards the end of The Hero's Children Paul Neuburg remarks that what the East Europeans most dislike is living in Eastern Europe. The Rumanians describe Bucharest as the Paris of the East"; the City Park in Budapest is affectionately referred to as the Hungarian Bois de Boulogne"; the textile town, Lodz, is the Polish Manchester. For the Russians, the Poles, the Czechs, the Hungarians, the Rumanians and the Bulgarians are their western neighbors.

title: Post Retains Met Track Crown as 8 Records Fall
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 12The Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association held its outdoor championship in New Jersey for the first time today and the athletes responded to the fine conditions at Rutgers Stadium by breaking more records in one day than ever before in the 40year history; of the meet.

title: Mrs. Walters Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Rupert Adrian Walters Jr. of Manhattan on April 28 in the Klingenstein Pavilion. Mrs. Walters is the former Miss M, Jean Reilly of Philadelphia. The child's father is a product manager with the General Foods Corporation in White Plains.

title: Skylab
description: CAPE KENNEDYIn the history of man expanding his frontiers, there has always been a pattern. The explorer is followed by the homesteader, the generalist by the specialist, the Lewises and Clarks by the wagon trains, The space frontier will fit the pattern.

title: Social Announcements
description: Hank and Marilyn joyfully announce the birth of David Michael's sister Jill Beth on May 3, 1973.

title: A JUDGESHIP DIMS POLITICIAN'S HOPE
description: HARTFORD, May 12In a series of judicial nominations made by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, some ambitions have been realized. but at least one has been cut snort.

title: Patrick Carberry Dead; Wall St. Journal Editor
description: RAMSEY, N.J., May 12Patrick Carberry, who retired in 1970 as bond editor of The Wall Street Journal, died today at his home, 55 Mechanic Street. He was 67 years old.

title: VEEDER T. COLANGELO
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 12 Veeder T. Colangelo, who retired in 1969 as professor of industrialteachertraining education, New York City Regional Center, State Department of Education, died yesterday at his home, 8 Beverly Place. He was 65 years old.

title: Mrs. Herlin Married to T. P. Grose
description: ESSEX, Conn., May 12Mrs. Eleanor Evans Herlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allyn Phelps Evans of Christmas Cove, Me., was married here this afternoon to Thomas Pierpont Grose, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Waldo Grose of Essex. The Rev. Dr. Edward C. Boynton, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Essex Yacht Club.

title: Pop Sock Rock and Amok Rock
description: GUITARIST Robin Trower's resignation last year from Procol Harum was a classic example of the heroic maneuver of burning one's bridges. It came after four years with the group and at a time when Procol Harum was riding a crest wave of popularity. The move, however, was understandable in light of Procol's regrettable propensity to vapid pomposity. Trower's own apparent inclinations pointed toward a more substantial and emotional music, a format which could better fulfill the promise offered by Song for a Dreamer, a tribute to Jimi Hendrix and the only Trower composition to be recored by the group.

title: More on Lessing
description: With considerable pride, we publish Elizabeth Hardwick's splendid essay on Doris Lessing (Page 1). With some diffidence, I would like to dissent from her judgment on the particular novel she is reviewing. I think The Summer Before the Dark is not only Doris Lessing's best novel, but the best novel to have appeared here since Garcia Marquez's One Hundred Years of Solitude.

title: Lag in Arrest System Noted Here
Windy's Daughter and Riva Ridge Triumph
description: Windy's Daughter, a Californiabred filly racing in the silks of Mrs. Paul Blackman, and Riva Ridge of the Meadow Stable shared the spotlight at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Officials of F.B.I. Resent Ruckelshaus
description: WASHINGTON, May 12William D. Ruckelshaus, who earned the unofficial title of Mr. Clean while head of the Environmental Protection Agency, is now trying to use his broom in the dusty recesses of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Anne Sanger Becomes Bride
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 12Miss Anne Durant Sanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Grant Sanger of Mount Kisco, was married here this afternoon to George Webb Gager, son of Mrs. John Jay Gager of Bozrah, Conn., and the late Dr. Gager.

title: Price Moderation by Businesses Urged
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12 (AP)John T. Dunlop, Director of the Cost of Living Council, told businessmen today that they could help bring about the end of wage and price controls by practicing price moderation this year.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Three companies in the perfume and cosmetics business,, all wholly owned subsidiaries of the British American Tobacco Company, have leased the 10th and 11th floors, comprising about 38,000 square feet of office space, in the Squibb Building at 40 West 57th Street. The 20year lease involved an aggregate rent of about $8million.

title: Music
description: OFFICIALLY the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center ended its season on April 22, when Beverly Sills and Eileen Farrell, those two vocal superstars, came together for an evening of intimate singing. Funny thing about that concert. Sills, as we all know, has made her biggest reputation as a specialist in the bell canto, coloratura style. But when it was all over, the thing that remained in everybody's mind was not her singing in a florid Handel aria, brilliant as it was, but her work with Farrell in a series of Schumann and Mendelssohn duets. Everybody has been talking about it ever since. It was not only that the two ladies sang so exquisitely together. More: it was that the music was so beautiful.

title: 49ers Hold 2,000 Tickets After Sale Reaches 57,000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (UPI)The San Francisco 49ers have announced that their preseason ticket sale has reached 57,000 and that they have stopped taking orders.

title: Fourie Scores by Decision
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 (AP)  Pierre Fourie of South Africa, a lightheavyweight, pounded out 10round decision over Connie Velensek of West Germany tonight. Fourie weighed 175 pounds and Velensek 174.

title: Kidnapping of Children Stirring Alarm in Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 6 Waves swept over the sand, splashing the feet of a halfdozen children kicking a volleyball along the surf. Mrs. Bertyl Desilva, a slight, frail woman, sat in the cool sand, watching her son, Philip.

title: CHINESE VISITORS TO U.S.INCREASING
description: Chinese gymnasts, journalists and water conservationists will be touring American cities in the next few days, showing visibly the impact of the accelerated exchange agreement reached between the United States and China in February.

title: Indochina
description: SAIGONWhen Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker boarded his special Air Force plane Friday to leave Vietnam after six years as America's presiding authority here, his secretaries and even his security guards had tears in their eyes.

title: The Region
description: Finally, it was out in the open. After months of rumors and three weeks of legal struggles over the release of grand jury minutes, Representative Mario Biaggi's testimony before a Federal grand jury in late 1971 was opened to public view yesterday. And Mr. Biaggi was exposed as a witness who had refused to answer several questions, and as a mayoral candidate who had at the least misled the public and his fellow politicians in repeatedly implying that he had answered all questions.

title: France Sells Naval Missile To Libyans, Magazine Says
description: PARIS, May 12 (UPI)France has sold missiles with a range of four miles to Libya for mounting on three launches built by Britain for the Libyan Navy, the French armed forces magazine says.

title: ENGLAND, SCOTLAND TRIUMPH IN SOCCER
description: LONDON, May 12 (UPI)England and Scotland, coholders of the title, scored victories today when the muchcriticized British international scrcer chamnionship began.

title: Impure Tap Water a Growing Hazard To the Health of Millions Across U. S.
lchord Asks I.R.S. to Study Liberties Union's Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The chairman of the House Internal Security Committee, Richard H. Ichord, Democrat of Missouri, said today that he had asked the Internal Revenue Service to decide if the American Civil Liberties Union's bid to abolish his panel is proper conduct for a taxexempt organization.

title: Wrong Note on Trade
description: Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz sounded exactly the wrong note in opening the drive on Capitol Hill for the Administration's trade bill. If he was serious about rejecting reciprocity as the basis for the coming negotiations with other trading nations, and especially those in the European Community, the United States delegation might as well stay home.

title: MIDIS EQUALS WORLD 100 MARK
Gasoline
description: WASHINGTONThe numbers are not comforting. National gasoline stocks in the week ended May 4 totaled 201 million barrels, 20 million below a year earlier. More than 560 gasoline stations have closed because of short supplies; another 1,370 are threatened. Some oil companies have announced informal rationing rules; Amoco, for example; has limited customers to 10 gallons at a time in some stations in New York and Illinois.

title: Metropolitan Briefs.
description: A fourday work stoppage by technicians at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center ended yesterday after members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Union agreed to submit grievances to arbitration. The stoppage began with the dismissal of an Xray technician, John Quintana, for refusing to perform a neck Xray without doctor's supervision after hospital officials warned technicians not to move patient's neck during the procedure. The stoppage was to have spread to the affiliated Albert Einstein College of Medicine on Monday.

title: US. Wrestlers Eye World Cup

Rothenberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Mona Rothenberg, to Gerald Jay Eichner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. Eichner of Hellam, Pa., and Great Neck. title: Brooklyn Farmer Faces Elements

title: Son for the Gagliottis
description: AMAGANSETT, L. I., May 12A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Gagliotti April 18 at the FlowerFaith Avenue Hospital in New York. The child has been named Jonathan Edward.

title: The possessed of the Middle East
description: Toward the end of this harrowing accountin fact a graphic topography of Bedlam and the best book I know on the madness and tragedy of the Palestinian guerrilla movementDavid PryceJones tells of an incident that took place last year in the occupied West 0Bank. Upon his transfer to another post, a senior Israeli Army officer was given a farewell party by a noted Palestinian Arab nationalist. Wistfully, his host informed the officer that he had recently appeared to him in a dream. In the dream, the Israeli occupation had ended, and the twoArab and Israeliwere enjoying a friendly reunion over dinner and drinks in a foreign country. When he returned to the no longer occupied West Bank, the Palestinian, in his dream, found himself arrested and courtmartialed for fraternizing with the Zionist enemy. But, damn it, just as the judge was handing down the verdict

title: On the Verge of Big Dealing
description: PARISThe biggest event of the recent KissingerBrezhnev dialogue at first seemed a nonevent. Despite widespread belief that a date would be fixed for the Soviet leader's United States trip, none was announced. It therefore came as welcome news that he will arrive in June as originally expected. A delay would have been too bad for both parties.

description: The address on the reelection campaign stationery of Borough President Sebastian Leone reads Brooklyn, N.Y., 4th Largest City in America.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The best season Dom DiMaggio ever had was in 1950, when he batted.328 and fielded like a fiend. Adoring Red Sox fans were so carried away that they used to chant a parody to Maryland, My Maryland. It even had the proper metrical cadence. It went, He's better than his brother Joe. Is Dominic DiMaggio. Although it was pleasing to the ear, the words were inaccurate. Joe DiMaggio was not only the best of the brothers, but he was voted the greatest living ballplayer in a nationwide poll of experts during the centennial year of 1969. Sports of TheTimes

title: Joan SnyderThe Energy And Surprise Have Gone
description: FOR one who has followed recent American abstract painting with hopeful enthusiasm, Joan Snyder's new show at Paley & Lowe, Inc., is not a happy occasion. Snyder has been one of the most promising of a dozen or so young artists, who have made Lyrical Abstraction One of the most promising developments of the last three or four seasons. Wonderfully gifted and only 32, she can scarcely be written off. on the basis of a single unimpressive show. But there is something in the way her new Work disappoints one's expectations that is almost alarming.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It's a long way from his first novel, From Here to Eternity to A TOUCH OF DANGER (Doubleday, $7.95), but James Jones has made the trip under full sail. A Touch of Danger is a privateeye mystery with a locale on a Greek island. It does not pretend to be literature. It has no aim except to entertain. Nor does it look deeply into character. It is a competent example of its genre, with all the conventions virtually intact.

title: John S. Caporale Weds Elisabeth S. Kessler
description: In the Central Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Sayer Kessler, daughter of Dr. Richard William Kessler and the late Mrs. Kessler, became the bride of John Stephen Caporale. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgilio Caporale of Derby, Conn.

title: Theater in Washington, D.C.
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.,

title: Numismatics
description: LATIN America is not eating anyone's dust. While numismatic popularity in some other regions seems to alternately spurt and sag, the coins, paper money, tokens and medals of the sprawling area from the Rio Grande River to Tierra del Fuego continue to attract new collectors at a steady rate. The result is a strong  sometimes even spectacular  pattern of increasing values.

title: BuzkashiIt Is Probably the Toughest Game in the World
description: KABUL, AfghanistanEighty riders jostle hard against each other, spur forward and begin to move across the field. As they approach, their blurred mass of color slowly separates into eight distinct sets, the eight teams of the Royal Buzkashi (literally, goat wrestlers, so named for the game they are about to play). Kettle drums beat tensely, as if to forcibly restrain the horses pace. Faces come into view beneath bristly fur caps. Some of the riders are dark, thickfeatured Pushtuns, some are blueeyed Tajiks and others have the raw complexion and flat cheeks of Hazarahs, decendants of the Mongols.

title: New Fiction
description: Fred Chappell's fourth novel departs rather dramatically from the dense, dark mood of the first three. The Gaudy Place is light, almost airy, and it is as different in setting as in mood. He has moved from the Southern countryside into the new Southern city, from the settings and themes of the past into a fiction that reflects the South of the present. This new South is a greatly changed place, and it is appropriate that Chappell should explore it in a novel so unlike its predecessors.

title: Prepay Plan On Legal Aid Encounters Legal Snag
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Bar Association's proposal to implement this year prepaid group legal insurance, a plan similar in concept to the medical coverage provided by Blue Cross, has run into a legal snag.

title: IntheWater Shows Going South
description: Inthewater boat shows will be going south for the winter. Paul Dodson, the producer of the Newport International Sailboat Show, and Peter Carroll and Jerry Wood, promoters of the sail and powerboat shows in Annapolis, Md., and Stamford, Conn., have announced separate shows for Florida's two coasts. Dodson's will come first, Nov. 21 to 25, in St. Petersburg's Bayfront Yacht Basin. Carroll's and Wood's production, called the Southern Sailboat Show, will open at Miami's Marine Stadium on Dec. 6 and run for four News four days. News of Boating

title: Bowling Purse Increased
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 12, (AP) The Professional Bowlers Association announced today that the prize money for the Showboat Invitation bowling tournament at Las Vegas, Nev., would be raised to $100,000 in 1974. For the last four years, it has been $77,777.

title: Rise in C.I.A. Retirements Is Approved by President
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The White House says that President Nixon has signed legislation increasing from 800 to 2,100 the ceiling on retirements by Central Intelligence Agency employes in the period ending June 30, 1974.

description: HACKENSACK  A potpourri auction for the benefit of financially disadvantaged youngsters in Bergen County will be held next Sunday at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 211 Essex Street.

description: BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP)  Laplander of Buckingham Farms caught frontrunning Chrisaway in the last few strides today to take the $59,500 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Art
description: STORRS, Conn.ADEQUATE definitions of folk art definitions, that is adequate to our experience of the art itself are difficult to come by. Adequate appreciation, stated in serious critical terms, is also a rarity. This absence of an established critical approach to the subject is at once an advantage and a disadvantage. It allows us to bring an uncluttered response to the peculiar felicities of the folk artist a response unburdened by the ideas and expectations we bring to more sophisticated modes of artistic expression but it also leaves that response suspended in an intellectual void. As a resuit, we tend to cherish the masterpieces of folk art in a part of the mind where distinctions and discriminations are not in force. In the presence of naive art, as folk art is often called, we tend to fall back Ann a naive pleasure, happily suspending our customary standards of esthetic disbelief. We tend, in other words, to take an intellectual, if not an esthetic holiday.

title: The New Play
description: A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE, the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center's revival of Tennessee Williams's play, got nine favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Glover, AP; Gayer, UPI; Harris, CBSTV; Sanders, ABC TV; Bookspan, WPIXTV) and three mixed reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Reidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Klein, WNEWTV).

title: The Audience Simply Rose and Fled
description: THE most interesting thing that happened the night I attended Edward Bond's Lear, now on the rotating schedule of the Yale Repertory Theater, took place in the audience, not onstage. Theoretically, interesting things were happening onstage; workers who accidentally dropped tools while building a wall that looked like Agamemnon's at Mycenae were being shot down in cold blood; tattered statesmen dripping gore were creeping about after Donald Davis as a new sort of King Lear with daggers in their hands, only to be discovered drowned in wells discolored with what blood they had left; pregnant women were being raped, Lear's daughters bayoneted and disemboweledwith Lear dipping his hands into the entrails of one to raise stained red fingers well into view; Lear himself was now being strapped to a chair and crowned with a newfangled electronic device designed to remove his eyes without damaging them for possible later use elsewhere. it misread. The for that had of it, turned fusal, steadily

title: Presidential Aides
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon, his Administration rocked by scandals of unprecedented proportions, was moving to, reshape the Government. But in doing so, he raised new questions as to his goals and the directions his Administration was taking.

title: Black Power

He had been killed a few days before in a shootout with police on the New Jersey turnpike that also left a trooper dead. A former Minister of Information for the Eldridge Cleaver faction of the Panthers, Mr. Shakur had died, in his father's words, as a struggler... a revolutionary.

Last Tuesday, after 10 weeks of shooting, two deaths, many injuries and seemingly endless negotiations, the occupation of this scrubby valley town by militant, Indians and their supporters dramatically ended as a United States marshal radioed: Gentlemen, the Village of Wounded Knee is clear.

title: the Senate is determined to recover some of its powers
description: WASHINGTON. Tourists peered, like innocent cherubim placed there for effect, over the edge of the circular secondfloor railing and down on the human fresco in the well of the Senate rotunda of the United States Capitol. Portable floodlights. Three television cameras. A dozen microphones. A rackety pack of the nation's premier investigative reporters. And, at the center, a broadshouldered, white4iaired, 76yearold oracle who alternately listened to questions with an amused smile creasing his McIntosh apple face or gargled answers in a cornmealmush dialect of the Appalachian South.
