description: WASHINGTON, May 23 The investigations subcommittee of the House Commerce Committee, which was scheduled to take testimony today from John W. Dean 3d, the dismissed White House counsel, has postponed the hear ing until Thursday.

title: People and Business
description: William M. Fine, has resigned as president of Bonwit Teller, according to an announcement yesterday from Genesco, Inc., which owns the 14store specialty chain.

title: Bridge: Aces Win the First Position In Qualifying Tourney Stage
description: GUARUJA, Brazil, May 23 The Aces, intent on a successful defense of their world team title, unexpectedly snatched first position in the qualifying stage from Italy here in the early hours of this morning.

title: HOUSE SUSTAINS PRESIDENT'S VETO ON CONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 President Nixon won a victory in the House today as it sustained his veto of a bill requiring Senate confirmation of the two top officials of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Topeka Woman Is Guilty Of Concealing U.S. Property
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 23 (AP)  A United States District Court jury found Mrs. Joyce Guerrero, 27 years old guilty yesterday of concealing Government property stolen from the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Washington.

title: Costa Rica's President Defends Vesco Relationship
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 23 (UPI)President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica told a nationwide radio and television audience last night that he was innocent of any wrongdoing in his relationship with Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier who has taken up residence in Costa Rica.

title: Antioch Ousts 7 Teachers and 20 Students in Strike
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 23 (UPI)Antioch College, shut down by a student strike for a month, dismissed today seven teachers who supported the strike, expelled 20 students and promised more to come in an effort to reopen the school.

title: EXKISSINGER AIDES SAY HE COPIED DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) Former aides of Henry A. Kissinger say he has made copies of classified foreign policy documents for his own use after he leaves the Government. Mr. Kissinger said, The only papers I have are personal papers.

title: Jersey G.0. P. Says It's Puzzled By Executive Club Beneficiaries
description: NEWARK, May 23State Republican party officials said today that they did not know of the existence of two organizations to which the now defunct Executive Club of the Republican Party of New Jersey reported to the Federal Government it had given more than $22,000.

title: On the Waterfront Returns to Hoboker
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 23They had come to look at Hoboken 20 years after, and soon one of the celebrated visitors was exclaiming:

title: 2 C.I.A.Officials Say That Nixon Did Not Ask Them If Agency Had a Watergate Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Key officials of the Central Intelligence Agency say that President Nixon apparently made no effort to inquire directly if the Watergate breakin involved covert C.I.A. operations.

title: A Cambodian Landscape: Bomb Pits, Rubble, Ashes
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 21The destruction Cambodia has multiplied greatly since the escalation of the American bombing began here in February. Scores of villages have been blown away. Twelvefootdeep bomb craters pock the ruins. Great numbers of livestock have been killed, harvested crops burned to ash, orchards destroyedall creating a degree of damage, and therefore reconstruction problem, that until now had been associated ,only with North and South Vietnam.

title: ABROAD PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The White House urged the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1970 to mount a massive counterinsurgency program, involving spying, wiretapping and burglaries, against the Black Panthers, potential Arab saboteurs, antiwar radicals and Soviet espionage agents, wellplaced sources said today.

title: JAMES BROWN SINGS AS SOUL GODFATHER
description: James Brown calls himself the Godfather of Soul these days and there can be no question that he is filling the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, during his engagement there this week. But it was equally clear at the Saturday midnight showwhich normally attracts the most boisterous of that theater's notably responsive audiencesthat the crowd was according Brown more affection and respect than spontaneous enthusiasm.

title: Sales of New Cars Increase Sharply
description: DETROIT, May 23Domestic new car sales in the middle 10 days of May totaled 289,609, which averaged 36,201 cars sold in each of the eight selling days in the period, a record.

title: Erskine Quits as Coach Of Indiana College Nine
description: ANDERSON, Ind., May 23 (UPI)Carl Erskine, former Dodgers pitching star, announced his retirement today after 12 years as baseball coach at Anderson College, where his teams won three Hoosier Conference titles.

title: Iceland Widens British Curb
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 23': (Reuters)Iceland today ex1 tended its ban on British tary aircraft using the coun try's facilities. The ban was widened to prohibit all British military planes, either owned or leased, from landing at Ice7.,. landic airports or flying over,: Icelandic jurisdiction. The on1Sii exemption will be for a British; military plane in distress.

title: People in Sports: Alleged Brave Is Not in Wigwam
description: Ernie DiGregorio is a Buffalo Brave, announced Paul Snyder, owner of the National Basketball Association team, yesterday. But was he? The Braves No. 1 draft choice from Providence College has agreed to a multiyear contract, the club insisted, but Ernie D. didn't show up at a news conference in Buffalo supposedly held to sign the 6foot playmaker and star shooter.

title: After Seven Years, a P.O. W. Tries to Adjust to a Changed World
description: DAYTON, Pa.Wendell Alcorn has been gone a long time.

title: ALCH ON THE STAND
description: WASHINGTON, May 23A onetime attorney for James W. McCord Jr. sought in Senate testimony today to undermine his former client's credibility and to suggest that McCord had participated in an antiAdministration vendetta.

title: Fugitive Bids Other Women Shun Leftist Units
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 Jane L. Alpert, who has been a fugitive since she jumped bail three years ago after pleading guilty to conspiring to bomb Federal office buildings in New York City, has reportedly written a lengthy open letter urging women to repudiate leftwing causes to work for ourselves.

title: HOUSE SUSTAINS PRESIDENT'S VETO ON CONFIRMATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 President Nixon won a victory in the House today as it sustained his veto of a bill requiring Senate confirmation of the two top officials of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Radio
Mrs. Whitman to Leave Nixon Economic Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)Marina Whitman, the first woman to serve on the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that she would probably leave the council this summer.

title: ANTITRUST CURBS ASSAILED BY CORT
description: The chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation called yesterday for new antitrust policies if the steel industry is to be able to compete with foreign steel makers.

title: New York City Is Still Largest Metropolitan Area
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) New York City is still the nation's largest metropolitan area even. though Nassau and Suffolk counties are no longer counted in its totals, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Sholom Aleichem: His Laughs Go On
description: Sholom Aleichem, who took Yiddish, a serious language, and turned it to laughter, used to write 12a on the tops the page 13's of his manuscripts. He died on May 12a, 1916, and his will asked those who wanted to remember him to gather on the anniversaries of his death and read one of his stories aloud  preferably a funny one. Until this year, the commemorative laughter sounded from the Upper West Side home of his daughter, Marie, and her husband, Ben Zion Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg died last December, so last week the gathering was moved to the Park Avenue apartment of Sholom Aleichem's granddaughter, Bel Kaufman, an author herself (Up the Down ####Staircase."

title: British Defense Official Resignsin SexandPhotograph Scandal
Cassius Puts Countess Back on Winning Trail
description: After an absence of six years, Countess Ercilia LeNy once again is showing dogs. Although known primarily for her Airedales, this time it is a Lakeland, Ch.Tarnbreck Cassius, who is bringing her fame. This is not a lean and hungry Cassius, but rather a gay and friendly little terrier, the Countess bought at Cruft's. On April 28, the English import, handled by Guenter Behr, gave the Countess her first best in show in a decade, taking the top prize at Augusta, Ga.

title: LEO FRIEND, 62, DIES; CHEMICAL ENGINEER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 23Leo Friend, a chemical engineer who served with the Manhattan Project that developed the atomic bomb in World War 11, died today in Princeton Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived at 7 Merritt Lane in Rocky Hill.

title: PRECEDENTS CITED ON BREAKIN PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, May 23While there is no explicit legal authority for Federal agents to engage in burglaries or wiretapping without a court order successive Administrations have permitted such activities under the President's implied power to protect the country from internal and external threats.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Although the Chinese authorities failed to have their way with The New York Times, they have succeeded in intimidating the Japanese media. News companies with correspondents in Peking have entered into written agreement with the Chinese authorities not to pursue a hostile policy towards China, not to participate in any plot to create two Chinas, and not to obstruct the restoration of normal JapanChina relations. Though these principles appear innocuous, the Chinese authorities have interpreted these principles unilaterally, and have applied their interpretations harshly.

title: Presidential Confessions
description: WASHINGTON, May 23In one of the most remarkable statements ever issued by the White House, the President made these confessions:

title: Peace Ship Broadcasts To Arabs and the Israelis
description: ABOARD THE PEACE SHIP, in the Mediterranean, May 22"This is the voice of peace, broadcasting on 1540 kilocycles from somewhere in the Mediterranean.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Rick Wise should be voted pitcher of the month for April, said Red Schoendienst a few weeks ago, forcing a smile as he flicked over the pages on his calendar from April to May. If that was a feeble joke, the manager the St. Louis Cardinals was in no position to offer livelier one. Besides, he didn't have the heart for it. The Cardinals had won a mere three of their first 19 games this season and Wise was the winning pitcher each time, the only winning pitcher they possessed.

title: Government Intervention Is Urged at Senate Hearings to Reform Amateur Sports
Firemen Shortage Stirs Women to Train
description: NISSEQUOGUE, L. I., May 23Don't wear mascara to a fire.

title: SWITCH TO CIGARS MAY BE HARMFUL
description: Many heavy cigarette smokers who switch to cigars may increase the risk to their health, according to the findings of a study in London.

title: Times Fills Advertising Post
description: Lane Beckham, who has been with The New York Times since 1964, has been named its amusement advertising manager. He is replacing Max Ginsberg, who retires on Friday.

title: Senate Speedily Confirms Richardson by 823 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Senate confirmed Elliot L. Richardson today as the new Attorney General by a vote of 82 to 3, sweeping away its usual rules to hurry the confirmation through and adding praise for Mr. Richardson personally and for his choice of Archibald Cox as special prosecutor in the Watergate investigation.

title: SOVIET WRESTLER AND TAYLOR DRAW
description: MADISON, Wis., May 23 (AP) The twotime National Collegiate champion, Chris Taylor, was held to a draw tonight as the Soviet wrestling team thrashed the United States, 173.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The New Jersey scholastic track and field championships, spawning ground for such Olympic champions as Andy Stanfield, Don Bragg, Milt Campbell and Tom Courtney, get under way this weekend with 16 public school sectional meets and two parochial school state meets.

title: Cortland State Reaches Lacrosse Tourney Final
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., May 23 (AP)Jud Smith, a freshman, scored three times and had four assists to lead Cortland State to a 14.8 victory today over Hobart in the semifinals of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association collegedivision tournament.

title: Music: New and Newer
description: There may be a lesson or two to be learned from the New and Newer Musk concert given at Tully Hall Tuesday night under the direction of Dennis Russell Davies. One lesson would be that a program of contemporary works by Oriental composers appears to have no drawing power here. Fewer than 100 persons showed up for this one.

title: General Foods Profits Rise in Quarter
Program on Guitar Given by Murtaugh In Festival Series
description: The acoustic guitar is not the most coloristically varied of instruments, and thus an evening of music exploiting it in conventional ways and making use of a rather faceless, internationalstyle chromaticism might not seem to promise many rewards. And that was precisely the case with the recital offered by John Hunter Murtaugh Tuesday night at the New School, the next to last concert of this year's Composers Theater May Festival of contemporary American music.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The investigation into the mysterious hanging deaths of an Upper Montclair matron and her married daughter Was extended to New York City yesterday. An assistant Essex County prosecutor, Anthony R. Mautone, who heading the investigative team, was reported in the city in connection with the case but no further information was available. The women, Mrs. Renie Cali, and her daughter, Mrs. Leslie Grant, were found dead last week their home.

title: Death Toll Is 40 in Indian State As Revolt by Police Continues
description: LUCKNOW, India, May 23 (Reuters)  A police rebellion that has taken 40 lives since it began yesterday here in Uttar Pradesh continued for the second day today in three towns.

title: Theater
description: Bless the Spanish Theater Repertory Company on three counts, starting with that blasted title, The Effect of Gamma Rays on ManintheMoon Marigolds. The program reads simply, Las Calendulas (The Marigolds), the rest is in smaller, preface type. Gracias.

title: ALBANY SETS BACK PENSION REFORMS FOR THIS SESSION
description: ALBANY, May 23The Legisfature late tonight passed complex bill ratifying a lablir agreement between Governor Rockefeller and state employes that, in effect, kills major reform in the vast array of public pension systems in the state for this legislative session.

title: Buckley in Survey of Current Events Explains His Vote to Override Veto
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Senator James L. Buckley gave a reception today for 38 released war prisoners, and offered his views on wiretapping, Representative Mario Biaggi, Governor Rockefeller, the news media, Watergate, the EllsbergRusso case and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a series of brief interviews between the bloody Mary's and the raspberry sherbet.

title: Will the Guide Michelin Reach for a Fourth Star?
description: PARISThe most delectable rumor in French gastronomy this spring is that the Guide Michelin is preparing to add a category of superexcellencefour stars.

title: KISSINGER AND TN END TALKS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, May 23The United States and North Vietnam today ended an intensive week of talks on how to end violations of the Vietnam ceasefire, and Henry A. Kissinger said significant progress had been made.

title: DAVID W. MINAR
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 23 (AP) David W. Minar, chairman of the department of political science at Northwestern University, died Monday night in Evanston Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: 7 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
JOHN LARNED, LED. MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: WILTON, Conn., May 23John I. B. Lamed, president of the International Management Development Institute, Inc., was killed Monday when his cart struck an empty stalled vehicle on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich. He was 52 years old and lived at 4 Borglum Road.

title: Raise for Aluminum Workers
description: PITTSBURGH, May 23 (UPI) The United Steelworkers announced today that 34,000 aluminum workers would receive a ninecentanhour costofliving pay increase from five companies effective June 1. The increase was the second this year under the 1971 contract. On March 1 they received a ninecent costofliving increase. The increases will be paid to employes of Alcoa, Reynolds, Kaiser, Ormet and Ormal.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: One Way to Spare the Rod
description: If one is angling far from civilization, a broken rod, which under ordinary circumstances would merely be an inconvenience, can mean a ruined trip.

title: They Had a Kick Coming
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 23 (UPI)A Brazilian soccer team made up of players 23 years old or less cancelled a scheduled appearance in the Republic of Malawi because immigration officials demanded they cut off their long hair, the team manager said today. Malawi enforces strict rules against hippie styles and border officials keep scissors handy for trimming the locks of longhaired travelers.

title: Lovers Face a Fatal Illness in A Warm December
On the Waterfront Returns to Hoboken
description: HOBOKEN, May 23They had come to look at Hoboken 20 years after, and soon one of the celebrated visitors was exclaiming:

title: Jersey G.O. P. Says It's Puzzled By Executive Club Beneficiaries
description: NEWARK, May 23State Republican party officials said today that they did not know of the existence of two organizations to which the now defunct Executive Club of the Republican Party of New Jersey reported to the Federal Government it had given more than $22,000.

title: J. Patrick Kennedy Dies; Former Teamster Leader
description: J. Patrick Kennedy, a former milk truck driver who became a leader in a rankandfile reform movement within the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died Saturday at his home, 2269 Hampden Place, the Bronx. He was 57 years old.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before Senate Panel Investigating Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony by John J. Caulfield and Anthony T. Ulasewicz in the fourth day of hearings on the Watergate case by the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities; and excerpts from a prepared statement to the committee by Gerald Alch, along with transcripts of his reading of certain documents that he interpolated into his statement:

title: Market Place: The Call Option Offers Leverage
description: Ask the average trader to explain call options and he's likely to tell you that he knows about as much about them as he knows about the Grand Canyon. He's sure both are far too deep for him.

title: State Collects $20.8Million In Taxes for Aqueduct Meet
description: ALBANY, May 23 (AP)The state collected $20,800,829 in parimutuel tax revenue from the 63day spring meeting at Aqueduct race track, the State Tax Department reported today.

title: Safety Measures Urged For Commercial Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board recommended yesterday that commercial airliners pad their bars to protect customers from injuries caused by air turbulence.

title: Beame Will Disqualify Himself In Vote on Convention Center
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie disqualified himself yesterday from voting in the Board of Estimate on the proposed $200million convention center for the West Side of Manhattan.

title: BEIRUT DECLARES EMERGENCY OVER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23The Lebanese Cabinet tonight decided to lift the state of emergency imposed May 7 be/ cause of clashes between the Lebanese Army and Palestinian commandos.

title: BAILEY IS SEEKING A SEPARATE TRIAL
description: ORLANDO, Fla., May 23 (AP)F. Lee Bailey, the trial lawyer, appeared before United States magistrate today on mailfraud charges and asked to be tried separately from codefendant Glenn W. Turner, an Orlando businessman.

title: San Antonio Power Low
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 23 (UPI)City officials cut electricity to street lights today and called on businesses and citizens to reduce their use of electricity to avert a possible blackout in nine days.

title: Red Reality, $3.20, Outruns 4 Rivals in Edgemere
description: Red Reality showed himself to be somewhat better than just a good horse by the way he won the $28,150 Edgemere Handicap at Belmont yesterday. The Cragwood Stable's 7yearold gelding was sent off the oddson favorite by the crowd of 15,174 and for a time in the stretch it appeared that he might let his backers down.

title: N.C.A.A. Playoffs to Open Today
description: Three of the best running teams in recent Eastern intercollegiate competition and one that makes up for lack of speed with long hitting will open the National Collegiate Athletic Association District II baseball playoffs today at Mercer County Park in Trenton in a twilightnight doubleheader. Seton Hall, Temple and Buffalo are the runners. Penn State counts on the long ball.

title: Caulfield Asserts He Believed President Authorized Clemency Offer to McCord
Three States to Get Help
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) President Nixon today declared Maine, Iowa and Colorado major disaster areas as a result of severe storms and flooding in recent months. The declaration was the first stop toward making Federal assistance available to the three states from the Federal Disaster Relief Fund.

title: Argentine Clashes Go On At Eve of Shift of Power
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 23Leftwing guerrilla activity and sporadic clashes between rival Peronist groups continued in Argentina as foreign dignitaries began arriving for the inauguJation Friday of Presidentelect Hector J. Campora.

title: Assembly Approves Bill to Transfer City Harbor Land to U.S. for Gateway
description: ALBANY, May 23The Assembly unanimously approved today a bill authorizing the City of New York to cede to the Federal Government 26,000 acres of land at the mouth of New York Harbor for the development of the Gateway National Recreation area.

title: GRAND JURY INDICTS 17 IN A FRAUD CASE
Joe Page Is Suing Magazine for Libel
description: PITTSBURGH, May 23 (UPI) Joe Page, the star relief pitcher for the Yankees from 1944 to 1950, filed a $1.5million libel suit in Federal Court here against Sport magazine today. He charged the publication had damaged his reputation with an article last month that termed him a drunkard, barfly and braggart:

title: Authorization of $3Billion For NASA Voted by House
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) A $3.073billion appropriation authorization bill for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was passed toplay by the House on a 322to73 vote and sent to the Senate.

title: Amex Prices and Trading Drop; Performance Tied to Watergate
Up Isn't Down
description: Chairman Stein of the President's Council of Economic Advisers has hailed as welcome the news that in April consumer prices rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.2 per cent, following a 10.8 per cent annual rate of increase in March. No housewife, said George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., could possibly agree.

title: The Tender Little Buds of East Germany
description: EAST BERLINThere's a slight change in the atmosphere of the Socialist half of the city, and the local standpatters, their thinking stuck in the ruts of the past, are audibly muttering their disapproval: Was da auf uns zukommt!

title: 500 Illegal Aliens Arrested in coast Crackdown
description: LOS ANGELES, May 23Immigration and Border Patrol officers apprehended 500 suspected illegal aliens here today and expected to double that number shortly, according to Federal spokesman.

title: Screen: Peckinpah s Tat Garrett and Billy the Kid
Excerpts From White House Briefing on Nixon Statement About Handling of the Watergate Investigation
description: WASFIINGTON, May 23 Following are excerpts from the transcript of a White House news briefing yesterday by Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary; Leonard Garment, President Nixon's Counsel, and J. Fred Ruzhardt, Special Counsel to the President, on Mr. Nixon's statement on the Watergate affair:

title: C.B. S. Chief Defends Decision To PostponeSticks and Bones
description: Arthur R. Taylor, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, yesterday broke a long silence on the matter and defended C.B.S.'s decision last March to postpone indefinitely) presentation of the controversial play Sticks and Bones on television.

title: Advertising: The Distaff View
description: There sat Tom Vohs at the head of the conference table, five women to the right of him, five women to the left of him. But there was neither volley nor thunder.

title: ... Footnote
description: Rational discourse between President Nixon and his critics about the phenomenon called Watergate has been foundering on an unfortunate verbal imprecision.

title: ALBANY SETS BACK PENSION REFORMS FOR THIS SESSION
description: ALBANY, May 23The Legislature late tonight passed a complex bill ratifying a labor agreement between Governor Rockefeller and state employes that, in effect, kills major reform in the vast array of public pension systems in the state for this legislative session.

title: Books of The Times
description: WITNESS TO HISTORY 19291969. By Charles E. Bohlen. With the Editorial Assistance of Robert H. Phelps. 562 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $12.50.

title: A More Intellectual Version Of the Over35 Singles Club
description: Lynn Shelton was a cheery blond stewardess for Eastern Air Lines until five years ago, when she retired at the age of 42. Now, she stood in front of a group of middleaged single persons in the Marble Collegiate Church parlor and said flatly: Society is sort of geared like Noah's Ark; everything is supposed to be in pairs after the age of 35.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Profits in Cable Systems Proving Elusive
description: If I can't do it, says Alfred R. Stern, chairman and president of the Warner Cable Corporation, then that spells the end of urban cable. Warner Cable is a subsidiary of Warner Communications, Inc., which recently agreed in principle to acquire for $20million in cash Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, which services the lower half of Manhattan, as well as other operations with. cable franchises on LongIsland. The seller is Sterling Communications, Inc., 70 per cent owned by Time Inc., which last year sold its broadcasting interests to concentrate on its cable systems. Time is now withdrawing from direct cable ownership and operations and reportedly plans to focus on programing and to settle for an equity position in one or more multiplesystem operators.

title: Net Revenue of Big Board In Quarter Drops Sharply
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its net revenues for the first quarter fell sharply, to $947,800 from $5.3million a year earlier.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: LyleNewton Bout Slated
description: DENVER, May. 23 (AP)Ron Lyle, sixthranked heavyweight, has been scheduled to meet Wendell Newton in a 10round bout June 11 at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. Lyle has won 21 of his 22 bouts.

title: Ford Will Pay $1Million To Halt Argentine Terror
description: DETROIT, May 23The Ford Motor Company decided today to meet terrorist demands to send $1million worth of ambulances and donations to hospitals in Argentina to prevent further attacks on its employes and its subsidiary in Buenos Aires.

title: Drug Raiders Arrest 19 In the New Haven Region
description: NEW HAVEN, May 23 (AP) A regional attack on drug trafficking in the 10community New HavenMeriden area resulted in 19 arrests by midmorning today, with more expected, according to the police.

title: Plan for Marianas Gives Some Status Of Commonwealth
description: AGANA, Guam, May 23 (AP) Representatives of the United States and the Northern Marianas Islands announced today that they had reached a broad preliminary understanding on an agreement that could bring the islands into a commonwealth relationship with the United States.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and city policemen futilely searched the offices of the Jewish Defense League yesterday for two concealed explosive devices. Officials of the militant organization charged that the agents had broken into a safe at its headquarters at 144 West 27th Street and had stolen membership and financial files, seized equipment and caused $1,000 in damage in a threehour search. A spokesman for the F.B.I, said the agents had had a search warrant.

title: Candidates'
description: He could have been a movie star  a stocky Dean Martin. He was signing autographs in front of Macy's in Herald Square as fast as his left hand could scrawl  selfpossessed, tanned, dapper, the recipient of numerous best wishes, handshakes, smiles and words of encouragement, particularly from the opposite sex.

title: Essick Harvard Swim Coach
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., May 23 (UPI)Raygssick, swimming coach at Southern Illinois University the last seven years and National Collegiate Athletic Association District 4 coach of the year in 1972 accepted today similar position at Harvard University. The 39yearold Essick, a native of Murphysboro, Ill., replaces Don Gambril, who has been named swimming coach at Alabama.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: Tigers Drop Yankees to 2d, 40
description: DETROIT, May 24  A fly ball whose flight to Matty Alou was interrupted by an empty green seat in the second tier of the rightfield stands was the most significant reason why the Yankees were returning home tonight not in first place.

title: 2 Soldiers Killed in Searching BoobyTrapped House in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 24Two British soldiers were killed and a third was seriously injured today by an explosion while they were searching a boobytrapped house near the Irish border.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: Memorial Day is the traditional time for New Yorkers to make the year's first moves toward getting out of town, to search for greener pastures and to flee the town's huddled masses (although for many, a day or so of this is more than enough).

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Jew Cleared of Killing for Nazis Takes Oath of U. S. Citizenship
description: PATERSON, May 24  A 50yearold Pompton Lakes man took the oath of citizenship today after a Passaic County District Court judge held: that charges that he had murdered inmates of a Nazi concentration camp were hearsay and incoherent.

title: Watergate Raider Sought Proof of Cuba Aid to Party
description: WASHINGTON, May 24One of the Watergate conspirators testified today that he had broken into the offices of the Democratic National Committee to search for proof of financial support of the party by the Cuban Government.

title: Richardson Determined To Get Sleaziness Out
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Elliot L. Richardson said today that as the new Attorney General he was determined to eradicate a kind of sleaziness that has infected the processes of government.

title: ShawGarrison Suit Put Off
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 24 (AP)  United States District Judge Frederick J. R. Heebe postponed indefinitely yesterday Clay L. Shaw's $5million damage suit against District Attorney Jim Garrison. Judge Heebe gave no reason for the continuance, but said it was agreeable to both parties. Mr. Shaw's suit charges that his constitutional rights were violated as a result of a conspiracy by Mr. Garrison and several others to persecute him.

title: 5th Ave. Shop to Reimburse Duped Buyers
description: A Fifth Aventie gift shop that sold a $2 roll of film for $10, a $7 carved bottle for $125 and $200 worth of bricabrac for over $5,000 has promised to change its ways following an investigation in which a 21yearold undercover agent worked in the shop for a week as a stock clerk, the Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: TV Coverage Planned For Skylab Inspection
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 24 (AP)Following is the tentative schedule (all times Eastern daylight) for the Skylab 1 astronauts to beam to earth tomorrow the first television pictures of the crippled Skylab space station:

title: Bridge: Aces Meet Early Disaster In the Championship Finals
description: GUARUJA, Brazil, May 24 Italy overwhelmed the Aces at the start of the World Team Championship final here this afternoon. The great foursomeBenito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, Pietro Forquet and Benito Bianchi led after 24 deals by the massive margin of 102 international match points, 107 to 5.

title: WOOD, WHITE SOX BEAT RYAN, ANGELS
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI)It was a classic confrontation, said Manager Chuck Tanner, of the White Sox after his knuckleballer, Wilbur Wood, defeated Nolan Ryan, the major league strikeout leader.

title: The Wali Jones Case Is Closed, but Not Tightly
description: MILWAUKEE, May 24 (UPI)With just one sentence, National Basketball Association Commissioner Walter Kennedy closed the case of Wali Jones's dispute with the Milwaukee Burks.

title: Security Eased in Lebanon; A Limited Curfew Remains
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24The Lebanese Army returned to its barracks today, leaving the job of maintaining order to the police and the paramilitary forces after the lifting of a 16day state of emergency last night.

title: M'CRANE INDICTED IN JERSEY AGAIN
description: NEWARK, May 24  Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. was indicted again today, this time by a Federal grand jury here on charges that he helped mastermind an incometaxfraud conspiracy involving Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign.

title: U.S. Bids 10 States Press Desegregation In Public Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The Nixon Administration disclosed today that it had told 10 states to submit by June 11 plans for further desegregation of public college faculties and students, or else face Federal fund cutoffs court action.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, MAY 25, 1973
description: Watergate Investigation; The United States Attorney in the Watergate case said he expected further indictments within 60 to 90 days, and that a key figure in the casereportedly Jeb Stuart Magruderhad agreed to plead guilty and serve as a prosecution witness. The Federal Attorney, Harold H. Titus Jr. said the indictments would be comprehensive and would focus on obstruction of justice in the Watergate coverup. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Hearing on Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that his panel would hold one day of public hearings on an expected request from the White House for an increase in the public debt ceiling. The temporary ceiling of $465billion will expire on June 30, and without an extension it would revert to the permanent ceiling of $400billion. The debt is now near the $465billion level.

title: EXCHANGES PLAN AFFILIATION TALKS
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday they plan to explore the feasibility of an affiliation  a move that could hasten the formation of a central market system.

title: Stink Bomb at Knoedler's
description: A foulsmelling chemical was dropped inside the Knoedler Gallery yesterday evening as visitors viewed an exhibition of paintings sent here from the Soviet Union. An anonymous caller told The Associated Press at 7:40 P.M., approximately the time the odor was noticed at the gallery, that the exhibition had been stinkbombed. The caller said things would get worse unless Soviet Jews were allowed to emigrate.

title: Retail Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week totaled an estimated $948million, up 16 per cent from $814million year earlier. Total retail store sales were about $9.8billion, up 13 per cent from last year's $8.6billion.

title: ALIENRADICAL TIE DISPUTED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Central Intelligence Agency reported in 1969 and 1970 that it could find no substantial evidence to support the Nixon Administration's view that foreign governments were supply.. ing undercover agents and funds to radicals and Black Panther groups in the United States, White House and intelligence sources said today.

title: Peter Paul to Increase Price and Size of Candy
description: Peter Paul, Inc., announced yesterday that it would increase the size of its candy bars and advance their prices from 10 cents to 15 cents a bar.

title: Towson Ousted in Lacrosse
description: TOWSON, Md., May 24 (AP) Finalperiod goals by Greg Lane and Mike Cordrey gave, Washington College a 108 victory over Towson State today in the semifinals of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association tournament. The Shoremen, runnersup last year, will play Cortland State for the title Saturday.

title: Barker Asserts He Sought Proof of Cuba Aid to Party
description: WASHINGTON, May 24One of the Watergate conspirators testified today that he had broken into the offices of the Democratic National Committee to search for proof of financial support of the party by the Cuban Government.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: CHICAGOSigned Darryl Maggs, wing, formerly with California Golden Seals of National League.

title: People in Sports: Rodgers Gets SixFigure Montreal Contract
description: Johnny Rodgers of Nebraska, last year's winner of the Heisman Trophy, has decided to play for the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League. Michael Trope, Rodgers's attorney, said yesterday that the contract the speedy running back and wide receiver had agreed to is in excess of six figures per year for three years, with triple pay if he is cut or traded.

title: Hartford Police Study Finds 40% of Cars Left Unlocked
description: HARTFORD, May 24 (UPI)The police here have issued the rsults of a survey that show that 28 per cent of some 4,058 cars checked were left unlocked. Twenty cars were not only unlicked, but the keys were left in the ignition.

title: 8Day Devon Horse Show To Get Under Way Today
description: DEVON, Pa.; May 24With more than 500 horses on the grounds, the eightday Devon horse show gets under way tomorrow with classes for juniors and ponies. By Saturday, all the junior championships will have been decided. Sunday is an off day and the seniors take over the ring on Monday.

title: SELASSIE CALLS FOR AFRICA FORCE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 24  Emperor Haile Selassie opened the 10th anniversary celebrations of the 11 Organization of African Unity here today by calling for the creation of a by of mutual defense for the 41 member nations.

title: FIRESTONE IN DENIAL ON NIXON LIBRARY
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) Leonard K. Firestone, head of the Richard M. Nixon Foundation, has denied reports that the Watergate investigation has caused the foundation to drop plans to build a museumlibrary complex commemorating the President.

title: Jobs for Women: Still the Resistance, but It's More Passive Now
description: Employers have been led to the water trough, Lee Christie remarked, but they don't know whether they want to drink.

title: Richardson Tells Navy to Close Culebra Gunnery Range in 75
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Elliot L. Richardson, as one of his final acts as Secretary of Defense, ordered today that the Navy end its controversial use of the small Puerto Rican island of Culebra as a practice gunneay range.

title: Deodorant Manufacturers Told to Prove Ad Claims
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)The Goverment today ordered eight manufacturers of antiperspirants and deodorants to prove such advertising claims as best wetness fighter, doesn't sting and a completely new idea in body odor prevention.

title: CORPORATE BONDS POST PRICE GAINS
BUFFALO NINE DOWNS TEMPLE IN PLAYOFFS
description: TRENTON. May 24  Jim Riedel, a freshman, allowed only three hits today as Buffalo University defeated the regional favorite, Temple University, 10, in the opener of the National Collegiate District II baseball playoffs.

title: Man Who Beat Bad Sport Wins Fair Play Trophy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 24 (AP)Stan Smith, the tennis star, has been awarded the 1972 Fari Play Trophy of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Bridge:
description: GUARUJA, Brazil, May 24 The Aces had an early disaster in the finals of the world team championship against Italy here this afternoon. Playing on the VuGraph against Pietro Forquet and Benito Biancchi, Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman, usually very accurate bidders, reached an unsound slam on the fourth deal and the defense took the first three tricks.

title: Weekend's Prospects for Fishing and Boating
description: AREA APoor fishing is reported by John Falkiewicz at Surf City. Atlantic mackerel have come and gone and the same is true of most of the winter flounder. A few small stripers are being taken on live shrimp in Barnegat and contiguous bays. At Barnegat, Meyer's Yacht Basin reports sea bass and ling being caught by bottomfishing boats offshore. Scattered stripped bass are about, but more are being taken in the bay than in the inlet or ocean. A few small bluefish have been reported. The evercooperative tilefish, for those who enjoy a long trip and deepwater fishing, are available. At Seaside Park, N. J., Colvin's Tackle Shop reports poor surf fishing but fair angling for small stripers and scattered small bluefish in Barnegat Bay. Ken's Landing at Point Pleasant says most of the fishing is confined to sea bass and ling. The mackerel have gone, but fluke are

title: Teamster Aide Who Backed McGovern Forced to Quit
description: ST. LOUIS, May 24  A highranking official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who had defied the union President, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, by endorsing Senator George McGovern for President has been forced to resign from office in his local union.

title: BILL ON HOUSING FOR AGED GAINS
description: ALBANY, May 24  A bill calling for a $100million bond referendum to be used to build housing for the middleincome aged was approved by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Con Edison Is Hopeful Of Curbing Brownouts
description: The prospect of brownouts this summer because of power shortages is more remote than in the last three years, Louis H. Roddis Jr., president of the Consolidated Edison Company, reported yesterday.

title: Giants to Play in Yale Bowl; Hope to Relax TV Blackout
description: Yale Bowl was officially designated yesterday as the site of the last five New York Giant home football games this season, but the knotty problem of how the local television blackout would be handled remained unresolved.

title: W. T. Grant Shows a Loss for Quarter
The Screen: 'Emperor of the North Pole' Arrives:Marvin Heads Cast of Stiffs and Tramps The Cast Action Melodrama Has Hobo Jungle Plot
description: Robert Aldrich's "Emperor of the North Pole" is a fine, elaborately staged action melodrama set mostly on the freight trains and in the hobo jungles of the American Northwest during the Great Depression.It's about bindle stiffs and tramps and a psychotic trainman named. The Shack, a man who keeps order with a chain in one hand and a hammer in the other, thus becoming known, not surprisingly, as "the meanest conductor alive." To those of you who have always thought of conductors as a docile breedtheir worst fault being an occasional inaudibility when coming into East Hampton (or was that Amagansett?)the film will be an expos not without its silly moments. I admit I found it most entertaining."Emperor of the North Pole" is a king-of-the-hill movie. It sees all life in terms of physical self-assertion, in terms of beating the other guy, not because there is anything valuable to win, but rather because if you don't win you lose, and when you lose, you're nothing. Absolute zero. It is a game a lot of small boys play all their lives. It is also one that's been overloaded with metaphysical associations in fiction romanticizing mountain climbing, bull fighting, boxing and big-game hunting, but never, as far as I can remember, the bumming of freights.Christopher Knopf, who wrote the original screenplay, is not without his impulses to set "Emperor of the North Pole" in a larger, more meaningful context, but usually he resists them. More important, he has created almost perfect action-movie characters, people who can't bore us with their earlier histories because they don't have any. They exist solely within the time and the action of the film itself. When it stops, they vanish, but we have had a sensational ride.With his last film, "Ulzana's Raid," and this new one, Aldrich clinches a claim to being the best director of this kind of film now at work. This is not because he plays down to a lower class of film but because he takes it seriously enough to get splendid performances from his actors and to stage the action sequences with a dizzying vividness and accuracy. Compare the technical proficiency of the various fights that Aldrich has staged here, a lot of them aboard moving freight cars, with the lethargic, dumbly bloody gunfights in Sam Peckinpah's "Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid." It's no contest.Boiled down to its irreducible minimum, which is not difficult, the story of "Emperor of the North Pole" is about the vow of A-No. 1 (Lee Marvin), a jaunty, aging hobo, acknowledged by his peers to be the champion of champions, to ride the freight captained (or conductored) by The Shack (Ernest Borgnine), from somewhere or other to Eugene, Ore. Nobody has ever successfully freeloaded. The Shack's train and, indeed, even before the title credits, we are treated to the sight of one of The Shack's hobo victims.The suspense of the film (which is so hugely violent that its PG rating is a mystery), is unrelenting and the performances first-rate, including that of Keith Carradine, a son of John, as a loudmouth kid to whom Marvin tries to teach the rules of the road. The only ludicrous thing in the film is a song sung behind the credits. It tells us, if my notes do not deceive me, that "a train's not a man, and a man's not a train, for a man can do things a train never can."

title: Argentina's Chance
description: In other circumstances the return of Argentina elected constitutional government after seven years military rule would be an occasion for rejoicing far beyond that country's borders. For many reasons, the celebration over the inauguration today of Dr. Hector Campora as President will be confined to the forces making up the Peronist coalition that elected him and their motley collection of admirers and supporters from abroad.

title: Suit Calls for Return Of Gifts to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)A retired businessman filed a class suit in Federal District Court yesterday to get back the money he gave to President Nixon's reelection campaign because, he said, it may have been used for illegal political espionage.

title: Candidates' Day
description: Representative Herman dillo said yesterday that if became Mayor the first thing would do would be to declai moratorium on cityfinanced construction and reuire that work forces and contractors be integrated before the construction resumed.

title: Railroad Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion tonmiles, 8.4 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 552,462 cars, 5.1 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 9.3 per cent above last year.

title: EVANS CAPTURES DECATHLON TITLE
description: EMMITSBURG, Md., May 24 Ron Evans weathered an afternoonlong rain better than 10 other competitors today and won the first decathlon of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America (I.C.4A.).

title: Gray Testifies He Told Nixon in July Aides Were Trying to Mortally Wound You
description: WASHINGTON, May 24L. Patrick Gray 3d, former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told a Senate appropriations subcommittee today that he had warned President Nixon last July 6 that people on your staff are trying to mortallly wound you by hampering an F.B.I. inquiry into the Watergate affair.

title: 3 Newspapers Here Offer Plan To Automate to Printers Union
description: The publishers of the city's three major daily newspapers have made a proposal to Typographical Union No. 6 that would permit the papers to introduce and utilize automation, including any and all compuers.

title: ATHENS ARRESTS NAVAL OFFICERS
description: ATHENS, May 24The Government said today that it had blocked an attempt by a handful of naval officers to overthrow the militarybacked administration.

title: Man Arrested in Shooting Of 3YearOld in Brooklyn
description: A 20yearold man was arrested last night after a police investigation into the shooting of a 3yearold boy in an apartment at 716 Bedford Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: A Centerfold for Laughing, Not Leering
description: There she is, lounging seductively on one elbow, displaying a rhinestone choker, black waterproof waders, gold lame bootsand her $4,000 facelift. It is Phyllis Diller, the first centerfold pinup girl for Field & Stream magazine.

title: ALCH SUGGESTS 3 TAKE LIE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Under aggressive and at times hostile questioning from the Senate Watergate committee, Gerald Alch, the original lawyer for James W. McCord Jr., suggested today that he, McCord and McCord's present lawyer take liedetector tests to see who was telling the truth.

title: Ecological Peril Cited
description: TRENTON, May 24Governor Cahill signed into law today a truth in labeling bill for household appliances that he said was another measure in the state's campaign to provide maximum protection for the consumer in the marketplace.

title: This Is Cinerama Returns, but Not Quite
description: This Is Cinerama, the first of five hugely successful Cinerama travelogue features originally opened at the Broadway Theater in New York on Sept. 30, 1952. It has now returned to the Ziegfeld Theater in New York with ads proclaiming: The last time you saw a show like this one, it was this one! Not quite.

title: MAJOR BANKS LIFT PRIME RATE TO 7
description: A dozen or so of the nation's largest banks announced yesterday increases in their prime, or minimum, interest rates on loans to corporations to 7 per cent from 7 per cent. The action had been expected.

title: EXP.O.W.'S CHEER
Soviet Bid for AntiChina Pact Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A highly placed Administration official said today that the Soviet Union had proposed a joint agreement with the United States in 1970 against any provocative actions by China or any other nuclear power.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: $1MILLION DAMAGES ASKED IN DRUG RAID
description: SPRINGFIELD, ILL., May 24 A Collinsville, Ill., man and his wife, who were terrorized in their home by Federal narcotics agents, filed today $1million damage suit against the Federal Government in United States District Court here.

title: U.S. TENNIS STARS ADVANCE IN PARIS
description: PARIS, May 24 (AP)  With Tom Gorman of Seattle and Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., leading the way, American players make a good showing today in firstround action of the $135,000 French tennis championships.

title: F.B.I. SAYS THREAT LED TO J.D.L. RAID
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that a search of headquarters of the Jewish Defense League on Wednesday was carried out with a Federal search warrant based on a telephone call warning that explosives would be planted at the Russian or Iraqi missions to the United Nations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:In spite of Watergate and its alarming implications, the people of our nation should not lose sight of the fact that our Government must continue to function. It's a $250billion business enterprise, and cannot be permitted to drift because of our preoccupation with the shocking revelations before the Ervin Committee. In this connection, Congress is now considering President Nixon's slashed budget.

title: 33 INDY DRIVERS GAUGE FUEL USE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24The 33 cars that have qualified fox the Indianapolis 500 participated today in Carburetion Day, traditionally the final practice session, before the 57th running of the 500 on Memorial Day, next Monday. Four cars ran laps faster than 190 miles an hour, and five others were timed between 189 and 190 miles an hour.

title: City Is Cutting Back DayCare Expansion
description: The Human Resources Administration announced yesterday that it was curtailing expansion of its daycare program, and that it would open 30 fewer centers than it had planned to open in the next [year.

title: NATION REGISTERS ITS FIRST SURPLUS IN TRADE SINCE '71
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The nation's foreign trade balance improved dramatically in April for the second consecutive month and moved into surplus for the first time since September, 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Harry Nilsson was in New York recently, hanging out with Ringo Starr (they are working on a satirical horror film, Son of Dracula) and catching up on his television viewing. He is a compulsive viewer who lives in Britain, where the stations close down earlier.

title: Economic Reports Unleash Wave of Buying Orders
VOTE ON CHARTER DELAYED TILL 75
description: ALBANY, May 24With only a few Assemblymen contesting it, both houses of the Legislature today approved Governor Rockefeller's bill to defer until 1975 a public referendum on the recommendations of the special State Commission to Revise the New York City, Charter.

title: Bishop of Hong Kong Dies
description: HONG KONG, May 24 (Reuters)  The Roman Catholic Bishop of Hong Kong, Francis Chenping Hsu, died of a heart attack in a restaurant here. He was 53 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24Steve Krisiloff's racing career has been a succession of learning experiences. The most important one has been the art of getting along with little money, which includes teaching yourself the innards of race car.

title: Skylab Astronauts Set to Lift Off Today
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 24Three American astronauts were ready tonight to embark tomorrow on a mission to repair the overheated Skylab space station and thus Rye a $2,5billion project aimed at learning how men react to longduration space flight.

title: Seals and Crofts With a Difference
description: Visually it looked very elegant. Seals and Crofts, nicely contrasting in white and plaid suits, perched on high stools on stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. And behind them massed ranks of tuxedoed string and brass players, conducted by Marty Paid This time in New York we thought we'd like to do things a little different, said Seals and Crofts.

title: Bid to Reopen Antioch Set
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 24 (AP)  Dean Ewell Reagin of Antioch College says another attempt will be made tomorrow to reopen the school, closed more than a month by student strikers. An attempt to end the strike Tuesday failed as Dean Reagin and an aide were pelted with eggs and blocked by strikers from entering several campus buildings. The dean rejected yesterday request by strikers to meet to discuss financial aid and the expulsion of student and faculty backers of the strike.

title: Bill to Enlarge City's School Board Gains in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 24  A bill that would establish an appointed, sevenmember New York City Board of Education picked up support from key lawmakers today and expected to be approved by the Legislature in this session.

title: Reichhold Reaches Agreement To Buy Tenneco Newport Unit
description: Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached tentative agreement with Tenneco Chemicals, Inc., for the acquisition by Reichhold of Tenneco's Newport division, a major producer of wood and oil naval stores and derivatives.

title: Peking's Foreign Minister To Visit Europe and Iran
description: PEKING, May, 24 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei of China will visit Britain, France and Iran early next month for wideranging talks with leaders of the three countries, it was announced here today.

title: NICKLAUS SHARES GOLF LEAD ON A 67
description: ATLANTA, May 24  Jack Nicklaus, an absentee at the last four tournaments, was back in action today with a 67 for a share of the lead in the $150,000 Atlanta golf tournament.

title: LOMENZO DENIES LEGALFEE STORY
description: Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo said yesterday that over a sevenyear period he had received a total of $200,000 in payments of $100 or so a week and at times more to buy out his share of a Rochester law partnership after he took public office.

title: Safety Board Aide Denies Putting Pressure on Staff
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The general manager of the National Transportation Safety Board has denied applying pressure to staff members of that independent agency to bow to White House wishes.

title: Red Smith
description: Ernie Terrell is taller than Primo Carnera, bigger than Sonny Liston and can sing just as loud as Joe Frazier. One would have to he noticeably absentminded to mislay him, especially when he is accompanied by his rock combo, The Heavyweights. Yet as far as most students of the Sweet Science were concerned, the former heavyweight champion of the globeas the globe was once defined by the World Boxing Associationhad been missing and unaccounted for until this week. He had been missing since the dark ages. of 1967, and if you don't think they were dark, why in those days boxing commissions were running Muhammad Ali off the block of because he wouldn't join the Army, Terrell was losing to Thad Spencer in the first round of a television tournament concocted to find a replacement for Ali, and Madison Square Garden hadn't yet dreamt up the ingenious idea of matching Frazier and Buster Mathis for the world

title: Football Transactions
description: BUFFALOSigned Brian McConnell, No. 7 draft choice from Michigan State, and Don McCall, running back, free agent released by San Diego.

title: PLAN FOR LENIENCY
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 United States Attorney Harold H. Titus Jr. announced today that one of the key figures in the Watergate case had agreed to plead guilty and serve as a prosecution witness at the trial.

title: MANE INDICTED IN JERSEY AGAIN
description: NEWARK, May 24  Former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. was indicted again today, this time by a Federal grand jury here on charges that he helped mastermind an incometaxfraud conspiracy involving Governor Cahill's 1969 election campaign.

title: Senegal's Embassy Bombed
description: PARIS, May 24 (Reuters)An explosion ripped through the Senegalese Embassy late tonight, and witnesses said the blast had been caused by a bomb. The building was heavily damaged but no one was reported hurt.

title: PRICES REBOUND ON AMEX AND OTC
2d Briton Resigns After Sex Scandal
description: LONDON, May 24Britain's sex scandals widened today with the resignation of Earl Jellicoe, leader of the House of Lords, who acknowledged that he had engaged in casual affairs with prostitutes.

title: Mets, Dodgers Tied at 33 Alter 11 Innings on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24Yogi Berra took his traveling medical show to California to night as the New York Mets opened a 12game trip with Tom Seaver pitching against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Dr. Thomas McGavack, 75, An Endocrinologist, Dies
description: Dr. Thomas H. McGavack, endocrinologist at New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and Metropolitan Hospital from 1936 to 1957, died Wednesday in Martinsburg, W. Va., where he lived. His age was 75.

title: People and Business
description: James E. Smith, 42 a Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury, was nominated yesterday by President Nixon to be Controller of the Currency, succeeding William B. Camp.

title: NURSE SPOTS TICK; BOY'S LIFE SAVED
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 24A 4yearold boy who might have died of paralysis from an unknown cause is well today because a nurse attended a lecture on ticks and mites at the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center here.

title: SAMUEL A. SCHREINER
description: PITTSBURGH, May 24Samuel A. Schreiner, a lawyer who founded the suburban township of Mount Lebanon in 1912 and became an authority on township law, died here Tuesday. He was 91 years old.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: PHILADELPHIASigned Ray Lewis, guard, bonus first round draft choice from Los Angeles State.

title: Excerpts From. Transcript of Testimony Before Senate's Committee on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, May Following are excerpts a transcript of testimony day in the fifth day of ings on the Watergate by the Senate Select tee on Presidential Carnpaign Activities:

title: Caulfield's Resignation Is Accepted by Shultz
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)Secetary of the Treasury George P. Shultz announced today that he was accepting the resignation from the Treasury Department of John J. Caulfield, who has testified that he offered executive clemency to a Watergate defendant.

title: Interludes End On Bland Note
description: The season's final Interludes concert at Town Hall on Wednesday was a very loosely organized affair featuring a quartet led by George Barnes, guitarist. In view of the fact that the quartet was also composed of Dick Hyman, Piano, George Duvivier, bass, and Jo Jones, drums, with Ruby Braff, cornetist, and Peter Dean, singer of nostalgic songs, joining the group briefly, relatively little advantage was taken of the variety of talent available. Only Hyman broke through the generally bland choice of material with a pair of solos that showed off his talents. JOHN S. WILSON

title: Prisoner Job to End
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (UPI)The use of prisoners to repair and maintain state highways will be discontinued July 1 in Georgia when employes of the State Department of Transportation take over the job.

title: City Charter Referendum Put Off by Albany Till 75
description: ALBANY, May 24With only a few Assemblymen contesting it, both houses of the Legislature today approved Governor Rockefeller's bill to defer until 1975 a public referendum on the recommendations of the special State ComOission to Revise the New York City Charter.

title: Soviet Advance Men For Brezhnev's Visit End 5Day U.S.Tour
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A 35man Soviet advance party for Leonid I. Brezhnev's trip to the United States next month returned to Washington today after a fiveday trip around the country, including an unpublicized tour of Manhattan yesterday.

title: Presbyterians Ask End to Indochina Intervention
description: OMAHA, May 24The general assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., at a nineday meeting that ended yesterday, called for the United States to end military intervention in Indochina, urged a Senate study of the Wounded Knee uprising and upgraded the status of women in the church.

title: Stacey D'Ette, 3 Others Triumph Under Vasquez
description: mares. With Vasquez guiding her, she took the lead early on the muddy track and drew away steadily to score by 71/2 Stacey D'Ette and Jacinto Vasquez were the stars of the show at Belmont yesterday. The former came through with the expected victory in the feature race, the latter thrilled the crowd of 15,553 by riding four winners.

title: 300 IN GUILD STRIKE CONSUMERS UNION
description: Three hundred Newspaper Guild members employed by the Consumers Union went of strike yesterday at company facilities in Mount Vernon and Orangeburg, N. Y., in a dispute over wages, pensions and other issues.

title: Singer's Widow Loses Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 24 (AP) The Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals has affirmed a lower court's decision that the widow of the country singer Hank Wiliams is not entitled to damages although she had been libeled in Your Cheatin Heart, a movie about his life. The court ruled that Billie Jean Williams Berlin was not entitled to damages because of lack of malice on the part of the movie maker.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SOYBEANS RISE
description: For the fifth consecutive session soybean futures yesterday jumped the 20centabushel daily permissible limit on the Chicago Board of Trade. Buying reflected continued strong demand for soybeans and their products, meal and oil.

title: 2d Briton Resigns After Sex Scandal
description: LONDON, May 24Britain's sex scandals widened today with the resignation of Earl Jel licoe, leader of the House of Lords, who acknowledged that he had engaged in casual affairs with prostitutes.

title: Convention Center Gains Estimate Board Approval
description: The Board of Estimate last night approved the plan to build a $200million convention hall on the West Side of Manhattan. The hearing, sometimes stormy, lasted until nearly midnight before the board approved the measure by a vote of 14 to 4. Controller Abraham D. Beame ab stained.

title: Judge Rules City School Aides May Be Given Permanent Posts
description: A Federal judge has ruled that 2,000 supervisors who hold temporary appointments in the city's schools may now be eligible for permanent appointments, even though most of them have not taken written examinations for their jobs.

title: C. S. BRYKCZYNSKI
description: Charles S. Brykczynski, who succeeded his father in 1942 as president of the Stuhmer Baking Company, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 295 St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

title: Italian Rightist Deputy Loses Immunity
description: ROME, May 24  The Chamber of Deputies tonight lifted the parliamentary immunity of the leader of the Italian Social MovementNational Right Wing, permitting the start of criminal proceedings against him on the charge of having reorganized the outlawed Fascist party.

title: Books of The Times
description: DOROTHY THOMPSON. A Legend in Her Time. By Marion K. Sanders. Illustrated. 428 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $10.

title: PLAN FOR LENIENCY
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 United States Attorney Harold H. Titus Jr. announced today that one of the key figures in the Watergate case had agreed to plead guilty and serve as prosecution witness at the trial.

title: Chancellor of Hofstra To Head Think Tank
description: Dr. Clifford L. Lord yesterday announced his resignation as Chancellor of Hofstra University to assume the post of president and chief executive officer of Hudson Institute, the think tank devoted to national and international problems.

title: PATRICK J. B. CROWLEY
description: Patrick J. B. Crowley, a lawyer in charge of distribution cases, for the General Motors Corporation in the United States and Canada, died Monday in Detroit at the age of 62. He lived in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: Two Businessmen Sue Alleged Mafia Figure
description: The owners of a Newark plastics concern have sued Michael Benjamin Ricciardi, a reputed member of the Philadelphia Mafia family of Angelo Bruno, for $250,000 in damages arising from the alleged takeover of their business by organized crime.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: May 25, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Will Whites Elect Black? Angelenos Ponder
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., May 22It was a workday, but the architect was wearing a sporty, opennecked shirt as he walked down Van Nuys Boulevard on a midmorning coffee break.

title: Frank Kneisel, Violinist Was Kansas Concertmaster
description: CASTINE, Me., May 24 Frank Kneisel, a violinist who was a former teacher at the Boston Conservatory and had earlier been concertmaster of the Kansas City (Mo.) Symphony, died here yesterday at the age of 68.

title: ASTRONAUTS SET TO LIFT OFF TODAY
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 24Three American astronauts were ready tonight to embark tomorrow on a mission to repair the overheated Skylab space station and thus save a $2.5billion project aimed at learning how men react to longduration space flight.

title: SULLIVAN MEETS THIEU ON TRUCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 (AP)  William H. Sullivan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam for an hour today on proposals to enforde the Vietnam ceasefire. Mr, Sullivan then met with Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam for further discussions.

title: S. W. CALKINS
description: BEAVER, Pa., May 24 (UPI) S. W. Calkins of Uniontown, publisher of newspapers in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Florida, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: EXP.O.W.'S CHEER
description: WASHINGTON, May 24President Nixon, in a spiritec address to about 610 cheering former prisoners of war, lashes out today at those who threater the secrecy of national security matters.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 3.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial material rose to 163.8 from 160.6 last week.

title: EASING WEIGHED OF DIVIDEND CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 The Government's Committee on Interest and Dividends is aware of growing complaints that its dividend restraint policy is inequitable to stockholdars and may relax its rule limiting dividend increases to 4 cent a year.

title: FASHION TALK
description: With luxury coming in, a little mink or broadtail wrap will be useful for some people as long as it's kept simple.

title: P.S.C.. Examiner Opposes Phone Company Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, May 24 (UPI)A Public Service Commission examiner has recommended rejection of a request by the New York Telephone Company for a $217million temporary rate increase.

title: TAX HELP IS URGED FOR STEELMAKERS
description: The head of the Inland Steel Company said yesterday that the industry must have, tax reforms if it is to meet a 1980 demand for 20 million to 30 million additional tons of steel a year.

title: Joseph F. Flannelly, 78, Dies; Auxiliary Bishop of New York
description: The Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, who was administrator of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral from 1939 to his retirement in 1969, died Wednesday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Revised Racing Bill Providing Job Security Expected to Pass Today
description: The threat of a shutdown of New York racing by track labor unions all but disappeared yesterday after legislative leaders drafted several chapter amendments to the state's new omnibus racing and betting bill.

title: Stock Index Soars 29.42 Points Despite Rise in Key Loan Rate
description: The stock market scored one of its sharpest advances in history yesterday in response to reports on economic developments. The DowJones industrial average soared 29.42 points and closed at 922.44.

title: Democratic Rivals Ask Greater School Role for Mayor
description: The four Democratic candidates for the mayoral nominalion feel that the new Mayor, as the city official ultimately held accountable by the public, must exercise a greater role in school affairs than that permitted by the present school decentralization law.

title: Tidbits of Forgotten Music Evoke an American Past
description: The current vogue for nostalgia was carried to unprecedented  some might say preposterous  lengths on Wednesday evening at the Gershwin Theater of Brooklyn College. There members of the American Music Group gave a program named Excessive MusicExtravagance and American Values. It was a gimmick title, in that only two works on the program could properly be called excessive or extravagant. But it did cover forgotten aspects of the 18201910 period of American music, giving the audience a series of drawingroom tidbits probably not played for generations.

title: 3 Airlines Agree on Plan To Limit Seats on 4 Runs
description: American, Trans World and United Air Lines said yesterday they had reached final agreement on a plan to limit by prearrangement the number of seats each may fly on four competitive routes for two years beginning Sept. 15.

title: Winnebago Cancels Plans
description: FOREST CITY, Iowa, May 24 (UPI)Winnebago Industries, Inc., has called off plans for a $20million motorhome manufacturing plant at Reno, Nev. John K. Hanson, chairman of Winnebago's board of directors, cited the cost of construction, cost of opening the plant and moving and other expenses that exceeded original estimates as triggering the decison.

title: Consumerism Stressed
description: If Ann Klein is elected in November as New Jersey's first woman Governor, one of her first acts, she said yesterday, would be to kill the Tacks Island Dam project.

title: MORTON OF BRAVES DOWNS GIANTS, 21
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (UPI)Carl Morton pitched a fivehitter and doubled in the deciding run tonight as the Atlanta Braves edged the San Francisco Giants, 21.

title: COMMUNISTS ACCUSE U.S. IN COPTER CASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24Hungarian and Polish officials of the International Commission of Control and Supervision said today they strongly suspected that two commission helicopters that crashed last month in Vietcong territory were also on an unauthorized reconnaissance flight for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: ALIENRADICAL TIE DISPUTED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Central Intelligence Agency reported in 1969 and 1970 that it could find no substantial evidence to support the Nixon Administration's view that foreign governments were supplying undercover agents and funds to radicals and Black Panther groups in the United States, White House and intelligence sources said today.

title: 8Horse Entry Cut in Half, But the Best It Does Is 2d
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI)Bill Resseguet's chance to make thoroughred racing history was a failure at Arlington Park today when the best the ownertrainer's fourhorse entry could do in the Hyde Park Stakes was a secondplace finish.

title: A HOUSE MEMBER APPARENT SUICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Representative William O. Mills of Maryland, a Republican whose 1971 special election was aided by an unreported cash transfer of $25,000 from the Nixon campaign committee, was found shot to death this morning, and the authorities called his death an apparent suicide.

title: Mr. Nixon's Historic Alibi
A.E.C. Unit to Weigh Plan For Offshore Power Plant
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 A proposal to create the world's first offshore floating nuclear power plant off the New Jersey coast 11 miles northeast of Atlantic City, will receive its first evaluation next month from a subcommittee of the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Lime on the Chicken
MAN HELD IN DEATH OF BROTHER IN 57
description: MANNSVILLE, N. Y., May 24 (AP)A father of 10 was arraigned today on a charge of murdering his brother 16 years ago. Skeletal remains of the victim were found yesterday on a farm near here.

title: BOY, 17, IS HELD FIT FOR MURDER TRIAL
description: BUFFALO, May 24 (UPI)Albert D. Cash, a 17yearold youth accused of four murders, has been judged mentally capable of standing trial, it was disclosed yesterday by City Court judge.

title: Ford Maps Aid for Hospitals In Yielding to Argentine Rebels
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 24Spokesmen for the Ford Motor Company's subsidiary here said today that the concern would begin the distribution next week of $1million worth of medical equipment, food and educational materials to meet the demands of leftwing Argentine guerrillas who have threatened to kidnap company officials.

title: People in Sports: Rodgers Gets SixFigure Montreal Contract
description: Johnny Rodgers of Nebraska, last year's winner of the Heisman Trophy, has decided to play for the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League. Michael Trope, Rodgers's attorney, said yesterday that the contract the speedy running back and wide receiver had agreed to is in excess of six figures per year for three years, with triple pay if he is cut or traded,

title: Russians Show New Model Of TU144 at Paris Show
description: PARIS, May 24 (AP)  The soviet Union today introduced an improved version of its TU144 supersonic airliner, designed to take 140 passengers from Paris to New York in free hours.

title: FamousBarr Chairman Named to Head A.'S,
description: Federated Department Stores, Inc., has picked a new chairman for Abraham & Straus from the top echelon of a rival chain.

title: Dining Out at Delmonico'sMore Pleasant Than Grand
description: *Delmonico Restaurant, Beaver and South William Streets, BO 91180.

title: Advertising: A Day of Parties
description: There are some days when this job seems to be just one round of parties. Yesterday was one of them.

title: Notes on People
description: With the fingertips of his right hand on a copy of the Old Testament, Ephraim Katzir was sworn in as Israel's fourth President. The new President, who was born in the Soviet Union, changed his name from Katchalsky after he was elected in April by the Knesset to the office, which is virtually powerless and largely ceremonial. Mr. Katzir, 57 years old, is the youngest President in Israel's 25 years as an independent nation. Mr. Katzir, in private life a prominent biochemist, said at his swearingin in Jerusalem that as long as peace has not arrived, we shall be forced to act as in the days of Nehemiahthe sword in one hand, the ploughshare in the other I'm a little bit excited, hoping for the best. I'm hoping that things will turn out all right in the future. At a reception after the ceremony, Mr. Katzir greeted guests as he stood beside Premier

title: The Wall Jones Case Is Closed, but Not Tightly
description: MILWAUKEE, May 24 (UPI)With just one sentence, National Basketball Association Commissioner Walter Kennedy closed the case of Wali Jones's dispute with the Milwaukee Burks.

title: Iran Tightens Pact With Oil Companies
description: Iran and the Western oil companies signed yesterday basic agreement giving the Government of Iran full and real control over the petroleum industry within her borders.

title: Amended Legal Services Bill Sent to House Floor
