description: WASHINGTON, May 24Legislation to continue the beleaguered program of legal services for the poor was approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee, but its final form remained in doubt.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on May 24 were:

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Art Exchange With Israel On

title: Stock Index Soars 29.42 Points Despite Rise in Key Loan Rate
description: The stock market scored one of its sharpest advances in history yesterday in response to reports on economic develop. ments. The DowJones industrial average soared 29.42 points and closed at 922.44.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
6 Key State Officials Convicted, 6 Are Indicted and Await Trial
description: NEWARK, May 24 In the last few years, a half dozen former state officials have been convicted on various charges. Another six have been indicted and are awaiting trial. Except where indicated, the charges were brought by the United States Attorney's office here.

title: Cruelty to Coyote Alleged
description: MILFORD, Utah, May 24 (UPI)G. B. Lyman of Payson was accused yesterday of binding a coyote with wire and displaying the animal in front of a cafe. D. H. McGarry, a conductor for the Union Pacific Railroad, signed a complaint before Justice of the Peace E. L. Smith. Mr. Lyman was charged with cruelty to animals.

title: Pay Rise for Legislators Is Headed for Passage
description: ALBANY, May 24A bill that is expected to pass handily in the Legislature would increase its members salaries in 1975 to $23,500 a year and replace the currentolulu expense system with a daily allowance of up to $40 for actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of duties.

title: Soviet, in Break With Secrecy, Names Crews for Space Flights
description: MOSCOW, May 24The Soviet Union, in a major break with secrecy, identified today for the first time some of its astronauts before they made space flights.

title: Police Rebellion in India Is Reported at an End
description: NEW DELHI, May 24The police rebellion in Uttar Pradesh was reported to have ended today with the surrender of the last two garrisons that were holding out against the army.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows;
description: THE PARADISE KID by Donna de Matteo. Directed by Herbert Berghof. Tomorvow through June 23 at 7:30 P.M. The H. B. Playwrights Foundation, Inc., at 124 Bank Street (YU 96540).

title: Evils Which Leave No Home in the World Untouched
description: WASHINGTONThe assorted crimes and scandals collectively known as the Watergate affair feature the involvement of national security institutions the C.I.A., the State Department, the National Security staff, the White House staff, the F.B.I., exC.I.A. operatives, duped Cuban refugee clients of the C.I.A. These institutions and the men in them have, under a screen of secrecy, been trained and become practiced in lawless behavior. For Watergate to be instructive to those who want to save the American society we need to understand the framework of our Government and the changes need in it.

title: Pearl Bailey Mixes Song and Talk in Inimitable Style
description: Not even a heart attack as recently as three months ago can stop Pearl Bailey. She is at the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, singing, dancing, climbing down off the stage to walk through the audience and talking with her customary wit and erve as though nothing untoward had ever happened.

title: Several Thousand Icelandic Protesters Attack British Embassy
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 24 (Reuters)The windows of the British Embassy were smashed tonight as several thousand demonstrators milled about outside in protest against Britain's challenge to the 50mile fishing limits proclaimed by Iceland.

title: State Battle Against Billboards Enters 2d Year, With Modest Gains
description: HUDSON, N. Y.The campaign to eliminate billboards and other forms of visual pollution in New York State is entering its second year with transportation officials reporting modest success.

title: Crowds, Bets Down as Roosevelt Closes
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 Rainy skies and discouraging statistics for Roosevelt Raceway's 70session meeting, which closed tonight, before 17,698 fans, combined to dampen the spirts of George Morton Levy, president and founder of the harnessracing track.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A man who had just begun serving a fivetosevenyear term for drug sale and possession was stabbed by a:State Prison inmate yesterday as he stood in line waiting for his prison clothing. The man, Daryl K. Curtis, 25 years old, of Jersey City, died less than two hours later in St. Francis Hospital in Trenton. County authorities and officials of the prison in Trenton said a suspect had been seized and was being questioned. No motive was disclosed for the attack.

title: Fire in Trade Center Tower
description: Firemen yesterday quickly brought under control a fire that started in an elevator shaft of the 110story North Tower, at the World Trade Center just after 3 A.M. when grease on the cables ignited. The cause of the fire was undetermined and there were no injuries.

title: Xerox Foresees Profit Record in 1973
description: Stockholders of the Xerox Corporation were told yesterday that 1973 would be another record year for the company.

title: EDUCATION STUDY CITES THE HOME
description: STOCKHOLM, May 24A report on a major international education survey said today that home background tended to be the most important factor in a pupil's educational achievement. The conclusion was similar to those of earlier studies in the United States.

title: Veterans Give Nixon Plaque
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) President Nixon is described as Richard the Lionhearted in a plaque that Vietnam prisoners of war presented to him today at a White House gathering in their honor. The inscription reads: Presented to Richard M. Nixon, May 1973. Above a heraldic lion is the inscription: Our leaderour comrade Richard the Lionhearted.

title: The Case for Impoundment
description: WASHINGTON"When the Congress appropriates funds it gives the executive branch an authority to incur obligations. Certainly none of us hold that we give a mandate to expend the funds appropriated.

title: OFFICIALS EXPLAIN NIXON'S ASSERTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 White House sources offered an explanation today for President Nixon's assertion that The New York Times in three installments of Its presentation of the Pentagon Papers had published a majority of documents not included in the 47volume Pentagon study.

title: Buffalo Is Investigating ReliefCheating School
description: BUFFALO, May 24  The District Attorney's office here is investigating a school for welfare chiselers that charges a tuition of $5 a class and accepts only young pregnant women as students.

title: Clam Fossil Described As Oldest Yet Found
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)A 570 millionyearold clam, the oldest yet recovered, has been found near Albany, the United States Geological Survey announced today.

title: Marijuana Packages Sent To Officials in Oregon
description: EUGENE, Ore., May 24 (UPI) At least three dozen persons, including four county judges and one member of the Oregon Court of Appeals, have been sent packages of marijuana through the mails in the last two days.

title: Cutback Set by Sohio In Sale of Gasoline
description: CLEVELAND, May 24 (UPI) The Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced tonight an immediate 25 per cent cutback in the sale of gasoline and other related prod ucts through July 1 because of an extended refinery shutdown in Lima, Ohio.

title: The Lure of Secrecy
description: President Nixon's speech to the former prisoners war at the White House yesterday was an impassioned defensenot of telling the truth or of obeying the law or of dealing fairly with one's adversariesbut secrecy.

title: Exchange Seat Price Falls
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that a seat on the exchange had been sold for $80,000, down $2,000 from the. previous sale May 22 and the lowest price since April 21, 1958, when a seat sold for $77,000.

title: Shows Trace Past and Fate of Drawing
description: Two sizable exhibitions devoted to the art of drawing have opened this week, each bringing its own order of revelations and pleasures.

title: France Agrees to Withdraw Troops From Madagascar
description: PARIS, May 24 (Reuters)France and Madagascar have reached agreement on, the withdrawal of French troops from the Indian Ocean island.

title: WEIS IS ACCUSED OF FRAUD BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the New York Stock Exchange firm of Weis Securities, Inc., with fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws and asked the Federal District Court in New York to appoint a temporary receiver.

title: Residents in Brooklyn Fight Relocation Plan
description: With anger, bewilderment and sometimes with tears, residents of the tiny industrialresidential enclave in Brooklyn known as Northside came before a City Council committee yesterday to plead against relocation from their homes.

title: FARE PLAN GIVEN BY BLUMENTHAL
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal offered a plan yesterday that would, he said, save the 35cent transit fare by tapping funds of the state, the Federal government and the Port Authority for $327million.

title: Blyleven of Twins Allows 1 Hit (Bunt) To Beat Royals, 20
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 24 (AP)Bert Blyleven pitched a onehitterEd Kirkpatrick's bunt singleto lead the Minnesota Twins to a 20 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: HOSPITAL EASES ABORTION POLICY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 24While at least 500 pickets proitested outside, the Atlantic City Hospital Board of Governors announced last night that the hospital would begin to allow abortions during the first three months of pregnancy if approved by the woman's physician.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by President to Gathering of Former Prisoners of War
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Following are excerpts from the remarks of President Nixon at a reception today for returned prisoners of war:

title: Jew Reported Held in Arctic
description: MOSCOW, May 24 (AP)The family of Yevgeny Levich, a Jewish scientist arrested eight days ago, believes he is now in a military labor camp above the Arctic Circle. The relatives say that the only crime of Mr. iLevich, a 25yearold astrophysicist, is that he wants to emigrate to Israel with the rest of the Levich family. They said they were told by a Communist party official that Mr. Levich had been drafted for military service.

title: At Small Quaker College, The Old Values Survive
description: RICHMOND, Ind.  At 10:45 A.M. last Saturday, students outside OlveyAndis dormitory here conducted an Indian sun dance. Fifteen minutes later the dark skies turned bright, and the rain, thunder and lightning that had been active through the night did not resume for 5% more hours.

title: NURSE SPOTS TICK; BOY'S LIFE SAVED
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 24A 4yearold boy whc might have died of paralysis from an unknown cause is well today because a nurse attended a lecture on ticks and mites at the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center here.

title: Concern of Nixon Family Expressed
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Mrs. David Eisenhower, mingling among the guests at a tea at the State Department for the wives, mothers and girlfriends of the former prisoners of war, said today that her mother is holding up very well under the strain of the Watergate case.

title: Networks Leave Watergate Plans Open
description: The three television networks are leaving their options open as to whether they will continue live gaveltogavel coverage of the Senate Watergate hearings when they resume June 5.

title: The District Attorney
description: For three decades Frank S. Hogan has been so identified with outstanding, politicsfree performance as District Attorney of Manhattan that it is hard to think anyone else holding this post. Through years of sickening revelations of abuse of governmental power at every level, the probity with which Mr. Hogan has administered his office has been a source of pride to most New Yorkers. He has combined vigor in prosecution with respect for civil liberties.

title: Hammond Puts Energy Into Blues
description: John Paul Hammond, who opened Tuesday at Kenny's Castaways on 84th Street off Third Avenue, is the kind of white blues singer who imitates his idols down to the last follicle. His face contorted with soulful agony, his accent slurred, his shoulders hunched, he sings with a strong if slightly swallowed, dull baritone and accompanies himself on guitar and harmonica in a way that obviously gives great pleasure to his fans. If you aren't put off by the perhaps unconscious pretension of it all, and if you respond to energetic, rhythmically emphatic blues (Hammond's footstomping almost amounts to an additional drummer), then Kenny's is the place to be, through Sunday.

title: A HOUSE EMBER APPARENT SUICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Representative William O. Mills of Maryland, a Republican whose 1971 special election was aided by an unreported cash transfer of $25,000 from the Nixon campaign committee, was found shot to death this morning, and the authorities called his death an apparent suicide.

title: ISAAC FUCHS
description: Isaac Fuchs, retired president of the Spaide Shirt Company, died yesterday at his home, 760 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx. He was 78 years old.

title: Stomping Rock From Hookfoot
description: Life on the road, the string of onenighters, tightens a group up, and Hookfoot is a group in the middle of the marathon United States tour essential to push a British group into the rock limelight. When Hookfoot opened Wednesday at Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South and 17th Street, its members showed the benefits of working together over a period of time.

title: PLAN FOR ABORTIONS SET IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, May 24Without an abortion law and without a chance of getting one in the twilight days of the 1973 session of the General Assembly, Connecticut will attempt to control abortions by public health regulations, Health Commissioner Franklin M. Foote said today.

title: House Panel Urges Curbs on U.S. Secrecy Practices
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The House Government Operations Committee has recommended a new law to overhaul government secrecy practices.

title: SWIMMERS RISK BAN TO HELP U.S
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The impending trip to China by a United States swimming team on a tour sponsored by the State Departmentand the athletes certain suspension as a result by the Amateur Athletic Unionwas the focal point of the Senate hearing today on proposed sports legislation.

title: New Zealand Excoriates France on ATest Plans
description: THE HAGUE, May 24 (Reuters)New Zealand today deslivered a stinging attack on France for refusing to halt nuclear bomb tests in the Pacific. French contamination of the atmosphere with radioactive fallout is pernicious and inexcusable, the New Zealand statement added.

title: Super Bowl, Shout by a Candidate And Conan Doyle Enliven Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, May 24At times today, the Senate's investigation into the Watergate conspiracy seemed more like a seminar at an American Bar Association convention.

title: Film: Happiness, a Silent Comedy From Soviet
description: Alexander Medvedkin, born in 1900, occupies a minor place in the history of Russian cinema,_mainly for the production of documentary and propaganda films, beginning in 1927 and extendinto the nineteenseventies. Roger Manvell's International Encyclopedia of Film credits Medvedkin with three features, all made in the thirties. The earliest of these, Happiness, opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room.

title: Amnesty Panel Hears Deserter, Who Then Surrenders to Police
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Edward R. Sowders, a veteran of the Vietnam war who deserted from the Army in 1970, appeared before an informal House hearing on amnesty today to announce that he would surrender to military authorities.

title: As a New Peronist Era Dawns, 4 of the Faithful Tell of Hopes
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 24 When Dr. Hector J. Campore assumes the presidency tomorrow, he will begin what almost all Argentines consider the most important chapter in their history since Juan D. Perlin was overthrown in 1955.

title: KENNETH ALLSOP, 53 BRITISH AUTHOR, DIES
description: WEST MILTON, England, May 24 (AP)  Kenneth Allsop, a British author and researcher into the American way of life was found dead last night at his home near here. He was 53 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Fifth Avenue gift shop In New York that sold a $2 roll of film for $10, a $7 carved bottle for $125 and $200 worth of bricabrac for more than $5,000 has promised to change its ways following an investigation by an undercover agent who worked in the store as a stock clerk, the City Department of Consumer Affairs announced.

title: Canopy Plans Improvised by Frantic Effort
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., May 24  To save the Skylab project, whose crippled workshop is in earth orbit, hundreds of specialists, from space physicists to pipefitters, from seamstresses to polymer chemists, have combined forces this week to produce the improvised canopies to be flown into space tomorrow.

title: Rickover Is in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) Vice Mm. Hyman G. Rickover, pioneer in nuclearsubmarine development, is in Bethesda Naval Hospital with a respiratory problem, a Navy spokesman said today. The 73yearold Admiral Rickover entered the hospital Sunday.

title: FIGUERES WON'T BE SHIELD FOR VESCO
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica May 24 (AP)President Jose Figueres said tonight that extradition of Robert L. Vesco to the United States would be automatic if a court here approved any move to extradite the financier.

title: Too Much Unchecked Power
description: The House, as usual, has sustained President Nixon's veto, this time of a misdirected Congressional effort to remove two high officials from office, then to assert the Senate's right to approve their reappointment. This may suggest that the Watergate disclosures have not reduced Mr. Nixon's political clout as much as might have been expected; but it does not change the necessity, made urgent by these same disclosures, for a stronger public check on the White House staff.

title: Skylab Repair Mission
description: If all goes on schedule, three astronauts will blast off this morning on an unprecedented mission whose initial stages, at least, will be far different from those originally envisioned. This time their first priority is to repair the giant Skylab vehicle orbiting earth in crippled condition. They will try to erect a sunshade to protect the space station from the harsh sunrays that now pour in without hindrance. In addition, the astronauts will try if possible to extend the solar cell panels that are now inoperative.

title: GUNMAN IS SLAIN IN $52,713 HOLDUP
description: Two payroll bandits disarmed and robbed two Pinkerton guards of $52,713 in the lobby of an office building opposite City Hall yesterday morning.

title: Equity Financing
description: A nonregistered spot secondary of 71,500 common shares of Community Public Service at $27 was reported oversubscribed yesterday by Salomon Brothers. The company's stcok closed unchanged at 27 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: East German Prosperity Is a Socialist Issue
description: COTTBUS, East Germany, May 5I have just planted 22 trees on my property out in the country and I have to drive out this weekend to water them. The man stroked his thoroughbred terrier as he spoke. The drive from the big city to the lakedotted countryside would be in his new Western sports car.

title: Compensation Commission Asks Extension of Tenure
description: TRENTON, May 24 (AP) Governor Cahill said today the special Workmen's Compensation Study Commission had aked that its term be extended to Sept. 30.

title: RENT CONTROL BILL SIGNED IN MARYLAND
description: ANNAPOLIS, May 24 (UPI) Gov. Marvin M. Mandel, with a gibe at President Nixon's economic policies, signed into law today what is believed to be the first statewide rent control bill in the nation.

title: Business Briefs
description: WARSAW, May 24 (Reuters)SwindellDressler of Pittsburgh, a unit of Pullman, Inc., said today that it had reached basic agreement in negotiations with Polish authorities on a $40million contract to supply foundry equipment for machine tools.

title: Friendly Bids U.S. Pay for Politicians Air Time
description: Fred W. Friendly, former president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System and now broadcast consultant to the FOrd Foundation, said yesterday that the broadcast industry must not be allowed to keep selling air time to political candidates if the country was to avoid the opprobrium of the Watergate case.

title: Dean Is Questioned About the Vesco and I.T.T. Cases
description: WASHINGTON, May 24John W. Dean 3d was questioned behind closed doors for more than three hours today by the House Commerce investigation subcommittee on two cases involving the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mrs. Meir's Labor Party Opens Its Rolls to All Arab Backers
description: TEL AVIV, May 24Israeli Arabs who have widely supported Premier Golda Meir's Labor party in national elections will now be able to join it.

title: G.E. NEGOTIATIONS NEAR A DEADLINE
description: Negotiations between the General Electric Company and unions representing 137,000 of its employes now appear likely to continue beyond tomorrow at midnight, when their present contracts expire.

title: Dance: Cranko's Gothic Legend of a Swan Lake
description: Normally, in ballet, conservatism is the best approach to the classics. Ws need to conserve the few relics of 19thcentury ballet we have left, and there are certain companies, and I am thinking particularly of Britain's Royal Ballet, Leningrad's Kirov Ballet, the Royal Danish Ballet, and American Ballet Theater, which have accepted a particular responsibility in this regard.

title: Milliard Dancers Honor Limon With 3 Premieres
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble presented three new works and two repertory pieces Wednesday night at the Juilliard School in a prograin dedicated to the late Josh Limon, whose choreography and teaching at the institution spanned two decades.

title: U.S. SUBMITS PLAN FOR RAILS IN EAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Following its late March recommendations to Congress for reorganizing the nation's Northeast railroads, the Department of Transportation sent legislation to Capitol Hill today asking for a private corporation to restructure the Northeastern rail lines.

title: EUGENE J. SCHULTE
description: Eugene J. Schulte, president of the Ferrostaal Overseas Corporation, importers, and of the GermanAmerican Chamber of Commerce in New York, died Wednesday in Brookville, L.I., where he lived. He was 62 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, May 25Merideth Lee Dean, named this week as Princeton University's associate director of athletics for physical education and women's programs, can view her new position as recognition of her success building a women's athletic program that surpasses its male counterpart in many sports.

title: Screen: Vampir Is a Serious Work
A FALSE ARTICLE LAID TO NEWSMAN
description: DETROIT, May 25Howard Kohn, a young, prizewinning reporter who for two years intensely investigated the heroin trade here, has become the center of a controversy in which his credibility is at stake.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
GOING OUT Guide
description: SUPER SONIC The Sonic Arts Union, which usually plays its contemporary electronic music in the regular concertsize package, is going all out this weekend with a performance that started yesterday morning and will run deep into Sunday night, 72 hours without letup. This musical flagpolesitting is taking place, for free, at WBAI's Studio C,.359 East 62d Street (8260880). The Union consists of four persons  Robert Ashley, David Behrman, Alvin Lucier and Gordon Mumma  who are not usually a playalltogetheratonce quartet but a group in which each member

title: Basketball Transactions NATIONAL ASSOCIATION
description: BUFFALOSigned Ernie DiGregorio, guard, No. 1 draft choice from Providence. CLEVELANDSigned Larry Farmer, forward, No. 7 draft choice from U.C.L.A.

title: New Swan Lake Faces
description: For its second performance of John Cranko's version of Swan Lake, the Stuttgart Ballet presented a new cast led by Richard Cragun and Birgit Keil on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Pact Would Let U.S.Check Swiss Banks in Tax Cases
description: BERNE, May 25The United States and Switzerland today signed a treaty designed to help American investigators track down members of organized crime by uncovering funds hidden in hitherto secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: First Medical Doctor in Space Joseph Peter Kerwin
description: In some ways, Comdr. Joseph Peter Kerwin  the first medical doctor to go into space for the United Statesis the opposite of his Skylab commander, Charles Conrad Jr.

title: Networks to Rotate Watergate Hearings
description: The three television networks agreed yesterday that when the Senate Select Watergate Committee hearings resumed June 5, they would broadcast each day's session on a rotating basis.

title: High School Notes
description: There is no shortage of help for students who want it at Haaren High School, the boys school at 10th Avenue and 59th Street. Each afternoon, upwards of 30 students stay after school to help fellow students with assignments and tutoring in English, reading and math.

title: Text of Statement on Nixon Home on Coast
The Kin of Missing Servicemen Push for Action on Their Status
description: Relatives and friends of some of the 1,359 American servicemen listed as missing in action in Southeast Asia urged local congressmen yesterday to see to it that both the United States and North Vietnam made greater efforts to resolve the status of the men.

title: Sri Lanka to Try 4,000
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 25 A total of 4,000 people alleged to have been involved in an uprising by ultraleftist youths that plunged the country, formerly Crylon, into fullscale guerrilla war in 1971 will face charges before the Criminal Justice Commission, which was set up specifically for this purpose last year. There is no appeal from its findings.

title: DIGREGORIO SIGNS WITH N.B.A.BRAVES
Stock Index Up 6.40 As Trading Climbs
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPORA BECOMES ARGENTINA'S CHIEF
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 25 Dr. Hector J. Campora, a loyal follower of former President Juan Domingo Perlin, was inaugurated today as the president of a popularly elected government, ending seven years of military rule in Argentina.

title: Litton Posts Profit for Quarter, In Contrast to Loss a Year Ago
Legislative Windup
description: In typically irresponsible frenzy, the State Legislature is winding up five sluggish months of limited activity by rush action on a huge number of bills that should have been voted up or down long ago. This final scramble is a mockery of the legislative process, no less repulsive because it is part of Albany's dreary tradition.

title: ETHIOPIA MEETING IS TOLD OF A PLOT
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 25  Three heads of African states declared here today that the white minority regime of South Africa, the Portuguese African colonies and Israel were all involved In an imperialist plot to retard independent African progress.

title: The Mr. Big Myth
description: WASHINGTON, May 25In retrospect it is easy to see that President Nixon loved secrets too much. He was not alone in that vice. Lyndon Johnson before him loved secrets to excess and often boasted of the secrets to which he alone was privy.

title: DIGREGORIO SIGNS WITH N.B.A BRAVES
description: BUFFALO, May 25 (UPI)The owner of the Buffalo Braves, Paul Snyder, said today he had signed Ernie DiGregorio to a multiyear contract with the National Basketball Association club.

title: Miss Carnahan Bride Of Louis A. Mangone
description: Miss Emily Hazelrigg Carnahan, a stewardess with American Airlines, was married here yesterday afternoon to Louis A. Mangone, a lawyer with the New York firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne performed the nondenominational ceremony in the Tillman Chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Pollution Suit Settled
description: HOUSTON, May 25 (Reuters) Armko Steel Corporation said today that it had settled an air pollution suit against its Houston works for a cash fine of $250,000. The suit was filed by Harris County and the state three years ago and charged that the plant violated air quality standards.

title: Philharmonic Adds A Ballet by Villella To Its Promenade
description: Edward Villella and Patricia McBride seem to hay become as necessary to the New York Philharmonic's Promenades season as domestic champagne. The solo dancers of the New York City Ballet returned to the popularmusic series on Thursday night (Mr. Villella for his fourth consecutive year), and went bubbling through a new ballet choreographed by Mr. Villella, Salute to Cole.

title: Mississippi Flooding Ends After. 77 Days, a Record
description: ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UPI)The 77day Mississippi River flooding ended officially at noon today, when the rver returned to its banks.

title: Antiques: At Brandywine
description: CHADDS FORD, PaNothing whets the appetite more for a view of vintage farm furnishings than a drive through the lushly green and rolling countryside approaching the Brandywine River Museum here. For in such landscapes, punctuated by grazing cow herds, wellbred horses, venerable stone dwellings and silvered post and rail fences, were born the painted dower chests, exuberantly decorated tole wares and crazyquilt coverlets that characterized rural America a century or two ago.

title: MITCHELL AND DEAN REPORTED ACCUSED
description: Two former White House aides, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, in depositions given yesterday in the Democratic party's civil suit, sought to put much of the blame for the Watergate conspiracy on former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Presidential counsel John W. Dean 3d, CBSTV News reported.

title: DIRK FOCH, COMPOSER AND CONDUCTOR, 87
description: Dirk Foch, Dutch composer and conductor who was a protg of Richard Strauss, died Thursday in Orselina, Switzerland. He was 87 years old.

title: French Left Attacks Minister of Culture
description: PARIS, May 25Poor Maurice Druon. Darling of the Paris salons, youngest immortal of the French Academy, winner of the prestigious Prix Goncourt for his second novel, a success at everything. And now? The French intelligentsia's public enemy No. 1.

title: Farm Agency Forms Network To Get Information for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Agriculture Department is setting up an information network reaching into virtually every county in the United States to advise the Nixon Administration on farm matters.

title: Art: Brooklyn Bridge Celebrated
description: The Brooklyn Bridge has long enjoyed a kind of mythological status among American painters, poets, photoggraphers and other artists. Admired both for its great formal beauty and as an almost mystical symbol of modern urban life, the bridge has served as subject matter and inspiration for a great many works of literary and pictorial art. In retrospect, it seems as if this particular feat of engineering and design embodied all the hopes and aspirations of the city itself in the days when it was not uncommon to regard city life not as a harrowing problem but as a glorious achievement.

title: Poker Night Favored Today in Mother Goose Field of 11
description: The Mother Goose, second part of the triple crown for fillies, has attracted an overnight field of 11 for its 17th running at Belmont Park today. Poker Night of the Hobeau Farm is the longrange favorite for the 1mile contest, with Windy's Daughter, owned by Mrs. Paul Blackman, and. C. V. Whitney's Bag of Tunes rated next.

title: Soviet Complains U.S. Concern Delays Kama Automotive Project
description: NABEREZHNYE CHLLNY, U.S.S.R.,May 22A vast, raw construction site of unfinished factory buildings and churned earth near this Kama River town 500 miles east of Moscow symbolizes the developing economic cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: KLEIN IS EXPECTED TO QUIT POST SOON
description: SAN DIEGO, May 25The last survivor of President Nixon's original Presidential campaign teama political associate for more than 25 years.

title: SID PHILLIPS
description: LONDON, May 25 (AP)  Sid Phillips, a leading British jazz bandleader, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 65 years, old.

title: Rockefeller Denies Aim Is Domination of City U.
description: ALBANY, May 25Governor Rockefeller today denied that he had any design to dominate the City University in his attempt to replace the university trustees with a new board that would include four members he would appoint.

title: RISH SONG WINS IN DEVON OPENER
YONKERS HOPING TO WOO BETTORS
description: YONKERS, May 25Caesar Gennari, track superintendent at Yonkers Raceway, put the finishing touches on the layours halfmile strip just before noon today and then said he wondered whether the Weather was going to cooperate for tonight's opening of the track's 52session meetinge

title: Four Mayoral Candidates. Opposed to Superagencies
description: Most of the city's nine superagencies  a trademark of the Lindsay administrationwould be dismantled under reorganization plans advocated by all four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: WINE TALK
description: Somewhere between the pass compose and the reflexive verbs, the students in Eugene Pascal DeFiore's French classes at the New School make themselves a huge salade NicoIse. With it, Mr. DeFiore insists they drink a ros wine from Provence.

title: Mrs. Byrne Is Wed To John P. Baldari
description: Mrs. Susan M. Byrne, daughter of Mrs. Burrell A. Parkhurst of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to John P. Baldari, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Baldari of Newton, N. J. Justice Arnold Guy Fraiman of the New York Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. Parkhurst, who is a financial research ,consultant.

title: ... City Council Primary
description: The newly expanded City Council has been such dismal failure over such a long period that voters may well be prompted to cast a ballot for any challenger against any incumbent in primary contests for Council seats June 4.

title: KEGAN SARKISIAN
description: Kegan Sarkisian, a research scientist who held patents in botany, died Tuesday at St. Michael's Hospital in Newark. He was 74 years old and lived in Englewood Cliffs, N. J.

title: Nixon Campaign Aide Says Ads Were Not Commitment
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)  Campaign advertisements saying that Rhode Island naval bases would remain open if President Nixon were reelected were not intended to be viewed as a commitment, an official of the Committee for the Reelection of the President says.

title: Lawyer Cleared in Charge Of Giving Heroin to Client
description: A Queens grand jury has exonerated a lawyer accused of passing heroin to his client in a courthouse detention cell.

title: SANDMAN SEES TAX AS THE MAIN ISSUE
description: TRENTON, May 25Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. told supporters in South Jersey today that the June Republican primary should be considered a referendum by the voters on the issue of a statewide income tax, which he opposes.

title: 2d Train Bearing Bombs Wrecked by Blast in West
description: BENSON, Ariz., May 25, (UPI) An ammunition train with a load of 2,600 quarterton bombs destined for Cambodia exploded in mushroom clouds and burned for hours near here last night.

title: Britain's Watergate
description: The resignation of two Government ministersboth prominent peersafter each admitted having had casual affairs with call girls has provided Britain with its spiciest sex scandals since the Profumo case of 1963. What cannot fail to impress Americans, however, is the striking contrast between Prime Minister Heath's handling of this embarrassing episode and President Nixon's tactics in the incomparably more serious Watergate affair.

title: Five in Watergate Plot Shifted to Danbury Jail
description: DANBURY, Conn., May 25 (AP)Five of the convicted Watergate conspirators have been transferred from the District of Columbia Jail to the Federal Correctional Institute at Danbury, officials said today.

title: Progress Reported As Talks Conclude On Money Reform
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Committee of 20 deputies negotiating world monetary reform concluded a weeklong session today with reports of progress but no specific agreements yet.

title: Radio
Bonn Aide Sees Arab Desire for Mideast Accord
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany said here today his tour of three Arab countries had convinced him that there exists a deep Arab desire for a peaceful solution to the Middle East conflict.

title: Books of The Times
description: SERPICO. By Peter Maas. 314 pages. Viking Press. $7.95.

title: METS DEFEATED BY DODGERS, 64
Bernard Yarrow. Dead at 73; Was Radio Free Europe Officer
description: Bernard Yarrow, retired senior vice president of Free Europe, Inc., which operates Radio Free Europe, and a former assistant district attorney here, died yesterday at his home, 112 East 74th Street. He also lived at Twin Brooks Farm, Lyme, Conn. He was 73 years old.

title: Candidates'Day
description: In his strongest attack yet on Controller Abraham D. Beame, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal charged yesterday flat Mr. Beame was involved in a conflict of interest because city funds were deposited in a Sank whose chairman is a large contributor to the Beanie campaign.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, May 25 (UPI)The dollar rose sharply European currency dealings today in apparent reaction news of the United States's trade surplus for April and the sharp rally on Wall Street yesterday. Simultaneously, gold fell heavily in most financial centers.

title: Assembly Approves a Bill Barring U.D.C. Projects
description: ALBANY, May 25  The As## restrictions in the measure, the corporation might be denied expanded bonding powers. sembly, ringing with charges of racism, approved a bill today that would allow towns and vil lages in the state to exclude lowincome and moderatein come housing projects sponsored by the State Urban Development Corporation.

title: 2 Held in 69 East Side Killing Of Son of a Florida Millionaire
description: The District Attorney's office in Manhattan announced the arrest yesterday of two men in the murder on the East Side four years ago of the son of Florida millionaire.

title: U.S. Aide Ends 3 Days of Saigon Talkes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 26  William H. Sullivan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Eastern and Pacific Affairs, left Saigon this morning after three days of talks with South Vietnamese Government officials on carrying out the ceasefire.

title: Nassau to Try 2 Devices For Driver Alcohol Tests
description: MINEOLA, L. L, May 25 A man in a station wagon pulled to the curb as a white Nassau County police car with lights flashing and siren blaring pulled up behind him this morning.

title: Memorial Day Proclaimed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 25 (AP)President Nixon issued today a Memorial Day proclamation calling for the nation to unite in prayer for permanent peace. And he ordered flags flown at halfstaff for Americans who died in Vietnam.

title: THREE ASTRONAUTS REACH SKYLAB, BUT FAIL TO DEPLOY POWER WING; THEN THEY ARE UNABLE TO REDOCK
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 25Three American astronauts rode an Apollo spacecraft into orbit today, rendezvoused with the crippled Skylab space station, failed to dislodge a jammed power wing, and then encountered missionthreatening problems in attempting to link up with the Skylab after having docked earlier.

title: Urban Decay Is Major Issue for Candidates in Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., May 24 Shortly after he was elected Mayor of Camden this month, Angelo J. Errichetti endorsed Brendan T. Byrne for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Byrne also has the endorsements of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City and Mayor Thomas Dunn of

title: Collision Sensor Devised for Autos
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A collision sensor for motor cars makes a decision 10 feet in front of the bumper and releases an airbag or other safety device. There is no waiting for the actual crash. Patent 3,735,398 was granted for the Barbi this week to Gerald F. Ross, manager of sensor systems at the Sperry Rand Research Center, Sudbury, Mass. Barbi is an acronym for Baseband Radar Bag Initiator.

title: 200 Cambodians Reported Missing In Attack on Post
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, May 25 (AP)  More than 200 Government soldiers have been reported missing after a Communist force overran their position on the east bank of the Mekong River 20 miles southeast of here.

title: CAMPORA BECOMES ARGENTINA'S CHIEF
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 25 Dr. Hector J. Campora, a loyal follower of former President Juan Domingo Perlin, was inaugurated today as the president of a popularly elected government, ending seven years of military rule in Argentina.

title: GRAIN DEALS SIZE HINTED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 25An official Soviet publication has hinted for the first time, perhaps inadvertently, at the magnitude of grain imports last year after a serious crop failure. The purchases, made at bargain prices, are believed to have insured an adequate sup4:ily of bread, a staple food in the Russian diet.

title: Theater: An Original ?!; Wit Spices Snippets by Westbeth Feminists
description: A nimbly pleasant little satirerevue with a succinct set of amusing fangsand a decided causehas the title of ?! (Whitzit mean? Dunno.) The material is by the Westbeth Playwrights Feminist Collective. Their engaging mouthpieces this time are a bright cast of six, the Joseph Jefferson Theater Company, cavorting on a small stage at 11 East 29th Street (parish house of the Little Church Around the Corner).

title: Wiretapper Gets Probation
description: HOUSTON, May 25 (UPI)W. J. Everett, 38 years old, a private investigator who pleaded guilty to helping wiretap the phones of four top aides to H. L. Hunt, the billionaire, was sentenced yesterday to three years on probation,

title: Pennsy W ill Defer. A Cut in Crew Size To Avert Walkout
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday that rather than risk a strike they had decided to defer their plans for unilaterally deciding the size of the railroad's train crews.

title: Communications Satellite Awards Hughes Contract
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation announced today that it had awarded a $40million contract to the Hughes Aircraft Company to build communications satellites for the Navy and maritime in dustry.

title: Milan Grenade Toll Now 2
description: MILAN, Italy, May 25 (AP)A policeman died today of injuries from a hand grenade thrown into a crowd in front of police headquarters here on May 17, when a woman was killed and 40 people were injured.

title: Pinned in Elevator Shaft, Boy Is, Seriously Injured
description: A 12yearold boy suffered multiple injuries yesterday when he fell in a shaft while accepting a dare of jumping from one elevator to another in a Bronx housing project.

title: Royal White House?
description: In The Twilight of the Presidency, George Reedy, former press secretary to the late President Johnson, wrote: The White House is a court.... This raises the greatest of all barriers to Presidential access to reality and raises a problem which will plague the White House so long as the President is a reigning monarch rather than an elected administrator. No nation of free men, Mr. Reedy warned, should permit itself to be governed from a hallowed shrine where the meanest lust for power can be sanctified.

title: Race for Jersey Governor Focuses on Urban Decay
description: CAMDEN, N. J., May 24Shortly after he was elected Mayor of Camden this month, Angela J. Errichetti endorsed Brendan T. Byrne for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Byrne also has the endorsements of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City and Mayor Thomas Dunn of Elizabeth.

title: Afghans Use U.S. Aid Project for Opium
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 24 Afghan farmers are harvest ing a bumper crop of , opium poppies on newly irrigated land that has been developed with foreign aid,

title: Badillo, vanden Heuvel Supported by The Post
description: The New York Post yesterday endorsed Representative Herman Badillo for Mayor and William J. vanden Heuvel for District Atorney in Manhattan.

title: Pacific Crossing Record Set on Maiden Voyage
description: LOS ANGELES, May 25 (UPI) The S.S. President Madison on her maiden voyage set a record for a Pacific crossing by ccargo ship, cutting 1 hour 31 minutes off the old record, the American President Lines said today.

title: Randolph C. Harrison Marries Mrs. Dorothy Quinn in Suburbs
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 25Mrs, Dorothy Thompson Quinn of Field Point Park, widow of Martin Quinn, who was a stock exchange specialist, was married here at noon today to Randolph C. Harrison, a retired banker, of 200 East 66th Street, New York. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the minister, the, Rev. George Pera.

title: Magruder Is Back on Job At Nixon Inaugural Croup
description: WASHINGTON, May 25?? Stuart Magruder went back on the payroll of the Nixon augural Committee this week at the same time that he was reported preparing to plead guilty and bear witness against other Nixon aides in the Watergate case.

title: Wiretapping Bill Amended
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 25 (AP) The State Senate amended wiretapping bill today to ban virtually all electronic eavesdropping in Maine.

title: Mayor of Haifa Dies
description: HAIFA,ISRAEL May 25 (UPI) Moshe Flieman, Mayor of Haifa for the last four years, died today of cancer. He was 68 years old. An electrical engineer by profession, Mr. Fileman served several prison terms in Soviet jails for illegal Zionist activity before emigrating in 1930 to the countrythat was then Palestine.

title: 5 COMMODITIES CLIMB THE LIMIT
Ruth Gallin Married to Dr. S. R. Spielman
description: Miss Ruth Iris Gallin was married here last evening to Dr. Scott R. Spielman, who graduated this month from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. The Rev. Dr. David Seligson of Central Synagogue performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gallin, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton M. Spielman, also of New York.

title: THREE ASTRONAUTS REACH SKYLAB, BUT FAIL TO DEPLOY POWER WING; THEY REDOCK AFTER DIFFICULTIES
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Saturday, May 26Three American astronauts rode an Apollo spacecraft to an orbital rendezvous yesterday with the crippled Skylab space station. They failed to dislodge a jammed solarpower wing but thenafter nine frustrating triesfinally achieved a hard dock with Skylab.

title: U.S. SUBMITS PLAN FOR RAILS IN EAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Following its late March recommendations to Congress for reorganizing the nation's Northeast railroads, the Department of Transportation sent legislation to Capitol Hill today asking for a private corporation to restructure the Northeastern rail lines.

title: Festival Ends With Concert for Brass
description: The Composers Theater fourth annual May Festival ended at the New School on Thursday night with a concert of music for brass instruments. Carl Ruggles's Angels, a work that is some 50 years old (though it does not sound it), was included in the program, but otherwise the pieces were either new or of relatively recent date.

title: U.S. Silver Stocks Decline
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (Reuters) Industry stocks of silver as of March 31 showed a further decline, dropping to 46 million ounces, according to a United States Bureau of Mines report on silver covering the first quarter of 1973. The lowerend March stock compared with holdings of 52.1 million ounces on Dec. 31, 1972, which the bureau revised downward from its preliminary previous estimate of 63.6 million.

title: Navy PacesI.C.4A Traction 21 Points
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 25John Hartnett of Villanova ran away with a title in the sixmile run today, but Navy muscle may have built an insurmountable lead for team honors in the 97th annual I.C.4A outdoor track and field championships.

title: Watergate And Tides Of History
description: LONDONIt is generally considered that the next two or three weeks will be critical in demonstrating whether President Nixon is able to pursue his main foreign policy objectives along the conceptual lines hitherto followed, or whether administrative chaos produced by the Watergate scandal may start to paralyze U.S. initiatives.

title: Roundup: Lee May Hits Two HomersNaturally
description: His Houston teammates marvel at the smooth easy way Lee May hits, and they had cause to do so last night as May's two home runs highlighted an 11hit attack and gave he Astros a 72 victory over the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

title: Friend of Nixon Is Identified as Backer In Purchase of Western White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The White House said today that the bulk of President Nixon's estate at San Clemente was controlled by an unnamed investment company formed by Robert H. Abplanalp, a multimillionaire businessman who is a close friend of the President.

title: HARRY MERWIN
description: Harry Merwin, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at University Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 16015 Powells Cove Boulevard, Beechhurst, Queens.

title: FifthGraders Help Whale to Learn Lessons at Coney Island Aquarium
description: Delighted grammarschool children got a chance to help teach a playful white whale and a frisky whitesided dolphin spectacular tricks at the aquarium at Coney Island yesterday.

title: Pilot in Search of New Frontier Paul Joseph Weitz
description: Comdr. Paul Joseph Weitz, like Comdr. Joseph P. Kerwin a space rookie, most closely matches the stereotyped image of the astronaut: blond, blueeyed, conventional, unemotional. And taciturn.

title: PELE AND SANTOS WIN
description: JERSEY CITY, May 25The Santos of BrazilLazio of Italy soccer game at Roosevelt Stadium tonight had all the characteristics of a match in Naples or Sao Paulo. There was scoring by the Brazilians and no scoring by the Italians. There were interruptions because of the fans, who threw beer cans, bottles and even chairs onto the field And of course, there was Pele, who displayed his usual tricks, on and off the geld.

title: Benjamin Thaw, Lawyer, United CigarWhelan Aide
description: Benjamin S. Thaw, a lawyer and former executive vice president of the United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation, died Thursdat of a heart ailment in White Plains Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 76 Vine Road, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Bridge: Italian Team in World Play Coasts to the Championship
description: GUARUJA, Brazil, May 25  Italy coasted to victory in tie world team championship here today against the Aces. The Italian team, a slightly modified version of the Blue Team that won 13 world titles, rested comfortably on a cushion of points gained during the first quarter of the match yesterday.

title: Weis Assets Are Tied Up By Court Till Wednesday
description: A Federal judge yesterday signed an order that effectively tied up assets at Weis Securities, Inc., until next Wednesday morning. The brokerage house was suspended by all stock exchanges on Thursday.

title: JOHN LONGUA
description: John Longua, who retired in 1971 as a partner in the New York Urban Servicing Company, a realestate financing organization at 60 East 42D Street, died Thursday at his home in Woodbury, L.I. His age was 68.

title: NICKLAUS, AT 133, 4 STROKES AHEAD
SATURDAY, mar zo, 1973
description: FIUMICINO, Italy, Saturday, May 26 (Reuters)A number of officers and enlisted men aboard a Greek Navy destroyer mutinied here last night and have requested political asylum from the Italian Government, port authorities said today.

title: Abplanalp, Nixon Friend, A Millionaire Industrialist
description: WASHINGTON, May 25Robert H. Abplanalp, identified as the financial backer in the purchase of the Western White House, is President Nixon's other millionaire friend, shyer and not so wellknown as Charles Rebozo, but at least as wealthy.

title: Nassau Parks Stiffen Curbs on Outsiders
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I, May 25When outsider from those alien territories like Queens or Brooklyn orgasp Manhattan try to use Nassau County's system of parks tomorrow, they will find it slightly tougher than in previous years.

title: BURNS WINS, 2 AND 1, IN FRENCH AMATEUR
description: PARIS, May 25 (AP)George Burns 3d, New York Metropolitan amateur golf champion, posted a 2and1 victory over J. Sousa E. Melo of Portugal today and advance into the quarterfinals of the French amateur golf tournament.

title: Msgr. William J. Shannon, Former Radio Singer, 62
description: SYRACUSE, May 25 (AP)Msgr. William J. Shannon, onetime radio singer who became vice rector and administrator of the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception here, died today in CrouseItving Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: GRAIN DEAL'S SIZE HINTED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 25An official Soviet publication has hinted for the first time, perhaps inadvertently, at the magnitude of grain imports last year after a serious crop failure. The purchases, made at bargain prices, are believed to have insured an adequate supply of bread, a staple food in the Russian diet.

title: Art: From Within, Prisoners Show
description: From Within, is the very apt title for an exhibition of paintings and mixedmedia works by the inmates of the Auburn Correctional Facility, a maximumsecurity prison. They are now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle. Despite the old adage that stone walls do not a prison make nor iron bars a cage, it seems to be the case that being penned up  whether physically or emotionally  does create a certain subjective intensity in one's emotional life. It is very much from within that the successes in this exhibition of 53 works by 21 prisderive.

title: 12 SAILORS SHIFTED IN NIXON YACHT UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Twelve sailors in the unit that maintains President Nixon's yacht, the Sequoia, have been transferred after some of them were discovered to be smoking marijuana, the Navy reported today.

title: The Kin of Missing Servicemen Push for Action on Their Status
description: Relatives and friends of some of the 1,359 American service. men listed as missing in action in Southeast Asia urged local congressmen yesterday to see to it that both the United States and North Vietnam made greater efforts to resolve the status of the men.

title: Toys and Disadvantaged Children: A Project to Spur I.Q. Growth
description: FREEPORT, L I.  The three are sitting on a couch: a boy about 3 years old between his mother and a volunteer woman worker. The boy is holding a book on his lap.

title: ALBANY EXPECTS SPECIAL SESSION ON PENSION ISSUE
description: ALBANY, May 25  A special session of the Legislature is expected to be called in July to deal with reforming the vast array of Public pension plans in the state.

title: Sweet Jesus, Preacher Man Opens
Plastic Bubble, New Dimension in U. S. Education.
description: COLUMBIA, Md., May 23 A strikingly mixed group of longhaired young people and generally welltrimmed older folk got together here this week to celebrate and promote the emergence, as an educational architecture form, of their common love the bubble.

title: The Dance: A New Ballet
Plan for City Sports Authority Backed in HomeRule Message,
description: The City Council yesterday rushed through passage of a homerule message requesting the Legislature to create a New York City sports authority. The action was taken over the cries of some Council members that it was a windfall and giveway, and that the city is being taken for a sleigh ride.

title: Cook Quoted as Saying He Quit S.E.C. in Fear of Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)G.Bradford Cook says that he quit as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission after he told the WhiteHouse he feared impeachment proceedings, The Washington StarNews reported today.

title: Amex and OTC Lists Post 2d Consecutive Gain
B.F. Will. Sell Part Of ItalianHoldings For $20 Million
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., announced in London yesterday that it was selling the major part of its operations in Italy to the Oil Chemicals and Transport Finance Corporation, S.A., an Italian company.

title: Miss Bennett Has Nuptials
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 25 Miss Geraldine Ann Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Donald Bennett, and John Paul Miert, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Miert of Greenwich, were married here this evening by the Rev. Edward Karl in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church. A reception was given at the Arnold Bernhard Fine Arts Center at the University of Bridgeport, of which Mrs. Miert is a trustee.

title: Peking Aide Off to U.S.
description: TOKYO, May 25 (AP) Huang Chen, head of China's new liaison office in the United States, left Peking today to take up his post, Hsinhua, the Chinese Government press agency, reported. The head of the United States liaison office in Peking, David K. E. Bruce, who arrived there on May 14, was at the airport to see Mr. Chen Hsinhua said.

title: Black Unionists Form Coalition To Act Within Labor Movement
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A new organization of black labor unionists opened its founding convention here today with the stated purpose of strengthening the influence of black workers in the labor movement.

title: Aide Says Lindsay Is Weighing 76 Senate Bid
description: Thomas B. Morgan, Mayor Lindsay's press secretary, said yesterday that the Mayor was thinking of running in 1976 for the United States Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, but the report was denied by the Mayor.

title: WALTER M. WEISBERG
description: Walter M. Weisberg, a founder of the Iranian Chamber of Commerce of New York and its counsel for 27 years, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 682 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Bonnie Cashin may be as much a national monument to the fashion industry in this country as Chanel was Paris, but she's relaxed about it.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In their travels, all the tennis pros look at the tournament draw each week, but Stan Smith sees beyond it.

title: DR. ALFRED LANGMANN
description: KEENE, N. Y., May 25  Dr. Alfred G. Langmann, a retired Manhattan pediatrician who was an associate professor of pediatrics at Columbia University, died yesterday in Keene Valley Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Baptists Name President
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 25 (AP) Dr. Peter H. Armacost, a layman, was chosen without opposition today to be president of the American Baptist Churches in the U. S. A.

title: Cox and Richardson Given Oaths in Contrasting Rites
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Archibald Cox took the oath of office as special prosecutor in the Watergate case today in a setting that seemed far removed from the men and policies of the Nixon Administration.

title: G. M. Expects NearRecord 74 Sales
description: DETROIT, May 25  While management exuded optimism on the continuing of nearrecord automobile sales next year, many shareholders at the 65th annual meeting of the General Motors Corporation today asked how the concern was dealing with current issues.

title: ANN KLEIN BRAVES COMMUTER CRUSH
description: NEWARK, May 25  Aim Klein, New Jersey's lone woman candidate for governor, took on two stampedes yesterday  morning and evening throngs of thousands of commuters  and was as calm as Annie Oakley in choosing her targets.

title: Girl Says Boy, 9, Loaded Gun In Classroom Before Shooting
description: An 8yearold girl who was in a Bronx schoolroom when 9yearold boy shot a classmate in the neck with a pistol has told police that she saw the boy load the gun with two bullets before firing, according to a police report of the shooting.

title: Thirsting for the Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTONThe United States was once a leading oil exporter. This year we will import about 5 million barrels a day, at a dollar outflow of more than $6 billion. By 1980 we will be importing about 11.6 million barrels a day, if we are still without North Slope Alaska oil, at a dollar outflow of about $16 billion a year. We can't avoid increasing oil imports for the next ten to fifteen years; but we can reduce our imports by increasing our domestic supply of oil.

title: Columbia Biologists Determine Components of a Nucleic Acid
description: Columbia University molecular biologists have determined the sequence of chemical building blocks in a nucleic acid capable of reproducing it self within a test tube, rather than in a living cell.

title: 149 YACHTS START BLOCK ISLAND SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 25 The Storm Trysail Club's love affair with Block Island got going today with 149 yachts in eight classes setting forth on the 28th annual round trip.

title: CONVENTION HALL GAINS ON FUNDS
description: The Board of Estimate's approval late Thursday night of plans to build a convention and exhibition center on the West Side made it likely, according to city officials and legislators, that the board and the City Council would vote the funds required for the center, which is expected to cost about $200million.

title: 2 on Senate Panel Now Back Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The unanimity of the SenatE Appropriations Committee or cutting off funds for bombing it. Cambodia has crumbled bit.

title: Libya's Leader:A Bedouin Simplicity, a Boyish Charm
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, May 17Here in the Libyan capital, the foreigners talk about Col. Muammar elQaddafi almost all the time; Colonal Qaddafi talks about the foreigners; the Libyans talk about the Egyptians and the Egyptians about the Libyans. That adds up to Something less than mutual admira tion societies, alof though, on balance, Colonel Qad dafi, the head of the Libyan military regime, seems to come out best. In the flesh and watched up close, he is a much more attractive figure than the image he conveys his formal

title: Notes on People
description: L. Patrick Gray 3d, the former acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a figure in the Watergate affair, is expected to return to private law practice in New London, Conn. Mr. Gray resigned from the F.B.I. on April 27 after the Senate had delayed confirming his appointment as the ageney's permanent director and after it was disclosed that he had destroyed papers related to the Watergate scandal. In New London, Louis C. Wool, a partner in the film of Suisman, Shapiro, Wool & Brennan, said Mr. Gray would rejoin the firm as a ,partner. It could be next: week, said Mr. Wool. It could be the week after he is going to elect his own Cane. Mr. Gray left the firm in December, 1970, to become an assistant attorney general in Washington. He has a, home in Stonington, Conn.

title: Four Mayoral Candidates Are Foes of Superagencies
description: The city's nine superagencies a trademark of the Lindsay administrationwould be dismantled under reorganization plans advocated by all four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Morning traffic on the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted again yesterday when the lead cars of two eastbound trains sideswiped each other as they left the Jamaica station in Queens, causing some thirdrail damage. No injuries were reported, but the mishap delayed other trains going through Jamaica. It was the second accident involving a L.I.R.R. train this week. Last Monday, a train derailed in Woodside, Queens, resulting in injuries to 38 passengers.

title: Polio: A Cure for the New Controversy
description: SAN DIEGOThis is the twentieth anniversary of the announcement of the polio vaccine. A strange and paradoxical situation exists now in the United States with respect to immunization. Although the incidence of the disease has been sharply reduced, nevertheless cases continue to occur. The reasons for this are clear. So is the remedy. Why, then, do the authorities who are aware of the problem seem to be looking the other way?

title: Group Bids Pilots Refuse To Bomb in Cambodia
description: Clergy and Laity Concerned, a religious peace group, has asked military chaplains to urge American pilots and crew members involved in the bombing of Cambodia to leave the Air Force, resist, or disobey orders rather than continue to participate in the bombing, which it called an offense against both God and man.

title: PENDER, WITH 0:05.8, TIES WORLD 60 MARK
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 25 (AP)Mel Render tied the world record in the 60yard dash with a time of 5.8 seconds tonight at an International Track Association meet.

title: SCARECROW SHARES CANNES FILM PRIZE
description: CANNES, France, May 25 (AP)An American production, Scarecrow, and a British film, The Hireling, were named today cowinners of the grand prize of the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Afghans Use U.S Aid Project for Opium
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 24 Afghan farmers are harvesting a bumper crop of opium poppies on newly irrigated land that has been developed with foreign aid.

title: Police Cars Recalled
description: DETROIT, May 25 (Reuters) The American Motors Corporation said today that it, was recalling 1,624 cars, mainly police vehicles, equipped with in incorrect air cleaner cover.

title: CLASSACTION RULING SENT TO HIGH COURT
description: A landmark decision of a threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here was referred for reconsideration yesterday to the United States Supreme Court after the full eightmember Court of Appeals refused by a vote of five to three to hear the case on appeal.

title: Commander of Skylab Crew Charles Conrad Jr.
description: On Nov. 19, 1969, two Apollo 12 crewmen were hurtling down toward the surface of the moon, moments away from making the second lunar landing in history. A tense time, guaranteed to turn the astronauts into super serious semi automatons. Right? Wrong. Not whenthe commander ofMen the mission is Charles Conrad in the Jr. He was like a News 5yearold boy at his first amusement park, oohing and aahing at the sights, chattering constantly, and  finally unable to contain his exhilarationgiggling and chorting with such highpitched abandon that he had earthbound listeners laughing to themselves.

title: Hearing in Rye on Bridge Draws Wide Cross Section
description: RYE, N.Y., May 25A woman wearing a Ban the Bridge button pushed her way, out of a smoky meeting room in the, Ryeridge Shopping plaza here last night, ready to go home. It was after 11 o'clock and a heated debate continued, inside.

title: The Screen
Navy Paces I.C.4A Track on 21 Points
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 25John Hartnett of Villanova ran away with a title in the sixmile run today, but Navy muscle may have built an insurmountable lead for team honors in the 97th annual I.C.4A outdoor track and field championships.

title: CarTheft Ring Termed Broken by Queens Raid
description: A police raid on a warehouse in Maspeth, Queens, yesterday was said to have smashed a $2millionayear ring of car thieves who stole to order, cut up the vehicles and sold the parts to auto body shops.

title: Iceland. Apologizes to Britain For Youths Attack on Embassy
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 25 (Reuters)A Foreign Ministry official visited the British Embassy here today to apologize for the windowsmashing attack staged by Icelandic youths last night in protest against Britain's refusal to recognize Iceland's 50mile fishing limits.

title: Hockey Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: PHILADELPHIAAcquired Bruce Cowick, left wing from the San Diego Gulls of the Western League for Torn Trevelyan and Jim Stanfield, centers, and Bo Hurlbutleft wing.

title: BLANCHE DOW, LED UNIVERSITY WOMEN,
description: NORTH KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 25 (AP)Dr, Blanche Hinman Dow, former president of the American Association of University Women, died yesterday. She was 80 years old.

title: Two File a Claim To Mine for Gold In Passaic County
description: PATERSON, May 25Fred Ferber, the West Milford conservationist, and a Hackettstown man have filed joint claims with the office of Governor Cahill to mine for gold and silver in an 11,000acre section in Passaic County.

title: City Council President...
description: The Council of the City of New York is a local legislative body that does not legislate, an investigative unit that does not investigate, a potentially valuable public forum that remains shuttered and silent for too much of the time and, when in session, too sparsely populated with councilmen. In sum, the City Council is a disappointing failure. Its inability to reapportion itself has forced the courts to allow the pending election to stand, but to order another within a year.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey; Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
description: ACheshire Cat, 52 Forest Avenue, Paramus (north of Route 4); (201) 8459480.

title: SportsCard Buffs Gathering for a Trip to Nostalgia
description: The dealer casually opened another suitcase, exposing thick stacks of elasticbound sports cards, some dating to 1890.

title: ALBANY EXPECTS SPECIAL SESSION ON PENSION ISSUE
description: ALBANY, Saturday, May 26 A special session of the Legislature is expected to be called in July to deal with reforming the vast array of public pension plans in the state.

title: Italian Inflation Fierce, and the Hedges Ingenious
description: ROME, May 25The wife of is Roman doctor who went to a downtown shop this week to have her mink stored for the summer was kept waiting for nearly two hours because all hands were busy with customers eager to buy expensive fur coats as an inflation hedge.

title: MADAM AUCTIONS PRIZED ANTIQUES
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., May 25 (AP)It's killing me, but what can you do, said Bowling Green's, and maybe the South's, best known madam as the rap of the auctioneer's gavel marked the sale of about 300 of her prized antiques.

title: Thousqpds Flee ,South From Parched Sahara Fringe
description: KANO, Nigeria, May 20 There is only death in the north, a refugee from drought. stricken Mali said.

title: David Eisenhower to Speak
description: ABILENE, Kan., May 25 (AP) David Eisenhower, grandson of the late President, will speak Monday at Memorial Day services on the grounds of the Eisenhower Center here.

title: DrugJudgeship Proposal Clears Senate, 36 to 22
description: ALBANY, Saturday, May 26By a vote of 36 to 22, the Republican majority early today pushed through the State Senate Governor Rockefeller's proposal to create 100 new judges to handle the increase in narcotics cases that is expected to result from the more stringent penalties for drug pushers passed earlier this month.

title: Equity Financing
description: First New England Realty Trust yesterday filed with Securities and Exchange Commission an initial offering of 300,000 sharesiof beneficial interest and $3million principal amount of 7 per cent convertible debentures due 1990 for sale through the Southeastern Securities Corporation. The securities will be offered in units consisting of 100 shares of beneficial interest and $1,000 prin'cipal amount of the debentures. Investment adviser would be First New England Realty Advisors, Inc., jointly owned by Berkshire Bancorp. and Phoenix Management Inc.

title: GEORGE A. J. HECK
description: EAST HARDFORD, Conn., May 25 (AP)George A. J. Heck, a former conductor of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, died Wednesday. He was 67 years old.

title: DR. MAX S. ROHDE
description: Dr. Max Spencer Rohde, urological surgeon and former hospital director, died May 16 at his home, 2 Horatio Street. He was 88 years old.

title: $50aTicket Party Planned for Mackell
description: A $50aperson retirement cocktail party has been arranged for Thomas J. Mackell, the Queens District Attorney who quit after he was indicted on charges of covering up a criminal investigation and after Governor Rockefeller said he would remove him from office.

title: Pact Would Let U.S. Check Swiss Banks in Tax Cases
description: BERNE, May 25The United States and Switzerland today signed a treaty designed to help American investigators track down members of organized crime by uncovering funds hidden in hitherto secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: Safety Group Asks F.T.C. to Prohibit Deception by STP
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)  The Center for Auto Safety asked the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to ban what the center called deceptive claims for STP an oil additive.

title: Police Cars Recalled
description: DETROIT, May 25 (Reuters) The American Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 1,624 cars, mainly police vehicles, equipped with an incorrect air cleaner cover.

title: Aide Says Lindsay Is Weighing Senate Bid, but Mayor Denies It
description: Thomas B. Morgan, Mayor Lindsay's press secretary, said yesterday that the Mayor was thinking of running in 1976 for the United States Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, but the report was denied by the Mayor.

title: People and Business
description: The horrendous Watergate developments now unfolding are a reminder that the need for integrity has never been greater, Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, said yesterday.

title: Silver SlippersEven for Daytime
description: If you spot a pair of silver slippers on Fifth Avenue at noon, they're probably not being worn by a straggler from a party the night before. More likely they come from the wardrobe of a fashionaware woman who's caught on to the fact that gleaming shoes of metallic leathersuch as gold, silver and luminous colors  are now designed to be worn in broad daylight.

title: State Waging a Campaign Against Invasion of Insects
description: TRENTON, May 23 (UPI) Heavy losses are expected in the state's attempt to counter a fourpronged invasion of eastern tent caterpillars, leaf rollers, cankerworms and gypsy moths, authorities said today.

title: Candidates Day
description: In his strongest attack yet on Controller Abraham D. Beame, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal charged yesterday that Mr. Beame was involved in a conflict of interest because city funds were deposited in a bank whose chaiman is a large contributor to the Beame campaign.

title: Ford's Base Price For Thunderbirds To Increase 15.4%
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of its 1973 Thunderbird models by 15.4 per cent, or $860, by standardizing a number of previously optional features. Several chemical price increases were also announced yesterday. The General Electric Company, on the other hand, said it would cut the price of its tiny solid state lamps by an average of (about 17 per cent. The new base price for the Thunderbird raises the suggested retail cost of the car to $6,437 from $5,577.

title: Man Slain Resisting Mugging By 3 TeenAged Girls and Man
description: A 37yearold man was stabbed to death late Thursday night when he apparently resisted an attempted mugging by three teenaged girls and a male accomplice on 52d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, the police reported yesterday.

title: Czechs Make Copper Find
description: PRAGUE (AP)Czechoslovak geologists have found.extensive copper deposits in northern Mongolia, the news agency CTK reported, quoting a Government official.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In their travels, all the tennis pros look at the tournament draw each week, but Stan Smith sees beyond it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Morning trafffic on the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted again yesterday When the lead cars of two eastbound trains sideswiped each other as they left the Jamaica station in Queens, causing some thirdrail damage. No injuries were reported, but the mishap delayed other trains going through Jamaica.

title: PHILLIPS OIL HELD COERCING LESSEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused the Phillips Petroleum Company today of stifling competition by intimidating and coercing its 3,600 gasoline station lessees across the country into buying Phillips products.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A toxological study of two women found hanged Their Montclair home showed trace amounts of drugs in their systems but so little as to be in no way contributory to the cause of death. The report, by Dr. Richard J. Coumbis of the State Medical Examiner's office, said that the drugs found were Librium, a tranquilizer, and Quaalude, a type of sleeping pill.

title: COSTA RICAN SEEKS U.S. PAPERS ON VESCO
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 25 (UPI)  Former President Otilio Ulate said today that he had asked President Nixon for all available United States documentation that might invorve Costa Rica in the Watergate scandal as a result of business dealings in this country by Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier.

title: KLEIN IS EXPECTED TO QUIT POST SOON
description: SAN DIEGO, May 25The last survivor of President Nixon's original Presidential campaign teama political associate for more than 25 years is expected to join the exodus of top Administration officials soon.

title: G.E.Workers Upstate Are Discontented With WorkItself
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 25Workers at the General Electric Company's Upstate New York plants are brimming with discontent as their old wage contract expires.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers in 2 Days, 19 Innings
FOOD BASKET COST ROSE 1.6% IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The retail cost of a market basket of foods produced in the United States continued to climb in April, moving 1.6 per cent above prices in March and 14.37 per cent above the figure a year ago, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Trailer Train to Add Cars
description: The Trailer Train Company, a carleasing concern in Chicago owned by 32 major railroads, announced yesterday a program for acquisition of 2,249 new railroad flat cars that will cost about $50million. Orders for the cars, it was said, have been placed with PullmanStandard, a division of Pullman, Inc., American Car & Foundry, a division of ACF Industries, and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: Screen: Music of the 50's;Let Good Times Roll Is Rock Revival
Networks to Rotate Watergate Hearings
