description: The three television networks agreed yesterday that when the Senate Select Watergate Committee hearings resumed June 5, they would broadcast each day's session on a rotating basis.

title: 22 INDICTED HERE IN GAMBLING CASE
Board to Check Charges on Jet Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that it would look into allegations by a Chicago legal researcher that a United Air Lines jetliner that crashed Dec. 8 was sabotaged as part of the Watergate case coverup.

title: Rain Forecasts Fail To Dampen Spirits For 3Day Weekend
description: Despite occasional showers and forecaSts of more to come, tens of thousands of New Yorkers joined the Memorial Day weekend exodus from the city in the late afternoon and evening yesterday, bound for beaches, resorts and country homes.

title: Nevada Requires Approval For Gambling Investors
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 25 (UPI)Corporations seeking to acquire interests in Nevada gambling resorts must first get approval from the Nevada Gaming Commission, according to new regulation adopted yesterday.

title: Boy Seizes Another And,in Phone Booth, Asks $150 Ransom
description: A 15yearold boy kidnapped a 14yearold boy yesterday and held him briefly for ransom in a telephone booth at Seveth Avenue and 56th Street, the police reported.

title: Alpine and Demarest To Weigh Next Step
description: DEMAREST, May 25The Mayors and Councils of this borough and of neighboring Alpine will sit down with their attorneys in separate caucuses next week to decide what to do about the proposed shift of 14, homes from one town to the other.

title: SEC. IN WARNING ON INSIDER DATA
People in Sports: Clarke's Feats Honored
description: Bobby Clarke of the Philadelphia Flyers, a diabetic, was named yesterday as the winner of the Hart Trophy, given annually to the National Hockey League player judged the most valuable to his team. The 23yearold center received 158 votes in a poll conducted among members of the Professional Hockey Writers Association. Phil Esposito of Boston was second with 96 votes and Bobby Orr of Boston third with 63. Orr had won the Hart Trophy the previous three years.

title: New Killing in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Way 25 (AP)  A man was found dead on the outskirts of Belfast tonight, apparently the victim of one of Northern Ireland's assassination squads the police said the man, 30 of 35 years old, had been badly beaten and shot through the chest. His death raised Northern Ireland's known death toll in nearly four years of sectarian fighting to 804.

title: Akron Paper Names Editor
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 25 (UPI) Mark Ethridge Jr. has been appointed editor and vice president of The Akron Beacon Journal, it was announced today by John S. Knight, president and editorial chairman of Knight Newspapers, Mr. Ethridge, years old, who had been editor of The Detroit Free Press, replaces Perry Morgan, 45, who is resigning to become executive editor of The Virginian Pilot and Ledger of ??.

title: Discovering Colombia's Gem of the Ocean
description: SAN ANDRES is eight miles long and wo miles wide. When you first see it from the air it looks like a flaw in an emerald,. embedded as it is in the luminescent light green of reef waters. Then the mass of palm fronds appears, topping the island with a virtually solid class of green undulating in the trade winds so that for a moment you are concerned about how they are going to get an airplane in there. Just in time the land strip bends into view as you bank in from the sea and head northeast into the wind.

title: GOVERNOR'S BILL FOR NEW JUDGES PASSES INALBANY
description: ALBANY, May 26Governor Rockefeller's bill authorizing up to 100 new narcotic judges received final approval in the Assembly tonight over Democratic objections that it was the most unseemly packing of the judiciary this country has ever known.

title: Good guy in blue, bishop in mufti, few in the South, beautiful people in trouble
description: Patrick O'Malleyson, grandson, nephew of New York police officers is in Vietnam talking to his black buddy and fellow medic, Kenyon, about life and sex and race, grasping for a philosophy as desperate men always do. Kenyon gives Patrick a test for the measure of a man: Why just that he keeps trying to find out things, I guess. That he don't go shutting no doors he never has even tried to open.

title: CAROUIJA'S AIDES WARNED ON BIAS
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., May 26Gov. John C. West bluntly warned state agency and department heads this week that if they did not cooperate with the South Carolina Human Affairs Conunission to end discrimination, their practices on minority hiring would be turned over to the Federal Government for possible action.

title: Movies
description: WE see John Schlesinger's Sunday Bloody Sunday and we know it is a good film, Its miseries are clear, inescapable, familiar. We see it a second and third time and it holds up. Still, there is a revealing flaw. In a world of motives, the motiveless young man, who is loved by both a divorcee and a middleaged bachelor, seems a mere construction. He is too artificially placed in the center as a device allowing the others to react. He is given a veneer of ambition, but this doesn't sufficiently account for his lack of commitment. We ask, why do these people do these things? And we expect an answer.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: BREAKFAST OF CHAMPIONS, by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. (Delacorte, $7.95.) Being the life and total collapse of Dwayne Hoover, whose wife ended it all by ingurgitating Drano and who goes berserk after reading a novel according him free willa comedy of despair.

title: Miss Greta J. Melford Plans Marriage
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N. Y., May 26The engagement of Miss Greta Jean Melford to Wilfred Reed Kindermann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred J. Kindermann of Chatham, N.J., has been announcd by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Melford.

title: A. Philip Randolph
description: On March 22, 1948, A. Philip Randolph dropped a bombshell. The mood among Negroes of this country, he told President Harry Truman, is that they will never bear arms again until all forms of bias and discrimination are abolished. Furthermore, he promised the Senate Armed Services Committee, he would encourage civil disobedience among black men in the event of selective service legislation that did not include desegregation of the armed forces. At the height of cold war hysteria, Congress was suddenly compelled to discuss universal military training in Randolph's terms, scurrying to find black witnesses who would deny him. A. Philip Randolph, throughout his career, has had a genius for getting the sharpest focus on the issues of his choosing. Typically, this early threat of civil disobedience foreshadowed, by 15 years, tactics which were to explode among us with telling force.

title: University of Connecticut Agrees To Stop Opening Outgoing Mail
description: STORRS, Conn., May 26The University of Connecticut agreed today to stop opening and examining mail sent out through the university mail room by faculty members which it had done in an effort to stop them from using the service for personal business.

title: CANNES VOTE CAST FOR ACTORS, LOVE
description: CANNES, France, May 26One of the winners at this year's Cannes Film Festival was titled, Film of Love and Anarchy.

title: Housewife With a Flair for Politics
description: At a recent political fundraising party, Gloria Steinem, the women's lib leader, told her audience: You've all got to give money and tell your friends to give. It'll be worth it to see the expression on Mr. Steingut's face when Helen wins.

title: News Summary and Index
Twins to Mrs. Silverman
description: Twin sons were born to State Democratic Assemblyman Leonard Silverman and Mrs. Silverman of Brooklyn on May 11 in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Silverman is the former Miss Sandra Stanger.

title: White Sox Sell Morales
description: CHICAGO, May 26 (AP)The Chicago White Sox sold an infielder, Rich Morales, to the San Diego Padres today and recalled an outfielder, Bill Sharp, their No. 2 draft choice in 1971, from Iowa. Sharp, who was batting 290 in the minors, was called after Ken Henderson injured his right knee last night.

title: Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The rise in consumer prices in April, reported last week as seventenths of 1 per cent, would in normal times be seen as distinctly bad news. But in today's inflationary climate, it was possible to be slightly heartened by the figure because it showed a smaller increase  and particularly a smaller rise in food prices  than in preceding months.

title: High Drama in a Space Rescue
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla.Three astronauts on an emergency repair mission lifted off from Cape Kennedy Friday morning in a spacecraft crammed with special tools and newlydesigned sunshades. Their goal: to salvage the crippled Skylab space station, in orbit 275 miles above the earth, and proceed with their original schedule of medical and scientific experiments.

title: Ranchers Oppose U.S.TakeOverPlan For Idaho Canyon
description: LEWISTON, Idaho, May 26The few patches of private land in Idaho's scenic Hell's Canyonthe deepest gorge in the continental United Statesmay soon become public property.

title: Elaine Tate Bride Of S. E. jespersen
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 26Miss Elaine A. Tate and Stephen Eric Jespersen were married here this afternoon. The Rev. T. C. Swackhamer performed the ceremony in the First United Methodist Church.

title: Mrs. Lytle Hull: At 80, She's the Epitome of the Grande Dame
description: Mrs. Lytle Hull sat qiiietly in her luxtarious Fifth Avenue duplex.

title: Paris Air Show Focuses On U.S.European Rivalry
description: PARIS, May 26 As the world's biggest international air show opened here this week, the talk in the display halls and in the private lounges of the 600odd exhibitors was of the choice faced by Europeans between more integration among themselves or more collaboration with the United States.

title: Toll Roads: Surprising Growth
Coach Who Split Hairs Falls Out
description: HOUSTON, May 26 (AP)A junior high school football coach who wrote an article critical of longhaired athletes resigned his job before the May publication of the story, school officials said yesterday.

title: For 3,300 Inmates,
description: TRENTONA total of 3; 300 of the more than 6,000 inmates within the state prison system are enrolled in schools that make up one of the state's newest school districts.

title: Ousted Welfare Official Denies Bias in Perot Bid
description: ALBANY, May 26  A former consultant in a controversial competition for a computer contract who was ousted by state welfare officials earlier this year has denied that he had any general bias against the proposal of one of the competitors, H. Ross Perot.

title: 3,000 Cyclists Begin a Marathon Of 24 Hours Inside Central Park
description: Nearly 3,000 cyclists, ranging from kindergarten pupils to veterans of the sixday races of the nineteentwenties, set off hopefully yesterday on the city's second annual 24hour bike marathon in Central Park.

title: A Solutionto Falling Reading Scores Continues to Elude BigCity Schools
description: The reading scores of innercity schoolchildren sink to new lows each year, and educators and others here and., inmost. big cities have been unable to find ways to reverse the trend.

title: Gunman Surrenders in Brooklyn After Holding an Infant Hostage
description: A 35yearold gunman who had been shot in the head during a gun battle with the police, laid down his two weapons and surrendered last night after holding a pistol to the head ??? eightmonthold baby for almost an hour while demanding his freedom in return for the child's life.

title: School of the Air In Newark Is 25
description: NEWARK  Station WBGO, the Newark Board of Education's School of the Air, is celebrating its 25th anniversary. Special programs through the year culminated in a birthday broadcast last week in which city and school officials participated.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Says Lindsay Intervened in 72 Race
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Representative Shirley Chisholm alleges in a newly published book that Mayor Lindsay tried to persuade her not to enter the Florida Presidential primary and, that his closest aides blamed her for destroying his own candidacy.

title: Says He Should Not Noll Nixon and Army Posts
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Senator Stuart Symington, as acting chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has questioned President Nixon's legal authority to make Gen Alexander M. Haig Jr. the nevi chief of staff, of the White House while the general still serves as Army Vice Chief of Staff.

title: Cuban Rifles Take Aim At U. S. Sportfishermen
description: With about 40 Cuban soldiers armed with automatic weapons running out from behind trees and onto the beach at Cape San Antonio recently, Herbert R. Phillips of Pompano Beach, Fla., the leader of a fleet of 15 sportfishing yachts anchored off Cuba, honked his horn.

title: BERKELEY EFFORT FOR RECALL GAINS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 26When the effort to recall a black City Councilman, D'Army Bailey, began here more than a year ago, it was given virtually no chance of succeeding. Not even Mr. Bailey took the challenge seriously.

title: Some Crocodilians
description: How doth the little crocodile/Improve his shining tale? wondered Alice (if we may be allowed a slight paraphrase). When the tale is the one told in these three books, the crocodile or alligator (crocodilian, collectively) might well wish to make extensive improvements in one case but in two others might have reason to grin cheerfully and neatly spread his claws, as described later in the verse.

title: Flood Experts Call for Curbs on Development in LowLying Areas
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Faced with the knowledge that levees in the Mississippi Valley succumbed to spring overflow and that dams in the midAtlantic states are still showing cracks and rips from last summer's tropical storm Agnes, new forces have joined conservationists in the running debate over the nation's multibilliondollar flood control program.

title: The Indianapolis 500: Festival of Speed and Color
description: With more than $1million in prizes and attendance in the 300,000 range, the Indianapolis 500 is the biggest sports event in America. The 57th running of the race tomorrow at the 64yearold Indianapolis Motor Speedway promises to be the fastest ever. Qualifying speeds of this year's 33car field average a record of 192.329 miles an hour.

title: This side of Paradise
description: Prospering on a diet of academic leftovers, the community collegethe stepchild of American higher educationhas grown into a strapping, obstreperous adolescent that now, if only by virtue of size, commands the attention that it has frequently been denied in years past. The community, or twoyear, college is a peculiarly American institution bastardized from the tradition of higher learning transplanted into New England's soil from Europe three centuries ago. Students attend the community college because of its proximity to their homes, the low cost, the chance to take technical and vocational courses that are not available in the typical fouryear academic program, the greater opportunity for individual counseling and remedial studies andmore than anything elsebecause the community college is not particular about whom it accepts. Though its students are of varying abilities, it is, especially in the urban setting, the last refuge of the educational downandouter, the haven of the scholastic ne'erdowell.

title: Pupil Performance
description: STOCKHOLM  The home is more important than the school to a child's overall achievement. Mass education does not lower academic standards for gifted students, as is widely held. Elitist school systems create and perpetuate inequality. American students compare favorably in testing with students of other countries.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Oregon, Where The Bird Watchers Lengthen the Lists
Policy Shift
description: WASHINGTON  The adjectives and epithets have been quite spectacular: unimaginative, obtuse, irresponsible, disastrous, catastrophic, lunacy.

title: Miss Keating Plans Bridal
description: CINCINNATI, May 26Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Keating Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Marie Keating, to Robert. John Hubbard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hubbard of Brooklyn, New York.

title: New Goals for Montclair State
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR David W. D. Dickson, Montclair State College's newly appointed fifth president, detected a sense of purpose and community.. and a high measure of loyalty. when he first visited the campus here.

title: Officials Debate Ohio Bridge date
description: CIEVELAND, May 26  A 708footlong bridge linking two of this city's western suburbs has stirred a controversy between government officials  most want the span torn down and replaced and others want it preserved as a historic landmark.

title: 2 Australians Win Finals In English Clay Tennis
description: CHINGFORD, England, May 26 (UPI)Owen Davidson and Diane Fromholtz, both of Australia, won the singles finals in a Rothman's claycourt tennis tournament today.

title: French Still Ponder 68 Revolt
description: PARIS, May 26In May of 1968 a, bewildering paralysis overtook France. Students and workers went into the streets, business halted and on May 24 Charles de Gaulle offered to hold a referendum that could decide the nation's futuie and his own.

title: Ann Arborites Accept a Tax Rise for Better Buses
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 26 Residents of this affluent college town are more than willing to ride city buses for ecology's sake, but they want the system to provide doortodoor service.

title: Catherine Cahil Is Bride
description: In St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Miss Catherine Amelia Cahil, daughter of Mrs. Joseph A. Cahil of New York and Los Angeles and the late Mr. Cahil, became the bride of Mark George Irwin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Irwin of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Robert Moher performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Aerial Loop
description: A cityplanners study not long ago calculated that if all the employes in Lower Manhattan simultaneously poured out of their offices, the sidewalks would be covered with a layer of humanity one and a half people thick. Even staggered working hours fail to prevent choked streets in the area, where 480,000 persons are employed.

title: Travel Notes: Step On the Gas, Gently
description: SHOULD the family planning to drive down to Florida for a visit to grandpa and grandma abandon the trip because of the reported gasoline shortage? The people who ought to know say: No. But they add this: Use a little automotive knowhow to help keep yourself and everyone else out of trouble.

title: Legislature
description: ALBANY  Continuing its dubious tradition of legislation by fatigue, the 1973 session of the Legislature rumbled towards adjournment this weekend. As lobbyists scurried through the corridors of the Capitol, the Republican majority leaders and Governor Rockefeller made their deals and compromises. These were then delivered to the lawmakers who sometimes seem to be to the decisionmaking process what the third Egyptian from the left is to a production of Aida.

title: Icelandic Ship Shells British Trawler After Chase
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 26 (Reuters)An Icelandic gunboat shelled a British trawler off Iceland's northern coast today, the coast guard reported here.

title: TV's Women Are Dingbats
description: I TURNED on my television set the other night and what I saw was mindboggling: There, on network television (NBC), on prime time, was Lee Grant playing an intelligent woman a judge, turned private eye. She was unmarried (happily, it seemed, not television's usual neurotic spinster), drove what looked like an Excalibur, and lived in a house right cut of House Beautiful.

title: The Issues
description: As the holiday weekend reached its midpoint, the following action had been take on major issues:

title: Mine Claims on 30 Million Acres Facing Challenge
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 26 Several Western states are taking action against Merle I. Zweifel, who, over the last 13 years, has staked mining claims that he says total 30 million acres, an area larger than Pennsylvania.

title: Joy C. Johnson Bride in Jersey
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 26  Miss Joy Carol Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell F. Johnson of North Plainfield, was married here this afternoon to Michael Francis Donahue Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of Burlington, Vt.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his review of my book Defensible Space, Samuel Kaplan attributes to that book a thesis it does not makethen proceeds to attack it. Here at the Center for Residential Security Design, we do not claim that design will solve all of society's ills; straw men are easily vanquished. Unfortunately, Kaplan has missed our central argument and findings.

title: Deborah N. Trench Has Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 26St. Michael's Lutheran Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Deborah Nelson Trench to Rawdon Moira Crozier Parry. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill, rector of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

title: 12 GROUPS CHARGE U.N. IGNORES WOMEN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 (AP)The United Nations has been accused by 12 international organizations of Ignoring a vital resource in helping needy areas of the worldwoman power.

title: The Politics
description: No one mentions politics in New York State without mentioning Nelson A. Rockefeller. The Governor dampened the hopes of such men as Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Republican of Montauk, when he all but announced he would seek a fifth term next year. Mr. Rockefeller is off and runningand many believe his eye is again on the Presidency in 1976.

title: State Set To Remove Illegal Billboards
description: TRENTON  The state's Deportment of Transportation did not couch the pronouncement in such terms, but that is the net effect of a widescale program to rid New Jersey's highways of more than 30,000 illegal sigps and billboards.

title: Survival Rules For Cookouts
description: THE delectable season of halfraw chicken and halfburned potatoes, of sudden showers and itchy mosquito bites; is back with us. Instead of dull dining in a comfortable house on wellprepared food, you'll be fighting off insects, inhaling quantities of smoke from the grill and doctoring your or your host's fingers to reduce the pain and blisters. That's really living!

title: China ReEstablishes Federation to Press for Equality for Women
description: HONG KONG, May 26Peking has frequently declared that Chinese women were liberated with the Communist takeover, but recent reports indicate that equality has yet to be achieved.

title: The correction of practices of correction
description: These are bad days for prison reformers. Not that anyone is content with the existing system: Most correctional institutions are and can be no more than mere warehouses that degrade and brutalize their human baggage  this is the verdict reached by a group of legislators, foundation executives, sociologists and attorneys at a recent American Assembly conference, and concurred in by countless judges, criminologists, radical lawyers, inmates, and other investigatory commissions. Nor is the dilemma that reformers are at odds over the proper direction for change to take. They all argue for communitybased corrections  offenders should remain in or rapidly return to the general population, either as residents in supervised boarding houses or, better yet, as clients of community service organizations. Rather, the difficulty is that now, for the first time, honest reformers cannot promise to accomplish very much good. They know they lack the knowledge and skill to rehabilitate deviants, and they cannot even imagine eliminating crime from

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Susanne Dughi a Bride
description: HOHOKUS, N.J., May 26 The marriage of Miss Suzanne Gardner Dughi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Dughl, to Michael L. Di Piazza, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Di Piazza of Hasbrouck Heights, took place here this afternoon in the Community Church. The Rev. Herbert Schneider, the minister, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Leonard Dembow of Fort Lee, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride's father is a vice president of Albert. FrankGuenther Law, Inc., the New York advertising and publicrelations agency.

title: College Trainees Interne in Puerto Rico for Bilingual Teaching in the City Schools
description: An innovative threemonth program to train bilingual teachers and teachers aides to work with Spanishspeaking pupils in the city school system is under way in a community college in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Close friends, woman's influence, vegetarians, femme fatale
description: Toward the end of his biography of Kafka, Max Brod writes, Dora took me to one side and whispered to me that that night an owl had appeared at Franz's window. The bird of death. Shortly afterward Kafka was dead. The apparition of the owl, the bird of night, foreshadowing comes to Francis Croft, the poethero of Susan Hill's new novel. Like Kafka, Francis is tormented by bouts of madness interspersed with periods of serene creativity. He is a celebrated writer and, again like Kafka, he relies on a close friend to see him through the dangerous lucidity of his madness.

title: The Texan on the Pole Is at Home in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26The chief mechanics of the 33 cars that will run Monday in the Indianapolis 500 were startled last night when their dinner speaker appeared in rented white tie and tails, but what else could he wear? A few minutes earlier, he had conducted the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra in a rendition of Indiana.

title: CAPTURES EIGHTOARED RACE
description: The New York Athletic Club swept to a sixlength victory yesterday in the featured elite eightoared shells event of the 106th annual Memorial Day Regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

title: Giants Defeat Expos, 103, as Maddox Connects for Five Consecutive Hits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 (UPI)Garry Maddox hammered out five straight hits and drove in four runs today to power the San Francisco Giants to a 103 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Prosecution Is Said to Link Haldeman and Ehrlichman To Ellsberg Case BreakIn
Misses Margo and Joy Jones Set Summer and Fall Bridals
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 26Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Jones have announced the engagements of their daughters, Miss Margaret Allen Jones to Gregory Connors, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Connors of Sugar Hill, N. H., and Miss Helen Joy Jones to Howard Denham Marsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Herbst Marsh of Riverside, Conn.

title: Pop
description: IN the early 1950's those vanguard comic book publishers, the Entertaining Comics Group (E. C. Comics), not only brought us Mad, that unruly magazine filled.with loving parodies of American popular culture, but also gave us The Crypt of Terror and The Vault of Horror, a horror comics line devoted to a lustrously animated. treatment of torture, mutilation and death. The E.C. horror comics blended suspense, gallows humor, and unmitigated violence into a malodorous and addictive pop brew.

title: 1914 Conspirator Recalls Sarajevo Assassination
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 26  In 1914 Vaso Cubrilovic was a slender 17yearold schoolboy with an intense interest in history. On June 28 of that year he took part in an event that changed the course of history  the assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand, heir to the throne of AustriaHungary.

title: COLBORN, BREWERS STOP ANGELS, 9 TO 0
description: MILWAUKEE, May 26 (AP) Oncebeaten Jim Colborn pitched a fourhitter for his fifth successive victory today as the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the California Angels, 90.

title: Indochina
description: PARISFour months after the triumphant completion of a Vietnam ceasefire accord, Presidential adviser Henry Kissinger and Hanoi's Le Due Tho were back in Paris holding intensive negotiations on how to make it work. They met for 30 hours over seven days, said they achieved significant progress and arranged for another series of Paris talks to begin on June 6.

title: THE OPENING
description: THE BOY WHO CAME TO LEAVE  Tuesday, Astor Place Theater, 7. A play by Lee Kalcheim.

title: Irish Eyes Smiling Mostly in Queens
description: Slight! more than half of the city's fast dwindling population of firstand second generation Irish residents now live in either Queens or Brooklyn, according to the Census Bureau.

title: MSGR. JAMES KELLY, CANON LAW EXPERT
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., May 26 Msgr. James P. Kelly, pastor of the Sacred Heart Church here since 1952 and a noted authority on canon law, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital. His age was 72.

title: FISCAL INCENTIVE FOR ARSON CITED
description: WASHINGTON, May 26An economic incentive for setting fires may account for the fact that the United States has the most deaths and property loss from fire of all industrialized countries.

title: Windy's Daughter Equals Record for Mother Goose
description: Eddie Belmonte, the Puerto Rican jockey who was brought East from California just to pilot Mrs. Paul Blackman's favored Windy's Daughter in the $88,275 Mother Goose, made his crosscountry trip to Belmont Park pay off yesterday.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Cross Westchester Corporate Park in White Plains has announced the leasing of more than 100,000 square feet of office space in its two newest buildings to 21 different companies, including seven that are relocating from New York City.

title: Miss Brenda Abbot Engaged To Alexander McG. Anderson
description: ROCKVILLE, Md, May 26 The engagement of Miss Brenda Lee Abbot to Alexander McGregor Anderson has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Mack Abbot Jr. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bennett Anderson Jr. of Sands Point, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: DeadlockNot Retreat
description: A deadlocked fourtofour vote by the Supreme Court has vacated an original order that would have forced a merger of Richmond's predominantly black school system with its surrounding, predominantly white suburban counties. The judicial tie has the effect of upholding last year's opinion by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which overturned the original merger order issued by Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. Specifically, the Appeals Court rejected Judge Merhig.e's claim that the state of Virginia, by means of disciiminatory housing and school construction policies, had directly facilitated the maintenance of a segregationist wall and a dual school system.

title: Rizzo Shifts on Taxes
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) Mayor Frank Rizzo, who last week suggested two new taxes despite a notax pledge, has changed his mind again. We just don't need them, Mr. Rizzo said Tuesday in announcing he was withdrawing from City Council the two tax proposals.

title: Joseph W. Penfold, 65, Dead; Leader in Conservation Field
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Joseph W. Penfold, nationally known conservation leader, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 65.

title: Artists Invade Enclave Of Staten Island Shops
description: There have always been a number of artists who moved to Staten Island to hide, but now the artists are coming out of the shadows.

title: Best Seller List
Borg 16, Fills Role of Tennis Prodigy
description: PARIS, May 26His motions are still jerky and at times he swings his racquet like a novice, but 16yearold Bjorn Borg has few other faults on the court. He feels confident he can handle the role of tennis's latest prodigy.

title: Is a Door Finally Opening?
description: LONDONWhat might prove by far the most significant American contribution to a European year of United States diplomacy is the careful hint from Washington to London and Paris that the United States might actively fever an Anglo.French nuclear military force operating on behalf of Europe.

title: Burns Reaches Final In the French Amateur
description: PARIS, May 26 (AP) George Burns 3d of Manhasset, L. I., scrambled into the final of the French amateur golf championship, today, but a fellow American, Mickey Van Gerbig of Palm Beach, Fla., was eliminated. Burns will meet Herve Frayssineau of France tomorrow in the 36hole final over the 7,169yard, par71 Chantilly course.

description: WASHINGTON  When President Nixon made his first public statement last December about his plans for this second term of office, he noted what he said was an historical tendency for reelected administrations to run out of steam, and he proclaimed his intention to make this one different.

description: MONROE STATION, Fla., May 26 (UPI)  A fire that has spread across 11,000 acres in the last three days raged unchecked through the Big Cypress Swamp today. Rangers said the only hope of stopping it soon was heavy rain or a shift of wind.

description: Kevin Hampe, captain of the hockey and baseball teams, has been awarded Harvard's athletic honor, the William J. Bingham Award for integrity, courage, leadership and ability in athletics.

title: U.S.Canada Airline Talks Entering Crucial Phase
description: MONTREAL, May 26The United States and Canada go back to the bargaining table next week in what aviation officials regard as a crucial phase of the negotiations over a new agreement on commercial air travel.

title: Kottulinski Drives a Lola To Victory in German Race
description: ADENAU, Germany, May 26 (UPI)  Freddy Kottulinski of Finland piloted his Lola to victory today in a formula SuperV auto race on the Nuerburgring speed circuit. The Finn was clocked in 43 minutes 9.6 seconds for a speed of 99.2 miles an hour.

title: The Day the Tennis Hustler Got Hustled
description: The saga of Bobby Riggs would not be complete without a chapter on the man who outhustled the hustler on the tennis court.

title: This Is Cinerama-Or Is It?:This Is Cinerama-Or Is It?
description: "THIS IS CINERAMA," the first feature program in what was once a giant, three-negative film process, has returned to New York where it originally opened Sept. 30, 1952, becoming such an immediate box-office hit that it made Wall Street investors careless with their money and prompted Hollywood technicians, who hadn't been very busy since receiving sound, to take another look at what God (and His representatives on earth) had wrought.However, the film that is now playing at the Ziegfeld Theater is not quite the same "This Is Cinerama" that caused the sensation at the Broadway Theater 20 years ago. The program itself is the same  including the roller coaster ride, the snatch of a performance of Handel's "Messiah" by the Long Island Choral Society, the sight-seeing in Edinburgh, Venice and Cypress Gardens, and the climactic air tour of the United States, all, more or less chaperoned by Lowell Thomas (on screen and soundtrack) in a fashion that lays more stress on the cheeriness of existence in Mr. Thomas's America than on real facts. "Crater Lake, Mr. Thomas exclaims ??? Cinerama plane flies over the deepest lake in North America. "Its bottom has never been found!" (Its bottom must have been found by somebody since the Encyclopedia Britannica says Crater Lake, Ore., is 1,932 ??? shabbier. Cinerama has been perfected until it's become something less than it first was in the early 1950s, when lots of people expected it to revolutionize movies. After all that original hubbub, which prompted the introduction of now-almost-forgotten processes like CinemaScope and VistaVision, movies are somewhat better visually and aurally, and they are certainly wider, but that's about all.The original Cinerama process, invented by Fred Waller and first used by the United States armed forces to instruct aerial gunners during World War II, involved the use of three interlocking projectors projecting three separate 35-mm film strips onto a deeply curved screen covering an arc of 146 degrees. As long as the process made use of three different negatives, the resulting picture was always slightly marred by lines where the images overlapped, and by a color imbalance among the three images, but it provided a brilliance of image definition never matched before or since, as well as a remarkable sense of audience participation because of the effect on our peripheral vision.This Cinerama process was a gimmick, and a marvelous gimmick, one that returned movies to what they are by that original definition: movies. Movies needn't always be movies. They can also be films, film or, at their intellectually fanciest, cinema, but movies also are important, not as literature, but as vicarious thrills, allowing us to experience sensations that we can otherwise safely experience only in dreams."This Is Cinerama" and the four subsequent Cinerama features released through 1958 were all basically journalism of a sort that would look square even in the pages of the National Geographic. As travelogues, however, they were superb. When we flew into Cairo in "Seven Wonders of the World" (1956), we saw Cairo as we'd never be able to see it on a commercial flight (unless we were in the pilot's cabin) and certainly not as we'd see it in a conventional film.In one panoramic sweep of amazing clarity, we saw not a blur of a portion of a city, but the relationship of the entire city to the Nile, to the pyramids at Giza, to the great desert itself, which just suddenly begins were the irrigated green ends.In these three-panel Cinerama films, we landed jet fighters aboard aircraft carriers, shot rapids in India, and bobsledded down Alps in Switzerland. They were immense fun even when Mr. Thomas might be droning on about "the sublime mysteries" of one Asian temple or another, or preparing us for a "great scoop," the Milan Opera's presentation of the triumphal march from "Aida" (which turns out to look a good deal like the opening of New York's Festival of San Gennaro with a slightly oriental flavor).The three-panel Cinerama films were expensive to shoot and expensive to show, and the two attempts to make conventional narrative films in the process"The Wonderful World of The Brothers Grimm" (1962) and "How The West Was Won" (1963) quickly proved that three panels were two too many, and that the huge screen had the effect of inhibiting a narrative instead of enhancing it.After a certain amount of work, Cinerama came up with a single-negative process, in fact a single-strip, 70-mm process, which is better, more flexible for story-telling, but never can compete with the definition and clarity of the pictures provided by three 35-mm images locked together.The version of "This Is Cinerama" at the Ziegfeld currently is the original three-negatives printed down to fit into a 70-mm frame. The lines (which never really bothered me) are still there, but the picture and color quality have deteriorated to such an extent that the movie sometimes doesn't look as clear as an ordinary 35-mm picture. Indeed, at the presentation I attended last week, even that portion of the film in which Mr. Thomas is introduced in 35-mm black-and-white looks to have been shot about the same time as those portions of "The Great Train Robbery" he shows us. It also seems as if a certain amount of important pictorial information at either side of the screen has been chopped off. Equally important (or disappointing) was the quality of the sound in much of the presentation.One of the most innovative aspects of the original Cinerama show was its introduction of seven-track magnetic sound ("we call it'stereophonic sound,'" Mr. Thomas says portentously, and the long-stereo-oriented audience at the Ziegfeld laughs). There are speakers in the auditorium at the Ziegfeld, but the quality of sound reproduction behind the screen sometimes seemed surprisingly tinny.There were other unintentional laughs at the performance I saw. Early in the film, Mr. Thomas tries to explain persistence-of-vision. "If it were not possible," he says, "the movie you are looking at would only be a blur." Which, at that point, it was.The passage of time has not been kind to Mr. Thomas's narration. When the Cinerama plane flies over Washington and he says something patriotic about the Pentagon, the audience boos. It then cheers wildly when he introduces the concluding section of the film with the once-innocent line: "Now for a climax! A culmination!"A lower order of fakery has replaced the beautiful illusion of the original presentation. The Ziegfeld has no real curtains to mask the screen, and instead projects the image of a curtain on the screen at the beginning of the show and between the acts.Even with these imperfections, especially the poor picture quality, the show does offer a greater sense of audience participation (if you sit in the center of the orchestra) than you'll probably get in most other movies these days. At the end of the show's first half, just after the Milan Opera's presentation of the march from "Aida," when the word "Intermission" was flashed on the screen, a woman sitting in front of me turned to her husband and asked: "Is that for them or us?"

title: Measure to Cut Pension Costs Is Passed
description: ALBANY, May 26The Legislature tonight voted a bill aimed at curbing the spiraling costs of publicemployee, pension systems and deferred action temporarily on another bill that would provide lawmakers in 1975 with pay raises of almost 60 percent as well as $40aday expense accounts.

title: MISS SCHMIDT SETS U.S. JAVELIN MARK
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 26 (AP)Herb Washington upset a confused Steve Williams in the 100meter wash today and Rod Milburn was the 120yard high hurdles in the 32nd California Relays. Kathy Schmidt shared the spotlight with Washington and Milburn early in the 37event program at Modesto Junior College Stadium. She bettered the American women's record in the javelin with a throw of 205 feet 6 inches. It was 4 inches better than her own work made last spring.

title: DUE THIS WEEK
description: THE HUNTERS ARE THE HUNTEDA German film directed by Peter Fleischmann, Wednesday at the New Yorker.

title: Poll Shows Yorty Trailing Bradley by Six Points
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26Thomas Bradley, a black City Councilman, holds a slight lead over Mayor Sam Yorty in the last poll taken beore the Los Angeles mayoral election next Tuesday.

title: For Wanaque, Growth Is a Problem
description: WANAQUEThe first thing that one discovers on entering this Passaic County community is that the 9,500 residents cannot agree on the pronunciation of the name of their hometown. Longtime residents use the old Indian WANAHKEY when they refer to the borough, while newer homeowners call it WANAHCUE. They do not argue about it with a visitor; they simply stress that you can tell the natives from the newcomers by the way they pronounce the name. New or old to Wanaque, however, most of the people who live here agree on the problems, which they relate schools and taxes. The Talk of Wanaque

title: Auto Junkyard With Touch of Americana Is Keeping Up With the Times
description: America's past has flowed through Leonard Knight's auto junkyard for close to 30 years, and, he says, he hp now reached the plateau of the family's second car. From this modern plateau, Mr. Knight cherishes intimate contact with such nostalgic Americana as the ModelT Ford, the Stutz, the PierceArrow, the GrahamPaige, and the 1924 Buick.

title: Rutgers College Is Graduating First Women
description: NEW BRUNSWICKSomething new will be added to the Rutgers College commencement on Thursday: five women graduates.

title: Four Japanese Golfers File for Montreal Event
description: MONTREAL, May 26 (UPI) Four Japanese golfers have applied to compete in the $50,000 La Canadienne golf championship, to be held here June 12 to 17, as part of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Theater Benefits.
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Democrats'
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The Democratic party commission considering changes in the controversial 1972 delegateselection guidelines announced today the sites of six regional hearings during the next three months.

title: News Summary and index
description: The commander of the Greek Navy destroyer Velos and 31 officers and men who had. joined in a mutiny against the military regime in Athens debarked in the Italian fishing port of Fiumicino, near Rome, and asked for political asylum. The Velos, anchored three miles off Fiumicino, was due to go on to Naples with the remainder of her crew of 270 officers and men. The disembarkment of the rebel commander, Capt. Nicholas Pappas, and the other mutineers came after more than 12 hours of tense negotiations with Italian officials, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Gteek diplomats and military officers. [Page 3, Cols. 46.]

title: Dave Anderson
description: Joe Namath will be 30 years old on Thursday, but he declined congratulations. He also declined condolences. What birthday? he said.
